HEADLINE: The Nation: Mourning in America; 
A Whiff of Dread for the Land of Hope

BYLINE:  By SIMON SCHAMA; Simon Schama is University Professor at Columbia University and the author, most recently, of "A History of Britain."

 BODY:
IS it heresy to suggest that America could use a modest dose of pessimism right now?
 Historically, mainstream American culture is conditioned to treat calamity --financial or fanatical -- as an aberration, not the norm; an affront to the national commitment to singing in the rain. Confronted by breaking news of its vulnerability, only two alternative responses seem available: irrepressible up-and-at-'em chirpiness or apocalyptic hysteria, Pollyanna or Chicken Little. But neither approach, neither the smirk nor the shriek, offers the best foundation for imagining what perils might lie ahead, nor the most prudent way to come to terms with the unwelcome fact that, for the foreseeable future, the perils will be as much part of the American way of life as apple pie. 
 Of course politicians crazy enough to tell bleak truths about the aging process of the American empire have not been celebrated for their refreshing candor so much as buried for the temerity of their pessimism, however smart. R.I.P, Jimmy Carter, hello "morning in America" -- that golden moment when optimism skyrocketed along with federal deficits. Any contest, especially in election years, between sunnyside-up breeziness and chastened realism will, of course, be no contest at all. When was the last time that political strategy-makers counseled their candidate to put on a sadder (if wiser) face? It is a truism of contemporary political life that it will never be afternoon in America, even though such cursory readings of world history as candidates can manage between fund-raisers will tell them that one day it must.
Out there in the Rest of the World, the unavoidable sadness of wisdom is taken as read. From the very beginning of its written record, European history was assumed to be a somber, ignoble story, "little more," as Gibbon mordantly confessed, "than the register of the crimes, follies and misfortunes of mankind." This verdict did not, however, reduce that history to fatalism. On the contrary, the assumption of the inevitability of disaster, humans being what they are, also presupposed the educative power of melancholy: the optimism, as it were, of pessimism. In the European tradition it has been an imagined immunity from the pratfalls of history that has ended up guaranteeing the most painful and the most sudden disappearing acts.
The tragic climax of Thucydides's "History of the Peloponnesian War" -- the catastrophic Athenian expedition to Sicily -- is just such a cautionary chronicle of hubris-laden comeuppance. The famous funeral oration for the fallen, imagined for Pericles by Thucydides, is a staple item of American college core curricula, principally for its eulogy of the sacrifices of citizen soldiers and its assertion of the singularity of Athenian democracy (a democracy, like the early American republic, supported on the backs of slaves).
Far more typical of Thucydides's pessimism, though, is his unnerving account of the city's meltdown during a plague epidemic, when (in the wonderful translation by another arch-pessimist, Thomas Hobbes) "dying men lay tumbling upon one another in the streets and men half-dead about every conduit through desire of water." Facing obliteration, the model democracy swiftly dissolves into grab-it-while-you-can plunder; debauchery, the stampede for the last Cipro.
Democracies, Thucydides says, are no better armed against panic in the face of adversity, nor are they necessarily more virtuous and discriminating when they exercise their power against it. During the debates over the prudence of the Sicilian expedition, the most withering contempt is reserved for the belligerence of armchair hawks whose enthusiasm for the campaign is in inverse proportion to their personal experience of combat. The warnings of the seasoned veteran, Nicias, against running "new dangers when the state of our own city hangeth unsettled" are allowed their full, cautionary eloquence. Nonetheless, the historian complains, "everyone alike fell in love with the enterprise: the old men upon hope to subdue the place they went to or that at least so great a power could not miscarry; and the young men upon desire to see a foreign country and to gaze, making little doubt but to return with safety."
In the carnage that follows it is Nicias himself who is left to watch the annihilation of the Athenian army and navy. Never suppose, implies Thucydides, wagging his finger, that any empire is invincible. Survival depends, above all, on an understanding of the economy of force.
Roman historians like Tacitus narrating the fate of legions swallowed up in the German woods confirmed that a world empire, especially one mired in plutocratic selfishness and back-biting intrigue, could be a soft target. Expect the worst and you will not be disappointed. The barbarians will always be at the gate, and generally they will find a way to squeeze through. Be of a stoical temper, urged the philosopher-emperor Marcus Aurelius at the climactic moment of Roman imperial power, and when misfortune strikes remember that all things -- empires as well as emperors -- are mortal. The best that can be expected is the intelligent containment of damage. Such is the instruction of ruins.
RUINS were 18th century Europe's antidote to hubris. Gibbon conceived the idea of his "Decline and Fall of the Roman Empire," he tells us, "as I sat musing amidst the ruins of the Capitol, while the bare-footed friars were singing vespers in the Temple of Jupiter." The milords flocked to the Forum for lessons on the inevitable erosion of grandeur. Artists like Piranesi and Hubert Robert supplied engravings and paintings of moss-draped Roman monuments overrun by beggars and goats. Landscapists would custom build ruins for the parks of the Quality so they could stroll soberly through gardens of wistfulness.
The attack on optimism reached its climax with Voltaire's Candide, whose faith in Dr. Pangloss's belief that we live in "the best of all possible worlds" is shaken by the Lisbon earthquake of 1755. Thirty thousand casualties unavoidably raise questions about either the benevolence or the competence of the Great Designer in the sky. Candide travels on through a landscape of unrelenting cruelty described by his raped sweetheart Cunegonde as "standard practice." All the greatest writing on the slaughter and mayhem that make up the sorry record of our modern centuries -- Stendhal at Waterloo; Tolstoy at Borodino, Hasek's "Good Soldier Schweik" -- is run through with black absurdity; the scamperings and scufflings of animal panic rather than ennobling acts of valor.
Such, they say, is the human condition. Get used to it.
America was created expressly as the rejection of those truisms. Ruins had nothing to say to a culture so deeply invested in freshness. Even now, those wanting to preserve Civil War battlefields like Chancellorsville as a place of meditation are up against developers for whom golf courses and front lawns whisper the great American mantra of "move on." Only at ground zero has the instinct to build over been checked by a comparably powerful yearning for a place of lament.
Against the stoical nostrum that man, wherever and whenever you look, is much of a muchness, the American claim was to have created a new kind of history-free citizen. When Alexis de Tocqueville came to America in the 1830's he was struck by the intensity with which Americans boasted of their singularity. He granted them their novelty, but immediately understood it was, above all, the product of their liberation from social and spatial claustrophobia. The happiness to which, apparently, Americans were entitled by birthright (and that Tocqueville saw with shocking clairvoyance actually meant the raw pursuit of material satisfactions) was conditional on perpetual motion. Happiness for Voltaire was cultivating one's garden. Happiness for Thomas Jefferson was rolling across the continent, gathering the millions of acres needed to make the American homestead.
Tocqueville also saw that this epic was not, as the tribunes of American felicity advertised, a calamity-free process. The white man's entitlement to happiness was the nonwhite man's guarantee of misery. For slaves there was the ordeal of confinement; for Native Americans ecological annihilation. European immigrants, on the other hand, were at last (relatively) free from the usual lot of the poor and defenseless. Sorrow and suffering, as a perennial way of life, became someone else's problem.
One of the most deeply felt narratives of catastrophe in the history of American freedom is Tocqueville's account of the uprooted Choctaws crossing the Mississippi in winter. "The snow had frozen hard upon the ground and the river was drifting with huge masses of ice. The Indians had their families with them and they brought in their train the wounded and the sick, with children newly born and old men on the verge of death. They possessed neither tents nor wagons but only their arms and some provisions. I saw them embark to pass the mighty river and never will that solemn spectacle fade from my remembrance. No cry, no sob was heard from the assembled crowd; all were silent. Their calamities were of ancient date and they knew them to be irremediable."
IT is only in our time, only perhaps last year, that such calamity has come home to America, and it is to be feared that it may not soon go away. In one morning the shelter of distance was traumatically obliterated, the skies made a lot less spacious. In place of the luxury of isolation, Americans have no option but to accept the necessity of connection. Sustaining their way of life and constitutional entitlement to filling up at a buck fifty a gallon demands continuing engagement in the fate of the rest of the world and not just hit and run "regime change," a euphemism that would better please the ghost of Thucydides if it were called by what it is -- invasion and occupation.
As a wrecking and removal crew Americans are, for the moment, unstoppable. But whether in Iraq or elsewhere, wrecking and removal is no strategy for their own survival unless they also sign the longer, more expensive, rebuilding contract.
If Americans are, for the foreseeable future, fated to live inside, rather than alongside, the imperfect, dangerous world, they are also likely to experience a greater, rather than a lesser, share of its ancient woes and misfortunes. The worst thing to do would be to treat such adversity as might come their way as if it were some sort of violation of American exceptionalism, when it is, in fact, the result of it. Perhaps, in any case, there are worse things than bidding farewell to the fond illusion that Americans would remain forever exempt from the ways of the world, calamities included. Besides, whoever said that growing older as a nation was going to be fun?

 BODY:

HEADLINE: DataBank; 
A Small Declinefor a Distracted Market

BYLINE:  By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
In a week when many investors thought more about the first anniversary of 9/11 than about stocks, the three major equity indexes did not fare too badly. All three fell for a third week in a row, but the declines were small compared with recent performances. 
 The market also held up pretty well against a rise in unemployment claims, a decline in consumer confidence and no signals of economic optimism from Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, when he testified before Congress. 
 The Dow Jones industrial average fell 114.51 points, or 1.4 percent, to 8,312.69, while the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index slipped just 4.11 points, or 0.5 percent, to 889.81. The Nasdaq composite inched down 3.90 points, or 0.3 percent, to 1,291.40.
 Honeywell International cut its profit forecast and fell 16.9 percent on Friday and 22.5 percent for the week. Tyco International, however, ended the week up 11.4 percent, even after the indictment of three of its former top executives and a 5.2 percent decline Friday.
 In the bond market, interest rates remained low, which should be a help for the economy. The yield on the Treasury's 10-year note dropped to a 40-year low of 3.91 percent.
 JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

HEADLINE: The Export-Import Bank: Who Is Helping Whom? 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 The article began with an example of a loan guarantee provided by the bank for the sale of a satellite manufactured in the United States to an international telecommunications company. It also discussed the satellite buyer's wealth and the manufacturer's politics, neither of which I believe to be relevant. 
 What is relevant is that an international telecommunications company needed to buy a satellite. That company had a choice: it could buy the satellite from an American manufacturer or from a European one. 
Following a basic principle of business, the telecommunications company compared prices, including the cost of financing. At a purchase price of $150 million to $200 million, a small difference in an interest rate can make or break a deal. 
In this case, the company chose an American manufacturer in part because the Export-Import Bank provided a loan guarantee that allowed the company to get a lower interest rate for the loan.
It is well known that European satellite manufacturers offer government-provided financing options to their customers. To compete effectively with these European rivals, the nation's satellite manufacturing industry must have available government financing options.
Loan guarantees are not corporate welfare. As the article states, the default rate on these loans is extremely small -- about 2 percent. Instead, the guarantees are a small and necessary national investment in the nation's satellite manufacturing industry. 
The global satellite industry is facing a steep decline in market demand due to a downturn in the telecommunications industry. It is projected that only two or three of the world's five commercial satellite manufacturers will survive current market conditions. Continued assistance from the Export-Import Bank is required to ensure that at least one of the survivors will remain in the United States.

ROBERT M. DAVIS
Santa Maria, Calif., Sept. 9

The writer is president and chief executive of the California Space Authority, a group that promotes space projects in the state.

HEADLINE: In Maryland, a Blowout Becomes a Nail-Biter 

BYLINE:  By FRANCIS X. CLINES 

DATELINE: COLUMBIA, Md., Sept. 12 

 BODY:
It is harsh enough that the double-digit popularity poll leads of Lt. Gov. Kathleen Kennedy Townsend's campaign for governor of Maryland evaporated over the summer.
 No less biting to her is the cool pronouncement lately by Representative Robert L. Ehrlich Jr., who was initially viewed as her little-known, long-shot Republican challenger, that "the Kennedy legacy is dead." 
 "The legacy just hasn't worked; its not that relevant anymore," says Mr. Ehrlich, whose unexpected equalizing of the poll numbers is triggering what he terms a highly enthusiastic flow of campaign contributions for the tooth-and-claw campaign now expected by both camps. 
"We knew this was going to happen," insists Mrs. Townsend, who was widely touted as an unbeatable Kennedy torchbearer a year ago after dedicating eight years to the grass-roots burnishing of her image in this liberal state's No. 2 executive post.
Hardly accepting Mr. Ehrlich's view that the Kennedy spirit has faded in the estimate of voters, Mrs. Townsend, the eldest offspring of Robert F. Kennedy, appears to be using it to try and spark some of the fiery resolve that critics have found lacking in her stump performances so far.
"I am outraged and horrified not only by my opponent's view of my family, but by his view on guns and Saturday night specials," she angrily declared in an interview, pointing to Mr. Ehrlich's high rating by the National Rifle Association. 
"I'm talking about what Saturday night specials have done to my family," she said, signaling her campaign strategy of debunking the record of political moderation that Mr. Ehrlich is claiming for himself in this two-to-one Democratic state.
She is denouncing him as "outside the mainstream," even as Mr. Ehrlich insists she represents "the incredible arrogance of a monopoly never challenged," the Democratic establishment that has held the governorship for 36 years.
The rising cockiness of Mr. Ehrlich, 44, a four-term congressman who has proven he can garner crossover votes in his Democratic district, and the embattled resolve of the 51-year-old lieutenant governor have suddenly made a compelling race of the Maryland contest. It is attracting increasing national interest and political money, notably a $1 million fund-raising visit next month by President Bush.
"The fading lure of Camelot" was reported on recently by The Economist, the British weekly, which concluded that Mrs. Townsend has "the thatched hair and toothy grin" of her father, but has run "a shambles" of a campaign so far.
Her problems include what even some Democrats admit was a slap in the face of the state's potent African-American voting bloc when Mrs. Townsend considered prominent black Democrats as her running mate but then chose an outsider, Charles Larson, a white retired Navy admiral who converted from the Republican Party. She was impressed by his knowledge of education reform, a major issue, and domestic security, Mrs. Townsend said.
In contrast, Mr. Ehrlich chose Michael S. Steele, an African-American well known as the state Republican chairman. He is a "camera-ready" professional politician, as Mr. Ehrlich likes to say as he happily estimates Mrs. Townsend to be in political "meltdown."
Her problems include federal investigations of the state's crime control and juvenile justice departments that have been part of Mrs. Townsend's executive responsibilities. Like statehouse incumbents across the nation, she is criticized by Mr. Ehrlich for growing budget deficits -- $1 billion in the Maryland administration of Gov. Parris N. Glendening, Mrs. Townsend's political mentor and an increasingly unpopular politician whom she has been avoiding in this campaign. 
Beyond any specific issues may be the emerging popular suspicion that Mrs. Townsend, a careful politician who likes to prepare richly detailed plans on education, environment and other bedrock issues, may lack that mythic Kennedy zeal for bare-knuckled political combat.
"Oh, I am up for this," she firmly insisted as her campaign prepared an all-out television barrage aimed at Mr. Ehrlich's claims to moderation. "I like the excitement, I like the fight," she said, offering a determined Kennedy grin to counter critiques that her style often includes skittishness on the stump.
Mr. Ehrlich campaigns as the self-made man from a blue-collar, middle-class background who won a Princeton scholarship for academics and football. The only mainstream he is outside of, he says, is the one defined by conservative right Republicans. "I'm pro-choice, for the right to die, medical marijuana, pro-slot machines," he says, while analysts find his record more mixed on such issues as abortion rights.
Mrs. Townsend excoriates the Republican for his education record, accusing him of voting against some of the very opportunities that helped him get to Princeton. She seized this week on Mr. Ehrlich's candid admission that he does "not agree on anything" with the Children's Defense Fund, the organization that has criticized his education record.
"He epitomizes the worst of self-centered success," Mrs. Townsend said. "In my family, we've always said we have the responsibility to help those who haven't been as fortunate."
Mr. Ehrlich, defending his education record as rooted in local rather than federal priorities, appears delighted by Mrs. Townsend's attacks.
"We always thought if we could make the race between the two candidates, not legacy and a famous family, we would win," he said.
"We don't want to go negative, but when they hit, we will hit back," he added, anticipating just the sort of spirited campaign that the lieutenant governor claims she is eager to wage for herself even more than for her family.

HEADLINE: Boeing Strike Vote Fails; Company Offer Is in Effect 

BYLINE:  By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

 BODY:
The Boeing Company, the world's largest aircraft maker, averted a strike threatened for yesterday when leaders of its biggest union announced that their call for a strike failed to gain the two-thirds support needed from workers.
 Late Friday, leaders of the International Association of Machinists, which represents 25,000 Boeing workers in Washington State, Oregon and Kansas, announced that 62 percent of the workers had voted to reject Boeing's final offer and 61 percent had voted to strike. Union leaders said the vote showed deep anger toward Boeing, but under the machinists' rules, the lack of a two-thirds majority meant that the workers automatically accepted Boeing's offer. 
 As a result, Boeing emerged largely triumphant in a bitter contract fight in which the main issue was the union's effort to curb Boeing's ability to contract out work to nonunion or overseas companies. In the new contract, Boeing obtained not only the provisions it wanted to allow it more freedom to contract out work, but also provisions that increase the workers' contribution to their health coverage. 
"It's a victory for Boeing, but it may be a Pyrrhic victory," said Margaret Levi, an expert on labor relations at the University of Washington. "It will be very problematic for the company to have this kind of intense anger with the labor force."
For leaders of the union, the vote not to strike was a rebuff and undercut the union's pledge to do its utmost to stop Boeing from transferring more components work to China and other countries. Boeing laid off one-third of its work force after the Sept. 11 attacks, and many machinists are fuming that the company has rehired few of those workers while continuing to move work overseas. 
"Our members clearly rejected the company's offer and saw it would eliminate jobs, but felt they could not strike the company at this time," said Mark Blondin, president of Machinists' Local 751, which represents the Boeing workers.
Boeing officials have long maintained that the company needs unrestricted freedom to transfer work to help it minimize costs and compete with its archrival, Airbus, the European aircraft giant. 
In the weeks before the contract expired on Sept. 1, Boeing officials sent signals that the company might be willing to weather a walkout to achieve its contract goals. Many industry analysts said Boeing was in a good position to weather a strike because its orders had dropped sharply after the attacks. The company plans to deliver 380 jets this year, down from 520 last year, and may cut production to 300 next year.
Alan Mulally, president of the Boeing commercial airplane division, said in a statement: "We're looking forward to getting back to the business of building airplanes. We will continue supporting our customers and ensuring that Boeing remains a reliable and competitive supplier to the world's airlines."
David Clay, a tool maker, said the company's threats and appeals to workers helped persuade them not to strike. "The company was completely on message, while the union was in disarray," Mr. Clay said. "The company kept saying, 'Times are tough. This isn't going to be good for our customers,' and all that talk affected some workers."
Machinists leaders were angry after the vote. It has been an especially difficult year for that union, which has endured tens of thousands of layoffs after Sept. 11, not only at Boeing, but at the airlines.
In light of the nation's weak economy and Boeing's own problems, labor relations experts said it was not surprising that Boeing's workers developed cold feet about striking. 
"It's simple economics," Professor Levi said. "Everyone has been asking isn't this a bad time for a strike, when there's a recession and people are scared of layoffs. Workers are more worried about striking than they would be in an upturn."
Boeing's machinists last went on strike in 1995, when aircraft orders were booming and the walkout lasted 69 days.
Under the new contract, the workers, whose annual salary averages $50,000, will receive an immediate 8 percent ratification bonus, a 2 percent raise in the second year, and 2.5 percent in the third. The workers' pensions will increase by 20 percent so that a worker who retires after 20 years will receive a pension of $14,400, up from $12,000 under the old contract.
As soaring health care costs become a central issue in labor negotiations across the country, union officials said that under Boeing's new contract, workers would have to contribute about $2,000 more per year toward their health coverage.
In a separate move, 1,400 workers represented by the United Auto Workers at a Boeing helicopter plant near Philadelphia went on strike yesterday. The walkout may slow deliveries of the CH-47 Chinook, a transport helicopter used by the American military in Afghanistan. In that dispute, health costs are a major issue.

HEADLINE: Mormon Leader Is Survived by 33 Sons and a Void 

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL JANOFSKY 

DATELINE: COLORADO CITY, Ariz., Sept. 12 

 BODY:
In their Sunday best, men in black, women in pastels, they came by the thousands today to honor their leader, a man they considered a prophet.
 Outstanding he was, by some measure. President Rulon T. Jeffs, of the Fundamentalist Church of Jesus Christ of Latter Day Saints, who died Sept. 8 after a long illness, was 93. He is survived by 19 or 20 wives -- no one could say for sure -- about 60 children and hundreds of grandchildren. At least 33 sons were pallbearers, including two of his namesakes, Rulon F. and Rulon H. 
 As the eighth prophet of the church, in a line that began with the Mormon pioneer, Joseph Smith, Mr. Jeffs led the largest religious group in North America that still practices plural marriage and is ostracized by the mainstream Mormon Church for the same reason. The larger church, based in Salt Lake City, banned polygamy in the 1890's as a condition for Utah gaining statehood. The fundamentalists consider mainstream Mormons the renegades, for abandoning the original Mormon teachings to solve a political problem.
Today, more than 5,000 fundamentalists packed the Leroy S. Johnson Meeting House for a two-hour service, then slowly walked along a dusty road to the cemetery where Mr. Jeffs was buried. He was praised by one speaker as "a man of principle and sweetness," by another as a man who "lived the attributes of God." The lives of church members were so absorbed with him that the funeral program said at the top, "President Rulon T. Jeffs Presiding."
His death leaves a void in church leadership that could take years to fill. Fundamentalists warm to their prophets rather slowly, and for now two church members are in the running: Fred M. Jessop, 92, a longtime bishop, and one of Mr. Jeffs's sons, Warren S. Jeffs, 45.
"It could take months, even years," said Raymond Scott Berry, a Salt Lake lawyer who represents the church but is not a member. "It's not a political decision. It's based on a subtly growing consensus that evolves from their faith and prayerful attitude." 
About 10,000 people in the United States and Canada belong to the Fundamentalist Church; the largest concentration of them, 4,000, live in the adjoining border towns of Colorado City, Ariz., and Hildale, Utah. They form a place perhaps like no other in the United States, coming as close to a theocracy as possible in a country where the Constitution provides a firewall between church and state. 
Dan Barlow, 70, a symbol of the mix as an elder of the church and mayor of Colorado City for the last 17 years, said the church owns about 85 percent of the land in the two towns under an arrangement developed in the 1940's with Mr. Jeffs, a wealthy businessman for much of his life, as a leading negotiator. The church, he said, gives parcels to its members. If a family moves away or breaks with the church, the church can give the property to another family.
Until a few years ago, local children attended public schools. But church leaders encouraged families to enroll their children in church schools and the public schools closed.
The church has been less successful in improving the economic standard of its members. Almost 25 miles from the nearest town of any size, Colorado City and Hildale have few commercial businesses -- a small restaurant, a clothing store, a gas station -- but no movie theaters, no fast-food outlets, no welcome signs along the road that leads in and out. In Colorado City, the larger of the two towns with 3,334 residents, 78 percent of residents receive food stamps, compared with 18 percent for all of Arizona. 
Mr. Berry called the fundamentalists "the last American pioneers," and their life here suggests as much. Houses sit on a grid of unpaved streets. Families raise horses and livestock adjacent to their house. In general, men can dress as they please, but women, including little girls, are required to wear long-sleeved, ankle-length dresses and to keep their hair long and braided.
But more than looks and location set them apart from mainstream America. Plural marriages, unusually large families and houses with multiple entrances attract the curiosity of outsiders and, to some degree, the interest of state officials.
Rarely are polygamists charged under bigamy laws, especially in Utah, where many residents are descendants of plural families, and prosecutors are reluctant to file charges against consenting adults in a religious context. Tom Green, who was recently sentenced in Juab County, Utah, to five years to life on a rape charge for impregnating one of his five wives when she was 13, was the first polygamist in 50 years to be prosecuted in Utah.
More often, members of plural families come to the attention of state and local officials through occasional allegations of welfare fraud, tax dodging, domestic violence and child abuse. But cases are difficult to build, said Ric Cantrell, a spokesman for the Utah attorney general's office. Not only are the county prosecutors generally overwhelmed with more serious offenses, he said, but investigators have trouble finding witnesses to testify.
Mr. Barlow said he would not comment on any criticisms of the church or its teachings, surely not on so solemn a day. He defended plural marriages as a core belief of the Fundamentalist Church, "that a man should have more than one family through marriages ordained by God." He said people are free to leave and insisted that no girl under 16 is forced into any marriage. 
But he acknowledged that the church is under stress lately, largely through the encroachment of the outside world through television, the Internet and news reporters whose interest in Fundamentalist Mormons was spurred by the Tom Green case.
"Our biggest threat is the liberal world," Mr. Barlow said. "It changes our young people, turning them away from holy and good principle. They are free to go out into the outside world. That's one of the very principles of our gospel, a person is free to do something different. We just believe that we teach a better way."

HEADLINE: BackTalk; 
Winning Is Leftwich's Answer to Every Question

DATELINE: BLACKSBURG, Va. 

 BODY:
"Saying you learned something from losing," Byron Leftwich said after he had lost, "is a cover-up for losing. We just lost. Now you think about the next game."
 No question Leftwich, a 22-year-old college quarterback, is pro material. He was standing in the chilly concrete bowels of Lane Stadium on Thursday night, handling reporters with the steady poise he had maintained throughout his Marshall University team's 47-21 loss to Virginia Tech. The question unanswered was the one that had perked much of the news media interest in the game, and one he refused to engage: After such a solid defeat, are you still a contender for the Heisman trophy? 
 "I don't matter," he said. When the questioning persisted, he added: "I'll let you guys decide. I just came here for a W, for a win."
Sounded to me like a candidate for something. 
Before the game began, a Heisman voter in the press box told me he thought there was something unfair about so much riding for Leftwich on Marshall's only nationally televised game this season against a major powerhouse. Virginia Tech is a member of the Big East, one of the conferences that dominate the politics and profits of college sports. Marshall, which is in Huntington, W.Va., is the lesser of two universities in a poor state long struggling with educational problems. Marshall is a "midmajor" in a conference, the Mid-American, struggling for the publicity that comes from nationally televised games. Money and a painstakingly assembled athletic program can gain that exposure over time. A short-cut could be blazed by a camera-ready superstar. 
Then Byron Leftwich ambled onto the scene with his easy grin and powerful right arm, smart and socially comfortable, sweet-natured and tautly focused, a 6-foot-6, 240-pound version of Shaquille O'Neal, the kind of athlete you could invite to photo ops and sudden-death overtimes. Marshall began promoting him as a Heisman candidate last year. The university has a comparatively small athletic budget, about $10 million for all its teams, so its sports information director, Ricky Hazel, spun Leftwich as a sentimental long shot against those Sunshine State front-runners, Rex Grossman of Florida, Ken Dorsey of Miami and Chris Rix of Florida State. 
The bobblehead Byron dolls sent to suspected Heisman voters fought that poor-boy message, except they were financed by a state program that used tobacco company settlement money to combat teenage smoking. "We're going to have to work a little harder now to get out the message," Hazel said after the game. 
Of course, the Heisman electorate is no monolith, a secret roster of perhaps 1,000, mostly members of the sports news media, fragmented by geography and personal ambition. My Heisman source in the press box, no fool, wondered if Marshall's poor showing might help Leftwich. There would be the sympathy vote for an underdog, for a bona fide pro prospect playing for a team that didn't deserve him, for a nonthreatening minority nice guy. Also, it would be a vote just for him, not for the sweaty social climbers from West Virginia and their low-caste league. 
The game itself, broadcast on ESPN, supported such a theory. The final score, 47-21, made it seem closer than it was. Marshall was trailing, 36-0, in the fourth quarter before it finally scored a touchdown. Both teams scored 21 points in that last quarter, often while giving second-stringers playing time. Leftwich was far better than his team. 
His statistics were solid. He completed 31 of 49 passes for 406 yards and 3 touchdowns with only one interception. More important, he seemed never to falter, coolly looking for a second, even a third receiver, using his size to shake off blitzers, firing those short, clothesline passes that can move a good team inexorably forward. 
But the Thundering Herd, alas, did not look like a good team, certainly not the team that rallied to win the GMAC Bowl last season or beat Appalachian State, 50-17, in this season's opening game. The usually excellent receivers dropped key passes, including one sure 5-yard touchdown in the first quarter that might have changed the momentum of the game. Within moments, instead of leading by 7-3, Marshall was down by 10-0. The Herd never thundered again. 
Even more damaging early on was Marshall's inconsistent defense. Tech's backup quarterback, Bryan Randall, threw only 12 passes as he sent seven runners, most notably Kevin Jones and Lee Suggs, on 66 rushes for 408 yards and 6 touchdowns, through holes that seemed to open like automatic doors. 
Leftwich would say only: "We just didn't make the big plays. We put our defense in a bad position . . . we failed. My performance could have been a whole lot better."
Near midnight, charmed and exasperated by the candidate's politic remarks, I asked him if he had lost any of his focus in the days leading up to the game as stories appeared in The Roanoke Times about the resurfacing of his biological father, Paul Anderson. Leftwich has maintained that his mother, Brenda, reared him in Washington, with some roughhouse help from his older brother, Kevin. Anderson, who split from Brenda Leftwich when Byron was 2, has said that he was more of a presence than he had been given credit for as his boys were growing up. He implied that he was calling attention to himself now to correct the record, not just because Byron was on the brink of a big N.F.L. contract. Predictions have Leftwich as an early pick in the pro draft.
Leftwich laughed at my question. "I heard something about that," he said.
We went back and forth for a moment, Leftwich deflecting the questions by saying he had not been reading the newspapers. Suddenly, there was a stir behind us in the stadium corridor and a middle-age woman swept up. She was wearing a T-shirt with Leftwich's No. 7 and the designation MOM. 
Leftwich and I both moved toward her. I asked her about the stories and she flashed Byron's big smile and seemed ready to engage when the quarterback threw that multimillion-dollar arm across his mother's shoulders and amiably said, "We gotta go now."
A moment later, they were side by side, heads close, murmuring, bodies bumping gently down the deserted corridor that led out of the ballpark. I'd vote for him. For president.

HEADLINE: Looking for Votes When Politics Are Topsy-Turvy; 
Candidates for Governor Find Favor in Untraditional Places

BYLINE:  By RICHARD PEREZ-PENA 

 BODY:
Many New Yorkers carry in their heads a template for making sense of state politics, a framework of Republican versus Democrat, liberal versus conservative, upstate versus downstate. But whatever they think they know, as the race for governor heats up, they might want to think again.
 Last week, a popular incumbent, George E. Pataki, suffered an embarrassing loss to a wealthy businessman, Tom Golisano, in the primary of the Independence Party, a party the governor was unable to win over, setting the stage for a three-way general election campaign. 
 Mr. Pataki, a Republican, is doing worse than expected upstate, better than expected in New York City and very well in the increasingly Democratic suburbs. In a liberal state, Mr. Golisano is making points by calling the governor a liberal. 
The leading challenger, H. Carl McCall, was the resounding choice of the Democratic Party. Yet he has so far been unable to tap into his party's enormous advantage in voter registration and its traditional strength in New York City, forcing him to resort to a strategy of reminding Democrats that they are Democrats. At the same time, he speaks daily of the woes of upstate New York, and claims to be more fiscally prudent than the governor.
Mr. Golisano has done little but attack Mr. Pataki, yet he seems to be taking just as many votes from Mr. McCall. The Conservative Party, increasingly a single-issue, anti-abortion group, wholeheartedly backs a governor who favors abortion rights, Mr. Pataki. The Liberal Party may give its nomination to the most conservative candidate in the field, Mr. Golisano. The Democrats cannot count on organized labor.
What gives?
To some extent, this is part of the national trend away from ideology, away from strong party identification, and away from the deep divisions among big-city, suburban and rural voters. But political analysts say there are other things going on here, though getting them to agree on what those things are is a lot like herding cats.
"This race is shaping up differently from anything we've seen before," said Lee Miringoff, director of the Marist College Institute for Public Opinion. "The question is whether any of this is a long-term realignment, rather than just short-term factors."
Maureen Connelly, a political consultant for both Republicans and Democrats whose clients have included Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, dismisses any talk of tectonic shifts in the electoral plates.
"In high-profile races, voters make decisions based on the individuals, not so much on the parties or the ideologies," said Ms. Connelly, who once served as Mayor Edward I. Koch's press secretary. Less-renowned races, she said, still get resolved along the usual lines -- Democrats still win overwhelmingly in the city and Republicans generally win upstate and in the suburbs.
Where there are variations, as in the governor's race, Ms. Connelly argues that they are due to particular circumstances. "I think George Pataki is doing far better in the city than a Republican would normally do, because of his persistence and presence in New York City after 9/11," she said. "But the upstate economy is faltering, and voters there see him focusing his time and energy on New York City, and they resent it."
Mr. Golisano's presence also changes the texture of the race. A billionaire businessman from Rochester, he is best known upstate, and he has built his expensive campaign -- spending more than $30 million so far -- around attacking the governor as a free spender who has done nothing for the state's economy. That pitch resonates far better upstate than it does downstate, and it helps explain why the governor leads Mr. McCall upstate in polls by just 15 points, not the 28 points he won by in 1994.
But some experts point to what may be more fundamental, long-term changes in the electoral balance. Over the last decade, Republicans have lost the defining issues that they used for generations to attack Democrats and motivate their own supporters. Communism collapsed, welfare was reformed, crime dropped, the culture wars mostly backfired, and taxes just don't generate the heat they used to.
"Republicans had to find some issues in the middle or die," said a top adviser to Mr. Pataki. "And that was more true in New York, where Republicans were always the minority and they were always pretty moderate, so it was impossible to build a base around the cultural issues like abortion."
Mr. Pataki ran against Gov. Mario M. Cuomo in 1994 on a platform of cutting taxes, reforming welfare and getting tough on crime, but even then, he also expressed support for abortion rights, gay rights and environmental protection. He has become even harder to pin down, ideologically, since then, talking up liberal causes like drug-law reform, raising spending sharply and promoting major new health care programs.
Another shift in New York has been the inroads that Republicans have made among Hispanic voters, what Alexander F. Treadwell called "priority No. 1" when he became state party chairman last year. Mr. Pataki has made a concerted three-year effort to win over Hispanic voters, and polls show him running even there with Mr. McCall.
"That is a huge threat to us if it holds, if it becomes a long-term thing," a top Democratic official said. Republicans around the country have tried to woo Hispanic voters without great success, except in Florida's Cuban-American community, the official noted, "but Pataki's been better at it than any of them."
Many political strategists think that voters generally fall into three factions. On the left are traditional liberals, mostly Democrats, who believe in using the power of government to solve ills. On the right are cultural conservatives, mostly Republicans, once defined largely by anti-Communism, and more recently by opposition to things like abortion, gun control and rights for gays.
In between are swing voters who are liberal on social issues and want less government and lower taxes, but do not want to sacrifice any services they rely on. By most accounts, the factions on the left and right have shrunk over the last two decades, while the one in the middle has grown. So far, neither major party has established a firm hold on that swing group.
All three candidates are trying, to varying degrees, to position themselves as the champions of that middle vote, presenting themselves as socially liberal and fiscally conservative, which blurs the usual geographic and partisan distinctions.
The swing vote also neatly matches Mr. Pataki's public image (though both his opponents question his claim to fiscal conservatism, and Democrats say the governor's commitment to environment and education are overblown).
Mr. Golisano fits into the middle group, as well, but with a libertarian bent. He promises to cut government significantly, something no other candidate says, but he said on Friday that he also favors civil unions for gay couples.
Mr. McCall lays claim to that center faction by accusing the governor of inefficiency, unsound budgets and rising debt -- even as he tries to win back urban and minority voters who are leaning Mr. Pataki's way.
For a few years now, Democrats have claimed that Republican redoubts in the suburbs and upstate were eroding, making the state more Democratic over all. Republicans insist that is not so. Each side points to specific races to bolster its argument.
What is more convincing: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, a Democrat, getting 47 percent of the upstate vote, or Michael R. Bloomberg, a Republican, being elected mayor? Democrats taking over county governments in Nassau and Westchester, or Republicans capturing Erie County, home to Buffalo.
"You could argue unique circumstances for each of those, or you could argue trends, and the same is true for all the strange things we're seeing in the governor's race," Mr. Miringoff, the pollster, said. "I don't think we know the answers yet. They will only be clear in hindsight."

HEADLINE: PRO FOOTBALL; 
A Changed Dr. Doom Returns

BYLINE:  By THOMAS GEORGE

DATELINE: FOXBORO, Mass., Sept. 12 

 BODY:
For most of his 50 years, Bill Belichick has approached his life the way he creates his stonewall defenses and perplexing game plans: always struggling to find balance and walk that line between what is too little and what is too much.
 He grew up the son of a football coach in Annapolis, Md. In high school, he experienced the initial years of America's educational integration. At liberal, eclectic Wesleyan University in Middletown, Conn. -- hardly an N.F.L. incubator --he played football, lacrosse and squash, studied economics and gained a perspective on race, religion and philosophy. 
 But once Belichick became an N.F.L. assistant coach in 1975, X's and O's and winning games became his passion. He became a fixture as Bill Parcells's defensive coordinator on the Giants in the 1980's, flopped as a head coach in Cleveland, rejoined Parcells with the New England Patriots and the Jets and finally became the Patriots' head coach in 2000. And along this route of nearly three decades, he became widely viewed as a brilliant but uptight Dr. Doom, unfriendly and abrasive, utterly lacking in charisma. 
Last season in New England, something changed. Belichick went back to his roots, found that balance, walked that line, started listening to the needs of his players and others. He remained constant, though, in devising defensive schemes that strangled offenses. He won the Super Bowl as a huge underdog. He evolved.
"He's smart enough and been a coach long enough to realize if something isn't working, you tweak it," Patriots cornerback Terrell Buckley said. "He tweaked it. I guess you really had to know what he was like before having all the control and all the input his way. The great coaches listen to their players but keep control. That's when you have something special. It makes players around here excited."
Belichick, whose Patriots take their 10-game winning streak to Giants Stadium on Sunday to take on the Jets, admits the change. He decided that to endure, to win this second time around as an N.F.L. coach, he had to introduce Belichick the communicator to Belichick the defensive wizard.
"In Cleveland is where a lot of that old reputation started, and that was a situation where I had an adversarial relationship with the team and the media," Belichick said. "I made winning football games the No. 1 priority, and everything else was a distant second.
"It took me time to learn that some of the things I could have handled better. I could have granted more access for the media and more freedom for the players. I'm not as tough as I used to be. You could say I've mellowed."
His competitiveness, however, remains intense. He wants to beat the Jets, the team he spurned in a comical scenario several years ago in which he was named the Jets coach one day and the next day announced he would not be the coach. He has been a part of 4 of the last 16 Super Bowls and desperately wants another one, the next one, and the ones after that. 
Belichick has not gone all warm and fuzzy. That irascible style, that smirk, can surface at any moment. He still pushes his players mentally and physically. And his team can be easily spotted: it is the one that plays football just the way he orders, full of zest and strikingly prepared.
"It's clear to me watching him on TV and listening to his press conferences that he has evolved into a polished performer," said Art Modell, who owned the Browns when Belichick was head coach and now owns the Baltimore Ravens. "His coaching is a given -- he is a great defensive mind -- but he has developed P.R. skills to the benefit of the Patriots and the league.
" In Cleveland, he was turning the media and people off. Some of it was our fault as much as his. But in New England he's found a new way and he did an incredible thing taking that team the distance."
Robert K. Kraft, the Patriots' owner, said the impressions that Belichick made as a New England assistant in 1996 led him to name Belichick coach and stick with him when Belichick produced a 5-11 record his first season and started last season with a 1-3 mark before finishing at 11-5 and winning the Super Bowl.
"People sent me tapes of his press conferences from Cleveland," Kraft said. "Some of my friends said I was making a big mistake. I listened, but I went with my instincts, even during the rough start, because I knew that Bill Belichick was a coach of substance if not style, a coach who is not lipstick and powder but one who runs a disciplined, tough team. That's what I think wins, and he proved us all right. We have what you could call a marriage that I want to last a long time."

The Beauty of Confusion
Belichick's signature is defense. He creates schemes that often confuse offenses, schemes that his players love to put into practice. The Patriots might use five defensive backs on one play, five linebackers on another, or even four safeties.
Belichick has excelled at showing quarterbacks one defensive alignment before the snap, another during the snap and another after the snap, constant, confusing and orchestrated movement by his players that creates offensive uncertainty and chaos. On one play, for example, a cornerback might align as a linebacker and drop off in coverage to a deep, opposite part of the field. His defenses fool offenses.
"To me, in all phases of the game, you have to have enough so you can counter your opponent but keep it simple enough so your players can execute," Belichick said. "You don't want to give them too much, but you don't want to be predictable, either. So that's where you are constantly finding that balance.
"You can't stop everything on offense but you do stop the variable that is most important in your particular matchup. So, I want defenses used in a game that are structured for situations -- for stopping a particular player, for the two-minute situation, for when teams are throwing the ball. I want defense that addresses problems."
The Patriots players say that they learn as many as 30 to 35 different defenses a game, far above the league norm. But Belichick and his staff, including the defensive coordinator, Romeo Crennel, make sure his players have a knack for retaining and executing them. To make some of the plays easier to remember, they are referred to by names of players or popular TV shows.
"It's like a classroom setting a lot of times," Buckley said. "We've got enough defenses that if an offense wants to script 15 plays, we could script 25 plays. It's a common-sense defense that uses a lot of groupings, and they get it across and make you feel like it's not on you but you are involved. We get to suggest things. We retain it."
Results matter, Patriots linebacker Willie McGinest said.
"We work hard and we listen around here because we know one thing: if you do it, and you do it right, you win," McGinest said. "And nothing gets players' attention more than a coach who says something is going to happen, it happens, you're prepared and you win the battle."
Cornerback Ty Law added: "I can't say that everyone here just loves Bill. Some don't really know him that well. But he has the respect and the ear of every player. You have to give him the credit for putting all of that together. We know he can make the difference in winning games."
Belichick's father, Steve, said that when his son played sandlot football, the other young players looked for him to tell them where to be. In high school, since his head coach did not have an assistant, Belichick was something of assistant coach and player, his father said.
"I was a coach and scout at Navy from 1956 through 1989, and as a young boy Bill would come with me on Monday nights when I made my scouting reports to the other coaches," Belichick, 83, said from his home in Annapolis. "He was around superior people and coaches at a very early age. Then later in the week the coaches would come by the house and we'd sit on the porch and talk football and Bill would sit right there and just listen.
"When he graduated from high school, he had a 700 test score in math and 500 in verbal and he comes to me and says he wants to go to prep school. With scores like that, why, I asked? He said that I told some kids a long time ago that they have to get all the preparation they can get to be successful. And that's pretty much Bill: He's always going to be prepared and work his tail off.
"It's amazing how things turned out with him winding up in New England, because I am certain that had the Jets' former owner, Mr. Leon Hess, not died, Bill would be coaching the Jets."
Had he stayed with the Jets, Belichick would have coached for at least a while in the shadow of Parcells, the person he had been most closely linked with in his N.F.L. career. In going to New England instead, he created a separate identity and ultimately won his own championship. Asked about Parcells, Belichick said: "We had a very successful relationship, but it's not like we socialized together every weekend. He did get in touch to congratulate me on winning the Super Bowl. All of the other stuff -- we could talk about that all night."

Love Has Little to Do With It
Significantly, Belichick has begun looking beyond the N.F.L. for perspective. In recent years, he has visited prison football teams, taken part in Drug Enforcement Agency sweeps in Newark projects and worked with charities involved in lifting reading skills. Those experiences, he said, have helped him identify more with some of his draft choices who come from impoverished backgrounds. Belichick, who is married with three children, is also an avid reader -- he collects old football books and has about 300 in his home -- and when his players have children, he often gives them books as gifts.
He has also found more creative ways to reach his players. During Super Bowl week early this year, he took turns giving his suite to players who were complaining about the size of their rooms. To break the monotony of training camp, he showed his players a film about Sir Ernest Shackleton, and how he and his 28 men survived in the Antarctic from 1914 to 1916 after their ship was destroyed. He arranged for the basketball Hall of Famer Bill Russell to visit.
He has, it appears, found a path from sourness to graciousness, from rigidness to more flexibility. He is walking that new line.
Kraft has challenged him to help lead the Patriots into becoming the most successful sports franchise of this decade. They can do it together, Kraft said, and Belichick agrees.
"Nobody achieves anything by themselves," Belichick said. "I feel extremely fortunate because this is the team that I want to be with and this is the only place I want to be."
Ultimately, Belichick is unlikely to become glib and gaudy, to turn flashy on the sidelines or intensely formal in a Tom Landry suit and fedora. He will never be universally loved. And it won't matter.
"That's never been a huge priority," he said. "I don't think it affects the final score."

HEADLINE: THREATS AND RESPONSES: SUSPECTS; 
Families and Neighbors Defend 5 Linked to Terror

BYLINE:  By MARC SANTORA 

DATELINE: LACKAWANNA, N.Y., Sept. 14 

 BODY:
Five men of Arab descent who were arrested in this old steel-making city just outside Buffalo and arraigned this afternoon on charges that they aided the Qaeda terrorist network were staunchly defended by their families and neighbors.
 At the same time, some who know the suspects described marked changes in their personalities in the last year, including an apparently deepening interest in Islam. 
 The complaint unsealed in Federal District Court here today said that the defendants were trained in a Qaeda camp in Afghanistan.
The arrested men -- Yahya Goba, 25; Sahim Alwan, 29; Shafal Mosed, 24; Yasein Taher, 24; and Faysal Galab, 26 -- were escorted into court in wrist and ankle chains. Only about a half-dozen friends and relatives of the defendants were present as the hearing got under way. 
But in the streets around the Lackawanna Islamic Mosque, which the suspects attended, many Muslims in the neighborhood were stunned by the arrests. 
"I am sick in my heart," said Fatim Mosed, the mother of Shafal Mosed. "I know my son, and he is a good boy. Everybody is telling lies."
Like the other suspects, her son attended Lackawanna High School roughly a decade ago and is a United States citizen. While much remains unclear about the men's activities, particularly in the last year, the accounts provided by neighbors and friends focus mostly on their suburban upbringing and social lives.
Mrs. Mosed said that her husband died about 15 years ago. The family moved from Dearborn, Mich., to Lackawanna around that time. She said she had four sons but was currently unemployed. Mrs. Mosed said she relied on her husband's Social Security and her sons' jobs for support.
"My son loves being an American citizen," Mrs. Mosed said. She said her son did travel to Afghanistan sometime in the last three years, but only to further his Islamic education.
Ellis Pierce, 25, who is not a Muslim but lives in the neighborhood, said he went to high school with several of the men. "In school they were normal, like everyone else." However, he said he had noticed a change recently. "Within the last year, they started to grow their beards long," he said. "They were still cool with me, but I noticed the beards." 
In Lackawanna, about five miles south of Buffalo, beards are not uncommon among the large Muslim population, mostly people of Yemeni descent.
Sam Vilanti said that about 20 years ago, many people came to replace striking workers at the steel plant. He said many of these people were Arabs. "Over the years, the population has just kept growing," he said.
Since the steel mill closed, the town has fallen on hard times.The mosque is the cleanest and best-looking building on its block. 
Yousef Goba, the brother of Yahya Goba, said he was confident that a trial would show the men did nothing wrong. "You only worry about the guilty and not the innocent," he said. Mr. Goba said his brother married about two months ago.
Yayha Goba said in court today that he would agree to be sworn in "only on the Koran, not on the Bible." He was sworn in without either. 
He told the court that the last time he was employed was in May 2000, with a company called Unity Wholesale.
His sister, Rahma Goba, said she, her brother and their six other siblings were born in Yonkers and lived there until 1989, when the father decided to move to the family's ancestral home, Yemen. "In Yemen, we went to Islamic school and learned to read and write Arabic," Ms. Goba said. 
Only one of the men seemed to hold steady work. Mr. Alwan told the court he worked for a company called Satellite Services outside Buffalo. He said he earned $31,500 a year. When the court asked if he was still employed, he replied dryly, "I don't know yet."
Outside his apartment, which is across the street from an Arab grocery store that was raided last night, a neighbor, Ahmed Shamsan, said that Mr. Alwan was married and had three children, ages 3, 8 and 9.
Mr. Taher told the court he held a job until August of this year. It was unclear if Mr. Taher was married, but he told the court he had a 3-year-old son.
Mr. Galab is married and has two children, said his father, James, 75. James Galab said he came to the United States in 1955 and his son was born here. He said his son was devoted to his faith. "He always is religious, since he was a little boy he was in the mosque all the time," he said. Mr. Galab did not know whether his son had traveled to Afghanistan.
Neighbors and friends said the five men were often seen together and loved to play soccer. Mason Kadi, 19, said he went to school with several of the men. He said Mr. Mosed and Mr. Galab played on the Lackawanna High School soccer team. "You would not expect anything like this from them," he said.
Another man who described himself as a friend of the men, Ali Shawaala, 28, said that lies had been spread about the Muslims in the community. He said he went to school with Mr. Alwan, the oldest of the suspects. "He wanted to be a cop," he said.
The imam at the mosque, Abdulwahab Ziad, said he had known the men since he first came to the community five years ago. "They are nice guys," he said. "Just because someone visits Pakistan or Afghanistan, it does not mean he is a terrorist."

HEADLINE: THREATS AND RESPONSES: INDICTMENT; 
U.S. SAYS SUSPECTS AWAITED AN ORDER FOR TERROR STRIKE

BYLINE:  By PHILIP SHENON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 

 BODY:
Five Arab-American men charged today with operating an active cell of Al Qaeda in western New York had received intensive weapons training in Afghanistan in the summer of 2001 and been sent back to the United States to await the order for an attack, federal law enforcement officials said today.
 The suspects, all of them born in the United States and of Yemeni descent, were arraigned today in Buffalo on federal charges of providing "material support" to terrorists. 
 Federal officials said the arrests in a Buffalo suburb suggested that, for the first time since the Sept. 11 attacks, the Justice Department might have detected an active Qaeda terrorist cell in the United States.
The Justice Department acknowledged, however, that it had no evidence to suggest that any attack by the group was imminent. The government did not contend today that the men had weapons in their possession or that they had participated in any violent act. 
"We have not seen any plans of an imminent attack in western New York or elsewhere in the United States," the F.B.I. director, Robert S. Mueller III, said in announcing the charges. But he added, "We do not fully know the intentions of those who are charged today."
The men were arrested on Friday night in raids on their homes and businesses in Lackawanna, a Buffalo suburb that has a large Yemeni community and where the suspects lived within a few blocks of one another. Officials said it was information from inside that community that led them to conduct an inquiry there. 
At a news conference in Washington, Deputy Attorney General Larry D. Thompson said the disruption of a "Qaeda-trained terrorist cell on American soil" was an important victory for the United States in combatting terrorism. 
"American citizens who see fit to aid and abet America's enemies will face the full force of America's justice," Mr. Thompson said.
A federal magistrate in Buffalo entered a not-guilty plea today on behalf of the five men, who are all in their 20's, and ordered them detained until a hearing on Wednesday.
Friends and relatives of the men have rallied to their defense, many suggesting that the arrests were the result of an anti-Muslim witchhunt.
"They are good citizens and good members of the community," said Khalid Qazi, a local leader of the American Muslim Council.
A criminal complaint released by the F.B.I. shows that the government believes three other men from Lackawanna received terrorist training in Afghanistan last year. The complaint identified them as "uncharged co-conspirators" and said they were now believed to be living outside the United States, at least two of them in Yemen.
A mostly impoverished Muslim nation of 17 million people that borders Saudi Arabia, Yemen has proved a fertile recruiting ground for Osama bin Laden's terrorist network. On Friday, American officials confirmed the capture in Pakistan of Ramzi bin al-Shibh, a Yemeni who, officials said, served as a paymaster for the Sept. 11 terrorism attacks.
Federal officials said they had no evidence to suggest that the five men in custody in western New York had any tie to the Sept. 11 attacks.
The criminal complaint in their case focuses on an allegation that they provided "material support" to Al Qaeda by receiving training from the group in the summer of last year. 
They are accused of attending a terrorist training camp in Afghanistan known as Al Farouk, the same camp that was attended -- at about the same time -- by John Walker Lindh, the young Californian who pleaded guilty last summer to taking up arms against the United States with the army of the Taliban.
As part of his plea agreement, Mr. Lindh agreed to cooperate with the government in other terrorism investigations. Law-enforcement officials joined with Mr. Lindh's lawyers in refusing to comment today on whether he led investigators to the men arrested in western New York.
"I can say that the debriefings continue," said George C. Harris, one of Mr. Lindh's lawyers, in a telephone interview. "He's being absolutely, fully cooperative." 
Federal law-enforcement officials said that they opened their investigation in Lackawanna, an old steel town on the southern border of Buffalo, after receiving information from within the area's Muslim community months ago that people loyal to Al Qaeda might be living among them.
But the criminal complaint shows that it was only last week, after months of denials by the suspects, that two men accused of involvement in the terrorist cell broke down in interrogations and acknowledged to the F.B.I. that they had attended the Afghanistan camp.
One of the men, Sahim A. Alwan, 29, was among the group arrested on Friday. 
According to the complaint, Mr. Alwan confessed in an interview on Thursday that he had gone to the training camp with six other men from Lackawanna last year, and that they had received training in the use of firearms and antiaircraft guns, along with lectures on "jihad (holy war), prayers and justification for using suicide as a weapon."
In previous interviews with the F.B.I., the complaint said, Mr. Alwan had insisted that he had traveled last year only as far as Pakistan, where he said he had received religious training.
According to the complaint, he said that during the seven-week training session in Afghanistan, Osama bin Laden visited the camp, which was near the former Taliban stronghold of Kandahar, and "gave a speech about the alliance of the Islamic jihad and Al Qaeda, espousing anti-United States and anti-Israel statements."
The complaint said that the other man from Lackawanna who confessed last week, identified only as "uncharged co-conspirator C," had been interviewed by an F.B.I. agent on Wednesday somewhere "outside the United States" and has also acknowledged terrorist training.
He reported, it said, that "he was trained on the use of the Kalashnikov assault rifle, handguns and long-range rifles" and that another of the men from western New York was trained in "heavy artillery."
Federal officials said it was the two confessions that led them to move on Friday to arrest Mr. Alwan and the four others from Lackawanna, identified as Yahya Goba, 25, who is unemployed; Shafal A. Mosed, a 24-year-old employee of a credit company; Yasein A. Taher, 24, who is unemployed; and Faysal H. Galab, 26, whose recent work history was not disclosed.
The men arrived for their court hearing in casual street clothes, their hands and feet shackled. They said little beyond yes or no to the questions of Magistrate H. Kenneth Schroeder, who asked the men about their ability to pay for defense lawyers.
Law-enforcement officials said that the recent developments in the Lackawanna investigation were a factor in the government's announcement on Tuesday that it had raised the national terrorism alert level to "orange," signifying a high risk of a terrorist attack.
At the news conference today, however, Mr. Thompson cautioned that "the elevation of our status alert was made after considering a number of factors" and that the discovery of the Lackawanna cell had "not specifically" led to the new terrorism alert.
Mr. Thompson and other officials today repeatedly praised the cooperation received from American Muslims in western New York and elsewhere in the search for terrorists who may be in the United States.
"I want to thank the Muslim community of Buffalo for their extraordinary cooperation," Mr. Thompson said, offering no details on the nature of that cooperation.
The five men were charged with violating a federal statute that makes it a crime to provide "material support" to a designated foreign terrorist organization like Al Qaeda.
In 1996, when the law was passed, Congress broadly defined material support to include almost anything of value except for medicine or religious materials -- a list that included the provision of "personnel" or "training" to a foreign terrorist organization. If convicted, each of the men would face up to 15 years in prison.

CORRECTION-DATE: September 17, 2002

 CORRECTION:
A front-page article on Sunday about terrorism charges against five Arab-American men in western New York, who were accused of having attended a terrorist training camp in Afghanistan, misstated the criminal charges to which an earlier defendant, John Walker Lindh, pleaded guilty last summer. Mr. Lindh, accused of attending the same camp, admitted having taken up arms as a soldier in the Taliban -- not having taken up arms with the Taliban against the United States.

PERSON: Gerald Rosenfeld 

HEADLINE: Private Sector; 
A New York Accent at Rothschild

BYLINE:  By RIVA D. ATLAS 

 BODY:
GERALD ROSENFELD prefers slacks and navy blue blazers to power suits and cuff links. He often rides the subway. He tells you what he thinks, plainly and quickly, with the bluntness that comes from growing up in Queens. 
 Not what you'd expect from the chief executive of Rothschild North America, an investment banking subsidiary of the Rothschild family empire, with all its European pomp. 
 "He is not one of those slick, Hermes-clad warriors," said Steven Rattner, managing principal of the Quadrangle Group, who worked with Mr. Rosenfeld in the 1990's when both were bankers at Lazard, another family-owned investment banking boutique. "He is a very straightforward guy."
On his third day at Rothschild, Mr. Rosenfeld said, he scrapped the strict business dress code. He called it "one of my enduring contributions."
What he really brought to Rothschild, at the age of 55 and with more than 20 years in the banking business, is a list of clients across corporate America. He's using it to help Rothschild muscle into the top ranks of Wall Street deal making.
Most recently, he was hired to advise the UAL Corporation, parent of United Airlines, on how to restructure its $7 billion debt, which could soon drag it into bankruptcy. Mr. Rosenfeld got the job because, while at Lazard, he advised the company on its employee buyout in 1994.
"Knowing Jerry was instrumental in our hiring the firm," said Frederic Brace, the chief financial officer of UAL, who described him as "very pragmatic and a problem solver."
Mr. Rosenfeld is blunt about UAL's lack of strategic options. "There aren't a lot of assets that can be sold without the unions' permission," he said.
While Rothschild is a significant investment banking force in Europe, it ranks only 14th among advisers on United States mergers, according to Thomson Financial. But that is still much higher than its 27th-place ranking three years ago.
Back then, Mr. Rosenfeld said, the Rothschild family realized that "if you are a global firm, how can you ignore the U.S.?"
Mr. Rosenfeld said he hoped the firm would crack the top 10 once the economy rebounded. "The good news is we didn't have any market share to defend," he said.
His timing is good. Some of the largest investment banks are under scrutiny from regulators for possible conflicts of interest and unethical behavior, giving smaller competitors like Rothschild an advantage.
When he took the job in January 2000, Mr. Rosenfeld asserted, "the conventional wisdom was that firms like Rothschild were anachronisms."
"Now," he added, "firms of our size are sought after."
His unconventional background may help at a time when the motives of the typical Wall Street banker are suspect. "I often cite him as an example that life is never over," said Roy Smith, a former partner at Goldman Sachs and a finance professor at New York University, where Mr. Rosenfeld teaches part time. "He has done a lot of different things."
Mr. Rosenfeld grew up in the middle-class Queens neighborhood of Kew Gardens, and made the 90-minute commute to the Bronx High School of Science, a prestigious public school. He majored in engineering at City College of the City University of New York and got a Ph.D. in applied mathematics at New York University. Then he taught for three years, at the University of Maryland among other places, but became frustrated with his career. "I was an O.K. researcher but I wouldn't have broken any new ground," he said. 
He joined McKinsey, the consulting company, providing analysis and data to support its theories. After three years, he grew restless again, joining Salomon Brothers in 1979. Lacking an Ivy League degree and a master's degree in business, Mr. Rosenfeld's chances for advancement at McKinsey were probably limited.
"We had him pigeonholed," said Roger Kline, a senior McKinsey partner who remains a good friend. 
Mr. Rosenfeld said he left McKinsey because he had been exposed to investment banking there and wanted to learn that business. He appeared to find his calling at Salomon, where brain power was prized more than pedigree. 
"He was a natural," said Michael Zimmerman, who hired Mr. Rosenfeld at Salomon and is now chief financial officer at ContiFinancial, a pork and poultry investment firm. "His background in mathematics makes him a rigorous, analytical thinker." 
Salomon customers also quickly came to appreciate Mr. Rosenfeld's unassuming style, Mr. Zimmerman said. "There is still a lot of the old neighborhood in him," he added.
Mr. Rosenfeld later worked at Lazard and NationsBanc Montgomery Securities, now part of Bank of America, then ran his own advisory firm before joining Rothschild.
He has replaced much of the old Rothschild team of bankers. He hired bankruptcy experts who have advised companies like Pacific Gas and Electric and Federal Mogul. Just weeks after he started, Mr. Rosenfeld advised T.W.A. on its acquisition by the AMR Corporation, parent of American Airlines. He is personally handling the UAL work.
In some cases, Rothschild has won advisory roles from European companies that require American expertise -- work that the firm would have missed before Mr. Rosenfeld came.
Last year, his group advised France Telecom, a longtime client in Europe, on restructuring the American debts of NTL, in which France Telecom holds a large stake. This year, Rothschild is advising Vivendi, the French media conglomerate, on its restructuring, which could include the sale of American divisions like Houghton Mifflin.
So far, the Rothschilds are pleased with how Mr. Rosenfeld has raised their firm's profile. "He has been able to gain the trust of people externally as well as within the firm," said Edouard de Rothschild, a senior partner in the family's Paris office. "Jerry has restored the credibility and respectability of the Rothschild name" in America.
Mr. Rothschild would not disclose precise figures but said the family's American business was profitable this year for the first time.
Mr. Rosenfeld said his typical 12-hour work day starts at 7:30 a.m., when he calls Europe from his Manhattan office. He lives in Manhattan with his wife, Judith Zarin, an independent film producer, and one of their three children. 
The stock market's slump, he said, hasn't dampened his enthusiasm for doing deals. "There have been a lot of difficult days," he said. "But over all, it's been terrific."
