HEADLINE: SCIENTIST AT WORK/Steven Pinker; 
In Nature vs. Nurture, a Voice for Nature

BYLINE:  By NICHOLAS WADE 

 BODY:
Who should define human nature? When the biologist Edward O. Wilson set out to do so in his 1975 book "Sociobiology," he was assailed by left-wing colleagues who portrayed his description of genetically shaped human behaviors as a threat to the political principles of equal rights and a just society.
 Since then, a storm has threatened anyone who prominently asserts that politically sensitive aspects of human nature might be molded by the genes. So biologists, despite their increasing knowledge from the decoding of the human genome and other advances, are still distinctly reluctant to challenge the notion that human behavior is largely shaped by environment and culture. The role of genes in shaping differences between individuals or sexes or races has become a matter of touchiness, even taboo. 
 A determined effort to break this silence and make it safer for biologists to discuss what they know about the genetics of human nature has now been begun by Dr. Steven Pinker, a psychologist of language at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. In a book being published by Viking at the end of this month, "The Blank Slate: The Modern Denial of Human Nature," he seeks to create greater political elbow room for those engaged in the study of the ways genes shape human behavior. "If I am an advocate, it is for discoveries about human nature that have been ignored or suppressed in modern discussions of human affairs," he writes. 
A principal theme of Dr. Pinker's argument is that the blank slaters -- the critics of sociobiology and their many adherents in the social sciences -- have sought to base the political ideals of equal rights and equal opportunity on a false biological premise: that all human minds are equal because they are equally blank, equally free of innate, genetically shaped, abilities and behaviors. 
The politics and the science must be disentangled, Dr. Pinker argues. Equal rights and equal opportunities are moral principles, he says, not empirical hypotheses about human nature, and they do not require a biological justification, especially not a false one. 
Moreover, the blank slate doctrine has political consequences that have been far from benign, in Dr. Pinker's view. It encourages totalitarian regimes to excesses of social engineering. It perverts education and child-rearing, loading unmerited guilt on parents for their children's failures.
In his book he reproaches those who in his view have politicized the study of human nature from both the left and the right, though in practice more of his fire is directed against the left, particularly the critics of sociobiology. They have created a climate in which "discoveries about human nature were greeted with fear and loathing because they were thought to threaten progressive ideals," he writes.
He accuses two of them -- Dr. Richard Lewontin, a population geneticist at Harvard, and the late Dr. Stephen J. Gould, a historian of science -- of "25 years of pointless attacks" on Dr. Wilson and on Dr. Richard Dawkins, author of "The Selfish Gene," for allegedly saying certain aspects of behavior are genetically determined.
And he chides the sociobiology critics for turning a scholarly debate "into harassment, slurs, misrepresentation, doctored quotations, and, most recently, blood libel." In a recent case, two anthropologists accused Dr. James Neel, a founder of modern human genetics, and Dr. Napoleon Chagnon, a social anthropologist, of killing the Yanomamo people of Brazil to test genetic theories of human behavior, a charge Dr. Pinker analyzes as without basis in fact. 
With this preemptive strike in place, Dr. Pinker sets out his view of what science can now say about human nature. This includes many of the ideas laid out by Dr. Wilson in "Sociobiology" and "On Human Nature," updated by recent work in evolutionary psychology and other fields. 
Dr. Pinker argues that significant innate behavioral differences exist between individuals and between men and women. Discussing child-rearing, he says that children's characters are shaped by their genes, by their peer group and by chance experiences; parents cannot mold their children's nature, nor should they wish to, any more than they can redesign that of their spouses. Those little slates are not as blank as they may seem.
Dr. Pinker has little time for two other doctrines often allied with the Blank Slate. One is "the Ghost in the Machine," the assumption of an immaterial soul that lies beyond the reach of neuroscience, and he criticizes the religious right for thwarting research with embryonic stem cells on the ground that a soul is lurking within. 
The third member of Dr. Pinker's unholy trinity is "the Noble Savage," the idea that the default state of human nature is mild, pacific and unacquisitive. Dr. Pinker believes, to the contrary, that dominance and violence are universal; that human societies are more given to an ethos of reciprocity than to communal sharing; that intelligence and character are in part inherited, meaning that "some degree of inequality will arise even in perfectly fair economic systems," and that all societies are ethnocentric and easily roused to racial hatred.
Following in part the economist Thomas Sowell, he distinguishes between a leftist utopian vision of human nature (the mind is a blank slate, man is a Noble Savage, traditional institutions are the problem) and the tragic vision preferred by the right (man is the problem; family, creed and Adam Smith's Invisible Hand are the solutions). 
"My own view is that the new sciences of human nature really do vindicate some version of the tragic vision and undermine the utopian outlook that until recently dominated large segments of intellectual life," he writes.
With "The Blank Slate," Dr. Pinker has left the safe territory of irregular verbs. But during a conversation in his quiet Victorian house a few blocks from the bustle of Harvard Square, he seemed confident of dodging the explosions that have rocked his predecessors. "Wilson didn't know what he was getting into and had no idea it would cause such a ruckus," he said. "This book is about the ruckus; it's about why people are so upset." 
"It's conceivable that if you say anything is innate, people will say you are racist, but the climate has changed," he says. "I don't actually believe that the I.Q. gap is genetic, so I didn't say anything nearly as inflammatory as Herrnstein and Murray," the authors of the 1994 book "The Bell Curve," who argued that inborn differences in intelligence explain much of the economic inequality in American society.
Despite his confidence, Dr. Pinker is explicitly trying to set off an avalanche. He compares the overthrow of the blank slate view to another scientific revolution with fraught moral consequences, that of Galileo's rejection of the church's ideas about astronomy. "We are now living, I think, through a similar transition," he writes, because the blank slate, like the medieval church's tidy hierarchy of the cosmos, is "a doctrine that is widely embraced as a rationale for meaning and morality and that is under assault from the sciences of the day."
Dr. Pinker is not the fire-breathing kind of revolutionary. He has a thick mop of curly brown hair, edged respectably with gray, and a mild, almost diffident manner. A writer for the Canadian magazine Macleans described Dr. Pinker, who was born in Montreal, as "endearingly Canadian: polite, soft-spoken, attentive to what others say." Teased about this description, he notes that Canadians also gave the world ice hockey.
Born in 1954, he grew up in the city's Jewish community, in the neighborhood described in Mordecai Richler's novel "The Apprenticeship of Duddy Kravitz." He was caught up in the debates of the 60's and 70's about social organization and human nature, but found his teenage anarchist views of the nobility of human nature dealt a sharp empirical refutation by the Montreal police strike of 1969; in the absence of authority, Montrealers turned immediately to lawlessness, robbing 6 banks and looting 100 stores before the Mounties restored order.
Trained as an experimental psychologist at Harvard, Dr. Pinker took up the study of language and became convinced that the brain's linguistic ability must rest on built-in circuitry. This made him think other faculties and behaviors could be innate, despite the unpopularity of the idea. "People think the worst environmental explanation is preferable to the best innatist explanation," he says.
Dr. Pinker first became known outside his specialty through his 1994 book "The Language Instinct," an approachable account of how the brain is constructed to learn language. He followed up that success with "How the Mind Works," in which he shared his enthusiasm for the ideas of evolutionary psychology. "The Blank Slate" further broadens his ambit from neuroscience to political and social theory.
Like Edward O. Wilson, who began as a specialist in ants and mastered ever larger swaths of biology, Dr. Pinker has a gift of summarizing other specialists' works into themes that are larger than their parts. Synthesisers are rare animals in the academic zoo because they risk being savaged by those whose territory they invade. "Everything in the study of human behavior is controversial, and if you try to sum it up you will ride roughshod over specialists, so you've got to have a strong stomach," Dr. Pinker said. 
The critics of sociobiology caricatured their opponents as "determinists," even though few, if any, people believe human nature is fully determined by the genes. Could Dr. Pinker's description of the Blank Slate similarly overstate their views? He says he shows at length how critics like Dr. Lewontin have made statements that "are really not too far from the collection of positions that I call the Blank Slate," with Dr. Lewontin and others having even written a book called "Not in Our Genes."
Though Dr. Pinker believes the politics and science of human nature should be disentangled, that does not mean political arrangements should ignore or ride roughshod over human nature. To the contrary, a good political system "should mobilize some parts of human nature to rein in other parts." The framers of the Constitution took great interest in human nature and "by almost any measure of human well-being, Western democracies are better," he says. 
Dr. Pinker believes that human nature "will increasingly be explained by the sciences of mind, brain, genes and evolution." But if political and social systems should be designed around human nature, won't that give enormous power to the psychologists, neuroscientists, and geneticists are in a position to say what human nature is?
"It's a game anyone should be able to play if they do their homework," he says, "so I hope it wouldn't become the exclusive province of a scientific priesthood." 

Born With It? Author Suggests Yes
There is evidence that some universal human social behaviors and faculties are innate, and presumably shaped in part by the genes. In "The Blank Slate," Dr. Steven Pinker lists some behaviors of political consequence which he considers may fall in this category. 

Innate Social Behaviors
*Primacy of family ties, making nepotism and inheritance appealing.
*A propensity to share based on reciprocity where nonrelatives are concerned (within the family, it is free).
*A drive for dominance and a willingness to use violence to attain goals.
*Ethnocentrism and other forms of group-against-group hostility.
*Variation in intelligence (leading to inequalities) and in conscientiousness and antisocial behavior (leading to punitive constraints).
*Self-serving biases that deceive people into thinking they are freer, wiser and more honest than they are.
*A moral sense, biased toward kin and friends, and linked to ideas of purity, beauty and rank.

Innate Abilities
*An intuitive physics, used to keep track of the "oomph" of objects as they fall, bounce or bend. 
*An intuitive biology, used to understand the living world by imputing an essence to living things. 
*An intuitive engineering, used to make and understand tools.
*An intuitive psychology, used to understand others by imputing to them a mind with beliefs and desires. 
*A spatial sense and a dead reckoner tracking the body's motions.
*A number sense, based on ability to register small numbers of things (1, 2 and 3) exactly and to estimate larger ones.
*A sense of probability, used to estimate uncertain outcomes by tracking how common one event is in relation to another. 
*An intuitive economics, used to exchange goods and calculate favors.
*A mental database and logic, used to represent ideas, associate one thing with another and devise causal explanations.
*Language, the gift of sharing ideas from the mental database with others. 

GRAPHIC: Photo: In his new book, Dr. Steven Pinker is trying to create more political elbow room for those studying the way that genes shape human behavior. (Rick Friedman for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Survey Finds Artists Since 9/11 Have Less Work and More Debt 

BYLINE:  By JESSE McKINLEY

 BODY:
A survey of the city's artistic corps has found that a vast majority of working artists are still reeling from the effects of last year's terrorist attacks, with significant lost income, spent savings and the threat of eviction among their chief concerns.
 The survey was commissioned by the New York Foundation for the Arts in conjunction with the Consortium for Worker Education, a nonprofit worker training and schooling program, and Downtown NYC!, a nonprofit arts organization. More than 700 artists -- representing music, film and theater as well as the fine arts -- responded to the survey, which was conducted over three weeks in August. The findings are to be released today. 
 According the survey, four out of five artists have suffered a loss of income since last September, with the average loss in individual income being 46 percent. As a result, artists are increasingly forced to dip into their savings and to increase their debt load; 60 percent of survey respondents reported taking on more debt in the last year.
The various problems reported by respondents included a reduction in film production (meaning lost jobs for actors), a drop in tourism (lost jobs in restaurants and hotels, sources of supplemental income for many artists), and fewer freelance writing assignments. 
Such economic strains are also having a profound effect on the basic necessities for artists; 13 percent of those surveyed had either been evicted or were in the process of being evicted from their homes, while 16 percent had lost or were losing their work spaces. In addition, 22 percent said they had become unemployed or lost support jobs outside their artistic discipline since last September. 
For those who monitor and assist artists, the results were sobering.
"The survey demonstrates the substantial economic loss that New York City artists have been enduring since 9/11," said Theodore S. Berger, the executive director of the New York Foundation for the Arts. "There is still much work to be done to get the arts community back on its feet."
Despite their problems, many artists seemed reticent to ask for help. Only about a third of respondents reported applying for any type of public or private disaster aid, with many citing bureacratic red tape as a reason for avoiding aid programs.
A similar number said they would be interested in information about job retraining or placement, though they were not optimistic about their prospects; 81 percent of respondents rated their chances of getting a new job as "poor" or "fair."
Others cited unique problems, including several respondents whose studios -- and work -- were located in the World Trade Center. A full one-third also reported Sept. 11-related health problems, including post-traumatic stress syndrome, that had affected their ability to work. 
All of which seems to have led to a mood of profound despair for the artists surveyed, most of whom are self-employed and therefore especially susceptible to economic droughts. 
"Without savings, health insurance or a pension plan, I feel profoundly at risk," one respondent wrote in an online questionnaire. "But as long as I don't get sick, or old, or step on the cracks in the sidewalk, I suppose I'll be fine."

HEADLINE: Why Japan Steps Gingerly in the Middle East 

BYLINE:  By KEN BELSON 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Sept. 16 

 BODY:
When OPEC ministers meet in Osaka on Thursday, the world will be reminded not just of the cartel's power on the global stage, but also the group's sway over its Japanese hosts.
 Despite spending decades developing other sources of energy, Japan, which must import almost all its oil, is more dependent on Middle East crude than it was in 1973, when the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries organized its first worldwide embargo. As this oil shock rippled through Japan's economy, the globe's second largest, prices spiraled upward and panicked consumers hoarded everyday goods like detergent, sugar and toilet paper. 
 Memories of that event, considered ancient history to most Japanese, are returning to the forefront as talk of a new Middle East war grows. Japan's economy, stuck in a decade-long funk, relies heavily on exports of autos, steel and other goods for growth. With OPEC production quotas at 11-year lows, a disruption of the oil flow from the Middle East could idle Japanese factories and throw Japan back into recession. 
Middle East oil is so crucial to the economy that it heavily colors Japan's role overseas. Reluctant to alienate oil-producing countries, Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi has, nonetheless, hedged his support for President Bush's campaign to attack Iraq. In the end, though, Japan may offer only moral support, analysts say.
Japan remains confident that it can secure enough oil to offset any temporary loss of Middle East crude. The country has a formidable stockpile of fuel, enough to last 171 days. Lawmakers also assume some producers would increase output to make up for losses elsewhere, something the Saudis did during the Persian Gulf war. The spot market is another, more expensive option.
Many critics, though, say that counting on such resources offers a false sense of security. Former Prime Minister Tsutomu Hata remembers how oil embargoes in the 1970's brought the global economy to its knees. Recalling the panicked buying in Japan and the long lines at American gas stations, he said policy makers and oil companies had done a poor job finding alternatives to Middle East oil.
"For a country which consumes so much electricity, it's unusual and very dangerous to rely so highly on Mideast oil," Mr. Hata said in an interview. The events of 20 years ago so shook Mr. Hata that during the summer he wears business suits with half sleeves as a way to urge citizens to turn off their air-conditioners.
To be sure, Japan has done more than most nations to diversify its energy strategy over the last three decades. It has developed nuclear power plants and increased imports of natural gas. Prodded by lawmakers, corporate Japan has not only reduced its use of energy, but also developed highly efficient cars, electronics and machinery.
Japan now relies on oil for 52 percent of its energy needs, down from 73 percent in the mid-1970's. As important, given current events, Japan gets only about 1 percent of its oil from Iraq.
Still, Japan remains dangerously tethered to events in the Middle East. It now imports more than 87 percent of its oil from the region, the highest since 1969. The main culprit is the growing competition for crude from China, Indonesia and Malaysia, which have cut exports and increased imports to fuel their own economies. By 2020, oil is likely to meet a greater share of China's energy needs than Japan's, according to estimates by the Institute of Energy Economics, Japan.
Unlike Japan, which is facing trouble finding local alternatives, the United States can step up imports from Mexico, Canada and other neighbors if the Middle Eastern oil spigot is turned off. European countries can tap the North Sea, Russia and Africa.
As choices for procuring oil narrowed in the last 15 years, Japanese refiners have revamped their operations to accommodate Middle Eastern oil. Compounding matters, Japan's domestic oil market was deregulated in 1996, forcing refiners long cloistered from international competition to slash capacity. With margins squeezed, most have been reluctant to invest in the equipment needed to process other types of oil from Russia, Mexico and beyond.
The government's efforts to help companies find new oil have largely failed, a point driven home two years ago when Japan's Arabian Oil Company lost its concession to fields on the Saudi-Kuwait border. And Japan still lacks oil companies with the needed capital and technology to unearth plentiful amounts of oil. For decades, the government-backed Japan National Oil Company has provided low-cost financing to help the refiners. Yet the public corporation has come under fire for racking up huge debts and encouraging companies to invest in projects they may have otherwise avoided.
"Japanese oil companies are very risk-averse," said Keiichi Yokobori, executive director of the Institute of Research and Innovation in Tokyo. "Perhaps there was a moral hazard because the refiners felt they could contain risks with the government on board."
Just 15 percent of the oil Japan imports is from fields its companies have a stake in. The government has abandoned efforts to raise that target to 30 percent.
Losing the Arabian Oil concession has prompted Japan to try to win access to oil fields in Libya, Iran and several Latin American countries. But here, too, Japanese companies must bid against global giants like Exxon Mobil and Royal Dutch/Shell, integrated refiners with deeper roots in the region and the economies of scale to extract oil profitably.
To keep factories humming and maintain its living standards, Japan has focused instead on shaping domestic consumption habits and diversifying energy sources. Most prominently, it has promoted nuclear power, which over the last two decades has tripled to 12 percent of the country's energy mix.
But the program has been hit by several accidents, including one in 1999 north of Tokyo in which two workers died. More bad will was created this month when the country's largest utility, the Tokyo Electric Power Company, admitted to falsifying safety records at its nuclear plants for more than 15 years. The revelation was particularly worrisome because government regulators knew about the problem two years ago but did little to expose it.
Still, the growth of nuclear power is likely to slow, not grow. With the economy projected to expand at an anemic 1.5 percent a year over the next decade, demand for electricity is likely to rise accordingly. The high cost of building and maintaining nuclear plants is another reason Japan expects to add only a dozen new nuclear plants by 2010, down from as many as 20 that were planned.
Japan has also expanded its use of natural gas, which now meets 13 percent of its energy needs, about half the levels in the United States and Europe. Here, geography plays a role. Since Japan has little natural gas of its own, it must purchase it from Indonesia and elsewhere. And to be shipped, the gas must be turned into liquid, driving up its cost.
To circumvent this, Japanese trading and oil companies have formed a consortium to build an ambitious pipeline from Sakhalin in eastern Russia to Japan, more than 900 miles across the North Pacific. The Japan Petroleum Exploration Company, which leads the venture, released a report last month that said the plan was economically and technologically feasible. But the pipeline would be laid across rough seas, and the companies have not clarified how they plan to compensate fishermen who ply these waters and would be forced to fish elsewhere.
Construction of the pipeline -- which newspapers here estimate could cost up to $12 billion -- may start in 2005 and help Japan tap the equivalent of more than two billion barrels of oil. The consortium, though, has still not secured commitments from utilities and manufacturers to buy the natural gas, which analysts say is likely to be expensive because the pipeline's builders will want to recoup their costs.
Despite these hurdles, the government has had success on the margins. By the end of the decade, utilities will be required to use fixed amounts of renewable energy, like solar and wind power, though the price of such energy remains high. Conservation laws passed in recent years require manufacturers to increase energy efficiency in computers, air-conditioners and other electronic gear by as much as 80 percent.
Prodded by the government's commitment to lower greenhouse gas emissions to 1990 levels, Toyota and Honda have led the global auto industry in developing cars driven by hybrid engines. The Toyota Prius, which runs on gasoline and electricity, "gets twice the fuel efficiency of a conventional car of the same class and has much cleaner emissions," said Paul Nolasco, a Toyota spokesman.
Still, fuel-cell cars -- the ultimate goal -- remain too expensive to produce. Industry experts and automobile executives say the combustion engine is here for at least a few more decades. In the meantime, the amount of oil Japan consumes for home heating and transportation continues to rise, more than offsetting the energy-saving steps taken by Japanese industry. And since consumers generally react more slowly to swings in global prices, a crisis in the Middle East may turn into a rude awakening if the government is forced to limit the use of oil in any way.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS; 
The Dow Ends a Bit Higher, but Technology Shares Slide

BYLINE:  By Reuters 

 BODY:
The Dow Jones industrial average ended higher yesterday for the first time in four sessions, but the broader stock market finished flat as the technology sector slumped on worries about earnings and the threat of war in the Persian Gulf.
 "Iraq is more than the usual worry because deadlines are getting closer and the situation is starting to accelerate," said Robert Basel, head of listed equity trading at Salomon Smith Barney. "And we are getting right into earnings-warning season -- that's something that is going to be an issue all week." 
 Stocks like Texas Instruments weighed on the high-technology sector after a raft of bearish research notes from Wall Street analysts sent a crucial gauge of that sector to its lowest point in about three and a half years. But the Boeing Company rebounded from days of decline, after averting a strike by its largest union. 
"Technology stocks seem to be saying that things are not getting better, so we should not be expecting too much," said Alfred Kugel, senior strategist at Stein Roe Investment Counsel. But he added that other sectors were doing better.
Yesterday's meager serving of economic news was encouraging. The government reported that businesses added to their inventories for a third consecutive month in July, stockpiling goods in a way that suggested increasing optimism on the economic outlook.
The broad Standard & Poor's 500-stock index ended little changed, up 1.29 points, or 0.14 percent, at 891.10. The Dow Jones industrial average was up 67.49 points, or 0.81 percent, at 8,380.18.
The technology-packed Nasdaq index lost 15.52 points, or 1.20 percent, to 1,275.88.
Technology shares followed a downward trend yesterday. Microsoft slipped 13 cents, to $47.78. I.B.M. lost 18 cents, to $72.32. Among other losers, Sun Microsystems lost 18 cents, to $2.93, and the Oracle Corporation shed 45 cents, to $9.28, ahead of its earnings report today.
Boeing shares jumped $1.65, to $37.23. Boeing's largest union said over the weekend that its members had turned down their leaders' call to strike, adopting a contract by default even though more than half the voters opposed the three-year pact.
Companies this week are expected to begin offering warnings of missed earnings. Analysts expect third-quarter earnings at companies in the Standard & Poor's 500 to rise 10.9 percent from the year-ago period, the research firm Thomson First Call said.
The threat of war against Iraq kept sentiment soft. The United States resumed lobbying for a strong United Nations resolution demanding that Iraq disarm, preferably with a threat of severe consequences if Iraq does not comply. The American campaign gathered strength over the weekend when Saudi Arabia said it would back action against Iraq if the United Nations approved it.
"We're waiting to see what happens with Iraq and what the timetable is there," said Michael Kayes, chief investment officer at Eastover Capital Management. "There is no real earnings reason for the market to move higher in a sustainable way. Earnings will turn one day, but the timing of that is uncertain." 
A profit warning from Chartered Semiconductor Manufacturing of Singapore and a raft of bearish research notes from analysts sent semiconductor stocks yesterday to their lowest point since late 1998.
"This is really just a crummy environment we have," a semiconductor analyst at Banc of America, Mark FitzGerald, said. "The analysts are just starting to pile on."
Texas Instruments fell 73 cents, to $18.27, after Prudential cut its price target to $28, from $33. Shares in the microchip maker Atmel tumbled 33 cents, or 18 percent, to $1.47, after Prudential lowered its target to $2 from $6.
Lucent Technologies fell 19 cents, or 15 percent, to $1.07 after hitting a record low of $1.05. Goldman, Sachs said that Lucent's financial warning on Friday showed there was no pick-up in telecommunications spending. --------------------

Treasury Prices Mixed
(By Bloomberg News) -- Treasuries were mixed as a rebound in stocks crimped demand for fixed-rate government securities.
"Higher equity prices have been identified with greater consumer confidence," helping the economy and dimming the allure of Treasuries, said Mark Mahoney, head of interest-rate strategy at UBS Warburg.
The price of the Treasury's 10-year note fell 2/32, to 103 24/32. The yield was unchanged at 3.91 percent.
The price of the 30-year note rose 5/32, to 109 18/32. The yield, which moves in the opposite direction, fell to 4.76 percent from 4.77 percent on Friday.

HEADLINE: W.T.O. to Rule on Possible Steel Quotas 

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: GENEVA, Sept. 16 

 BODY:
The World Trade Organization agreed today to rule on a United States complaint that European Union quotas and tariffs on steel imports are illegal.
 The E.U. said in March that it might apply tariffs as high as 26 percent on some steel products to protect its manufacturers. 
The Europeans fear a surge in imports looking for new markets after the United States imposed tariffs as high as 30 percent. 
 On top of the safeguard measures, the E.U. may choose to retaliate against United States steel protection by imposing tariffs worth as much as $350 million on citrus, clothing and other imports from the United States. The European trade commissioner, Pascal Lamy, is expected to make a decision on retaliation by the end of the month.
The European Union announced the safeguard measures "without clear evidence that increased imports are causing or threatening to cause serious injury" to its domestic steel industry, Steve Fabry, senior legal adviser at the United States mission to the W.T.O. in Geneva, told a W.T.O. dispute meeting.
European steel tariffs would apply to 15 products, from sheets for car doors to wires used in construction. They would take effect once last year's global imports of 27 million metric tons are exceeded.
The E.U. "strongly deplores the U.S. decision" to bring a W.T.O. complaint against the safeguard tariffs, Carlo Trojan, European ambassador to the W.T.O., told the dispute meeting.
Aimed at preventing steel intended for the United States from being diverted to the European market, the safeguards "fundamentally differ" from the United States tariffs, Mr. Trojan said.
A W.T.O. dispute panel may take at least a year to deliver a final decision on the United States complaint.

HEADLINE: ON THE GROUND: San Francisco; 
A Good Time for Bay Area Bargains

BYLINE:  By DREW LIMSKY; This feature about places to stay, eat and visit in leading business destinations appears every Tuesday.

 BODY:
While stories of unemployed professionals abound in San Francisco, home to the headquarters of Fortune 500 companies like Wells Fargo, the Gap and Levi Strauss, there is an upside to the Bay Area's economic slowdown for corporate visitors. Top hotels are offering specials, and some of the city's best restaurants no longer require reservations a month in advance. 
Downtown is known as Union Square, a high-end shopping area flanked by Nob Hill to the northwest and the financial district to the east. Cars are unnecessary, and parking is expensive. Time-short travelers may want to skip the crowded cable cars that run north up to the souvenir shops of Fisherman's Wharf. Happily, seats are almost always available on the east-west California Street line, which climbs Nob Hill and is steps from most major hotels.

HOTELS
 At the MANDARIN ORIENTAL (415-276-9888, $500 to $3,000), which occupies the top 11 floors of the third-highest office tower in the city, the commanding views make it difficult to keep your mind on business. Still, it is in the heart of the financial district, is wired for videoconferencing, has 3,900 square feet of meeting space and provides high-speed Internet access. It also has a 24-hour fitness center and features large bathrooms, some with vistas of the Transamerica Pyramid and the Golden Gate Bridge. 
 The RITZ-CARLTON (415-296-7465, $450 to $5,200), the chain's flagship property, occupies a stunning 1909 neoclassical building halfway up Nob Hill. One-third of the 336 rooms are found on the club level, the "hotel within the hotel" that provides a separate concierge service. For corporate regulars, the Ritz-Carlton launders and stores clothes between visits in its "luggageless travel" program.
The Ritz-Carlton's dining room (415-773-6198, $200 for two, including wine and tip) is formal, while the more relaxed Terrace serves lunch fare like lobster salad and turkey sandwiches with huge slabs of avocado. It also provides seating in its outdoor garden.
Just off Union Square, the low-key CAMPTON PLACE (415-781-5555, $335 to $2,000) provides five meeting rooms, evening limousine service and an overnight shoeshine -- and is known for its substantial breakfasts. The French toast is a winner, cut thick and served with whipped cream and peach compote.
On Nob Hill, the MARK HOPKINS INTER-CONTINENTAL (415-392-3434, $355 to $3,000), home of the famous Top of the Mark lounge, offers 22 business guest rooms equipped with printer-fax-copier machines and lumbar-friendly ergonomic desk chairs.

DINING OUT
BOULEVARD (415-543-6084, $150) offers New American food in an Art Nouveau dining room. Valerie Harper, who recently starred in "The Tale of the Allergist's Wife" at the Curran Theater, is a regular when she is in town. "I had the most fantastic mushroom soup, the most extraordinary little confection," she said. Save room for the chocolate pudding cake, served with three kinds of chocolate ice cream -- dark, milk and white.
SILKS (415-986-2020, $150), the restaurant at the Mandarin, gets high marks for both its contemporary American fare with Pacific Rim influences and its efficient service. The chef, Christophe Vessaire, creates dishes like crab agnolotti with asparagus, prepared with tarragon or a truffle-oil-based sauce. Silks at Six -- an early, three-course prix fixe dinner for $39.95 -- is popular with business travelers. 
Iris Chan, executive vice president of Wells Fargo, recommends Wolfgang Puck's POSTRIO (415-776-7825, $150) for its hospitality as well as its cuisine, which she describes as "very San Franciscan and very Californian."
AQUA (415-956-9662, $200), set in a dramatically lighted, earth-toned room, is the city's most prestigious seafood restaurant; its menu features delicacies like caviar parfait and potato-encrusted sea bass.

ENTERTAINMENT
Ms. Harper enjoys the "fabulous kitsch" at TONGA (415-772-5278), the Polynesian bar at the Fairmont Hotel known for its fake rainstorms. At the CURRAN THEATER (415-551-2000), Baz Luhrmann's "La Boheme" will be having a pre-Broadway run from Oct. 1 through Nov. 10.

ON YOUR OWN
This city is a walker's delight, and some of the best tours are detailed in "Fodor's San Francisco." Russian Hill on foot can be magical, with its hidden staircases and parks, and North Beach, the San Francisco version of Little Italy, is ringed with cafes and pasta places, some right off pleasant Washington Square Park. The landmark CITY LIGHTS BOOKSTORE (415-362-8193), long associated with the Beat Generation, is worth a browse, and Chinatown and Telegraph Hill are not far away.

LOCAL LORE
San Francisco's unusual topography and atmospheric mists have served as the backdrops to many movies, especially mysteries. The Barbary Lane in "Tales of the City" was inspired by Macondray Lane in Russian Hill, and film buffs will remember the obsessed Jimmy Stewart trailing Kim Novak in "Vertigo" to the York Hotel on Sutter Street and to a stately Nob Hill building on Sacramento Street.

HEADLINE: U.S. Will Get Power, and Pollution, From Mexico 

BYLINE:  By TIM WEINER 

DATELINE: MEXICALI, Mexico, Sept. 11 

 BODY:
American companies have long faced intense resistance to big new power plants from communities crying, "Not in my backyard."
 Now they have a big new backyard: Mexico. 
 Here on the edge of Mexicali, a few miles from the California border, two huge power plants are rising in the desert, near a graveyard and a clutch of hovels. They will generate billions of watts for millions of Californians, a handful of jobs for Mexicans and pollution on both sides of the border. 
They are "what free trade is all about," says an official of InterGen, the company building one. But a California congressman calls placing the plants in Mexico a form of environmental imperialism. 
The plants will be the first of many built in Mexico specifically to provide power for the United States, says Mexico's energy secretary, Ernesto Martens. And that represents a new phase in relations between the two nations.
First came the labor of migrant workers. Then, in the 1990's, came the maquiladoras, the assembly-line factories providing cheap Mexican labor for American and multinational corporations under the North American Free Trade Agreement.
Now these 21st-century plants -- call them energy maquiladoras -- represent a new way to generate wealth and power by capitalizing on the economic and legal differences dividing Mexico and the United States. 
Mexico's environmental law enforcement is weaker, its government less transparent, its desire for foreign capital bottomless. California's energy demand is enormous -- as big as its citizens' resistance to huge power plants. 
These projects are the first result.
"Building anything on the Mexican side is much cheaper, mostly because of the regulatory system," which is less stringent than in the United States, said Ernesto Ruffo, President Vicente Fox's border commissioner.
President Bush and the United States Department of Energy had to issue special presidential permits for the plants, which will be powered by natural gas piped from Texas, cooled by Mexicali's sewage and linked to California's grid next year.
One is being built by InterGen, owned by Shell Oil and the Bechtel Corporation. Up to 560 of its 1060 megawatts will go north, 500 to Mexico. The company concedes that the plant does not meet California's pollution standards and would not be licensed across the border. 
California's senators and two congressmen whose districts border Mexico have introduced legislation to stop InterGen from providing power to the state without meeting its standards. One, Representative Bob Filner, a San Diego Democrat, called placing the plants in Mexico "19th-century imperialism."
But even though, as Mr. Filner said, "the Border Patrol has not yet figured out how to stop air pollution," United States laws do not govern Mexico.
The second plant, built by Sempra Energy, based in San Diego, meets California standards. It could conceivably have been built there, but at a greater cost to its owners, who would have to pay to offset what pollution it would create. All its 600 megawatts will go to California.
A megawatt is roughly enough electricity for up to 1,000 homes. The plants together can power more than one million California houses.
Don Felsinger, president of Sempra Energy Group Enterprises, said "we thought it was good business and it made environmental sense" to build its plant to California standards. It took only six months to license the plant; in California, it would have been two years, he said.
Like California, Mexico is facing an energy crunch. The country needs at least 29,000 more megawatts over the next decade, at an expected cost of $30 billion -- money Mexico does not have.
The irony of exporting power when Mexicans need more -- and when their electricity bills are doubling -- is not lost on the populace. But support for the new plants among politicians is nearly total. Public opposition to the plants was muted by the fact that they were a done deal before the public knew anything about them. 
"There is no right to know in Mexico," said Fernando Medina, a social scientist in Mexicali. "Even had we known these plants would be built, no social or political force could stop them." 
Margarito Quintero, who like Mr. Medina teaches at the Autonomous University of Baja California, said: "There are no laws in Mexico to limit these plants. Their existence is a reflection of the inequalities between the two countries."
The plants will pollute the air and the water in California's Imperial Valley, a heavily Hispanic region north of Mexicali, according to local officials. But they appear exempt from the environmental laws of the United States.
"Our Department of Energy said this project is not going to have any environmental impact, and we were screaming, saying, 'That's garbage, of course it will,' " said Steve Birdsall, director of the Imperial County Air Pollution Control District. 
He said the InterGen plant would send more than 3,800 tons of pollutants a year into the air (Sempra's smaller plant will emit one-tenth that much). And he assailed InterGen for ignoring California standards.
"They are the epitome of corporate arrogance," he said. "They have not been honest with us."
At InterGen, John Foster, a senior vice president, said his company had been "honest and straightforward." He said InterGen might even retrofit its plant to comply completely with California standards, assuming consumers would help pay the added cost of up to $20 million.
He said the key to building more plants in Mexico to serve the United States -- "a great idea" -- was to harmonize the two nations' environmental laws.
"Then everybody would be playing by the same rules," he said.
In Mexicali, so close to the United States and yet so far, people who live next to the plants accept them with a fatalistic shrug.
Elisabeth Figueroa, 31, started work this week as an office cleaner at the InterGen plant, making $2 an hour on a month-to-month contract. "We need the light and electricity around here, but most of it is going north," she said. "And we know it will be bad for the environment, but we need the work.
"Maybe it's unjust," she said. "But we Mexicans are used to injustice."

HEADLINE: For Sale Upstate: Home and Underground Silo (Missile Extra) 

BYLINE:  By The New York Times 

DATELINE: SARANAC, N.Y., Sept. 12 

 BODY:
For sale: In beautiful Adirondack Park, just 20 minutes from golf courses and ski areas, the ultimate in mountain luxury. Three bedrooms, three baths, septic system, Jacuzzi and seven-story underground missile silo designed to absorb the shock of a direct nuclear hit.
 All this and more, including a private airstrip, may be yours if you are the high bidder in an eBay auction that ends Sept. 25. 
 "This is a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity for you to purchase one of the most secure residential properties in the United States today," reads the property description. "This could be your weapon against growing world terrorism." 
With a required minimum bid of $2.1 million, the auction has yet to attract any buyers. But Bruce Francisco, who owns the property with his cousin, Gregory Gibbons, said he was not worried. "From what I understand, everyone waits until the end to bid," he said.
The property is one of several Cold War missile-launching sites around the country that have been converted to homes -- part of a small, increasingly costly real estate niche. 
Still, the silo here has not been an easy sell. The owners promote the property, which has been on the market for several years, as both a cutting-edge "extreme home" and as a nostalgic curiosity, "a rare 20th-century collectible." In 1999, as Year 2000 fears mounted, it was advertised as a secure data-storage facility. And now, a year after the terror attacks, the owners are appealing to Americans' renewed sense of vulnerability.
"In a year, or 10 years, this thing may be priceless," Mr. Francisco said. "Who knows, with the world the way it is?"
The silo dates to 1960, when the nation's fears focused not on Middle Eastern terrorists but on Cuba and the Soviet Union. Around that time, a dozen Atlas-F missile sites were built within a 40-mile radius of Plattsburgh Air Force Base in northern New York.
Missiles and crews arrived in 1962, but the Atlas was declared obsolete within two years. The Defense Department moved on to more advanced weaponry, and the Atlas sites were deactivated. Plattsburgh Air Force Base closed in 1995.
Salvage companies bought some of the sites for the steel. Several were acquired by town governments, which used the above-ground Quonset huts to store highway equipment. Individuals bought several locations; at least two others in the Plattsburgh area are on the market.
Mr. Gibbons bought his property, which is midway between Saranac Lake and Plattsburgh, as an investment a decade ago for $55,000. He first intended to salvage the steel, but could not bring himself to dismantle the silo. Instead, he pumped out the water and sludge, hauled away old, rusted equipment and built a house on a neighboring lot. He and his cousin, a Connecticut real estate developer, then built on the missile site.
The result is a normal-looking house above two unseen underground cylinders. The smaller cylinder, which served as a two-story control center, is connected by tunnel to the deep silo that once housed an 81-foot missile.
The control center is a living space, accessible by a staircase leading to two sets of thick steel doors. Subterranean bedrooms, bathrooms and living areas surround a thick central support tower wrapped by a spiral staircase.
Backlit block-glass windows create the effect of outdoor light, but this is not a home for the claustrophobic. The underground floors are utterly quiet, with a constant ambient temperature of about 58 degrees.
Mr. Francisco describes the space as ideal for sound sleeping and focused work. "There might be a blizzard outside and you wouldn't know it," he said.
The tunnel and the silo have been cleaned but not renovated, Mr. Francisco said.
If the eBay auction does not produce a buyer, there are other strategies. Alternative uses suggested on Silohome.com, the owners' Web site, include a bed-and-breakfast, movie location and recording studio.
Mr. Francisco is also showing the property to other potential buyers who expressed an interest before the auction began.
Sooner or later a buyer, if only for investment purposes, will be found, predicted Edward Peden, who owns Twentieth Century Castles, a Kansas-based company that specializes in selling underground properties.
"I don't push the fear factor," he said. "But there are things that could happen in the world that could cause these properties to be among the most coveted in existence."
Mr. Peden, a former high school teacher who lives in a former Atlas silo outside Topeka, has sold 27 former missile sites in the last seven years. His company listed a missile silo on eBay last summer. A potential buyer met the minimum bid of $1 million, but the deal later fell through.
Although the company received a flurry of calls after the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, sales have not increased, Mr. Peden said.
"The economy is flat," he said. "More and more, these are becoming properties for the wealthy."
Early buyers found sites for as little as $40,000. More recently, a Colorado site sold for $487,000. Values are likely to continue climbing because of property improvements, scarcity and global uncertainties, Mr. Peden said.
"There's only a handful of these in existence," he said. "They are historic. We think they are the American counterparts of the European castle."

HEADLINE: Kmart Reports Loss As Sales Stay Slow 

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: TROY, Mich., Sept. 16 

 BODY:
The Kmart Corporation said today that its quarterly loss was unchanged, at $377 million, as it closed stores. The company lost another $144 million last month as sales tumbled. 
 On a per-share basis, the loss narrowed to 75 cents from 77 cents, Kmart said. Sales in the period, which ended July 31 and was the second quarter of Kmart's fiscal year, fell 16 percent, to $7.52 billion from $8.92 billion. 
 Kmart's sales have fallen as consumers have slowed their spending in the faltering economic recovery and as rivals like Wal-Mart Stores and Target have tried to siphon off Kmart's customers. The company, based in Troy, has closed 283 unprofitable stores and laid off about 22,000 workers to pare costs. 
"We've gotten past the stage in the first part of bankruptcy where there were so many nonrecurring and reorganization-related items," said Richard D. Hastings, an analyst at Cyber Business Credit. In the first quarter, Kmart had a loss of $1.45 billion, or $2.88 a share. 
Sales at stores open at least a year fell 11 percent in the most recent quarter and dropped 12 percent in August. Such same-store sales are a crucial retail indicator because they exclude results from new and closed locations. 

CORRECTION-DATE: September 18, 2002

 CORRECTION:
An article by Bloomberg News in Business Day yesterday about Kmart's quarterly results misstated the company's loss for August. It was $126 million, not $144 million.

HEADLINE: Worst-Hit Firm Faults Fairness Of Sept. 11 Aid 

BYLINE:  By DAVID W. CHEN 

 BODY:
Officials with Cantor Fitzgerald, which lost more people than any other company in the World Trade Center attack, have concluded that the federal fund meant to compensate survivors of victims is unfair, violates several laws and threatens to shortchange the families of its 658 slain employees by hundreds of millions of dollars.
 At the heart of the firm's objections, contained in a formal report that Cantor will submit to the federal government this week, is its claim that the administrator of the fund has set a cap on awards in violation of the legislation that created the fund. The officials also argue that the decision by the fund's special master to make awards based on after-tax projections of lost income is illegal under New York State law and will deprive families of a third or more of the total payment to which they are entitled. 
 While a chorus of discontent has swelled recently about the fairness of the fund, Cantor's report represents the most substantive and serious challenge yet to the basic rules underlying the fund. And given the firm's financial clout and sympathetic public stature, its attack on the fund has the potential, some lawyers and family members say, of plunging the entire program into disarray. 
Yesterday, the special master in charge of the Sept. 11 Victim Compensation Fund, Kenneth R. Feinberg, said he had not seen the report, and could not comment on it. While he continued to express confidence that his rules would pass legal muster, he also said that he eagerly awaited Cantor Fitzgerald's conclusions.
"I look forward with great interest to receiving it," he said. "I will review it with great care, because anything that will help me in the difficult task of computing awards in individual cases, I welcome."
Cantor's findings are based on a six-month examination conducted with the help of the law firm of Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom in New York and the economic consulting firm of Chicago Partners in Chicago. The report, a copy of which was given to The New York Times, was mailed to Cantor families over the weekend and was scheduled to be posted on its Web site this morning.
Cantor's general counsel, Stephen M. Merkel, charged last week that Mr. Feinberg had assumed "the role of a sovereign power" with too much discretion and too little oversight of the fund, which was established by Congress after the terror attacks. As a result, Cantor is now suggesting that its families -- as well as the families of all other Sept. 11 victims -- refrain from applying for money from the fund unless wholesale reforms are made or, if necessary, legal challenges are mounted.
"The regulations are wrong on so many levels, because they are contrary to the statute," said Mr. Merkel, who is also Cantor's executive managing director. Then, referring to Mr. Feinberg, he added: "I think his heart is in the right place. But his role is ministerial, not prime ministerial. He is supposed to carry out acts mandated by Congress. He has not been given some role of sovereign power."
Under Mr. Feinberg's projections, the family of a 30-year-old broker at the firm who was earning roughly $110,000 on average over the last three years would be entitled to an award of roughly $3 million. Under the firm's formula, which uses gross income and a more bullish estimation of future earnings, the family should receive an award closer to $5 million. The award itself would not be taxed in either case.
Cantor Fitzgerald's assessment comes at a critical moment for the multibillion-dollar fund. Having failed so far to attract large numbers of families, the fund is set to make an important series of awards that many families and their lawyers believe will at long last give a clear sense of how generous the payments are likely to be.
But yesterday, Mr. Feinberg indicated he was unlikely to overhaul the rules governing the fund. He repeated earlier public pronouncements that "there will be no change in the final rules and regulations," partly because 52 families have already been offered awards averaging $1.57 million each.
However, one law professor who is not connected to Cantor but who has reviewed the company's submission, says that it contains strong arguments that could have significant implications.
"The legal arguments made in the submission about legislative intent and state law call into question the judgment -- as well as the biases -- of the special master's discretionary interpretations on the important issues of calculation of salaries and fair compensation, and are supported by substantial case law and precedent," said Pamela S. Falk, a professor at the City University of New York who has written extensively about the fund.
The core of the firm's dissatisfaction with the fund and its rules concerns what it believes is, in effect, an artificial lid on payments to high-income employees. Cantor officials assert that the fund is illegally forcing families to prove "extraordinary circumstances" for awards higher than the fund's generic calculations of the potential earnings of those lost on Sept. 11. In that, they say, the fund and its administrator are denying the families the full recovery for their losses explicitly promised by Congressional leaders when the fund was established.
In other words, what Mr. Feinberg should not be doing, the report says, is making "value judgments about different groups of income earners."
At 59 pages for the legal portion, and 17 pages for the economic one, the report contains many legal and economic arguments, as well as a revealing look at the company's complex compensation packages.
Cantor officials say there are huge discrepancies -- sometimes by differences of 100 percent or more -- between Mr. Feinberg's census-based projected increases in individual salaries and Cantor's actual data. Indeed, more than 250 Cantor victims had incomes above the 98th percentile, the highest level to be calculated on Mr. Feinberg's generic chart.
Those income figures do not include stock options, said Karen L. Valihura, a litigation partner with the office of Skadden Arps in Wilmington, Del.
The report argues that the Cantor Fitzgerald Relief Fund, a charity that was started soon after the attacks, should count as a charitable deduction and not as a mandatory deduction -- or "collateral offset," in the fund's formal language. It also argues that the presumed awards of $250,000 for the pain and suffering of each decedent's family are "woefully inadequate" and "violate the statute" because they do not take individual circumstances into account.
The average age of Cantor's 658 victims was 38, and the report contends that the fund is biased against single victims. As a result, the family of a victim who was married in early September 2001 would receive an award 56 percent higher than the family of a victim who was to be married the next week, said Kevin Dages, a principal with Chicago Partners.
By late yesterday, few Cantor families said that they had received the report, which has been so highly anticipated by all companies affected by Sept. 11 that it has become known as the Book. In about two weeks, Cantor's families will also receive another individualized report detailing the performances and prospects of each employee before he or she died in the attack.
But when told of the macroeconomic findings in this report, they expressed a mix of surprise and satisfaction -- particularly the section that states that anyone who feels that regulations were "arbitrary, capricious, an abuse of discretion, or otherwise not in accordance with law" can legally challenge the regulations.
"As the victims' families, we have no choice but to wait until someone steps forward and challenge what we're stuck with," said David Chirls, whose wife, Catherine, was a banker at eSpeed, a division of Cantor. "So this is wonderful to hear that Cantor has done this."
The report amplifies growing criticism of the fund that has emerged recently. There is legislation pending that seeks to amend the original statute. And Charles Wolf, whose wife, Katherine, worked at Marsh & McLennan, started a Web site last week, www.fixthefund.org, which suggests that Congress eliminate the fund's mandatory deductions of life insurance, pensions and other benefits and increase noneconomic damages to $1 million.
Of the 52 families who have already been offered awards averaging $1.57 million apiece, 25 have accepted, 5 have asked for hearings to appeal the decisions and the others have not yet responded. And With additional awards expected soon, Mr. Feinberg expects a heavier flow of applications, especially since the first anniversary has passed. 
But Cantor officials hope that their report -- which was compiled by dozens of people, all working free -- provides a forum for discussion for all families, because the total value of undercompensation for the roughly 3,000 people will be much more than $1 billion.
More than anything else, Mr. Merkel wants to avoid receiving more e-mail like the one he received recently from a family member of a victim who received an award offer, even though the family member thought the methodology was flawed.
It was heartbreaking to read, he said, because it conveyed a sense of resignation, intimidation and frustration.
"It's very hard for people to accept that the government or the special master could make these kinds of giant mistakes, but they have," Mr. Merkel said. "But part of America's greatness is that people are able to challenge the government, and the government is stronger for it."

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS; 
TOOL MAKER'S PROFITS TO FALL SHORT OF EXPECTATIONS

BYLINE:  Reuters 

 BODY:
 Illinois Tool Works Inc. said yesterday that its third-quarter profit would fall short of the average Wall Street forecast because of slower-than-expected sales, setting off a 4 percent decline in its share price. 
The company, a diversified manufacturer, stood by its full-year forecast, however, saying it expects economic trends to improve for the remainder of the year. Illinois Tool Works' shares fell $2.25, to $61.05 a share, on the New York Stock Exchange. Last month the company, which is based in Glenview, Ill., forecast a profit of 75 cents to 85 cents per share.

HEADLINE: Up, Down, In and Out in Beverly Hills: Rats 

BYLINE:  By CHARLIE LeDUFF 

DATELINE: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., Sept. 12 

 BODY:
"Beverly Hills is a nice place to be a rat," Ray Honda explained, admiring the cool, verdant landscape of the moneyed class, with its fruit trees, bird feeders, swimming pools and dog-food bowls. "It's a very good address."
 Mr. Honda, a Los Angeles County health inspector whose speech and demeanor bring Peter Lorre to mind, was quick to append, "the four-legged kind," adding: "More rats than people, probably. And when they get really bad you can smell them." 
 Across Beverly Hills and the other lush corridors of Los Angeles, rats -- yellow-bellied, pink-tailed, flea-bitten rats -- are wriggling through the woodwork and rooftops. They have come down from the trees and in from the fields, forced into neighborhoods by a strangling drought that has gripped the region. They are eating from dog bowls and drinking from swimming pools and acting in surly ways not normal to the genus. 
How did rodents end up in the lap of luxury? After four consecutive mild winters, their population has multiplied, though no study has been undertaken to determine exactly how many rats there are in Los Angeles County. The rule of thumb is one rat for every human, Mr. Honda said. Add in the severe drought and you have rats commuting to the neighborhoods with low-hanging fruit, exotic gardens and patios, with their outdoor parties and exquisite crumbs.
Take the humiliating case of the well-to-do doctor who recently built himself a dream house off Sunset Boulevard.
The doctor was giving a party a few weeks ago when three rats helped themselves to the crumbs of his outdoor buffet table. One scurried into the postmodern palace through an open door.
If that were not enough, the doctor found five rats swimming in his marble pool on a recent Saturday afternoon.
Mr. Honda, the ratologist, was called in for consultation.
"The thing to do is keep the rats out of the house," he told the housekeeper. "And keep the bamboo shoots trimmed. They like bamboo shoots."
The doctor was called at his office for a telephone conference.
"In my pool," the doctor sighed in the tone of a man who has found a scratch on his new car. "I just built the place. I hear this is happening all over Beverly Hills. It's the drought, they say."
Before he put the phone back on the receiver, the doctor asked a favor. "Can you keep my name out of the newspaper?"
The four-legged scourge is commonly known as the roof rat. Unlike its city cousin the Norway rat, which prefers the denuded and grimy confines of the East Coast, the roof rat, or Rattus rattus, prefers the warm climes of the West. An excellent climber, it lives in trees, shrubs and attics. It is less aggressive and well suited to the California lifestyle, preferring a vegetarian diet.
The roof rat, the carrier of the Black Plague, is a roamer and will take it upon itself to walk to more hospitable habitat -- lush suburban-style enclaves like Beverly Hills, Joining the roof rat in ZIP code 90210 are the wood or field rats, which have been pushed out of the hills by brush fires and the continuing building boom.
For now, the county is not pursuing wholesale rat eradication. Its budget for rodent control efforts -- mainly putting out poison -- is the same as last year's. But that may change as the infestation persists.
Over the last two months a half-dozen restaurants have temporarily closed along the Santa Monica Promenade because of rats. Then there are the phone calls from the panic-stricken socialites in Beverly Hills and Pacific Palisades.
"We'll get hysterical calls about rats crawling on the roofs of houses in Beverly Hills," said Oscar Gonzalez, an exterminator to the stars, who said business is up 30 percent this year. "But that's the price you pay for messing with Mother Nature," Mr. Gonzalez said. "The closer you live to the wild, the closer the wild is to you."
It is not just Beverly Hills. Rats have become a problem across the desiccated West. The lush rose gardens of Pasadena are infested. In Hawaii, the country mice of the sugar cane fields have moved to the city in search of a better way of life. North of Flagstaff, Ariz., health officials have captured plague-toting rodents.
As New Yorkers know so well, rats are indomitable survivors. They can wiggle through a hole the size of a quarter. They can jump two feet high and eight feet long. Able to swim a half-mile and tread water for three days, they can survive being flushed down a toilet and have been found alive in a block of ice. Rats can chew through metal, wood and concrete, which is necessary to their survival because their incisors grow five inches a year, and left unchecked, their teeth would grow through the roofs of their mouths. They breed voraciously and are said to have 15,000 descendants before they die in a year.
Up the coast in Ventura, the public beaches are overrun with rodents.
"The problem is people keep feeding them," said Mike Montoya, the city parks manager. "We've got people taking 30-pound bags of dog food and buckets of water and leaving it out for the squirrels and birds and, yes, the rats. If we take the food away, the rats might move towards town."
But Ventura officials may have contributed to the problem. Several years ago, dogcatchers rounded up the feral cats that marauded Ventura's public beaches. Without the predators, rats have flourished.
In a related case, a brouhaha is bubbling on the beaches of San Pedro in southern Los Angeles, which does not have a rat problem. Animal control officials are considering trapping and removing the 100 or so feral cats that make their dens under the piers. The cats, some residents complain, have created a giant stinking litter box. 
Cat lovers vow a fight. "You take them away and we're going to get rats," said Joann Adler, a local, who collects the cats, has them neutered and then returns them to the beaches. "Besides, what are they going to do with the cats after they capture them? Kill them. That's what."
A solution to the cat and rat problem might be found in downtown Los Angeles, where rats once overran the flower market, gorging themselves on carnations. In an interesting piece of urban wildlife management, a pride of feral cats was introduced, and according to Mr. Honda, the market has never looked cleaner, rat-wise.
Perhaps, it was suggested to Mr. Honda, the neutered beach cats from San Pedro could be set loose in the alleys and peaks of Beverly Hills. The cats would hunt rats, never reproduce and die of old age.
"I wonder if the city of Beverly Hills would go for something like that." Mr. Honda said.
A call was made to the Beverly Hills City Hall. "Feral cats? Oh, no," said a city official, who asked to remain anonymous, because indiscretions often lead to unemployment.
"People here already complain about the coyotes and raccoons and skunks," the official said. "They'd never stand for feral cats."
If any proof of this was needed, an old man who lives in the hills of Alpine Drive happily accepted a bucket of rat poison from Mr. Honda. As an afterthought, he asked, "You have anything for rabbits?"

GRAPHIC: Photo: Nadie Cambronero, left, works for a doctor who lives in this Beverly Hills house. Apparently the doctor shares his dream home -- in particular the pool -- with rats. Ray Honda, right, a health inspector, offered advice. (Monica Almeida/The New York Times)(pg. A24)

HEADLINE: NYC; 
Brother, Can We Spare The Penny?

BYLINE:  By CLYDE HABERMAN 

 BODY:
THESE are odd times for Abraham Lincoln. One moment, he's on a roll, his best in years. The next, some want to give him a one-way ticket to Palookaville.
 Lincoln really hit his stride last week with the commemorations of the terrorist attacks on Sept. 11, 2001. In New York, tongued-tied government leaders did not even try for original thoughts about where the city and state stand one year later. They borrowed instead from the past, notably Lincoln's Gettysburg Address. 
 For a while, New York Democrats feared that they would be outclassed in the Lincoln-worship department and that the Republican governor and mayor might gain an advantage. So they considered a 9/11 remembrance of their own, a television spot showing that Democrats, too, could read the Gettysburg Address without their lips hurting. It did not take them long to realize that imitating Republicans imitating Lincoln was not a sign of an innovative spirit. They tossed that idea.
Still, for Lincoln and his legacy, it was a heady time. Then modern realities intruded.
Word came the other day that an internal committee of the United States Mint had raised the possibility of dropping Lincoln from the penny. American coins have become fuddy-duddy, this panel said.
Maybe it is time for a redesign.
The penny would not be alone in undergoing change. Another possibility mentioned by the committee was minting a new dime without the image of Franklin D. Roosevelt, the only president named after a Manhattan highway. But no one would be affected as much as Lincoln. He has graced an American coin longer than any other historic figure, four score and 13 years, or since 1909, for those too weary to do the math.
(He is also the only president on a coin who faces right, an anomaly that officials at the United States Mint say reflects the designer's preference and has no deeper significance.)
Nothing has been decided, the mint says. And nowhere on its radar, it seems, is the possibility of going a giant step further. This would involve designing not a new appearance for the one-cent coin but rather a funeral.
Isn't it finally time, some believe, to put the penny out of its misery? How long, they ask, will the government continue to crank out, by the billions, a coin that is doomed to be treated as a nuisance and ultimately exiled to sock drawers and old jelly jars?
Granted, this is not a new debate.
Pro-penny forces like Americans for Common Cents cite tradition and their belief that rounding prices to the nearest nickel, as urged by those who find the penny dreadful, would inevitably lead to higher prices. Those who want to dump the penny see no reason to assume that rounding prices would be inflationary, and they see even less sense in churning out a coin that is little used.
In 2000, the mint produced a record 28 billion coins. Of those, 14.3 billion were pennies. That pattern is holding, though with the economy's decline, far fewer coins are being minted now.
"Half of all the work of the United States Mint is for a denomination that doesn't circulate," said Beth Deisher, editor of Coin World, a magazine for collectors published in Sidney, Ohio, near Dayton.
FROM a New York perspective, the penny seems especially ill suited to local ways. You can't buy anything with a single penny. Bus drivers won't take the coin. Subway token clerks will, in theory. But try paying the fare with 150 pennies at rush hour. At the supermarket, a sure way to rile people is to fumble for a penny while standing at the head of the checkout line. This impatient city is, if anything, the fidgeting capital of the world.
Even some who you might think thrive on pennies say they could get along without them. Take Teddy Gross. A dozen years ago, he founded Common Cents New York, which encourages schoolchildren to scour their apartments for pennies and then give the money to good causes of their choosing. Last year, Mr. Gross said, students harvested more than 200 tons of coins, worth $720,000 in all.
Nonetheless, "I don't feel the least bit committed to the penny as a coin," he said. If there were no penny, he would simply turn to some other humble object that tends to be wasted. "It's a metaphor really, symbolic of the resources that are available if you look for them," Mr. Gross said.
Don't expect any upheaval soon. Lincoln's coin may be widely regarded as an irritant but hardly an intolerable one. Face it: how often have you had a thought for your pennies?
Sorry. Couldn't resist that one.

HEADLINE: Amid Talk of War Spending, Bush Urges Fiscal Restraint 

BYLINE:  By ELISABETH BUMILLER 

DATELINE: DAVENPORT, Iowa, Sept. 16 

 BODY:
President Bush returned today to collecting big checks for Republican candidates and warning Congress to hold the line on government spending, even as his chief economic policy adviser, Lawrence B. Lindsey, said the cost of a war with Iraq could be as high as $100 billion to $200 billion.
 Mr. Lindsey's pronouncement, published in today's Wall Street Journal, contrasted with the message of fiscal restraint that Mr. Bush took to the heartland in a campaign stop for Representative Jim Nussle, the chairman of the House Budget Committee, who is in a close race for re-election. 
 In an appearance with Mr. Nussle in a muggy Starlite Ballroom of the Mississippi Valley Fairgrounds, Mr. Bush praised the Republican-controlled House for passing a budget and then criticized the Democratic-controlled Senate for failing to do so.
"It's important to have a budget in Washington, because without a budget, there is a tendency to overspend," Mr. Bush said. "Without a budget, every idea sounds like a brilliant idea. Without some kind of constraint on the appropriations process in Washington, as they might say in this part of the world, somebody is liable to go hog wild."
In an interview with The Journal, Mr. Lindsey dismissed the economic consequences of spending what he estimated might be 1 percent to 2 percent of the national gross domestic product on a war, and said that it would not seriously affect interest rates or add a great deal to the $3.6 trillion federal debt. As a one-time war cost over one year, the estimated expenditure, Mr. Lindsey said, was "nothing."
Speaking today in Portland, Me., Treasury Secretary Paul H. O'Neill echoed Mr. Lindsey, saying the United States could well pay for any war with Iraq, although he did not give a cost. 
"Whatever it is that's finally decided to be done," Mr. O'Neill said, "we will succeed and we can afford it." 
Democrats said the White House was engaged in budget hypocrisy.
"Clearly you can't attack Congress for overspending at the same time that you're asking for $200 million for military aid," said David Sirota, a Democratic spokesman for the House Appropriations Committee. "They need to stop talking out of both sides of their mouths. It's a joke to call them fiscally responsible."
The Bush administration's apparent willingness to pay for an expensive war with Iraq was in striking contrast to its tone of last month, when Mr. Bush signaled that he could crack down on spending by announcing at an economic forum in Waco, Tex., that he would not release $5.1 billion in emergency funds requested by Congress to fight terrorism. Mr. Bush said then that he wanted to move toward a balanced budget as soon as possible.
Mr. Lindsey's projections on the financial consequences of a war are at odds with those of other government officials and economists, who have said an attack on Iraq could profoundly affect the economy because the country would have to pay most of the cost and bear the brunt of any oil price shock. Twelve years ago, Iraq's invasion of Kuwait and the subsequent Persian Gulf war cost the United States and its allies $60 billion and helped set off a recession caused in part by oil prices.
Mr. Bush did not address Mr. Lindsey's projections in his remarks here today, and White House officials refused to elaborate on them. Scott McClellan, the deputy White House press secretary, told reporters that since Mr. Bush had not yet decided on a course of action on Iraq, discussions about the cost of that course were premature.
Mr. Bush's four-hour trip to Iowa, his eighth as president, included a tour of Sears Manufacturing in Davenport, a maker of seats for tractors and trucks. Afterward, Mr. Bush warned several hundred people crowded near the welding department that without a budget the Democratic Senate was likely to be fiscally irresponsible.
"And when they overspend, they not only overspend for this year, this coming year, they'll overspend for every year afterwards, too," Mr. Bush said. 
Mr. Bush then left for the fairgrounds to raise $225,000 for Mr. Nussle, a Republican who is running against Ann Hutchinson, the mayor of Bettendorf. Along the way Mr. Bush passed a group of about 100 protesters who waved signs saying "Iraqi Lives Are Precious, Too" and "Drop Bush Not Bombs."

GRAPHIC: Photo: On a tour of Sears Manufacturing in Davenport, Iowa, President Bush took a seat yesterday in a new tractor chair. Mr. Bush campaigned in Davenport for Representative Jim Nussle, who is in a close race for re-election. (Associated Press)
