HEADLINE: German Rival, in Hard Race, Raises Specter of Immigrants 

BYLINE:  By STEVEN ERLANGER 

DATELINE: BERLIN, Sept. 16 

 BODY:
Germany's conservative opposition, trying to regain its lead in the opinion polls before national elections on Sunday, opened a new front today, contending that the government of Gerhard Schroder was undermining national security and the economy by letting in too many immigrants.
 Mr. Schroder has revived his own supporters and earned a small lead in the polls by running hard to the left. His rival, Edmund Stoiber, who has run a bland, centrist campaign, is making a last-minute lurch to the right, trying to win back his own voters in a volatile climate. 
 In a television interview this morning, Mr. Stoiber said he would throw out a government reform passed earlier this year intended to open Germany to qualified immigrants with needed skills.
"When there are more than four million jobless," Mr. Stoiber said, "then it is irresponsible to open up the job market to everyone."
Mr. Stoiber's spokesman on police and immigration matters, Gunther Beckstein, said today that the government was hurting domestic security and compromising Germany's economic future with its immigration policy.
Mr. Beckstein cited a Greens politician who called the new law a step toward making Germany "a modern, multicultural land of immigration."
Mr. Beckstein said, "That is exactly what we don't want."
Instead, Germany must integrate the 7.3 million foreigners who live here and find work for the more than four million Germans who do not have jobs, Mr. Beckstein said. He called for the deportation of any foreigner sentenced to prison for more than two years and for limits on the residence permits of immigrants on welfare.
Mr. Schroder called the new conservative strategy a sign of "helplessness and aggressiveness," adding, "It is a desperate attempt to find a topic with which one can arouse emotions, but I think the public will see through it."
Mr. Schroder has revived his chances to win re-election through his handling of Germany's disastrous floods and his sharp message of opposition to a new, American-led war in Iraq.
His campaign to preserve the peace -- in open and pungent opposition to the Bush administration -- has won him support, while making Mr. Stoiber seem wishy-washy, unwilling to support the Americans but also unwilling to rule out a war in Iraq.
While many had thought that Mr. Stoiber would run to the right, he had instead sounded moderate on social issues while hammering hard at the poor state of Germany's economy. But Mr. Schroder has argued that unemployment and low growth are a result of global factors beyond his control -- not his inability to challenge his union supporters and make the labor market more flexible.
In early August, polls indicated, Mr. Stoiber's conservatives were between five and seven percentage points ahead of Mr. Schroder's Social Democrats, who govern in coalition with the Greens. Now, with the vote on Sunday, Mr. Schroder has opened a small lead, and has the momentum.
He has sought to capitalize on his own popularity and that of his foreign minister, Joschka Fischer, a Green, by trying to run as a kind of personality ticket, highly unusual in a parliamentary democracy. Mr. Fischer, an elfin former radical, is Germany's most popular politician, with an approval rating of more than 80 percent in the polls, and both men are more popular than their own parties.
So on Sunday evening, Mr. Schroder held an unusual joint rally in downtown Berlin with Mr. Fischer, under a giant red and green poster that read, in English: "Go on!" -- to another term with what is called his red-green coaliton.
"I want this foreign secretary and no one else," Mr. Schroder said, pointing to Mr. Fischer. The foreign secretary then returned the favor, saying: "I do not want to become chancellor. I want Gerhard Schroder to be the next chancellor."
But as the immigration question returned to the political agenda, Deutsche Bank said Germany's population could fall from 82 million to 65 million in 50 years -- with the work force shrinking by 27 percent, to 30 million by 2040 -- unless politicians allow more immigration and provide incentives to women to combine a career with child-rearing. About 500,000 immigrants a year would be needed to prevent a decline in the working-age population, the bank said.

HEADLINE: McCall on the Budget 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
You suggest (editorial, Sept. 12) that the New York State budget, proposed by the governor and passed by the Legislature, is "approved" by the comptroller. In fact, the comptroller simply must make a determination -- only if the budget is late and only to release legislators' paychecks -- that the Legislature has technically passed a budget. 
 By law, this narrow definition does not involve approval or certification or even determining whether it is a good or bad budget. 
 An on-time budget requires absolutely no action by the comptroller.
I have proposed reforms to the broken budget process to make it more responsive to taxpayers' needs. I've strongly and consistently criticized the closed budget process and the final product, which this year includes more than $4 billion in fiscal gimmicks. 
We have not had an on-time budget for 18 years. During the last eight years of fiscal surpluses and economic prosperity, Gov. George E. Pataki has failed to put our fiscal house in order. We've seen late budgets, bad budgets, increased debt and critical problems left unresolved. 
We need real reform, hard work, commitment and the ability to bring people together. That's what I have done. That's what I will do.

H. CARL MCCALL
New York, Sept. 17, 2002

The writer is state comptroller and the Democratic candidate for governor.

HEADLINE: Not All Sunshine for Teensy Set's Troubadour 

BYLINE:  By ROBIN POGREBIN

 BODY:
You almost don't want to meet Raffi in person. You want to preserve the vision of the man you know only as a voice, lulling squirmy children in the back seat of the car with original folk songs like "One Light, One Sun," or standards with a twist like "This Little Light of Mine."
 You don't want to realize that the Canadian singer, 53, in real life is a considerably darker, far more complex person -- as most adults are. That he has no children of his own who can laugh along with his rendition of "Apples and Bananas" or fall asleep to his lullabies. That he is divorced from his high school sweetheart -- whose mother brought him in to sing at her nursery school, which started his career. That when he tried to make a grown-up record it did not sell very well. Even that he has been proselytizing about saving the environment. 
 But because Raffi had not made a record in seven years, one must deal with such grown-up questions as the man behind the voice. Now that he has returned to familiar ground with a new children's album, "Let's Play!" and is on tour with a stop at Town Hall in New York on Saturday, Raffi talked about this moment in his career. 
"I am blossoming," he said in an interview at a Manhattan hotel. "I feel like I'm in a really good creative, potent period of my life in my writing, in my conceptual ideas." 
In the 25 years that he has been writing and recording, Raffi has produced 13 records and three concert videos and is widely credited with setting a new standard for children's music. His albums in North America range from gold to triple platinum and have sold more than 12 million copies. "Raffi is the grand master," said Jim Powers, owner of the Chicago-based independent rock label Minty Fresh, which recently spun off Mini Fresh, a label for children. "His records have held up incredibly well over time."
While some musicians have dismissed Raffi's music as condescending, others say its simplicity and repetition are appropriate for his audience: children under 5. 
"It's a warmth he has, a sense of fun," said Moira McCormick, who has covered children's audio for Billboard and other publications for the last decade. "There is something extremely endearing about his vocal style, his stage presence."
With big eyes like marbles, a small smile and a banana pin on his lapel in honor of his song "Bananaphone," Raffi talks of the importance of play and saving the environment with the earnestness of someone untouched by the world's complexity or cynicism. He calls the seven people who work with him "team troubadour" and their cause "child-honoring." 
He defined this cause as "both a way of being in the world and a way of looking at the world." He added: "We're not talking about a child-centered society. We're talking about honoring our young, which starts with seeing who they are."
His new album, distributed by Rounder Records, includes classics like "Yellow Submarine, "What a Wonderful World" and "The Eensy Weensy Spider" as well as new songs by Raffi like "Swing" and "Roots and Shoots Everywhere." 
Where has he been for the last seven years? "You live, you grow, you develop, you mature," he said. 
His parents died in 1995, within 12 hours of each other on the same day, his mother of abdominal cancer, his father apparently of grief. "It was an astonishing exit for two remarkable lives," he said. "I knew one chapter of my life had come to a close." He wrote his autobiography (printed on chlorine-free paper), "The Life of a Children's Troubadour" (Homeland Press: 1999) and went on a book tour. And he began to get involved in children's environmental health issues, attending scientific conferences, reading literature on the subject, studying infants' brain development. "I'm fascinated by children and how they grow," he said.
In his autobiography, Raffi refers to his own "melancholy" childhood, growing up in fear of his demanding parents. "There was so much I was not doing right or hearing right," he writes. "Always something that made me wrong in my parents' view."
This experience played out as depression in adulthood. In his memoir, Raffi discusses mood swings that made him wonder if he was manic-depressive. "Like my father, I had the habit of seeing what was wrong or missing in things at first glance," he writes. He describes himself as insecure yet controlling and intolerant of other people -- tendencies that dissipated with spiritual counseling.
"I was so absorbed with my role in the limelight and so accustomed to being the center of attention that it was often hard to find balance offstage, at work or at home," he writes. "It was hard for me to be in a conversation that didn't revolve around me or my work."
On his new album, Raffi said he wanted to include songs that would influence policymakers, thus "It Takes a Village," which the CD's liner notes say was "inspired by Dr. Fraser Mustard" -- an expert in early childhood development -- and is based on an old African proverb.
Raffi said the proceeds from the 2001 CD "Country Goes Raffi" (Rounder), a tribute album with Raffi favorites sung by country greats, went to the Partnership for Children's Environmental Health. Speaking of the financial rewards of his career, he said: "It's given me more than what I need. Enough that it's wonderful and not too much."
To address the situation in the Middle East, Raffi recently wrote "Salaam Shalom," available at turnthisworldaround.org. He said the song took him back to his roots. He was born Raffi Cavoukian in Cairo. His Armenian parents escaped the massacre of Armenians in Ottoman Turkey in 1915. After living in Jerusalem and Syria, they emigrated to Toronto in 1958, where Raffi sang in his church choir, got his first guitar and became obsessed with Bob Dylan. "Dylan rocked my world when I was young," he said.
He was inspired by the music of Woody Guthrie's "Songs to Grow On," and of the group the Babysitters. And he realized there wasn't much for preschoolers in the bins at record stores. The mother of Deborah Joan Pike, his wife to be, invited him to sing at her nursery school. As Raffi recounted the story, "A children's entertainment angel said: 'Here is this folk singer. Maybe he needs to direct his music to another audience.' " The singer added, "I feel it's been a calling." His first album, released in 1976, was "Singable Songs for the Very Young." 
Raffi described his joy at seeing children on the ferry from Vancouver to his home on Mayne Island, British Columbia. "Just seeing their dazzling light: 1-, 2-, 3-, 4-year-olds,' " he said. "It's marvelous." Why didn't he ever have any children of his own? "Neither Deb nor I had any interest," he said. "Having kids isn't a prerequisite. It's just one of those things."
His one attempt at a record for grown-ups, "Evergreen, Everblue" (Rounder), released in 1990, was a folk album aimed at educating people about ecology. "That sort of thing doesn't necessarily sell boatloads," Ms. McCormick of Billboard said.
But Raffi said he returned to children's music, not out of economic necessity, but because it still enthralls him. "I'm told there are few who can do this well," he said. "If that's the case, I'm lucky this work found me and that I've grown in it."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Raffi, on screen, at a Special Session on Children concert at the United Nations in May. (Marilynn K. Yee/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Barrick to Cut Gold Hedging and Build 4 More Mines 

BYLINE:  By BERNARD SIMON 

DATELINE: TORONTO, Sept. 17 

 BODY:
Barrick Gold, once the gold industry's leading proponent of hedging as a protection against falling prices for metal, said today that it would reduce its forward sales position -- the amount of gold still in the ground that it has already sold for future delivery -- by one-third.
 Right now, Barrick, which is based in Toronto, has outstanding contracts to deliver 17.9 million ounces, or 22 percent of its current reserves. The company said today that it would cut that figure to 12 million ounces, or 15 percent of reserves, by the end of 2003. The use of other hedging devices, like options and variable-price sales contracts, will also be cut, the company said. 
 The company also outlined plans to invest $2 billion over the next five years to build four mines to tap ore deposits in Peru, Argentina and Australia, stepping up its gold output 1.2 million ounces a year, to reach 6.9 million ounces in 2006.
The world's biggest gold producer, Newmont Mining of Denver, expects to sell 7.5 million ounces this year.
Earlier this year, Barrick said that it planned to sell half its 2002 gold output on the spot market, the first time in 14 years that it has not hedged its entire production.
Victor Flores, an analyst at HSBC Securities in New York, said: "Clearly, the market has been more favorable to the unhedged producers. That has not been lost on Barrick." 
Randall Oliphant, Barrick's president, said in a telephone interview, "We see no compelling reason to be adding to our hedge position." He cited low interest rates, which mean lower premiums on forward sales, as well as Barrick's strong financial position and an improved outlook for the price of gold. Gold closed today at $318.20 an ounce, up from last year's average of $271, the lowest since 1978.
Barrick will give priority to the Alto Chicama deposit in Peru, discovered earlier this year. Production is scheduled to start in 2005, with annual output of 500,000 ounces at a cost of $130 an ounce. If the gold price averages $325 an ounce, the expansion plan will double Barrick's profits by 2006, the company predicted. "We're laying out numbers that we can be held accountable for," Mr. Oliphant said.

HEADLINE: COMMERCIAL REAL ESTATE; 
IndustrialComplex Available for $1

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL BRICK 

DATELINE: ELKHART, Ind. 

 BODY:
It is no secret that the jobs are leaving this city. Every assembly line worker, machinist and scientist could see it coming four years ago, when the pharmaceutical company Bayer, which once employed 3,000 people here, sold an undeveloped 400 acres near the airport that it had held in reserve for decades as a new headquarters site.
 "The community has adjusted and is still adjusting to that," said David L. Miller, the mayor of Elkhart. 
 It is what Bayer might leave behind that gnaws at Elkhart, a small industrial community near South Bend that bills itself as the city with a heart and is best known for building Coachmen, Monaco Coach and Forest River motor homes.
As the company moves production to Germany and Lerma, Mexico, it has no further use for its million-square-foot complex of assembly lines, offices, laboratories and warehouses built in 1938, with additions constructed as late as the 1970's. The complex is designed around production lines for water-soluble dyspepsia salves and vitamin tablets dosed with sugar and carved with the inexact bas-relief of Flintstones characters to enhance their appeal to children. Selling it is not feasible, the company has decided. 
"Not everybody and their brother needs a million square feet," said Joe W. Martin, a senior vice president of Bayer Diagnostics responsible for a business unit that makes diabetes tests and plans to remain here. There are 750 employees on the campus now.
So, Bayer has joined forces with several chambers of commerce and economic development groups to turn the situation into a public relations campaign with a simple message. To a buyer that will bring jobs to town, as long as they are not pharmaceutical industry jobs, the company will sell the whole complex for one dollar.
"Like any piece of real estate, it was built for a specific purpose, and it will probably need to go through a metamorphosis, and that's going to require an investment," said James C. Skillen, a vice president of Cressy & Everett, a local brokerage affiliated with the national real estate services firm Grubb & Ellis. Mr. Skillen is the broker of record for Bayer.
"Usually in a real estate transaction, the highest bidder comes forward and everybody goes away happy," he said. "This is not about money. This is about finding a company that is willing to use it." 
Inside the complex, there are 43,000 square feet of laboratory space, much of which resembles a high school chemistry classroom circa 1978. Overhead vents like triple-armed ceiling-mounted vacuum cleaners hang above big black countertops. The occasional personal computer offers a counterpoint to the humdrum tools of basic science, cabinets full of glass beakers, and an egg timer here and there. 
These sealed spaces spill onto scuffed packing rooms with wide doorways leading to more of the same, the sprawl broken only by the odd metal cage or cramped machine shop. There is a full cafeteria with hot food service; executive quarters with a business, engineering and law library; marketing offices; and a wood-paneled boardroom.
A self-contained energy production complex, with redundant heating, ventilation and air-conditioning systems, is joined to this building. The vast open rooms of gears and wheels and tanks resemble the inside of a submarine, only with daylight streaming in. Engineers watch the global fuel markets and switch between burning natural gas and No. 6 fuel oil when prices change. Two locomotive engines are used to generate a little energy at peak-use hours to reduce the cost of energy from the utility company.
"Any way you run the numbers, it starts costing Bayer something to maintain the building," Mr. Skillen said. 
Demolishing the buildings, by Bayer's estimate, would cost $20 million. Because the complex has not changed hands in its 64 years of existence, no comprehensive environmental study has been performed to estimate cleanup costs, though the two-million-gallon fuel oil tanks and the roomful of locomotive engines suggest that those might be formidable. Bayer officials said they had not commissioned an environmental study.
The complex, on 27 acres of a 55-acre parcel, cost Bayer $372,000 in property taxes in 2001, according to the company; the tax bill for the larger parcel was $479,000, roughly 1 percent of the budget of Elkhart County, according to the county treasurer.
Mr. Skillen advised Bayer that selling it could take five years -- with maintenance costing as much as $7 million a year during that time -- and that it might bring as much as $12 million. Such a sale would lose any possibility of profit after the property had been on the market for about a year and a half, he said.
As the economy has slowed and as the value of residential properties rises, many corporations are having trouble disposing of commercial real estate assets that became liabilities when plans or market conditions shifted. In Hillsboro, Ore., for example, Komatsu Metals is quietly trying to sell an industrial complex at a price significantly below the $200 million that it cost to build. Honeywell is trying to sell obsolete properties across the country into a buyer's market.
The specter of a closed industrial complex looms particularly large here. Fifteen miles away in downtown South Bend, some factories operated by Studebaker have sat crumbling on 120 acres since the company shut down in 1963. Ten miles away, the City of Mishawaka paid to demolish 58 buildings, 1.7 million square feet of industrial space in all, covering 43 acres that Uniroyal abandoned on April 1, 1997.
Local officials are pressing Bayer to help them fill the vacancy. Mr. Miller, the mayor, traveled to Bayer's headquarters in Leverkusen, Germany, to ask the company to donate the property and pay the city tens of millions of dollars to have it converted for use by another company. Bayer declined, but told the mayor it would give the city the building without money; he declined that.
The amount necessary to convert and modernize the building is anybody's guess, and that is the primary obstacle to a sale. Brokers here say that there is a glut of industrial space built much more recently, in the 1970's, and that banks are offering better amortization terms for purchases of newer properties.
Mr. Martin, the manager of the Bayer unit remaining here, said that the company had set aside money for demolition. Bayer has set a one-year deadline on the offer to sell the property for a dollar, but no agreement has been reached on what will happen if the deadline expires.
Simply transferring ownership is no panacea, not at this price, said John K. Letherman, a county councilman and a partner in the commercial real estate firm FM Stone Commercial. He points to a multistory, 150,000-square-foot industrial building at the corner of Michigan Street and West Beardsley Avenue as an example of what can happen when industrial properties change hands at an extremely low capitalization. This downtown building, he said, like several others, has been converted to multitenant use, but the owners have not paid taxes for years, and the county has not condemned the building because it could not sell it at auction.
Ross C. Miller, the managing partner of FM Stone, noted that there was no market in Elkhart for the conversion of industrial properties to loft space, a residential trend that has worked in cities like New York and Chicago in the last decade.
The deteriorating buildings and the lack of demand for modern urban residential developments are intertwined, because they make this place unattractive to businesses seeking to relocate and even to natives of Elkhart, Mr. Letherman said.
"If I put my public official hat on, and I have one, I say Bayer ought to tear down that thing before they leave," he said. "I know the chamber of commerce is all excited about selling it for a dollar. I look down the road and I see something that's bought by somebody cheap and undercapitalized, and they'll run it into the ground and eventually stop paying taxes on it."
Mayor Miller said he was optimistic the company would find a buyer.
"I'm just grateful that they didn't padlock the building and walk away from it," he said, "because that's happened so often."

PERSON: LaWanda Page 

HEADLINE: LaWanda Page, 81, the Aunt On TV's 'Sanford and Son' 

BYLINE:  By MEL WATKINS 

 BODY:
LaWanda Page, the acid-tongued comedienne who, as the cantankerous Aunt Esther, traded barbs with Redd Foxx on the 1970's sitcom "Sanford and Son," died on Saturday in Los Angeles. She was 81.
 The cause was complications of diabetes, The Associated Press reported. 
 Ms. Page was a veteran of the black circuit of theaters and nightclubs. She began as a dancer, added a fire-swallowing bit (billed as the "Bronze Goddess of Fire") and moved gradually into skit and stand-up comedy on the so-called Midwestern "chitlin circuit." Most of those clubs, she later said, were dumps, the kind of places "where if you ain't home by 9 o'clock you can be declared legally dead." 
Her big break came when she was tapped for a supporting role in the second season of Norman Lear's "Sanford and Son," which starred Foxx, a friend from comedy club days, as Fred Sanford, an eccentric and irascible junk dealer in the Watts section of Los Angeles. As the ungainly, wisecracking, Bible-toting sister of Sanford's late wife, Elizabeth, she quickly became one of the show's most popular characters. 
Her character, Aunt Esther, took her share of zingers from Foxx and other cast members -- Sanford's friend Grady once quipped, "Nice having her around, she makes the junk look so pretty." But Aunt Esther usually responded with equally stinging rejoinders. "Watch it, sucker!" her favorite catch phrase, was followed by a spate of sharp-tongued invective. The exchanges between her and Sanford were among the weekly highlights. "Sanford and Son," ran from 1972 to 1977 on NBC and remained one of television's top rated shows, inspiring several spinoffs in which she also appeared.
Ms. Page was born in Cleveland on Oct. 19, 1920, and began her dancing career at age 15. After years on the club circuit with comedians like Foxx and Richard Pryor, Ms. Page moved to Los Angeles in the 1960's and joined the comedy group Skillet, Leroy & Co. She soon developed and honed her trademark feisty comic approach -- more shrill but still reminiscent of Moms Mabley's homespun wit. ("Honey, that old man couldn't keep no kinda job. That's the only man I know that ever went to the unemployment office and lost his place in line.") 
She is survived by a daughter, Clara Johnson, of Los Angeles.
Throughout the 1970's and 80's, Ms. Page played cameo roles in a few feature films and made guest appearances on talk shows and sitcoms. Offstage, she was an advocate for equal opportunities and better pay for black performers.

HEADLINE: Schools Adapt Old Lesson: Share and Share Alike 

BYLINE:  By MAREK FUCHS 

 BODY:
Building schools is the largest financial commitment most communities make.
 But in a sputtering economy, raising money from taxpayers for schools can be a challenge. That is one reason why more schools, particularly in New York City, are sharing buildings, either with other schools or with noneducational enterprises. 
 The popularity of charter schools and of smaller schools with specific focuses has also created a need for space and a resulting willingness to be flexible. For those schools, which can start up in a matter of months, lack of time and money make the building of a dedicated new building impossible. 
In the Bronx, 10 new specialized schools opened this school year -- seven of them within the walls of larger public high schools, like Christopher Columbus and Evander Childs. 
Three other new schools have space on City University of New York campuses -- Lehman, City and York Colleges, sharing common spaces like the library and gymnasium. 
When high schools are on college campuses, there can be synergies. In addition to being able to take Advanced Placement classes taught by high school teachers, students at the High School of American Studies at Lehman College have the option of taking take actual college courses.
In Jamaica, Queens, construction began in May 2001 on a $100 million building that will house both the Police Athletic League Community Center and another new specialized school, the High School for Law Enforcement and Public Safety, which is expected to attract students interested in a career in law enforcement.
In Craryville, N.Y., in Columbia County, the Taconic Hills Central School serves as something of a community center, with an auditorium that opens into an amphitheater for concerts, and gyms and a weight room and aquatic center that anyone can pay to use.
"Shared space is a no-brainer, financially and also educationally," said Jon Snyder, the dean of the Bank Street Graduate School of Education in Manhattan. "Since children stopped learning at the feet of their parents, educators have been trying to address the separation between school and the real world." Placing a school in an environment where different generations and professions come into contact offers an opportunity to bridge that gap, he said. 
"But," he added pointedly, "it can all fall apart in the practicalities. It's like two families buying one house together. Logistically, it's just a big challenge." 
Myra Luftman, principal of the High School of American Studies, at Lehman College, agreed. "It takes a lot of thought, compromise, flexibility and a constant redesigning of your own perceptions," she said. 
In a figurative sense, four families bought a house together at 600 East Sixth Street. Three schools (Public School 64, the Earth School and Tompkins Square Middle School) coexist in the building with the New York City Police Department's School Safety Division, which uses 20 classrooms as its headquarters. 
Many parents are comforted by the presence of uniformed police officers in the school. But some have reservations.
"It's a building full of kids," said Trishka Marek, the mother of an eighth grader, "and there are grown men there who spit and swear and carry guns." 
The police agency used to be the sole occupant of the third floor, but it began to share the floor during the last school year, when the Tompkins Square Middle School opened. The police also use a parking lot that some parents, including Mrs. Marek, feel is needed for playground space. 
The police agency is in the process of relocating some of its staff to 110 Livingston Street in Brooklyn, the school system's former main office, but as the school year approached, it found itself in a battle over how quickly it was relinquishing rooms. The disagreement was not settled until shortly before school opened. 
"There is always going to be a natural concern when you use classroom space for anything other than instruction, whether it's the police or parent groups," said Assistant Chief Demosthenes Long, the commanding officer at the site.
Even when a college and a high school are sharing space, there can be a clash of cultures. 
"It's difficult for a college to conceive of a high school to be on campus," said Mrs. Luftman of the High School of American Studies at Lehman College. "We do have to prove ourselves." 
There is sometimes a corporate component to these partnerships, as in the case at the Henry Ford Academy in Dearborn, Mich., a charter school that is a joint effort of the Wayne County Regional Education Service Agency, the Ford Motor Company and the Henry Ford Museum and Greenfield Village, on whose grounds the school sits. Many classes are taught in museum rooms and Ford employees give guest lectures, while the company offers internships to some students.
But how seamlessly can 400 students go to school alongside 1,200 adult workers? 
"Every now and then," said Cora Christmas, the principal, "we get a phone call that one of the kids has gone astray" on the 88-acre complex. But that is rare, she said, and the adult contact can help the children mature, in addition to adding a realistic element to their education. 
"If they can see that something they learn is making someone in the real world money," Mrs. Christmas said, "they'll listen."
Not all educators support the concept of shared space. Noreen Connell, the executive director of the Education Priorities Panel, a coalition of 24 civic organizations that monitors schools, said that something can be lost when too many concerns are yoked together under one roof. 
"Houses of worship have remained buildings by themselves and it may be because there is a cultural value in doing so," she said. "When you open a school up to so many uses, there's a symbolic dimension that you're bucking. People want buildings that are institutions of learning: they want to feel that the whole building is about learning. I mean, what could be next? A school on one side of the building and a Home Depot on the other?"
Off-Site Education Services, however, is grateful for any usable space it can get. The organization, part of the New York City Board of Education, runs 75 small public schools for troubled children, most of whom live in New York City. The schools, which educate 15 to 100 students each, are not in Board of Education space, but in drug treatment centers, housing projects and other nontraditional locations.
"When there is a need for education at a site," said Jerry Krantweiss, assistant principal of administration for Off-Site Educational Services, "we visit and make sure the space and equipment needs can meet the contractual needs" of the teachers' union. 
"We don't select the location," he added, "but we make sure it can accommodate a school." 
The process is always a negotiation. "When we set up a school in the projects," Mr. Krantweiss said, "not only do we have to deal with the Housing Authority, but we also deal with the local management of each building and the residents." 
At Bank Street, Mr. Snyder need look no further than his own institution, where the graduate school shares space with a nursery school and an elementary school. 
"Here we have a direct linkage and the same mission and it can still be a problem," Mr. Snyder said. "The children run around, they play on the elevator, and are they evil? No, but they can be a major inconvenience. We have to clean up the messes that kids make with the toilet paper and sit in chairs that are too small for us." 
That is why, in any circumstance, the only road to constructive coexistence, Mr. Snyder said, is preparation and attention to the details of life together. But with that rolling dialogue in place, shared space can work, bringing financial relief and real-world flavor to a school. 
"And one day," Mr. Snyder said, "wouldn't it be wonderful if schools could be combined with banks, medical facilities and public libraries?"

HEADLINE: 300 Firms Competing to Help Remake Downtown 

BYLINE:  By EDWARD WYATT 

 BODY:
More than 300 architecture and planning firms, including those of the notable architects Philip Johnson and Robert A. M. Stern, have answered the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation's call for more innovative concepts for the World Trade Center site, rebuilding officials said yesterday.
 Most of the firms are seeking to be one of five participants in a new, four-week planning and design study, but rebuilding officials said some of the submissions that arrived by the deadline yesterday were answering two calls for consultants, one in urban design and the other in graphic arts. The 300 submissions are from firms on every continent except Antarctica, the officials said. 
Alexander Garvin, the vice president for planning, design and development at the corporation, said at a board meeting that a panel of six designers would narrow the field for the four-week study to 15 to 20 firms. 
The panel of judges comprises Toshiko Mori, the chairwoman of the department of architecture at the Harvard Graduate School of Design; Eugenie L. Birch, the chairwoman of the department of city and regional planning at the University of Pennsylvania; Richard N. Swett, an architect, former congressman from New Hampshire and ambassador to Denmark during the Clinton administration; Kinshasha Holman Conwill, an arts and management consultant and former director of the Studio Museum in Harlem; Terence Riley, chief curator of the department of architecture and design at the Museum of Modern Art; and Michael Van Valkenburgh, a landscape architect and professor at the Harvard Graduate School of Design. 
A committee from the development corporation will make the final choice, picking as many as five teams for the study by early October. The urban design consultants also will be selected by a committee of development corporation representatives by early October. 
The teams will prepare several plans for the site and adjacent areas based on various requirements, including some with less office space and more residential and other space than were included in the original six designs created by Beyer Blinder Belle and Peterson Littenberg, the original architecture and planning firms hired by rebuilding officials.
The resulting designs will be used by rebuilding officials, Beyer Blinder Belle and Peterson Littenberg to develop three new plans for the site. Those plans are to made public by the end of the year, and a final plan will be developed from them by the spring of 2003. The contracts of firms whose initial plans are selected for further use may be extended. 
A report on the economy of Lower Manhattan was presented at the board meeting by McKinsey & Company, the consulting firm. 
McKinsey said its study showed that nearly half the 138,000 jobs that the Sept. 11 attack cost the area were not expected to return. More than 85 percent of the departed jobs were in the financial services industry.

HEADLINE: The Transfer At Secaucus Edges Closer To Reality 

BYLINE:  By RONALD SMOTHERS 

DATELINE: NEWARK, Sept. 17 

 BODY:
The Secaucus Transfer, the long-awaited station that will connect 11 of the state's 12 commuter rail lines and shave minutes off commuting times to Midtown Manhattan for thousands of commuters, will be slowly phased in beginning next fall, New Jersey Transit officials said today.
 The station will for the first time allow riders from northern New Jersey and southern New York State to transfer to a stream of trains that will transport them in a breezy six minutes into Pennsylvania Station in Midtown. 
 It will also allow them to transfer to southbound trains to the Jersey Shore and Trenton. Those riders must now travel all the way into Hoboken, then take PATH trains to 33rd Street in Midtown or to Newark to connect with southbound trains. 
The $450 million project, a four-tiered station on the edge of the Meadowlands astride several of the rail lines, has been on the drawing board since the 1980's and under construction since 1995. 
It is nearly completed and had been scheduled to open this fall. But George D. Warrington, executive director of New Jersey Transit, said today that the agency would have to phase in the new service more slowly because any increase now in the number of passengers on trains headed into Midtown would create "unacceptable crowding conditions." 
He explained that the agency had experienced a steep increase in ridership since the World Trade Center attack and the destruction of the Lower Manhattan PATH station that had served 66,000 commuters daily. Many of those riders now take New Jersey Transit trains to Midtown, where their jobs have been temporarily relocated. 
Those lines heading into Manhattan are now operating at about 130 percent of capacity and cannot accommodate any of the increased ridership expected to result from full operation of the Secaucus Transfer, Mr. Warrington said. 
Consequently, he said, full use of the station will have to wait until early 2004, when the new PATH station in Lower Manhattan is expected to be completed, allowing the return of many companies to that part of the city.
The PATH station beneath the World Trade Center is being rebuilt with $544 million from the Federal Emergency Management Agency. It is scheduled to be finished by December 2003, said a spokesman for the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey. 
At a board meeting of the transit agency today, Mr. Warrington said that starting next September, the agency would begin the phase-in with weekend service at the Secaucus Transfer for trains on the Main Line, Bergen Line and Pascack Valley Line, as well as the New Jersey Coast Line and Northeast Corridor Line. That phase-in will continue into January 2004, allowing the agency to calibrate service to the most efficient level once the PATH station is restored. 
That will also allow more time for the completion of a modernized signaling system that can dispatch more trains at shorter intervals from Secaucus through the tunnel into Manhattan. 
By opening up Bergen County and other locations to the north to the new service directly into Midtown and the Jersey Shore, James P. Fox, state commissioner of transportation and chairman of the New Jersey Transit board, said the agency was creating an "economic driver" for the county and other surrounding areas.

(Lara Solt for The New York Times) Map of Secaucus highlighting the Secaucus Transfer: The Secaucus Transfer will connect 11 commuter lines.

HEADLINE: Industrial Production Falls For First Time in 8 Months 

BYLINE:  AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 

 BODY:
Industry, the sector of the economy hardest hit by last year's recession, stumbled in August, the Federal Reserve reported today, with production falling for the first time in eight months. 
 While the report disappointed economists, most viewed the situation as temporary rather than a sign that the economy is sliding back into recession. 
 Turning in its worst performance this year, output at factories, utilities and mines fell 0.3 percent in August from July. 
Much of the weakness came from a 2.5 percent drop in output at gas and electric utilities, something economists did not consider particularly worrisome because the figures tend to bounce around from month to month because of weather changes. 
At factories, production dipped 0.1 percent in August as makers of cars and automotive parts cut back production, after increasing output in June and July. Production at mines rose 0.8 percent last month. 
David Huether, chief economist at the National Association of Manufacturers, called the decline in industrial production last month a "speed bump" after three months of brisk growth in which industrial output rose an average of 0.5 percent. 
"The manufacturing recovery will continue to run on less-than-all cylinders," Mr. Huether said, "until a sustained recovery in business investment takes hold in 2003." 
One big reason economists remain optimistic that neither the national economy nor manufacturing will backslide into recession is because consumers, whose spending accounts for two-thirds of economic activity, have been holding up amid the economic turbulence. 
The decreases in overall industrial output and in factory production in August were the first declines for each category since December, when the economy was trying to claw its way out of a recession. 
Last month, autos and parts, home electronics, appliances, furniture and carpeting, and communications equipment all posted drops in production. The declines outweighed gains elsewhere, including in semiconductors; primary metals, the category including steel; industrial machinery; and electrical equipment. 
On a more positive note, industrial production in July rose 0.4 percent, revised figures show. That was twice as fast as the Fed first estimated. For the 12 months ended in August, industrial output is up 0.4 percent.

HEADLINE: TECHNOLOGY; 
Drop in Overseas Sales Hurts Oracle

BYLINE:  By MATT RICHTEL 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 17 

 BODY:
Blaming lower-than-expected sales in Europe and Asia, the Oracle Corporation reported first-quarter software sales today that were on the low end of earlier projections.
 The company also had a drop in operating margins -- the ratio of a company's profits to the cost of producing and marketing its goods. 
 Even so, Oracle met Wall Street's projection that it would earn 7 cents a share in the quarter.
Oracle, a maker of databases and other programs that companies use to organize and automate their business, said that while it expected sales to improve gradually in the second and third quarters, the growth would be slower than previously estimated. 
Jeffrey O. Henley, the chief financial officer, said he continued to believe that the economy in the United States had bottomed out, but that the company's sales force was caught off guard by a sudden drop in demand from overseas. He noted that "for the first time," the international market was slower than the domestic one.
"Our international guys are scratching their heads and saying they're not sure what's going on," he said. "Maybe there's a more fundamental problem there than any of us have clearly understood yet."
Oracle reported that its first-quarter revenue was $2.03 billion, down more than 10 percent from $2.27 billion in the quarter a year ago. Profits excluding a charge associated with the company's investment in Liberate Technologies were $386 million, or 7 cents a share.
The company lagged in sales of new software licenses, a fundamental measure of Oracle's fiscal health. Sales of new software licenses for the quarter were $549 million, down 23 percent from the quarter last year -- and down 52 percent from the last quarter of last year -- and lower than the $560 million to $570 million Wall Street analysts expected.
Before the report, shares of Oracle closed at $9.03, down 25 cents. They fell as low as $8.40 in after-hours trading. 
The company's operating margins were 28.6 percent, compared with 33.1 percent in the first quarter of last year, said Mark R. Murphy, an analyst with the First Albany Corporation, who called the dropoff "disconcerting." He said that "the trend in operating margins could become a big issue."
Robert B. Austrian, an analyst with Banc of America Securities, said the sales decline in general appeared to be more related to the larger economy than specific to Oracle, and he said that Oracle appeared to be performing well under the circumstances. But he also said that the operating margins might become more significant if sales did not improve, because Oracle, like other technology businesses, had already made a lot of cutbacks and cannot cut costs much further. 
"Companies are as lean and mean as is practical," Mr. Austrian said. "You might read in that that the days of expanding margins on lower revenue are behind us."
Mr. Henley appeared to affirm this point, saying that until sales rebound considerably, he does not see how the company can meet its earlier objective of operating margins of 40 percent. 
Oracle has continued to try to cut costs, partly through reducing the number of workers. The company said it lost about 600 employees during the first quarter, because of attrition and layoffs. Mr. Henley said the current 41,500 employees could be reduced another 500 to 600 next quarter, partly through layoffs, mostly in Europe.
Mr. Henley projected that in Oracle's second quarter the company would have earnings of 8 cents to 9 cents a share, compared with the consensus projection of 9 cents a share from Wall Street analysts. He said that second-quarter revenue would be down 4 to 7 percent from the quarter a year ago.
Mr. Murphy of First Albany said the quarter represented "decent execution in a tough environment." But, the analyst said, there is "nothing to suggest a rebound" in information technology spending.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS; 
2 Key Indexes Drop to Lowest Levels Since Early August

BYLINE:  By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
The Dow Jones industrial average and the Standard & Poor's 500 index dropped to their lowest levels since early August yesterday as more weak economic reports drove stocks and interest rates lower.
 Stocks fell after the Federal Reserve said that industrial production fell a surprising 0.3 percent last month, the first decline in eight months and below the Wall Street forecast of an increase of 0.1 percent. 
 "The solid pace of recovery in factory output that had been evident during the first half of the year seems to have stalled," said David J. Greenlaw, chief United States fixed-income economist at Morgan Stanley. "This reflects the fact that inventory rebuilding is largely behind us, and manufacturers and retailers are cautious about prospects for demand strength going forward." 
On the anniversary of the market's reopening after last year's terrorist attack, the Dow dropped 172.63 points, or 2.1 percent, to 8,207.55. It was the Dow's lowest close since Aug. 5 and barely 500 points above its four-year low on July 23.
The S.& P. 500 index fell 17.58 points, or 2 percent, to 873.52, its lowest close since Aug. 6 and 76 points above its five-year low, also on July 23.
The Nasdaq composite index dropped 15.94 points, or 1.3 percent, to 1,259.94. This index dipped as low as 1,251 on Sept. 5.
In the bond market, the price of the Treasury's 10-year note rose 25/32, to 104 17/32 as the yield, which moves in the opposite direction, fell to 3.82 percent in late afternoon trading, from 3.91 percent Monday. 
That is the lowest yield on a Treasury security with a 10-year maturity since 1963. The fall from 4 percent a week ago should push mortgage interest rates even lower.
Declining interest rates have encouraged Americans to buy houses and cars and have been a positive force on the economy. But investors are yet to be convinced that the economic recovery, which many analysts believe began late last year, will be strong enough to assure a rebound in corporate earnings.
McDonald's, a component of the Dow industrials, provided a sign of possible consumer weakness yesterday, saying sales in the United States and Europe were lower than it had expected. It said third-quarter profits would slip to 38 cents a share, shy of the Wall Street forecast of 42 cents a share. MacDonald's stock fell $2.78, or 12.8 percent, to $18.91, and accounted for about 19 points of the Dow's decline.
Other bad news came from Charles Schwab, the discount brokerage firm. It said it was cutting about 10 percent of its work force because of a decline in trading volume. The stock dropped 60 cents, or 6.1 percent, to $9.17.
Lucent Technologies, the nation's largest maker of communications equipment, traded below $1 a share for the first time. On Friday, the company said that it would continue to eliminate jobs as its sales plunge. The stock closed at $1, down 7 cents, or 6.5 percent.
After the market closed, J. P. Morgan Chase provided more bad news on earnings, announcing that its third-quarter profit from operations would drop "well below" the 58 cents a share reported in the second quarter. During regular trading, J. P. Morgan stock dropped 16 cents, or 0.7 percent, to $21.55. The stock fell as low as $19.51 in after-hours trading.
Oracle also offered negative news after the close. Its earnings fell 33 percent in the quarter ended Aug. 31 from a year earlier. Sales dropped 10 percent. The stock fell as low as $8.44 in after-hours trading. During regular trading, the stock dropped 25 cents, or 2.7 percent, to $9.03.
Investors seem ready to sell on any negative economic news and to ignore any positive development. The futures contract for the S.& P. 500 index indicated that professional investors expected the stock market to open much higher yesterday morning, after the reports Monday night that Iraq had agreed to allow weapons inspectors to return.
But that rally, which sent all three major indexes up more than 1 percent in early trading, faded as soon as the Federal Reserve released the August industrial production data.

HEADLINE: California Power Failures Linked to Energy Companies 

BYLINE:  By JOHN M. BRODER 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 17 

 BODY:
Widespread power failures during California's energy crisis of 2000 and 2001 could have been avoided if five independent energy companies had not withheld electricity they were capable of producing, a study by state regulators said today.
 The investigation by the California Public Utilities Commission said the five companies -- Duke, Dynegy, Mirant, Reliant and AES/Williams -- had withheld power from their California plants. 
 This contributed to the "unconscionable, unjust and unreasonable electricity price spike that California experienced during the energy crisis," the report said.
The commission did not directly accuse the companies of deliberately trying to drive prices up. Officials said investigations were continuing into possible price manipulation and collusion among the companies. 
The commission said that the companies took plants off line for necessary maintenance and were subjected to sharp increases in natural gas prices but that they still had sufficient generating capacity to avoid all four days of blackouts in Southern California and 65 percent of the blackout hours in Northern California.
"On all but 2 of the 32 statewide blackout and service interruption days shown, the five biggest independent electricity generators did not supply well over 500 megawatts of power they could have generated," the study found.
A megawatt of electricity is roughly the amount needed to power 750 homes.
The generators responded that there were legitimate reasons for the service disruptions and that their plants were running as hard or harder during the crisis as before or since.
"California's merchant generators ran at historically high levels to power our state throughout the crisis," said Jan Smutny-Jones, executive director of the Independent Energy Producers, a trade group. "The average age of these plants is over 36 years old. Despite their age, California's power plants ran 88 percent harder in 2001 than they did in 1999, and some increased output as much as 206 percent to meet our state's energy needs, making up for decreased energy imports from the Northwest caused by a drought."
Company officials also said that some plants were taken off line to add equipment required by state environmental regulations. They also blamed the public utilities commission for ordering continued sales of electricity to Mexico at a time of power failures in San Diego.
The report looked at the 38 days from November 2000 through May 2001 when millions of Californians experienced large-scale blackouts and selective power failures. The blackouts were the first in California since World War II and caused thousands of businesses to close and interrupted power to homes, hospitals, schools, theaters and shopping malls.
Wholesale prices for power leaped to as high as $1,500 a megawatt-hour from $40 per megawatt-hour, causing electricity bills to jump, forcing two major utilities into bankruptcy and plunging the state into debt as it spent billions of dollars buying electricity on the deregulated market. The state entered into long-term energy contracts at the inflated prices of 2000-2001, one factor that has led to the state's $24 billion budget deficit.
The utility commission found that on each of the days when power was interrupted all of the five main electricity generators had capacity that went unused. For example, on May 8, 2001, there were two-hour blackouts caused by a shortage of 400 megawatts of power in Northern and Southern California. But Duke Energy had about 1,000 megawatts of available capacity that was not used that day, the commission report said. "Thus, Duke alone had more available and unused power than the total amount of power that was needed to avoid the blackout that day," it said.
Terry Francisco, a Duke spokesman, responded: "Duke's plants have run harder, broken down less and been available more than any other time during utility ownership and never more than during the crisis. Our capacity utilization during the crisis was among the highest in California among all the generators."
The report mentions the role of Enron Corporation only in passing, noting that federal officials had found that its energy trading strategies contributed to California's energy woes and might have been an effort to manipulate prices.
Enron, employing a variety of trading schemes known by such names as Death Star, Fat Boy and Get Shorty, tried to "game" the state's power grid to make quick trading profits, according to internal company documents.
"Thus, the potential for simultaneous withholding and gaming (including strategies not yet revealed) is very serious," the report stated, "and probably accounts for a large part of the rapid increase in costs in California during the crisis." 
An Enron spokesman, Eric Thode, said that company officials had not seen the report, but that Enron "continues to cooperate in the various investigations."
Frank Wolak, a professor of economics at Stanford University and chairman of the market surveillance committee for the state's power grid, said the utilities commission did not establish that the generators deliberately withheld power they were capable of producing. But he compared that task to an employer's proving that an employee was playing hooky when he called in sick.
"It sure looks suspicious," Mr. Wolak said, because the shortages led to huge increases in prices and profits. "But it comes down to a 'he said-she said' sort of story."

HEADLINE: THREATS AND RESPONSES: THE GULF REGION; 
Commander's Visit Part of Growing Role for Qatar

BYLINE:  By JANE PERLEZ 

DATELINE: DOHA, Qatar, Sept. 17 

 BODY:
The commander of American forces in the Persian Gulf, Gen. Tommy R. Franks, arrived here today for talks about the rapidly expanding American military presence in this gulf state that is expected to play a key role in a war against Iraq. 
 Relations remain somewhat strained between the United States and neighboring Saudi Arabia, a fact that has benefited the hereditary ruler of Qatar, Sheik Hamad bin Khalifa al-Thani, in his assiduous courtship of the American military since assuming power seven years ago. 
 The meetings between the general and the emir, as Sheik Hamad is known, represent an affirmation of a new relationship that will allow the Bush administration virtually unfettered use of Al Udeid, the large airfield here, Qatari and American officials said. 
Al Udeid, a 15,000-foot airstrip about 20 miles west of the capital, was described by American officials as the longest in the Middle East. It provides for a wide range of military action, including bombing raids, air and ground surveillance, and air refueling, they said. 
The installation is capable of handling large numbers of fighters and transports, and includes warehouses and storage facilities that would give protection against chemical and biological warfare. 
There is nothing in writing to specify what the United States may or may not do from the base in the event of a war against Iraq, the officials said. But the emir, who is also the defense minister, views the United States as his country's ultimate protector and is unlikely to present any obstacles to the needs of the American military, the officials said. 
The Qatari foreign minister, Sheik Hamad bin Jassim bin Jabr al-Thani, a cousin of the emir, encouraged the United States last week to resolve the Iraqi situation peacefully but also indicated that it was up to Saddam Hussein, Iraq's leader, whether there was war. 
Also last week, General Franks announced that he would move about 600 officers, or about one-quarter of his staff, to Al Udeid Air Base in November for a war games exercise. About 2,000 American soldiers are on the base, down from a high of 4,000 during the war in Afghanistan, American officials said. 
The new complement of officers is likely to remain after the exercise in preparation for a war against Iraq, the Pentagon said. 
In coming to Qatar, General Franks is following in the footsteps of Vice President Dick Cheney and Secretary of Defense Donald H. Rumsfeld, who were here earlier this year during the Afghan war. They inspected Air Force operations at Al Udeid and spoke of the important role Qatar would play with the United States in the future. 
Something of a maverick in the Arab world, the 52-year-old emir has actively sought an American military presence, said Gen. Anthony C. Zinni, the former head of Central Command. 
The Qatari leader has been eager to protect his nation's natural gas reserves from potentially meddlesome neighbors, General Zinni said, and that desire for protection dovetailed with the desire of the United States in the late 1990's to "spread out our presence" in the region. 
In 1995, when the emir overthrew his father in a nonviolent palace coup, Qatar was considered little more than a spit of sand with glorious pearl diving. 
In his ensuing course of modernization, one of the emir's first moves was to develop, in concert with Exxon Mobil, the nation's vast quantities of natural gas. Qatar is now considered one of the world's largest producers. 
Other initiatives were meant to show that Qatar would not remain entirely inhibited by the conservative Wahabi strain of Islam that dominates life here. 
The emir started a satellite television channel, Al Jazeera, which is widely watched in the Arab world and beyond for its unrestrained reporting on Arab issues. It is Al Jazeera that has been a source of several tapes from Osama bin Laden. 
The emir also allowed the second of his three wives, Sheika Moza bint Nasser al-Misned, to head a foundation that has paid $750 million for Cornell University's medical school to open a branch campus in Doha. The first pre-med classes of the school began two weeks ago. 
Qatari women are allowed to drive cars and voted in municipal elections two years ago. But, paradoxically, Wahabi beliefs forbid the display of photographs of Sheika Moza, despite her prominent foundation role. 
Another part of the emir's modernization drive was to expand his country's military capacity, officials said. But with only about 8,000 soldiers in his army, and 12 Mirage fighter jets bought from the French, he needed help. 
That was where Washington came in. Immediately after the Sept. 11 attacks, the emir was warmly greeted at the White House, and he contributed to the firefighters fund in New York City. 
With 140,00 people -- one of the smallest indigenous populations in the world -- Qatar has a per capita gross domestic product of $110,000 -- compared with $10,000 for Saudi Arabia where the population is about 17 million, said Simon Henderson, a London-based consultant for Saudi Strategies. That makes the Qataris far richer than the Saudis, a fact that heats up historical rivalries, Mr. Henderson said. 
General Zinni said Qatar was in a central position in the Persian Gulf and described the air base was "phenomenal," with "a lot of capability." 
American officials said that General Franks signed a "statement of intent" with the Qataris in July 2001. Immediately after Sept. 11, the officials said, American planes began operating from the base for the first time. 
Though the operations were based on a handshake, as one official put it, the Qataris have not changed their minds. They are not standing in the way of whatever the Americans need to do in the coming months, another said.

HEADLINE: TECHNOLOGY; 
Rebel Wants Japan's Inventors To Get Some U.S.-Style Rewards

BYLINE:  By JOHN MARKOFF 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 17 

 BODY:
Ordered to stop the scientific research he thought extremely promising, Shuji Nakamura hid the work from his superiors at a Japanese chemical company. He secretly obtained patents in the company's name.
 Dr. Nakamura's mission paid off: his inventions revolutionized the world of consumer electronics. One helped make possible an array of products, from flat-panel computer screens to video billboards to long-lasting, efficient flashlights. Another will make it possible to store 5 to 10 movies on a single DVD-like disk. 
 Dr. Nakamura has been celebrated in the United States as an innovative pioneer. But in Japan he is more controversial. After it was clear his inventions would make a lot of money, his bosses took them to market without additional compensation for him. So Dr. Nakamura sued the company, claiming that the patents were a result of his efforts and he should receive royalties.
His case points to striking differences in the ways the United States and Japan treat innovators.
In the United States, engineers and inventors often share in the corporate rewards from innovation, through employment contracts that specify royalties or other incentives like stock options. But in Japan, engineers and scientists are almost universally treated as "salarymen" who do not participate in corporate profits. Compensation for an invention is at the company's discretion and seldom amounts to more than $300.
Dr. Nakamura's suit is challenging many of Japan's basic assumptions about conformity in a culture where personal gain or greed, particularly among technical people, is still considered distasteful.
"This case will have a huge psychological impact on Japanese business," said Paul Saffo, a Silicon Valley technology consultant. "This goes to Japan's entrepreneurial soul."
If Dr. Nakamura wins, an avalanche of similar suits may follow from Japanese researchers who believe they have been denied fair compensation from their inventions.
"This will teach researchers and companies alike to negotiate and make explicit rights and compensation in advance," said Joichi Ito, president and chief executive of Neoteny Company, a Japanese investment firm. "This is great because it will help force technical people to think about business and companies to think about incentives."
Dr. Nakamura, who is now in Japan awaiting the court ruling, is scheduled to receive an innovation award in absentia for his research from The Economist magazine in San Francisco on Wednesday.
In an interview last week at the University of California in Santa Barbara, where Dr. Nakamura is director of the Center for Solid State Lighting and Displays, he said his case's becoming a cause celebre in Japan was an encouraging development.
"Everyone wants to change our system," Dr. Nakamura said. "The Japanese press likes me a lot but the problem is the Japanese government. It's very bureaucratic."
Dr. Nakamura has long been a rebel in Japan's technology world. Although he got the go-ahead to work on his invention, known as a blue- light-emitting diode, or L.E.D., from the former chairman of the company where he worked, Nichia Chemical Industries, the company's president and its engineering managers bitterly fought his efforts because his research was seen as a cash drain. 
In the late 1980's Dr. Nakamura was such a pariah in his company that he hid both his seminal scientific papers and his patent applications from his superiors, making applications by approaching a new member of the patent department. His company found out about their star researcher's breakthrough only after Nichia sales executives were contacted by researchers from large Japanese companies who wished to purchase the blue-light-emitting diodes that Dr. Nakamura had been specifically ordered not to explore. 
"They were furious with me because I was spending money in an area they believed we couldn't possibly compete in," he said. Officials of the company did not respond to requests for comment.
His subsequent invention, in 1996, was a blue-violet laser, an invention that this year will bring a dramatic advance in the capacity of DVD's,
Dr. Nakamura, 47, grew up on Shikoku, the smallest of Japan's four main islands. He received a master's degree in electronics engineering in 1979 from Tokushima University, which awarded him a doctorate in 1994 based on his work with light-emitting diodes. He then joined Nichia, one of the few companies of any size on Shikoku.
"My dream was to work for one of the big electronics companies like Sony or Panasonic," he said. However, because the cost of living was high in Tokyo, he instead took a job with Nichia, a virtually unknown chemical company near his home that was seeking to diversify.
He made electronic materials, like gallium arsenide, that Nichia tried to sell. But each time, Nichia fared poorly against big companies already in the materials business.
He then turned his efforts to designing less exotic L.E.D.'s, but he was forced to act as researcher, manufacturer and even salesman for the products, which were also being made by larger Japanese companies. Nichia was unable to find a market for the devices.
In 1989, Dr. Nakamura began pursuing the blue light. He said he was ultimately able to succeed in building the first blue L.E.D. in 1993 after he chose to work with an exotic material, gallium nitride, while most of his competitors were focusing on a competing material, zinc selinide.
His company had permitted him to study in the United States to obtain technical expertise and he returned to Japan and purchased a special furnace to help with his research. He modified the furnace and then began a laborious series of experiments.
He said that at the time, he was as much interested in attaining scientific recognition as he was in making a commercial blue L.E.D. Since so few people were experimenting with gallium nitride, it seemed to be an obvious candidate.
"It was easy to be the best in the world because there were only 10 people working with that material," he said.

HEADLINE: New Jersey Intends to End Incentive Plan On Pollution 

BYLINE:  By LAURA MANSNERUS 

DATELINE: TRENTON, Sept. 17 

 BODY:
New Jersey officials plan to end an air quality program introduced by former Gov. Christie Whitman that relies on economic incentives for polluters to reduce smog-forming emissions.
 The program allows companies to buy and sell rights to emit regulated pollutants -- an idea that the commissioner of environmental protection, Bradley M. Campbell, has questioned since he was appointed by Gov. James E. McGreevey in January. 
 Mr. Campbell called the program "an experiment that failed" and said today that the Department of Environmental Protection would issue a public notice of its intent to phase out the plan. The decision was first reported today in The Star-Ledger of Newark.
Mrs. Whitman has made market-based incentives a theme in her approach to environmental regulation, as governor of New Jersey and now as head of the federal Environmental Protection Agency. When approved for the post 19 months ago, she promised to "move beyond the command-and-control model" of environmental regulation.
But critics of the state emissions credit-trading program called on her shortly afterward to reject the program, which had not received final approval from the E.P.A. They complained that the program had not cut emissions in New Jersey but had merely shifted them from one source to another.
The state program, introduced in 1996, allows polluters that reduce emissions below federal clean air standards to reserve the unused portion of their allowance as credits. The credits can be used later or sold to other companies that want to exceed the standards. A spokesman for Mrs. Whitman, Joe Martyak, said today that as governor Mrs. Whitman had started "an innovative program" and that as recently as January 2001 it was praised by the Clinton administration in an E.P.A. news release. 
While other states have expressed interest in emissions-trading programs, only Michigan and New Hampshire have adopted similar approaches, Mr. Martyak said. 
The federal environmental agency never formally approved the New Jersey plan, known as the Open Market Emissions Trading program, although such credits were authorized in a broad revision of the Clean Air Act in 1990.
The program has been dormant for months, and when the federal agency asked Mr. Campbell whether the new administration planned to continue it, he responded, in a letter dated Aug. 13, that "the program has failed" and should be ended.
Mr. Campbell noted that the state's registry of credits had been shut down since last fall, when the private contractor that handled it withdrew. In January, the largest generator of credits, the P.S.E.&G. Power Company, agreed in talks with the state to forfeit them. The settlement "dried up the market," Mr. Campbell said.
The state reached a settlement in May with another utility, Conectiv Atlantic Generation, which had planned to meet the clean air standards by using credits but found there were none to buy. 
Mr. Campbell said that the state would not prosecute any companies that had bought credits in good faith but that environmental officials did not know of any companies still relying on the program. 
Under the program, reductions in emissions generated credits for 30,000 to 40,000 tons of pollutants, said Amy Cradic, a spokeswoman for the Department of Environmental Protection. Most of those, Ms. Cradic said, were for nitrogen oxides, which produces ground-level ozone, or smog. 
Most of the credits were generated by Public Service Electric and Gas, the state's largest public utility, which transferred them in a 1999 corporate reorganization to its newly created affiliate, P.S.E.&G. Power. 
The emissions credit-trading program places no cap on the emissions allowed with purchased credits, which Mr. Campbell said was a serious shortcoming. "I think there's wide agreement even among environmental groups that market mechanisms can be used effectively," he said, but only if there are restrictions limiting total emissions. 
Jeffrey Tittel, the president of the state chapter of the Sierra Club, said that the trades were never properly monitored and that the state relied on the polluting companies to report their own data. "It was an environmental con game that didn't work," he said. 
But Mr. Martyak emphasized that the New Jersey program was voluntary and that Mrs. Whitman and President Bush were proposing other, mandatory measures to control airborne pollutants. "She's all for finding ways to ways to reduce pollution," he said. "She'd welcome their sitting down and working with the agency."
