HEADLINE: Group May Estimate Effects of Tax Cuts 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 

 BODY:
Without attracting much attention, Republicans are on the verge of achieving a cherished goal: official assessments of whether proposed tax cuts will help the economy and ultimately pay for themselves by generating more revenue for the government.
 For years, supply-side economists have argued that the current system of evaluating tax cuts overstates the expense to the federal budget by looking only at lost revenue and not taking into account benefits like increased output and jobs. 
 But they have faced opposition not only from liberals but also from prominent conservatives and Republicans, including Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, and Dan L. Crippen, the director of the Congressional Budget Office. The opponents say there is no way to develop sufficiently precise estimates of the effect of tax cuts on an economy as complex as the United States's. 
Members of both parties now say Republicans seem about to get much of what they want from the official arbiter of tax cuts, the nonpartisan staff of Congress's Joint Committee on Taxation.
The change was largely engineered by Representative Bill Thomas, the California Republican who is chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee. Economists and Congressional aides on both sides of the aisle said it could give Republicans important, if somewhat flawed, new ammunition in favor of tax cuts, including a justification for their assertion that tax cuts can generate new revenue to offset their direct cost to the federal budget.
With budget deficits mounting and the economy continuing to struggle, such ammunition could be vital to Congressional Republicans and President Bush in promoting their tax-cutting agenda in coming years.
Realizing the implications, Democrats have tried in recent weeks to slow the plan by stocking a Congressional panel of economists studying the issue with new members sympathetic to their objections. But some Democrats said the effort would probably not be more than a holding action, and that the new practice would likely be put to use soon, probably next year.
Prodded by Mr. Thomas, the staff of the Joint Committee on Taxation is polishing a new economic model intended to simulate the effect of tax cuts on economic growth and revenues. Though some proponents of the approach acknowledge that the model still has problems, its use would be a start for conservatives who want a more ambitious revision of the way tax cuts are evaluated.
"If they start doing it, even in a flawed manner, it will start a process that will move, perhaps slowly, toward more reasonable scores," said Kevin A. Hassett, an economist at the American Enterprise Institute, a conservative research group.
The joint committee's staff has indicated that it intends to issue reports that would for the first time assess the likely economic effects of changes in tax policy. In particular, the staff reports would offer guidance on whether any economic growth stimulated by the tax cut would produce new tax revenues.
The new reports will supplement but not replace the current system under which the committee provides official estimates of what a tax cut will cost in lost revenue without calculating the long-term economic effects. But members of both parties said the new reports would be a big step toward what supply-siders have sought for years, a "dynamic scoring" system that incorporates offsetting revenue gains in calculating the cost of tax cuts.
Economists who have been involved in the issue said the new approach is being put into effect despite apparent reluctance on the part of Lindy L. Paull, a Republican appointee who is chief of staff for the Joint Committee on Taxation. Despite objections from Democrats, she has pushed forward with a review by an outside panel of economists, and she signaled several months ago that she was about ready to meet Republican demands to begin looking at tax cuts the way they prefer.
"In the near future," she said in little-noticed testimony to the Ways and Means Committee in May, "the joint committee staff expect to be able to produce comparative analyses of the long-term growth and associated revenue feedback effects of major tax proposals."
Democrats said Ms. Paull, who did not return phone calls seeking comment, appeared to have been pressured by Mr. Thomas into backing an approach that the joint committee staff had long been wary of adopting. 
"If one reads the first 15 pages of Lindy Paull's testimony and stops, one would have to conclude that dynamic scoring was a bad idea," said Al Davis, the chief economist for the Democrats on the Ways and Means Committee. "Yet, the last page says that the J.C.T. staff is going to go ahead anyway. It is no coincidence that Chairman Bill Thomas's name was cited to make this improbable transition."
Mr. Thomas's effort to push for dynamic scoring is built on a rule adopted by the House several years ago that requires the Joint Committee on Taxation to provide such estimates. Democrats largely ignored the effort, and passed up a chance last spring to recommend economists to an advisory panel set up by the committee to help develop a computer model to evaluate the economic and revenue effects of tax cuts.
But as it became clearer this summer that the joint committee staff was on the verge of going ahead with the new approach, Democratic leaders began to worry. Senator Tom Daschle of South Dakota, the majority leader, and Senator Kent Conrad, Democrat of North Dakota and the chairman of the Budget Committee, wrote to Ms. Paull on June 25 expressing "surprise and distress" that the committee was proceeding with the plan. They urged her "as strongly as we can" to suspend consideration of the new approach.
In August, four Senate Democrats -- Bob Graham of Florida, John Kerry of Massachusetts, Robert G. Torricelli of New Jersey and John D. Rockefeller IV of West Virginia -- asked Ms. Paull to name five economists of their choosing to the advisory panel, which already had 14 members, including some sympathetic to the Democratic position. Earlier this month she agreed with the request. 
The original members of the committee have already reviewed the economic model, which was developed by Joel Prakken of Macroeconomic Advisors of St. Louis, a well-known economic forecasting firm. Some economists on the panel said problems with the model could be fixed. Others said the problems were so fundamental that the model would never yield reliable estimates.

HEADLINE: A Dismal Retail Season 

BYLINE:  By TRACIE ROZHON 

 BODY:
Retailers, suffering through a dismal back-to-school season, have plenty of culprits to blame, from the hot weather of late summer to their customers' anxiety over the economy. 
 But some analysts and shoppers are suggesting that the stores, particularly apparel merchants, should point the finger in another direction: at themselves. The slump in August sales, they suggest, occurred at least partly because consumers did not like what they saw on the racks. 
 Shari Schwartzman Eberts, an analyst with J. P. Morgan, said the overall lackluster results reflected not only a weak economy but also "the lack of excitement over the lack of new fashion trends." Russell Jones, a vice president at the consulting firm Cap Gemini Ernst & Young, said that two factors conspired to keep consumers out of the stores. "We had too many outlets offering too similar products and they didn't provide a whole lot of inspiration to the consumer to spend more." 
For clothing sellers, the back-to-school season is the second-most-important season of the year and is considered a good predictor of the all-important holiday shopping season. What makes this August's mediocre end-of-summer showing scary for these retailers is that the drops in student apparel took place while consumer spending was relatively healthy in other categories, like automobiles and home furnishings. 
"If parents are not spending for their children -- who have grown an inch and are wearing pants above their ankles -- why would anyone think they'll spend on themselves or for gifts?" asked Marshal Cohen, co-president of NPDFashionworld, a market research company. Mr. Cohen pointed out that to make matters potentially worse, this year's holiday shopping season, between Thanksgiving and Christmas, is shorter: only 19 days, compared with 25 last year.
Retail sales for the country, including cars and appliances, were up 1 percent over a year ago, according to the Goldman, Sachs retail composite index, casting an even darker shadow over the comparable- store sales for traditional back-to-school retailers. Wet Seal, a store that caters to teenagers and young people, basked in the glow of being a Wall Street darling. But this year, August sales were down 12 percent compared with August of last year. The Gap was down two points from last year's disappointing showing, and even Target -- where so many teenagers tell researchers they love to shop -- was down 0.1 percent. Sears was off 11.1 percent. Saks was down 3.3 percent. Federated, which owns Bloomingdale's, Macy's and Neiman-Marcus, was down 5.8. May Department Stores, which owns Lord & Taylor, was off 8.6 percent from August 2001.
Of the major department stores, only Kohl's and J. C. Penney, both sellers of basic, low-priced apparel, are up substantially: 4 and 2.9 percent, respectively. Even that was disappointing to some: just before the statistics were released, Credit Suisse First Boston was predicting that Kohl's would be up 5 to 7 percent.
The Spoer-Morton family of Santa Monica exemplifies the combination of lower spending and the boredom with current trends that so disappointed the back-to-school retailers. Danelle Morton, a writer, did not have as much money to spend this year on her daughter, Marissa Spoer, 13, and her son, Ben Spoer, 17. To her relief, she found her children did not mind a bit. 
"I have my own weird fashion thing; I'm a thrift store junkie," Marissa said. "I just bought a pink poodle skirt from the 50's in a vintage clothing place for $2. All my friends are into the same weird thing. I'm not an Abercrombie & Fitch kind of person."
While her brother does not frequent the thrift shops -- "my sister would pick stuff off the back of a dumpster," he said -- he, too, has spent little money on back-to-school clothes this fall. "Maybe $75; I bought one or two things, a T-shirt, a long-sleeved shirt." 
Ms. Morton is delighted. "As a single mother, this was a tough year for me, and I was surprised -- and relieved -- to find out they really didn't want much at all." 
For Marissa and many others in her age group and a little older, the store-bought, assembly-line jeans and peasant tops have no excitement. She and her friends are reaching toward vintage clothing to make their own fashion statement. At the same time, her brother is bored by the same old merchandise. 
"The reason I didn't do much shopping is that none of the clothing really appeals to me," said Ben, a senior in high school. "It's absurdly overpriced." Ben said he "won't walk into a Macy's -- what little shopping I do, I do at Target," (which he pronounces with a French accent, tar-ZHAY, to give it a high-class sound).
Not every teenager is haunting thrift shops. But analysts suggest that a shift is taking place away from department stores and specialty shops to the discounters like Wal-Mart and Target, where the clothes are cheaper and, analysts report, better made than they used to be. 
Britt Beemer, president of America's Research Group in Charleston, S.C., said that on average, parents are spending less for their children's clothes, wherever they buy them. Mr. Beemer interviewed parents in 1,000 families throughout the country during the first week of August. Last year, the average back-to-school budget was $336, he said. This year, it has dropped about 10 percent, to $304. He also found that parents are spending less per item. "They're buying at Target and Walmart where three years ago, they shopped at the Gap," he said.
Art Spar, the chief executive of STS Market Reserve, interviewed the young people themselves. "Among the young men, the only category that was up solidly was T-shirts." He paused. "Now what does that say?" Athletic gear, a mainstay of the teenage boys last year, was down sharply. Jeans and casual pants were flat for boys -- but popular among young women. The specialty stores -- Old Navy, the Limited and the Gap -- were losing favor among the girls, who are increasingly hitting the discount stores.
Barbara L. Coffey, an analyst with Jefferies, called most of the back-to-school statistics "abysmal." Ms. Coffey follows Alloy.com, an Internet site for youth-oriented clothing, which early this month, was downgraded from buy to sell. She says that to make its goals, Alloy may have to mark down merchandise, further reducing its profit levels.
Despite Alloy's poor showing, other Internet companies -- including Abercrombie.com and Old Navy.com -- proved a lot livelier than many brick-and-mortar stores, said Ken Cassar, a senior analyst with Jupiter Research, an online market research firm. Altogether, the online sales volume of back-to-school apparel is up 22 percent, said Dan Hess, a vice president with ComScore Networks, a Web measurement firm.
Still, analysts cautioned that those figures might not be as spectacular as they seem because the Internet market is growing so fast, and many of the businesses are still small. ("If you sold $400,000 last year and sold $800,000 this year, that's still a 100 percent increase," Mr. Beemer said, "but you're still nowhere.") Mr. Hess estimated that Internet sales -- taken together -- total 1.2 to 2 percent of America's retail sales.
Analysts worry that retailers -- online and off -- are so drastically reducing prices to meet their sales volume goals that they are seriously damaging profit margins. While one of the brightest spots in apparel is denim jeans for women, some anxious stores began marking them down in mid-August, Mr. Cohen said. 
"Retailers have already begun pushing the panic button; if they're marking down their hottest items now, how are they going to get people in the stores for Christmas?" 
For their part, the stores argue that the unseasonably hot weather kept shoppers out of the stores; they predicted parents and their children would start shopping when the weather cools. But it is not clear that stores have what younger shoppers want.
Amid the gloom of the back-to-school season, there are a few bright spots. Pacific Sunwear, a specialty retailer that caters to surfers and snowboarders, showed an increase of 12.9 percent over last year, considered impressive in the gloomy retail climate. 
"Every year there is one hot retailer who nails it," Mr. Beemer said. "This year, it's PacSun."
Moody's Financial Services, which kept its negative overall outlook for the retail industry, issued some good news this week: largely because of reduced inventory, the flow of rating downgrades for retail businesses has been stanched -- at least for now.
According to John E. Puchalla, a senior economist at Moody's, retail inventory has been reduced from an inventory-to-sales ratio of 1.55 to 1 to a ratio of 1.5 to 1. Although that decline sounds minuscule, Mr. Puchalla said it represented millions of dollars of inventory. In 1995, inventory peaked at a ratio of 1.74 to 1.
Moody's, in a report prepared by the company's economists, was cautiously positive: "A heavily promotional environment has produced sales at the expense of some profits, but cost cuts, thinner inventories and a focus on debt reduction have contributed to fewer ratings reductions."
The other potential bright spot for retailers is, unexpectedly, New York City. Several analysts predicted that Christmas sales in the city might be better than expected -- partly because tourism is up from last fall. While Wal-Mart is expected to drain a lot of department store dollars in cities across the country, Mr. Beemer said New York City stores still had glamour -- and no Wal-Marts. And, of course, there is not far to go to beat last year's Christmas sales, which plummeted in the aftermath of the terrorist attacks.
"Last year in New York, offices were canceling Christmas parties because of 9/11 and donating the money to help the victims," he said. "Now, manufacturers say they're shipping a lot of holiday evening apparel to high-end stores like Saks and Bergdorf Goodman."

HEADLINE: Reno Concedes Defeat And Endorses Her Rival 

BYLINE:  By DANA CANEDY 

DATELINE: MIAMI, Sept. 17 

 BODY:
Janet Reno ended her colorful campaign for governor today, conceding defeat a week after the Democratic primary to Bill McBride, a Tampa lawyer.
 "Bill McBride is the Democratic nominee for the governor of the state of Florida and I congratulate him," Ms. Reno, 64, said in a speech at her headquarters. "I congratulated him on the positive and very effective campaign he ran and I told him that I thought he was going to be a great governor." 
 With a final tally showing her losing to Mr. McBride by 4,800 votes out of 1.3 million ballots cast on Sept. 10, Ms. Reno said today that she was turning to life "in a private capacity." She said she would support Mr. McBride, a former marine and Vietnam veteran who won a contest she had been expected to win easily.
Ms. Reno accepted defeat only after elections supervisors in Miami-Dade County sent final vote tallies to state elections officials for certification. With the Miami-Dade results as well as a ballot review in Broward County last week, Ms. Reno picked up 3,400 votes -- not enough to pass Mr. McBride or to force a recount. Initial results released by the state division of elections had Mr. McBride leading by 8,196 votes.
State elections officials preliminarily declared Mr. McBride the winner on Thursday based on that figure. That was before Miami-Dade, Broward and a few other counties had to amend their results because of problems at the polls: precincts opened late, workers operated machines improperly and elections officials failed to retrieve voting data from some equipment.
Even Ms. Reno had trouble voting at her precinct on Election Day.
Mr. McBride, in contrast, gave a victory speech hours after state elections officials declared him the unofficial winner and days before Ms. Reno accept defeat. Today, Mr. McBride, 57, issued a statement praising Ms Reno and thanking her for her support.
"I have known Janet Reno for almost 30 years," Mr. McBride said. "She is my friend. My respect for her cannot be overstated."
Mr. McBride said he would focus on issues that were important to them both. "The issues Janet Reno spoke most passionately about during the campaign, prescription drug benefits, protecting the most vulnerable of Florida's children, improving our public schools, protecting our wonderful but fragile environment, and guaranteeing everyone's right to vote are also my issues. Together we will move this state in the right direction again."
Mr. McBride did little public campaigning today, concentrating on fund-raising and his search for a running mate. State Democratic Party insiders speculated today that Mr. McBride would name Tom Rossin, the Democratic leader of the Florida Senate from Royal Palm Beach, as his running mate as early as Wednesday.
Ms. Reno said today that it was time to put the campaign behind her. Asked what she intended to do next, Ms. Reno said, "I plan to learn how to play the piano more effectively than I can, to perfect my Eskimo roll" -- a kayaking move -- "and to go visit the people I have met along the way."
Above all, Ms. Reno said, she would help Mr. McBride defeat Gov. Jeb Bush. "I want to do everything that I possibly can to see that he gets elected," Ms. Reno said. "I urge everybody to support him because I think this is going to be one of the most critical elections in Florida's history."
State political observers said Ms. Reno had little choice but to hold out on conceding until she was confident that all votes had been counted. "I think she had the responsibility to see if she had sufficient votes to win before she would concede," said Lance de Haven-Smith, a political science professor at Florida State University.
Even so, Mr. de Haven-Smith said, the delay slowed momentum in the McBride campaign. "It should have been his day in the spotlight for this enormous upset and that would have brought a lot of attention to him and enhanced his reputation as an extraordinarily successful newcomer into Florida politics," he said. "But instead what got all the attention were the election problems. That certainly is a lost opportunity. But I don't think it will be a major blow for him."
At an appearance in Fort Lauderdale today and in a statement issued earlier, Mr. Bush congratulated Mr. McBride said he looked forward to a series of debates leading to the general election in November. 
"Now that we are down to two candidates, I hope that there will be a real focus on issues for the next seven weeks," Mr. Bush said. "I hope that my opponent will tell all Floridians his plan to address important issues like the economy, the environment and health care."
Ms. Reno said she would also devote much of her time to working on election reform in Florida.
"What I want to do is find out exactly what happened from the time I stood at that election polling place and was told I couldn't vote for another 80 minutes," she said. "The sobering experience of being told you couldn't vote on Election Day has stuck with me."
Ms. Reno said she was not sure if her days in politics were over. But she said she would conduct her work on election reform "as a private citizen."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
J.P. Morgan Says Earnings For Quarter Will Be Weak
J. P. Morgan said third-quarter earnings would be worse than expected because of bad loans to telecommunications companies and weak trading results. Stung by its relationship with Enron, losses on loans and its business in Argentina, the company has failed to meet expectations since the merger of J. P. Morgan and Chase Manhattan nearly two years ago.
 Losses on loans to companies, especially telecommunications and cable companies, are expected to rise to $1.4 billion in the third quarter, up sharply from $302 million in the previous quarter. Market Place. Page C11. 

California Crisis Tied to Companies
Widespread power failures during California's energy crisis could have been avoided if five energy companies had not withheld electricity they were capable of producing, a study by regulators has found. A22.

Layoffs Planned at Charles Schwab
The investment firm Charles Schwab plans to lay off an additional 10 percent of its employees, in what some analysts said was likely to be part of a round of year-end layoffs in the securities industry. Schwab expects to cut about 1,800 employees, a crucial part of its efforts to save $225 million a year. C7.

G.M. Reaches Labor Deal in Canada
General Motors and the Canadian Auto Workers union agreed on a new three-year contract covering 19,000 workers. C2.

Stock Markets Fall Sharply
The Dow Jones industrial average dropped 172.63 points, to 8,207.55. The Standard & Poor's index fell 17.58 points, to 873.52, and the Nasdaq dropped 15.94 points, to 1,259.94. C11.

Output at factories, utilities and mines fell 0.3 percent in August from July. C7.

Support Sought for Security Report
Administration officials hope to build support among high-technology companies before releasing the final version of a report intended to help shore up cybersecurity. A21.

Even as the Transportation Department races to install million-dollar machines in airports to screen checked baggage, questions remain about their use and efficiency. A21.

Oracle Warns on Earnings
Blaming soft sales in Europe and Asia, Oracle said that first-quarter software sales would be on the low end of projections. C4.

A Big Draw for 'The Sopranos'
Powered by an expansive promotional campaign and another wave of laudatory media coverage, the fourth-season premiere of HBO's "The Sopranos," starring James Gandolfini, left, attracted 13.4 million viewers, the most-watched show in the history of the cable channel. The show was the third most-watched show on cable television since 1994. C6.

Vivendi Universal Awaits Financing
Vivendi Universal is expected to receive $1.94 billion in new loans this week from a group of banks, taking it a step closer to shoring up its financing ahead of a board meeting. C6.

Joint Effort to Sell a Building
Bayer has joined forces with several chambers of commerce and economic development groups to turn the sale of its plant in Elkhart, Ind., into a public relations campaign. To a buyer that will bring jobs to town, as long as they are not pharmaceutical industry jobs, the company will sell the whole complex for one dollar. Commercial Real Estate. C8.

HEADLINE: BULLETIN BOARD; 
N.Y.U. Bolsters Economics Faculty

BYLINE:  By Karen W. Arenson 

 BODY:
 New York University has hired THOMAS J. SARGENT, an economic theorist whose work with the Nobel Prize winner ROBERT E. LUCAS Jr. raised questions about the effectiveness of federal economic policy. He joined N.Y.U. this month from Stanford University, but will remain a senior fellow at the Hoover Institution at Stanford. 
At N.Y.U., he will teach graduate students and undergraduates and help shape the graduate program in macroeconomics. 
 Dr. Sargent is one of eight economists N.Y.U. has hired in recent months as it seeks to build its faculty. The others are: JUSHAN BAI from Boston College and XIAOHONG CHEN from the London School of Economics, both in econometrics; JONATHAN EATON from Boston University, who edits The Journal of International Economics; WILLIAM EASTERLY, a specialist in development economics who formerly worked at the World Bank; JOHN LEAHY from Boston University, in the field of economics and psychology; ENNIO STACCHETTI, formerly of the University of Michigan, in dynamic game theory; and GIANLUCA VIOLANTE from University College, London, in macroeconomics and labor markets. Karen W. Arenson

HEADLINE: Paid Notice: Deaths; 
BLANCHARD, ANNE HILL

 BODY:
BLANCHARD-Anne Hill, 48. Of Manhattan and Erwinna, PA., died on September 16, 2002. Beloved wife of Edward Vermont Blanchard Jr. and loving mother of Lydia, Catherine and Cordelia; she was also the cherished daughter of W.T. Hill of Huntsville, AL and devoted sister of Liz Hill of Ann Arbor, MI; Bill Hill and Susan Hill of Huntsville, AL; and James Hill of Mineola, NY. Professor of economics at Queens College and former Chair of the department, Anne was an energetic and tireless advocate for women's education and economic well-being. She was a dedicated Trustee of the American Folk Art Museum and served on the Museum's Executive Committee. A prominent collector, Anne was instrumental in recognizing the work of contemporary self-taught artists and helped shape the burgeoning field of outsider art. Funeral services will be held on Saturday, September 21, 2002 at 11AM at the Church of the Heavenly Rest, 5th Ave at 90th Street. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the American Folk Art Museum, 45 West 53 Street, New York, New York 10019. 
 BLANCHARD-Anne Hill. The Board of Trustees and professional staff of the American Folk Art Museum record with deep sorrow the death of their cherished friend and colleague, Anne Hill Blanchard, for many years a member of the Museum's Board of Trustees and Executive Committee. A person of integrity, conviction and courage, Anne gave of herself unstintingly to the Museum, playing a significant role in the institution's successful efforts to build a new home in the heart of Manhattan, and leaving a lasting legacy of true accomplishment. As chair of the Education Commmittee and as a founder of the Museum's Contemporary Center, she was an inspiring and devoted leader and a dedicated advocate for excellence in all aspects of the institution's service to the public. Possessed of a keen intellect and a generous spirit, Anne embraced life to the fullest, even in the face of serious illness. She will be remembered by us with affection and respect as much for her unfailing kindness and the special quality of her friendship as for her many contributions to the growth and development of the Museum. To Anne's husband and our dear friend, Monty, and to their daughters, Lydia, Catherine and Cordelia, go our most heartfelt condolences. Ralph Esmerian, Chairman L. HEADLINE: China Is Warming To Hollywood's Glow; 
Before Big Profits, Hurdles Remain

BYLINE:  By RICK LYMAN

DATELINE: BEIJING 

 BODY:
At the Da Hua cinema one recent afternoon, on a bustling stretch of Dongchang'an Street near Tiananmen Square, Julia Roberts was barely recognizable in a lacerated print of her 1997 comedy "My Best Friend's Wedding," playing to a sparse crowd of young women and chattering couples.
 "Normally I only go to the cinemas to see something that has a lot of special effects, like 'Star Wars,' " said Qui Alina, 25, who recently left her marketing job with an international candy company and said she hoped to study abroad. "Otherwise I just stay at home and watch the movies on DVD." 
 Nothing stirs Hollywood's covetous soul these days quite so much as the mention of China. With 1.3 billion people and only 5,000 movie screens -- North America, with one-fourth the population, has more than six times as many screens -- China looks to Hollywood much like the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge must look to the oil industry: vast, untapped and potentially fat. But the potential for profit is undercut by the flood of illegal DVD's into Chinese homes. 
Many believe that the recent trickle of Hollywood films into Chinese theaters, along with those illegal DVD's, has played a role in spurring yearnings for accelerated change among ordinary Chinese citizens. Images of prosperous, independent Westerners -- if not explicitly standing up for their rights, at least dressed in cool style and living it up -- might have a fundamental impact on this huge, complex society as it emerges from its cocoon.
"I don't think there is any doubt that Western films have had a fairly large, popular impact," said Nicholas Lardy, an expert on the Chinese economy at the Brookings Institution in Washington. He pointed to obvious changes in everyday dress and slang, as well as to what may be more subtle shifts. But others fear overstating the case.
"To the extent that there are hidden messages in popular culture, that is possible," said Catharin E. Dalpino, another China expert at Brookings. "But the problem with buying this argument is that it will be distilled into saying Hollywood is helping to democratize China. And the truth is, I don't think the Chinese people are relying on Hollywood to help them develop a social conscience."
While signs from China's cloistered film bureaucracy are propitious, no one really knows how quickly officials will allow the country to open more fully to the outside world. But here at the rickety, odorous Da Hua cinema -- where horrible projection washes out the images, and thick humidity bleeds in from the street with every metallic screech of the theater's doors -- once can see the hurdles Hollywood must clear.
The theaters for the most part are decrepit and uncomfortable. And this, mixed with the easy availability of pirated versions of Hollywood films, often on Beijing street corners the week they open in New York, has led many to wonder whether Hollywood, even if it is able to break into this populous market, will be able to wean ordinary Chinese from their cheap-DVD habit.
Hollywood is largely holding back, awaiting signs from Beijing that more films will be allowed into the country, and that investments in infrastructure, like new multiplexes, will be safe and profitable, before beginning the pour in cash and resources.
There are exceptions. Columbia Pictures, for instance, has a Hong Kong subsidiary that makes films directly for the Asian market. The company says it hopes that this gesture will put it in good stead with Chinese authorities once the market truly opens up. And Warner Brothers is in a partnership, still awaiting final government approval, on an up-to-date multiplex in a Shanghai shopping mall, the theory being that more good theaters will create more movie fans, creating more pressure for more Hollywood films to fill them.
The Hollywood films that have done the best in China -- "Pearl Harbor," for instance, or "The Lord of the Rings: The Fellowship of the Ring" -- have been the kind of giant, special-effects blockbusters designed to draw fans like Ms. Qui away from their DVD machines.
Since China has no ratings system for films, meaning that anyone can get in to see anything, Chinese authorities and Hollywood studios have shied away from the kind of overly violent or sexually explicit films that might upset the country's conservative bureaucrats. The closed nature of China's bureaucracy also poses a puzzle. Censorship has not been a huge issue, officials in both countries said, largely because so few Hollywood films are being admitted.
"China is still quite conservative in terms of politics, especially in the film industry," said Zhang Yang, one of China's best known young directors. "The reforms that other industries have seen in recent years are only just beginning to start in the movie industry."
Still, many see signs of fundamental movement. This year the Chinese government doubled its quota of Hollywood films that are allowed to come into the country -- to 20 from 10 a year -- and relaxed rules that awarded one quasi-private company, the China Film Group, an absolute monopoly over the importation and distribution of foreign films. 
Many are waiting to see what comes out of the 16th Communist Party Congress in Beijing on Nov. 8, at which many expect Jiang Zemin to step down as party chief and announce his retirement as president. Which officials emerge from the congress in bigger jobs may well dictate whether the recent reforms will continue and what impact they will have on film, other media and China's cultural future.
"Some of the new leaders are supposedly -- and I put a heavy emphasis on the word supposedly -- more liberal and said to be more pluralistic than their predecessors," Mr. Lardy said. "There is some reason to think they are more interested in recognizing the need for openness."
Jack Valenti, chairman of the Motion Picture Association of America, which represents the major studios, said that he has been heartened by the reforms of recent years but that he felt the future was not yet clear.
"It's a difficult process," he said. "Because they move slowly, and there's so much going on behind the scenes that we don't know about, I don't care how much of an expert you are."
That China will eventually open up its market to Hollywood and other foreign film producers is considered close to a sure thing, partly because China's recent admission to the World Trade Organization creates impetus for it and because China's economic reforms of the last decade create a logic for it. "It's inevitable," said Han Sanping, vice chairman of the China Film Group and president of its Beijing Film Studio.
But how many films will be allowed in? Who will distribute and market them? And who will own the theaters and reap the exhibition profits? These are still questions awaiting answers.
China, which has been energetic about economic reforms in recent years, has been just as energetic in opposing political reforms, which makes movies a tricky topic. As other countries have learned over the years, popular entertainment has a way of bleeding over into politics when you least expect it.
Why Hollywood turns its covetous eye on China is obvious.
"You just have to look at the numbers," said Barbara Robinson, managing director of Columbia Pictures Film Production Asia. "They're humongous."
Mr. Han said he foresaw a day, perhaps five years away, when a swift rise in the number of Chinese cinemas and an increase in the number of Hollywood films shown here would transform Beijing and Shanghai into rivals of London or Frankfurt in providing box-office dollars for Hollywood. "I believe that China will become, before long, the single most important foreign market for Hollywood movies," he said. "After all, in five years there will be 20 million people in Beijing, and the same in Shanghai."
Until about five years ago the only way a foreign distributor could get a movie into China was to sell rights to it -- at a flat rate -- to the China Film Group. Mr. Valenti was instrumental in negotiating the new quota system in which profits on foreign releases are split between the Chinese and the Hollywood studio. Distribution and marketing of films remain firmly in Chinese hands. 
This new system has made studios more eager to get movies into China, but it has not been without problems. "The deal we worked out was that we would split the profits 50-50," Mr. Valenti said. "Unfortunately, by the time you pay all the taxes they lay on you, you only come out with 8 to 12 percent."
"I am not looking for any instant gratification there," Mr. Valenti said. "We're looking three, four or even five years down the road."
Millard Ochs, president of Warner Brothers International Theaters, agreed that the day would come when Shanghai and Beijing will compare with London and other cities in the prevalence and popularity of Hollywood films. But he said Mr. Han and Mr. Valenti were a little optimistic, adding it would take at least 10 years.
Three years ago, when he detected a shift in mood among Chinese officials in favor of closer Hollywood ties, Warner Brothers decided to go into the Chinese multiplex business, Mr. Ochs said. Since Chinese law does not allow a foreign entity to own a majority interest in a movie house, Warner Brothers joined with a Shanghai theater company and a Hong Kong real estate investment concern in a recently opened, nine-screen multiplex in Shanghai. 
If the partnership gets final approval from the Chinese government, Warner says it intends to put its name on the multiplex and perhaps to look into further partnerships elsewhere in China.
Hollywood is also interested in exploiting the production side of the Chinese film industry, where costs are significantly lower than in the United States and most other countries. Columbia Pictures had what for China was a huge hit last year with "Da Wan" ("The Big Shot's Funeral"), a mainstream comedy from the director Feng Xixogang, whose cast included Donald Sutherland and Paul Mazursky.
Most agree it is only a question of time before one of the major Hollywood studios goes into business with the China Film Group or some other entity in a new movie studio somewhere in China. Gareth Wigand, vice chairman of the Columbia TriStar Motion Picture Group, said his was not the only company considering such a move. "It's just too tempting a pasture not to attempt to break in there," he said.
That still leaves the issue of rampant video piracy, which has received most of the international attention in recent years, as Hollywood executives remain convinced that it must be overcome or at least blunted before they can expect to make significant inroads in China.
Tickets to that afternoon screening of the Julia Roberts comedy at the Da Hua cost about $2.44, compared to $3.05 for more recent blockbusters like "Spider-Man" and $7.34 that some of the handful of new multiplexes have been able to charge for some new releases.
All fairly cheap by United States standards, but a lot more than the roughly 85 cents it costs to buy a pirated DVD of the same films. "In China, the concept of the movie is that it is something that you watch on TV," said Ciu Jian, China's first Western-style rock star and one of the country's most recognizable pop figures.
That's the dilemma. Like Ms. Qui, most Chinese movie lovers satisfy their desires at home and only occasionally are tempted to the theater.
"It's not that people don't want to go out to the movies," said Jiang Wen, one of the country's most celebrated directors and actors. "It's simply that the cinemas are so bad. Too often the seats smell like the toilet, and the lobbies are dirty. Some say, why will people pay for cinema when they can watch cheaper DVD's at home? But I say, everyone has a kitchen at home, yet there are still many restaurants."
Mr. Jiang's most recent film, "Devil At My Doorstep," won the grand prize at the Cannes Film Festival in 2000. But he fell afoul of the Chinese government by not seeking its permission to take the film to the festival. As a result it has never been released in China, and Mr. Jiang did not work. Now, however, he is at work again on a new project, perhaps one more indication that film strictures are loosening.
"It's a country of intrigue, excitement and caution, all at the same time," Mr. Ochs said. "It has not opened up as quickly as we'd hoped, but certainly moved further than it was a few years ago."

CORRECTION-DATE: September 20, 2002

 CORRECTION:
An article in The Arts on Wednesday about Hollywood's hope for more profits in China misstated the English title for a film by the director Jiang Wen, who was quoted as saying that deplorable conditions in movie houses were one reason people preferred to watch pirated DVD's. The film is "Devils on the Doorstep," not "Devil at My Doorstep."

HEADLINE: Iraq, Upside Down 

BYLINE:  By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN 

 BODY:
Recently, I've had the chance to travel around the country and do some call-in radio shows, during which the question of Iraq has come up often. And here's what I can report from a totally unscientific sample: Don't believe the polls that a majority of Americans favor a military strike against Iraq. It's just not true.
 It's also not true that the public is solidly against taking on Saddam Hussein. What is true is that most Americans are perplexed. The most oft-asked question I heard was some variation of: "How come all of a sudden we have to launch a war against Saddam? I realize that he's thumbed his nose at the U.N., and he has dangerous weapons, but he's never threatened us, and, if he does, couldn't we just vaporize him? What worries me are Osama and the terrorists still out there." 
 That's where I think most Americans are at. Deep down they believe that Saddam is "deterrable." That is, he does not threaten the U.S. and he never has, because he has been deterred the way Russia, China and North Korea have been. He knows that if he even hints at threatening us, we will destroy him. Saddam has always been homicidal, not suicidal. Indeed, he has spent a lifetime perfecting the art of survival -- because he loves life more than he hates us.
No, what worries Americans are not the deterrables like Saddam. What worries them are the "undeterrables" -- the kind of young Arab-Muslim men who hit us on 9/11, and are still lurking. Americans would pay virtually any price to eliminate the threat from the undeterrables -- the terrorists who hate us more than they love their own lives, and therefore cannot be deterred.
I share this view, which is why I think the Iraq debate is upside down. Most strategists insist that the reason we must go into Iraq -- and the only reason -- is to get rid of its weapons of mass destruction, not regime change and democracy building. I disagree.
I think the chances of Saddam being willing, or able, to use a weapon of mass destruction against us are being exaggerated. What terrifies me is the prospect of another 9/11 -- in my mall, in my airport or in my downtown -- triggered by angry young Muslims, motivated by some pseudo-religious radicalism cooked up in a mosque in Saudi Arabia, Egypt or Pakistan. And I believe that the only way to begin defusing that threat is by changing the context in which these young men grow up -- namely all the Arab-Muslim states that are failing at modernity and have become an engine for producing undeterrables.
So I am for invading Iraq only if we think that doing so can bring about regime change and democratization. Because what the Arab world desperately needs is a model that works -- a progressive Arab regime that by its sheer existence would create pressure and inspiration for gradual democratization and modernization around the region.
I have no illusions about how difficult it would be to democratize a fractious Iraq. It would be a huge, long, costly task -- if it is doable at all, and I am not embarrassed to say that I don't know if it is. All I know is that it's the most important task worth doing and worth debating. Because only by helping the Arabs gradually change their context -- a context now dominated by anti-democratic regimes and anti-modernist religious leaders and educators -- are we going to break the engine that is producing one generation after another of undeterrables.
These undeterrables are young men who are full of rage, because they are raised with a view of Islam as the most perfect form of monotheism, but they look around their home countries and see widespread poverty, ignorance and repression. And they are humiliated by it, humiliated by the contrast with the West and how it makes them feel, and it is this humiliation -- this poverty of dignity -- that drives them to suicidal revenge. The quest for dignity is a powerful force in human relations.
Closing that dignity gap is a decades-long project. We can help, but it can succeed only if people there have the will. But maybe that's what we're starting to see. Look at how Palestinian legislators just voted no confidence in Arafat; look at how some courageous Arab thinkers produced an Arab Human Development Report, which declared that the Arab-Muslim world was backward because of its deficits of freedom, modern education and women's empowerment.
If we don't find some way to help these countries reverse these deficits now -- while access to smaller and smaller nuclear weapons is still limited -- their young, angry undeterrables will blow us up long before Saddam ever does.

HEADLINE: Best Buy Net Down as Spending Slows 

BYLINE:  AP 

DATELINE: EDEN PRAIRIE, Minn., Sept. 17 

 BODY:
The Best Buy Company said today that its second-quarter earnings fell 27 percent because of a slowdown in consumer spending since July, particularly in recorded music and home office products.
 The results, however, beat Wall Street expectations, revised last month after the company warned of lower profits because of lagging sales. 
 Best Buy, which is the nation's largest consumer electronics chain, earned $62 million, or 19 cents a share, in the quarter, which ended Aug. 31, down from $85 million, or 26 cents a share, a year earlier.
Second-quarter sales rose 20 percent, to $5.01 billion from $4.16 billion a year earlier, reflecting the addition of 88 new stores over the last year and the inclusion of sales from 100 Future Shop stores.
"This earnings decrease reflects the significant slowdown in comparable-store sales gains since July," Brad Anderson, the chief executive, said.
As a result, Mr. Anderson said, Best Buy is delaying some of its investments in higher-end home technology. The company, which is based in Eden Prairie, has also set aside, for the time being, any plans for international expansion and does not expect any major acquisitions within the next 18 months.

HEADLINE: Work Begins on Oil Pipeline Bypassing Russia and Iran 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD ALLEN GREENE 

DATELINE: BAKU, Azerbaijan, Sept. 18 

 BODY:
Construction formally began today on a new pipeline to carry oil from the Caspian Sea to the Mediterranean coast of Turkey, bypassing Russia and Iran. 
 Huge reserves of oil and gas are believed to be recoverable in the Caspian basin, but exploitation of them has been limited in part by the difficult logistics and the difficult politics of transporting the output to Western markets. The new pipeline, to be built and operated by a consortium led by BP, is expected to begin carrying 375,000 barrels of oil a day by early 2005 and 1 million barrels a day by 2007. 
 Presidents of the three countries crossed by the 1,094-mile pipeline -- Azerbaijan, Georgia and Turkey -- took part in a groundbreaking ceremony for the pipeline today, as did the United States energy secretary, Spencer Abraham. The United States has been a major proponent of the project. 
Mr. Abraham said at the ceremony that the pipeline would give Western nations "greater energy security with a diversified supply" of oil that depends less on the Middle East. He read a letter from President Bush, who called the project "an essential component of an East-West energy corridor."
Azerbaijan's president, Geidar Aliyev, said the pipeline could "become a guarantor of peace, stability and security in the Caucasus."
Critics have said that the logic behind the pipeline is geopolitical, not economic. The southern end of the Caspian, near Baku, is not where the most promising energy reserves have been found, and some analysts doubt that the pipeline can be viable if world oil prices fall much below $20 a barrel. 
But Julian Lee, an analyst at the Center for Global Energy Studies in London, said the pipeline would nonetheless play a significant role in the market. 
By itself, Mr. Lee said, Azerbaijan's expected output of 850,000 to 1 million barrels a day "is not a huge amount." But in the context of world demand, which is growing annually by only 100,000 barrels a day, "this looks more significant," he said. 
Even relatively modest amounts of new oil reaching world markets from the Caspian could affect how the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries sets it production levels, said Akbar Noman, the head of the World Bank office in Baku, because it "might make OPEC countries feel that their bargaining position has been weakened."
"If there are major new discoveries in the Caspian," he added, "it could have a significant effect."
Experts disagree on just how much oil the Caspian contains, and to whom it belongs. The five nations that border the sea -- Azerbaijan, Iran, Kazakhstan, Russia and Turkmenistan -- have disputed their maritime boundaries for years, and the offshore exploration that has been done lately in undisputed Azerbaijani waters has tended to yield disappointing results.
Kazakhstan has had better luck, and its territory may include 70 percent of the sea's total reserves by some estimates. Some experts say the Baku-Ceyhan pipeline can prosper by attracting shipments of Kazakh oil. But the Kazakh fields are hundreds of miles from Baku, and they have alternative shipping routes that may prove cheaper, including a new pipeline to Novorossiysk on Russia's Black Sea coast.
Still, Ahmet Necdet Sezer, the president of Turkey, urged Kazakhstan to join the project in his remarks at the groundbreaking ceremony, held at the Sangachal oil terminal 25 miles south of Baku. A crane lowered a symbolic first section of pipe into place, and Mr. Sezer, Mr. Abraham, Mr. Aliyev and Georgia's president, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, each shoveled some earth to help bury a time capsule containing a message from the three presidents. The event was broadcast on Azeri television.
BP, as lead partner, owns 35 percent of the $2.9 billion pipeline project. Azerbaijan's national oil company, Socar, has the next largest stake at 25 percent. Other partners include Statoil of Norway, Unocal and Amerada Hess of the United States, TPAO of Turkey, Eni of Italy, TotalFinaElf of France and Itochu and Impex of Japan.
A gas pipeline is also planned for the route, with an Iranian company, OIEC, as a minor partner.

HEADLINE: AT HOME WITH: Frederic Schwartz; 
The Man Who Dared the City To Think Again

BYLINE:  By ALASTAIR GORDON 

 BODY:
FREDERIC SCHWARTZ flinched at a flash of light outside the window of his architecture studio in SoHo. "Did you see that? It's an airplane," he said, pointing at the fuselage of a commercial jet banking harmlessly over the Hudson River.
 Mr. Schwartz is unusually sensitive to subtle shifts in light and sound, and with good reason. "I was getting ready to go to work when the first plane flew over my loft," he said. "I called 911 before it even hit, or at least that's how I remember it. It just sounded wrong -- out of place, like a missile." He ran to the corner of Church and Canal Streets in time to watch the towers collapse. 
 Mr. Schwartz then did what came naturally: he began to draw, sketching quickly with colored pens on scraps of paper, restaurant tabs and napkins. On the back of a cardboard coaster he sketched the towers engulfed by black clouds. "I kept drawing horrible things," he said. "I drew what I saw." 
Within weeks, the nightmarish imagery had subsided, replaced by Mr. Schwartz's first glimmerings of how Lower Manhattan might be reorganized and restored. "I started to redraw the skyline. I started to draw what should happen," he said.
Those impromptu drawings were the conceptual seeds of a master plan for downtown redevelopment -- a plan that was published earlier this month in The New York Times Magazine and is now displayed in Venice at the Eighth International Architecture Exhibition at the Biennale. It was drafted as an alternative to the official versions unveiled in July by the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation, which met with tepid public response. 
Under Mr. Schwartz's proposed design, the 16-acre void at ground zero would be left alone, permitting a respectful period of reflection before a permanent memorial can be agreed upon. He would instead bury part of West Street, the forbidding multi-lane state highway, in a tunnel running north from Battery Park to Chambers Street, and build on the reclaimed land on top. He envisions a series of parks and buildings linked by a tree-lined promenade that would reconnect Battery Park City with the old city grid. "People were thinking of West Street physically but not metaphysically. Is that the right word?" Mr. Schwartz said. "They weren't thinking that you could do two things at once."
While Mr. Schwartz's plan has no official standing, it has stirred debate by injecting imagination into the proceedings and showing how aspirational design could help repair the city.
"His presentation stood out from so many others," said Jordan Gruzen, a member of New York New Visions, an advocacy group of architects and planners formed after Sept. 11. "Now everyone else has taken this point of view, and every scheme that comes forward deals with West Street."
After living in SoHo for 22 years, Mr. Schwartz, 50, has an intimate feel for Lower Manhattan. "I walk and look and Rollerblade on all those streets," he said. "I know the buildings and I know what's going on inside them."
He owns a ground-floor loft in a 19th-century cast-iron building in SoHo, where he lives with his girlfriend, Tracey Hummer, an editor at Art in America magazine. 
The loft formerly belonged to his friend, the architect Alan Buchsbaum, who helped popularize the loft look of the early 80's and designed loft conversions for Bette Midler, Diane Keaton and Billy Joel. Mr. Buchsbaum died of AIDS in 1987; Mr. Schwartz moved in a year later. Aside from a new shower mosaic depicting an underwater scene, Mr. Schwartz has changed almost nothing; he wanted to preserve the high-tech style that was Mr. Buchsbaum's signature. "Living here makes me remember Alan all the time and how talented he was," Mr. Schwartz said. 
The loft is furnished with an eclectic mix of furniture by Mr. Buchsbaum, Frank Gehry, Robert Venturi and Mr. Schwartz's own designs, including a chair from 1985 in the shape of a house. (Mr. Schwartz has edited a book about his friend's work, "Alan Buchsbaum, Architect and Designer: The Mechanics of Taste," Monacelli Press, 1996.)
"He was the master of loft design," Mr. Schwartz said. "He was like the older brother I never had." 
The loft's ceilings are stamped tin from the late 19th century, and old beams and columns have been stripped to expose original timber. Industrial light fixtures, a mainstay of Mr. Buchsbaum's high-tech style, hang in the kitchen and living area. "I feel it's timeless," Mr. Schwartz said. "That's why I can't change it, because it's not getting old." One of Mr. Buchsbaum's few eccentric touches is an amorphously shaped hot tub. 
"I love my loft, but I don't live at home," Mr. Schwartz said. "I live at my office nowadays." Mr. Schwartz starts his mornings at about 8 at the Westside Coffee Shop on Church Street where he greets the proprietor, Johnny Morillo, with a high five. "I drink a triple shot of cafe con leche -- rocket fuel -- to get me going," he said. Then he walks to his studio, eight blocks north on Varick Street. "I have a wonderful walk through SoHo every morning, and I'm always aware of the empty sky." he said.
Mr. Schwartz's studio, on the 15th floor of a former printing plant, has expansive views of SoHo and, to the south, ground zero. "When you have this incredible panorama of the city you are more aware of what's missing," Mr. Schwartz said. "When you also happen to be an architect, you're hypersensitive to what's not there."
Mr. Schwartz has worked on New York City projects since 1978, including eight years with the firm of Venturi, Rauch & Scott Brown on Westway, the contentious plan to build a 100-acre park on the West Side. The project was never built, but Mr. Schwartz received an invaluable lesson. "Westway taught me the importance of working with the community," he said. "We had to listen to the needs of different neighborhoods, including TriBeCa, Chelsea and the West Village."
Since opening his own firm in 1996, Mr. Schwartz has designed dozens of New York projects, including the Whitehall Ferry Terminal now under construction. "I grew up going on that ferry to Staten Island to visit the grave of my great-grandfather," he said. His commercial projects include the offices of Rolling Stone magazine, Joe's Restaurant in Greenwich Village and the offices of Deutsch, an advertising firm based in Chelsea. 
Mr. Schwartz has no official planning role, but he has managed to insinuate himself into the redevelopment process by becoming a regular presence at public hearings. Many days he would attend a development corporation meeting at 8 a.m. and then, in the evening, go to a community board meeting. "It started to get insane," he said. "I'd go to meeting after meeting." He would listen patiently before taking the floor to remind the assembled that the objective was to create a plan that would include all of Lower Manhattan, not just ground zero. "Sometimes, I would go ballistic," he said. "I would say: 'Don't you get it? If you keep thinking about the site, you're stuck.' " 
While Mr. Schwartz does not have an official title, his persistence has paid off. In April he presented his ideas to Amanda Burden, chairwoman of the City Planning Commission. He also showed his plan to the Battery Park City Authority and to Alexander Garvin, head of planning and design at the development corporation. "He's tenacious," said Nancy Owens, a chairman of the land use committee of Community Board 1.
In July, Mr. Schwartz began meeting with a group of other architects dissatisfied with the development corporation's six designs. "He unrolled these drawings, and we all realized that he had done a tremendous amount of research," said Charles Gwathmey, one of the participating architects. "It was the one thing that we all universally agreed on. The West Street move clarified the opportunities and de-obligated one from having to deal with the 16 acres of the World Trade Center." 
Rafael Vinoly, another collaborating architect, said: "Fred's plan removed the limitations on the thinking process." 
Two weeks before his plan was published, Mr. Schwartz entered the Ear Inn on Spring Street, a favorite neighborhood spot.
A waitress nodded in recognition as he took a seat at a back table. "I live here in the city, and I made it my mission to understand," he said, drawing a quick sketch on a paper napkin. "Urban planning has to find a way to make it all work together."
Mr. Schwartz continues to refine his ideas and has begun to focus his attention on what might be done with ground zero itself. "This is different than other memorials," he said. "You have to have bigger ideas. You're dealing with heaven and hell."

HEADLINE: Low Prices Threaten Coffee Farmers' Livelihood, Report Says 

BYLINE:  By TIM WEINER 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Sept. 18 

 BODY:
Global economic forces are crushing millions of coffee farmers around the world, the British charity Oxfam said in a report released today.
 In Latin America, Africa and Asia, farmers are paid roughly 24 cents a pound for their beans, which may be the lowest price in a century, the report said. 
 Four multinational companies -- Kraft, Sara Lee, Procter & Gamble and Nestle -- buy nearly half the world's coffee and sell it for an average of $3.60 a pound, the report said. People in New York, Paris and Tokyo may pay almost that much for a single cup. 
The value of coffee exports has fallen by $4 billion since 1997 as supplies glut a market that was once regulated and is now free. Farmers in places like Mexico, Nicaragua and Guatemala are penniless and starving while "the coffee companies are laughing all the way to the bank," the report said. 
"Asking some of the poorest and most powerless people in the world to negotiate in an open market with some of the richest and most powerful results, unsurprisingly, in the rich getting richer and the poor getting poorer," the Oxfam report said. 
Oxfam timed the release of its report to coincide with the opening of a five-day meeting of the International Coffee Organization, in London, on Thursday. The organization has a plan to cut the coffee glut by barring export of the lowest-quality beans.
Oxfam will ask members of the group -- 40 major coffee importers and exporters -- to agree to destroy about 660 million pounds of the lowest-quality coffee sitting in the world's warehouses, a move that would cost about $100 million.
An economic analysis conducted for the International Coffee Organization said destruction would raise prices paid to coffee-producing nations by roughly $750 million and, Oxfam suggested, perhaps save some lives among the rural growers. 
The four corporations cited by Oxfam each said, in varying ways, that as buyers they were well aware of the crisis among coffee growers. But Kraft says it is "fundamentally opposed to any scheme that intervenes on price." Sara Lee says it is "uneasy about price support." Procter & Gamble says it wants "to help address the underlaying social and economic issues" -- but not through the International Coffee Organization.
Nestle, alone among the four, says it supports a price-control scheme led by the coffee organization. "Nestle is against low prices as they are not only bad for farmers, but also bad for Nestle's business," the corporation said. 
Fair Trade coffee, the response of an international movement that helps businesses buy directly from rural coffee cooperatives, eliminating the corporate middleman and paying farmers double or more the market price, is a growing alternative. Fair Trade coffee now represents about 2 percent of the world market. In the United States, such coffee is sold at about 10,000 retail outlets; sales grew 36 percent last year.
But without a worldwide plan to raise prices paid to farmers and give them new alternatives to old ways, Oxfam said, the livelihoods of millions are at risk.
"The coffee market is failing," the report said. "It is failing producers on small family farms for whom coffee used to make money. It is failing local exporters and entrepreneurs who are going to the wall in the face of fierce international competition. And it is failing governments that had encouraged coffee production to increase export earnings."

PERSON: David D. Rodriguez 

HEADLINE: PUBLIC LIVES; 
Enhancing the 'Brand Name' of the Revered Apollo

BYLINE:  By LYNDA RICHARDSON 

 BODY:
DAVID D. RODRIGUEZ, the executive director of the Apollo Theater Foundation, does not get easily worked up. He is as smooth and steady as the jazz notes that drift from the bass that he sometimes plays as a sideman on stage.
 On a recent morning, Mr. Rodriguez, who even performed at the Apollo before taking his current job, is leaning back in his sparse office in the theater on West 125th Street. An amiable man with roundish build and graying hair, he is fielding questions about news about the historic theater. There has been a lot of it lately. 
 A week ago, it was reported that the Apollo was holding off plans for a performing arts center that was to have been centered on the theater, with foundation executives citing a poor economic climate. The postponement prompted the foundation's president and chief executive, Derek Q. Johnson, a former senior vice president at AOL Time Warner, to resign.
Mr. Rodriguez, 40, is temporarily filling in for Mr. Johnson, adding real estate duties to a palette that includes theater operations and artistic direction.
Under Mr. Rodriguez's watch, the theater's programming has become more ambitious. There's 9 to 12 shows a week, including the well-received George C. Wolfe revue "Harlem Song" and the televised amateur talent show "It's Showtime at the Apollo," which has a new Emmy-award-winning producer. This fall, the talent show goes on a 40-city tour. In March, the theater is to feature the Royal Shakespeare Company's production of Salman Rushdie's allegorical novel "Midnight's Children," sponsored by Columbia University and the University of Michigan.
So, he's asked, what's up with the performing arts center? Is raising money a problem?
"I don't see what we're going through as being a problem whatsoever," he says. "In a sense, right now, we are taking a cautious, reasonable approach. Our overall goal here at the Apollo has been, 'How do we expand the programs and extend the Apollo?' It's an incredible brand name."
"We're not here to do real estate development. We're trying to enhance the brand name of the Apollo, not just throughout the country but the world."
Mr. Rodriguez leans over to offer a muffin and coffee, but he won't offer up more about the center, which was to encompass the Victoria Theater to the east of the Apollo and an empty lot to the west.
For now, he says, the Apollo is fixing up its own house. A $53 million restoration of the 1,500-seat theater is under way, with the first phase scheduled for completion this spring.
Mr. Rodriguez gives a quick tour, stepping onto the new stage and sweeping a hand out over the house.
"Before the renovation, people would walk in and the lighting wasn't up to snuff and there were holes in the carpet and they'd say, 'It's O.K. in Harlem," he says. "It makes your heart want to drop, this perpetual state of lower expectations. When you come to Harlem, you should expect the best."
Mr. Rodriguez is respected as an arts director who sees the link between the arts and the development of neighborhoods. He's also a Latino running a theater that is an revered African-American institution. But Mr. Rodriguez, who is Puerto Rican and Spanish, says his heritage has not been an issue.
Since his arrival early last year, the theater has initiated programs like Latin Nites, with a Chilean rock band opening the concert series this year. He says the expanded music menu has been well received, adding that it's not as if the Apollo's traditional array of music has been shoved aside.
KEEP in mind, the theater was completely underutilized, and what people want to see, more than anything, is the Apollo alive and functioning," he says. "An Apollo that is alive and active has a positive effect. Whether that is sharing the stage with our Latino brothers and sisters or artists such as David Byrne, associated with Midtown audiences, or Mary J. Blige, a mainstay of the Apollo, it all contributes to the whole."
"I think we want to make this a very inclusive place. The Apollo represents all of Harlem, as we see it, and represents urban communities across the country."
Before the Apollo, Mr. Rodriguez was the executive director of the John Harms Center for the Arts in Englewood, N.J., for three years. He is divorced and lives there with his girlfriend, a nurse-anesthetist. He grew up in Fanwood, N.J. His father sold maritime insurance and his mother taught children with learning disabilities.
But he has a Harlem history. For seven years, he was executive director at Aaron Davis Hall, at Convent Avenue and 135th Street. He previously managed development at the Queens Museum and the Intar Hispanic American Arts Center in Midtown Manhattan, where he generated support for Hispanic music and theater.
Mr. Rodriguez says his musical passion came from family visits to Spain, where his paternal grandfather lived. A barber there taught him to play classical guitar. He later studied bass at the Eastman School of Music in Rochester and Mansfield University in Pennsylvania.
"One of my teachers told me that everyone needs a bass player, and that appealed to the practical side of me initially, and then I saw it was a supportive thing," he says. "There was real value in supporting the solo musician or others, and that's probably one of the reasons I got to be an arts administrator. I thought having one of us on the other side of the fence would be a good thing for the field."

HEADLINE: THREATS AND RESPONSES: QAEDA'S BANKROLLS; 
Front Companies Said to Keep Financing Terrorists

BYLINE:  By DOUGLAS FRANTZ 

DATELINE: ISTANBUL, Sept. 18 

 BODY:
Hundreds of companies worldwide form a shadow network capable of providing money and logistical support for continued attacks by Al Qaeda and other loosely connected militants, investigators and financial regulators in Europe and the United States say. 
 A United Nations report this month concluded that Al Qaeda remained a threat partly because it retained access to between $30 million and $300 million controlled by ostensibly legitimate businesses associated with the terror network. Many of these suspected front companies, it said, are in countries with few regulations and can pack up and disappear overnight. 
 "The real problem for the Americans is not freezing bank accounts," a Swiss banking regulator said in a recent interview in Zurich. "The bigger challenge is stopping the unknown number of apparently legitimate businesses set up to move money around the globe to terrorists." 
Nearly a year after Al Qaeda's base of operations in Afghanistan was destroyed, efforts to disrupt the flow of money to its remaining operatives in other parts of the world have become one of the primary goals of the United States and its allies. So far, the results have been mixed. 
One instance of the elusive nature of Qaeda front companies is Maram, set up in Istanbul as a travel agency and import-export business by three men described by American investigators as Qaeda associates. 
The investigators said in recent interviews that they suspected that the company had provided money and other assistance to Qaeda operatives traveling between Europe and Afghanistan and might have been involved in efforts to obtain material for nuclear weapons. 
But after one of its principals, Mamdouh Mahmud Salim, was arrested on a trip to Germany and extradited to New York on terrorism charges in 1998, the company cleaned out its offices overnight and disappeared. 
Counterterrorism experts in Europe and the United States also said Islamic charities continued to disburse funds to militants. The United Nations says governments are having a particularly difficult time regulating and monitoring the millions of dollars paid out by the charities. 
In the latest instance of a possible connection between charities and militants, the Dutch newspaper Eindhovens Dagblad reported last week that the security police were investigating financial links between a Saudi-financed mosque in the southern Dutch city of Eindhoven and members of the group from Hamburg, Germany, that was involved in the Sept. 11 attacks. 
The United Nations report said the terror network was "alive and well," with access to considerable money. Senior American officials disagreed, saying arrests in Europe, Southeast Asia and elsewhere and the freezing of $112 million in suspected terrorist money had weakened the organization. 
Stopping the money flow is the best way to stop terrorism, said David Aufhauser, the general counsel at the Treasury Department and the chief of an interagency task force on terrorist financing. 
"Much of the intelligence war is, in fact, suspect -- the product of treachery, deceit, custodial interrogation, bribery and encrypted talk," Mr. Aufhauser said at an international symposium on economic crime in Cambridge, England, last week. "But audit trails do not lie. They are diaries of terror." 
Not every transaction leaves an audit trail, however, and some experts question whether the money can be stopped, given the myriad means of transferring cash around the world. Much of the terror network's wealth has been shifted beyond the reach of banks, according to the European intelligence authorities and bank regulators. 
Valentin Roschacher, the attorney general of Switzerland, said the consensus of officials in all major European banking states was that Al Qaeda had protected most of its assets by shifting from cash to diamonds and gold before the Sept. 11 strikes in the United States. 
"They are able to function, and we believe they still have enough money to possibly carry out other attacks," Mr. Roschacher told reporters recently in Washington. 
Nikos Passos, a professor at Temple University and a consultant to the Treasury Department on illegal money transfers, said, "The chief parallel aim should be to stop the terrorists, because the financing system cannot be completely controlled." 
The Turkish business linked to Al Qaeda offers a lesson in the difficulty of monitoring seemingly legitimate enterprises. 
Mr. Salim, a Sudanese engineer and longtime associate of Osama bin Laden, set up the company in Istanbul in November 1996 at a time when Al Qaeda was expanding its financial reach from Afghanistan and Sudan into Europe. In the incorporation statement filed with the Turkish authorities, Mr. Salim said Maram would be involved in travel and in imports and exports. 
American investigators and prosecutors said Mr. Salim, 44, had a history of moving money and shopping for weapons for Al Qaeda. In 1994, he was involved in an attempt to buy nuclear material and in later efforts to develop chemical weapons, according to testimony last year at the trial of other suspects in the 1998 bombings of the American Embassies in Kenya and Tanzania. 
Mr. Salim is awaiting trial in New York on charges related to his suspected role in the embassy bombings. 
A few months after Mr. Salim created Maram, records show that he transferred shares in the company to two other men identified by the American authorities as Qaeda members. 
One was Wael Hamza Jalaidan, 44, a Saudi businessman described by the American authorities as a founding member of Al Qaeda. Earlier this month, the governments of the United States and Saudi Arabia jointly designated Mr. Jalaidan as a financial supporter of Al Qaeda, meaning his assets will be frozen. 
Mr. Jalaidan is on the board of the Rabita Trust, a Pakistan-based charity accused by the United States of providing logistical and financial support to Al Qaeda. 
Attempts to reach Mr. Jalaidan were unsuccessful. The Saudi press has reported that he issued a statement last year saying he cut all ties with Mr. bin Laden in 1992. 
A senior American government official said that Mr. Jalaidan was in Saudi Arabia and that Saudi officials knew his location, though he was not believed to be in custody. 
The other partner in Maram was Muhammad Bayazied, 42, a Sudanese also involved in setting up businesses for Mr. bin Laden, according to testimony at the New York trial. He also took part with Mr. Salim in the attempt to buy nuclear material and handled substantial amounts of cash, Jamal Ahmed al-Fadl, a former Qaeda member now cooperating with the government, testified. 
A senior American official in the region said Mr. Bayazied once lived in the United States and was believed to be an expert in explosives and chemical weapons. 
By the mid-1990's, Istanbul had become a frequent transit point for Qaeda operatives traveling between Afghanistan, Sudan and Europe, the American and European intelligence authorities say. The German police said one suspected Qaeda recruiter, Muhammad Heidar Zammar, passed through the Istanbul 40 times traveling between Europe and Afghanistan. 
The senior American official in the region said that Maram was suspected of making travel arrangements for Qaeda operatives and that there were strong suspicions that Mr. Salim and Mr. Bayazied continued their efforts to buy components for nuclear weapons. 
"We don't know what they were doing for sure," the official said. "They were up to no good, but we don't have any details." 
The suspicions that they may have been trying to buy nuclear components were buttressed by a Turkish accountant, Yavuz Subasi, who handled Maram's books. 
Mr. Subasi said that the company had no real business transactions, but that Mr. Salim had traveled extensively in Russia, Romania and Bulgaria, countries where the authorities say nuclear material is sometimes available on the black market. 
Mr. Salim and Mr. Bayazied lived in Istanbul with their families on and off for at least two years, but they never attracted any notice from the Turkish authorities. Neighbors said the men kept to themselves, though they said there were many visitors to their apartments who appeared to be Arab. 
In September 1998, Mr. Salim was arrested in Germany at the request of American prosecutors and extradited to the United States. Within days, Maram's tiny office in a huge anonymous office building in Istanbul was cleared out. 
"I just came one morning and saw the office was empty," said Ahmet Evgin, who runs a small restaurant nearby. "Nobody knows what happens." 
By the time the security police came around asking questions a few months ago, he and other former neighbors said, there were no traces of what might have been an important cog in the Qaeda financial machinery.
