HEADLINE: Daschle Sharply Attacks Bush's Economic Policies 

BYLINE:  By ALISON MITCHELL 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 

 BODY:
The Senate majority leader offered a blistering assessment of President Bush's fiscal policies today, citing two million lost jobs, weak economic growth and a stock market decline that he called unparalleled since Herbert Hoover.
 The senator, Tom Daschle of South Dakota, made his critique of an economic record he termed "tragic, deplorable, abysmal" in a lengthy speech on the Senate floor a day after he put his support behind Mr. Bush's effort to win Congressional authorization to use force in Iraq. 
 Democrats called the address the beginning of a partywide effort to turn attention away from Iraq and back to the domestic agenda in the final weeks heading into the mid-term elections that will determine control of the House and Senate. 
In a sign that budget fights and deficits are likely to shadow domestic politics for a long time to come, Mitchell E. Daniels Jr., director of the White House's Office of Management and Budget, separately told reporters today that federal revenues were dropping even more than the administration had expected.
Mr. Daschle pointed today to job losses across the last 18 months, meager economic growth of 1 percent, the stock market decline, and the return to federal deficits even though Mr. Bush entered office with a projected surplus of $5.6 trillion.
"There's a story, a life story behind every one of those numbers," Mr. Daschle said, noting that the number of long-term unemployed had more than doubled to nearly 1.5 million people.
Of the stock market drop he said, "You have to go all the way back to Herbert Hoover to see a performance in the Standard & Poor's 500 equal to what we are experiencing right now." 
He strongly implied that the president had become all-consumed with events overseas. "As busy as we are and as important as the war on Iraq is," Mr. Daschle said, "I hope this administration will dedicate some of its time each week to economic security as well, to these declining numbers, to this atrocious record."
Republicans promptly countered with an orchestrated barrage of criticism, noting that Mr. Daschle had proposed no solutions and that the Senate under his leadership had been unable to produce a budget for the first time in years.
Mr. Daniels said of Mr. Daschle's speech, "It was a disappointing and dispiriting performance; I'm tempted to say a tantrum."
Representative Tom DeLay of Texas, the House majority whip, said the speech was "driven by political greed, not the public good."
"People are hurting," Mr. DeLay said, "but Democrats are extending America's economic misery by refusing to move the president's agenda."
Mr. Daschle's speech, in a way, brought his party full circle in what has been an unpredictable political year. He opened the year with a similar assault on the president's fiscal stewardship, saying Republicans had caused the "most dramatic fiscal deterioration in our nation's history" by enacting Mr. Bush's major tax cut. But with Democrats divided he stopped short of calling for a rollback of the tax cut.
Today's speech telegraphed some of the final dynamics of the fall campaign in which the parties are in a bitter struggle for control of the Senate, with several races virtually tied.
Republicans are hitching themselves to Mr. Bush's high wartime approval ratings and to his record of fighting terror and threats overseas. Democrats, after three weeks of disarray over how to respond to the president on Iraq, are trying to turn attention to a different kind of security, economic security.
Terry McAuliffe, the chairman of the Democratic National Committee, said today that Congress would vote on an Iraq resolution "very quickly" and the return to the "kitchen table issues" that he asserted would turn the election.
Mr. McAuliffe said the party was advising its candidates to focus on three dates when the economy is going to be an issue: Sept. 30, when voters will start to receive revised 401(k) statements for the third quarter; and Oct. 4 and Nov. 1, when the government releases the unemployment rate.
Mr. Daschle today once again criticized the president's $1.35 trillion 10-year tax cut, but once again he did not call for it to be delayed or altered.
"What is the president's solution?" he asked after setting out the economic trends. "They have one economic, all-purpose antidote to everything, and that is tax cuts, tax cuts largely dedicated to those at the very top. The only thing I have seen the Bush administration fail to suggest a tax cut for, so far, is the drought."
He went on to use a chart showing that while people earning an average $9,300 a year received an average annual tax cut of $66, the top 1 percent of Americans earning more than $1 million would get a $53,1234 annual tax cut.
Speaker J. Dennis Hastert, Republican of Illinois, promptly accused Mr. Daschle of wanting to "increase taxes to pay for more spending."
The sparring over fiscal policy is likely to become more heated as revenues continue to decline below projections.
The administration estimated this summer that the budget deficit for the fiscal year that ends Sept. 30 would be $165 billion. 
Mr. Daniels said today that the final figure would still be close to that because the revenue shortfall would be largely offset by slightly lower-than-anticipated federal spending. He said the revenue shortfall would be in the "low two figures" of billions, meaning at least $10 billion.
Mr. Daniels said the revenue trend, combined with the costs of fighting inflation and perhaps waging a war in Iraq, increased the pressure on Congress to hold down spending.
With Congress unlikely to pass all the spending bills needed to keep the government running after the end of the fiscal year, Mr. Daniels said the president would agree to stopgap funding measures for the rest of the government only if Congress first passed the spending bill for the military.
He said the administration would reject possible bipartisan efforts on Capitol Hill to attach $6 billion in drought aid for farmers to the stop-gap measures.
Mr. Daniels suggested that the combination of growing fiscal pressure and a lack of time on the Congressional calendar meant it was unlikely that Mr. Bush would press ahead with a new package of tax cuts for investors before the Congressional elections.
Mr. Daniels also said that because government revenues had fallen far short of official projections for the last several years, the administration was going to change the economic model the Treasury Department used to predict tax receipts.
As a practical matter, he said, that means current deficit projections for coming years are likely to grow, creating further tension between the parties over taxes and spending.

HEADLINE: Study Says Middle Class to Lose Much of Bush Tax Cut's Benefit 

BYLINE:  By DAVID CAY JOHNSTON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 

 BODY:
Nearly all middle- and upper-middle-class families will lose some of the income tax cuts scheduled over the next eight years as they are forced to pay a separate tax originally intended to make sure that the rich cannot live tax-free, a study released today found.
 By the end of the decade, when the tax cuts pushed into law by the Bush administration in 2001 become fully effective, 85 percent of taxpayers with two or more children will be forced off the regular income tax and onto a separate system known as the alternative minimum tax. 
 The additional burden will fall largely on families with incomes of $75,000 to $500,000. Just three years ago fewer than one million taxpayers, most at the upper reaches of the income spectrum, were subject to the complex separate tax. But if nothing is changed, by 2010 about 36 million taxpayers will face it. Indeed, virtually all taxpayers earning $100,000 to $500,000 will fall under its sway. 
"What was a class tax is becoming a mass tax," said Len Burman of the Urban Institute, one of the study's authors and a tax expert under former Presidents Ronald Reagan and Bill Clinton.
Under the alternative minimum tax system, many deductions are denied, including those for children, the taxpayers themselves and for state and local taxes. At that point, taxes are calculated at rates of 26 to 35 percent.
"We're talking about a really nasty marriage penalty," Mr. Burman said. "You are 25 times to 30 times more likely to be on the alternative minimum tax if you are married rather than single."
The study, drawn from computer models of tax behavior similar to those used by Congress and the administration, was made by the Tax Policy Center, a joint venture of the Brookings Institution and the Urban Institute.
The authors of the study are economists who have served under both Republican and Democratic administrations. While generally espousing moderately liberal positions, they have done research and made calculations that are generally considered nonpartisan and are widely respected.
It has been known since shortly after Mr. Bush's tax cut bill was introduced last year that its rate cuts would force many middle-class people off the regular income tax and onto the alternative tax. But the study provides the most in-depth look to date at the impact on millions of taxpayers of the interaction between the regular system and the alternative tax.
Claire Buchan, a White House spokeswoman, said that "the administration is aware of this issue and will continue to look at it and work with any members of Congress who are interested."
The study, however, shows just how hard it will be to repair the problem, demonstrating that almost any solution will cost the Treasury hundreds of billions of dollars or require raising taxes elsewhere to compensate for the losses. No action is expected anytime soon.
The new study also raises questions about whether the government has, inadvertently, adopted an antifamily tax policy despite years of talk in Congress and on the campaign trail about giving tax relief to middle-class families.
The study found that 97 percent of families with two children and income of $75,000 to $100,000 would be forced off the regular income tax system by 2010.
"This is a cop married to a nurse," said William Gale of the Brookings Institution, one of the study's authors.
The alternative tax will raise only about $13 billion this year, but its impact will soar to $141.4 billion in 2010, the authors calculated. By 2008, they said, it would cost more to repeal the alternative tax than to repeal the regular tax, an indication of the government's growing reliance on the tax.
For those making less than $50,000 -- roughly three-fourths of all taxpayers -- the alternative tax has only negligible effects.
For those making $50,000 to $75,000, the alternative tax in 2010 will, on average, take away 18 cents of each dollar of the scheduled Bush tax cuts. For those making $75,000 to $100,000 it will take back 42 cents and for those making $100,000 to $500,000 it returns 71 cents of every dollar of rate relief to the tax collector.
Taxpayers making more than $1 million, however, will lose just 8 cents on each dollar of the Bush tax cuts because most rich taxpayers would still face higher rates under the normal system than under the alternative tax.
More than half of the Bush tax cuts, when fully effective in 2010, will go to those making more than $1 million, other analyses have shown.
The study yesterday showed that the burden of the minimum tax will shift from the richest Americans to the middle class, which the authors defined as including people making up to $100,000.
Today people making more than $1 million pay 20 cents on each dollar that the alternative tax raises, but in 2010 that will fall to 5 cents. At the same time taxpayers earning $50,000 to $100,000 will see their share of the alternative tax triple to 18 cents of every dollar raised.
This shift in who pays the alternative tax explains, the authors said, why those making $75,000 to $200,000 will pay a larger share of all income taxes in 2010, while those making $1 million or more will pay less.
Those making $100,000 to $200,000, for example, will pay 21.8 percent of the combined revenue from the regular and the alternative income tax this year. That will rise to 27.1 percent in 2010. 
For those making more than $1 million, however, their share of taxes will go down, from 21.6 percent this year to 18.5 percent in 2010.
When the current form of the alternative tax was adopted, as part of the 1986 tax reform act, it raised only about $1 billion from a relatively small number of rich taxpayers who used aggressive techniques to avoid income taxes, Mr. Burman said.
The authors said that the revenue from the alternative tax is rising so fast that to return it to its original intent would cost as much as $951 billion over the next decade. They said simply abolishing the tax would make the system less fair. But limiting it to the old target could be financed, they said, by freezing the 2001 Bush tax cuts, for both income and estates, at their current levels.

HEADLINE: DRIVING; 
Drive-Ins, Near Death, Arise From The Weeds

BYLINE:  By GEORGE P. BLUMBERG 

 BODY:
IT was Saturday night, and Ed Gudinas could have been in Brockton, Mass., on a cushy couch, watching a movie on his large-screen home theater with surround sound. Instead, he was sitting in a camp chair on an open field, swatting the occasional mosquito and watching "Men in Black 2," the first half of a double feature on a 50-by-110-foot screen at a drive-in more than 100 miles from home.
 That he is still able to find a drive-in is itself remarkable. By 1990, most of the 4,063 that dotted the nation at the industry's height in 1958 were out of business. Where moviegoers by the hundreds had once screamed at "Creature From the Black Lagoon," only a few cars would be scattered about a weed-choked lot as X-rated gyrations filled the screen. Even love-struck teenage couples, a loyal clientele for decades, had drifted away. 
 Yet something of a renaissance may be under way. A hardy 430 drive-ins are operating across 47 states, according to the United Drive-In Theater Owners Association. In the 1990's, 15 new drive-ins were built, and 39 old ones were reopened.
Mr. Gudinas, 50, and his son, Adam, 24, were seated behind their Dodge van, in which they had made the trip to the Mansfield Drive-In in Connecticut. The van's rear faced the screen, and the open doors revealed a cooler of sodas and sandwiches.
The Gudinases are technology sophisticates whose business is installing electronic security equipment. Their van is a rolling tribute to electronics, including an Audiovox color TV with a VCR, a high-powered stereo and an X-Box DVD system. But here they were, watching a movie the way it was done on the cheap in the 1950's. Why?
Of course, there are the memories. Adam Gudinas recalls his parents' smuggling him in under a blanket at the Mansfield when they lived nearby -- not as an economy measure but more for the traditional drive-in sport of it.
But nostalgia isn't the whole story. The drive-ins that succeed in 2002 have been updated to please 21st-century audiences. Today's typical drive-in shows a double feature, and many have several screens. The audio is broadcast in stereo over the vehicles' FM radios or personal players. The movies are suitable for children.
"We cater to a family-oriented experience and always have one of our screens G-rated, the others PG-13," said Michael Jungden, 54, owner of the Mansfield. It has three screens, each serving about 300 cars. "Business is better than ever," Mr. Jungden said. On the night the Gudinases visited, the drive-in was also showing "Spy Kids 2."
The price is $7 for adults and $4 for children 4 to 11. On Wednesdays, $13 admits everyone in a carload. And there's no baby sitter to pay -- the children can come along and go to sleep on the back seat.
There is a snack bar, but many patrons bring their own refreshments. Some like to tailgate. Near the Gudinases' back-of-the-van setup, a big four-door Chevrolet pickup pulled into a spot, the bed facing the screen. With quick precision, four adults and three children converted the pickup into stadium seating, with small spectator chairs for children on the tailgate and larger chairs for the adults behind them. They pulled sodas from their cooler and grabbed slices of a pizza they had brought along. "It's like a community," said Kristie Leonard, one of the adults in the party.
And it feels safe. "This is not like walking around a mall parking lot at night," she said.
Safety is also a concern for Juli Czajkowski, 38, and her husband, David, 41, of Peoria, Ariz., a Phoenix suburb, who frequent the nine-screen Glendale Nine drive-in near their home. "This may sound silly," Ms. Czajkowski said, "but since Sept. 11, we feel safer at a drive-in than at a mall or a closed cineplex building."
In Berlinsville, Pa., 11 miles north of Allentown, Becky's Drive-In carries on with just a single screen, as it has since 1946, when it was started by the father of the current owners, Cindy Depee, 48, and her brothers and sister. Its clientele is devoted. Michael Carroll, 38, and his wife, Jackie, 31, of Mendham, N.J., make a 140-mile round trip to Becky's each week.
"We're not nostalgia hunters," Mr. Carroll said. "It's just a great way to see a movie." He added that the French fries weren't frozen and "the employees dress in theme costumes, including for "Men in Black" and "George of the Jungle."
Becky Norris, 21, of Belvidere, N.J., and her fiance, Shawn Stewart, 20, go to Becky's once a week. "Under the sky you stretch out, or people can smoke in their cars or talk and not bother anyone," Ms. Norris said. "The sound is great through the car stereo, and little kids can cry and not disturb anyone." They are trying to get their friends to go to the drive-in, too.
"Lots of people," she said, "don't know it's just not a place to go and make out anymore."

GRAPHIC: Photo: REVIVALS -- Drive-ins like the Glendale Nine in Peoria, Ariz., are drawing in new audiences by becoming family entertainment centers. (Pat Shannahan for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: ART GUIDE 

 BODY:
 A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show.

Museums

"AMERICAN ANTHEM: MASTERWORKS FROM THE AMERICAN FOLK ART MUSEUM," 45 West 53rd Street, (212) 265-1040 (through Jan. 5). The last of three shows celebrating the American Folk Art Museum's new building, "Anthem" displays more than 250 objects acquired since the museum opened 40 years ago. And in the museum's cleverly designed new digs, the show really comes on strong. It displays some of folk art's most esteemed icons, among them the "Flag Gate," a weathered farm gate of painted wood in the shape of an American flag; a pair of spiffy lady-and-gentleman portraits by Ammi Phillips; a spirited carousel horse from Coney Island carved by Charles Carmel; and a life-size baseball player at bat, carved by Samuel Anderson Robb. For the first time, the show includes the work of 20th-century self-taught artists in context with earlier folk art in the collection. Also for the first time, the museum demonstrates its recently expanded collecting interests beyond the United States, showing the work of 20th-century self-taught Europeans like Adolf Wolfli, Madge Gill and Carlo Zinelli. Hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Fridays, 10 a.m. to 8 p.m. Admission: $9; $5 for students and 62+ (Grace Glueck)

* "CULTIVATED LANDSCAPES: REFLECTIONS OF NATURE IN CHINESE PAINTING WITH SELECTIONS FROM THE COLLECTION OF MARIE-HELENE AND GUY WEILL," Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82nd Street, (212) 535-7710 (through Feb. 9). This show is basically a rotation of the permanent collection, of the kind required to protect light-sensitive silk scrolls and ink-painted album pages. But the Met has a flair for turning necessity into a virtue by reintroducing work along thematic lines and introducing fresh material to lend a sense of event. Such is the case here. At the center of the reinstallation is a group of splendid Ming and Qing dynasty paintings recently given or promised to the museum by the New York collectors Marie-Helene and Guy Weill. They are a genuine attraction in themselves, and a logical link in the continuum that this museum's remarkable Chinese holdings span from beginning to end. Hours: Sundays and Tuesdays through Thursdays, 9:30 a.m. to 5:30 p.m.; Fridays and Saturdays until 9 p.m. Admission: $12; $7 for students and 65+ (Holland Cotter).

* EXPOSED: THE VICTORIAN NUDE, Brooklyn Museum of Art, 200 Eastern Parkway, at Prospect Park, (718) 638-5000 (through Jan. 5). For the latest overview of British naughtiness, you may once again go to (where else?) Brooklyn, for this show of not very prudish Victorian art. "Exposed" has even more naked women without their pubic hair than the last Vanessa Beecroft show at the Gagosian Gallery. The naked young maidens here, shackled to a rock or draped over the oars of a ship (the boatmen bravely stare straight ahead) or riding horses or just standing there with an anaconda wrapped around their bodies are Andromeda, the Sirens, Godiva and Harmonia. The artists include Sargent, Frederic Leighton and Herbert Schmalz, whose "Faithful Unto Death" presents half a dozen or so naked damsels, loosely bound to herms, awaiting lions in the Circus Maximus. Lawrence Alma-Tadema imagines apple-flushed Victorian women soaking in a Roman plunge bath. Fortunately, the show does not stint on genuine porn. Perfume and underwear advertisers today clearly have nothing on the feisty Victorians. The show ends with works by Walter Sickert and Gwen John, artists at the turn of the last century who dispensed with the kinky fantasies of antigravitational breasts and painted what they really saw. From Alma-Tadema to Ms. Beecroft and cold cream commercials. From John and Sickert to Lucian Freud, who could never be confused with Herbert Schmalz. Hours: Wednesdays through Fridays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. (until 11 p.m. the first Saturday of each month). Admission: $6; $3 for students and 62+ (Michael Kimmelman)

* "GAUGUIN IN NEW YORK COLLECTIONS: THE LURE OF THE EXOTIC," Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82nd Street, (212) 535-7710 (through Oct. 20). The first major New York exhibition in four decades devoted to Gauguin isn't major-major by Met blockbuster standards: more than half of the 120 pieces are drawings and prints. But these are pretty spectacular, and they are joined by some two dozen paintings, including coral-and-mango-colored visions of a mythical South Pacific that are among the most beautiful images created by any modern artist. Only the Met has the resources to put this kind of material together, though if you want to get a real sense of the not-so-nice artist himself, check out the new critical biography by Nancy Mowll Mathews, "Paul Gauguin: An Erotic Life." Hours and admission: See above (Cotter).

"GREAT MASTERS OF MEXICAN FOLK ART FROM THE COLLECTION OF FOMENTO CULTURAL BANAMEX," National Museum of the American Indian, at the United States Custom House (Smithsonian Institution), 1 Bowling Green, (212) 514-2843 (through March 15). This big, lavish crowd-pleaser of an exhibition offers a colorful and entertaining selection of more than 500 works by 181 contemporary Mexican artisans, and it includes sculpture, furniture, ceramics, weavings, toys, religious objects, glassware, bead work, leather work and much more. Fine craft predominates, but there are works of compelling imagination, too, like the wonderfully animated wooden fantasy animals of Manuel Jimenez Ramirez; the magical, intensely patterned ceramic assemblages of Alfonso Castillo Orta; and the crowded, miniature bullfight scene, carved out of a log, by Hipolito Vazquez Sanchez. Hours: Daily, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Thursdays until 8 p.m. Free (Ken Johnson).

"MOVING PICTURES," Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum, 1071 Fifth Avenue, at 88th Street, (212) 423-3500 (through Jan. 12). This survey of photography with a small selection of video, film and installation art appended may be the largest exhibition of its kind in a major New York museum. Drawn almost entirely from the Guggenheim's permanent collection, it has a snappy yet unobtrusive design by Hani Rashid and ably surveys the expansion of contemporary art by camera-dependent media from the late 1960's to now. It begins with works by Nam June Paik, Bruce Nauman and Robert Smithson, then moves up the museum's ramp through photographs by Nan Goldin, Cindy Sherman and Andreas Gursky, concluding with video and film by artists like Stan Douglas, Shirin Neshat and Pierre Huyghe. An added attraction are the foam-lined, cavelike video galleries perched at the top of the spiral, which give the show a giddy, Hall of the Mountain King finale that seems to say "onward and upward with video." Hours: Sundays through Wednesdays, 9 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Fridays and Saturdays, 9 a.m. to 8 p.m. Admission: $12; $9 for students and 65+ (Roberta Smith)

* MUSEUM OF MODERN ART, QUEENS, 45-20 33rd Street, at Queens Boulevard, Long Island City, (212) 708-9400. People in Queens are now finally free to complain the way obnoxious Manhattanites have always done about the bridge and tunnel crowd bringing their Prada sandals for a walk on weekends and spoiling the neighborhood. The Modern's new temporary home (until 2005) has finally opened in the former Swingline staple factory with part of its permanent collection of paintings and sculpture on view. The galleries approximate the classic industrial loft aesthetic, efficient and airless, like the inside of a storage center, which is exactly what this building is, but touching for Cezannes, Seurats and Braques, which suddenly look fresh and seem to pop off the movable bare white walls. The temporary shows include a display of Rudy Burckhardt's little-known photographs of Queens in the late 1930's and early 40's (through Nov. 4), a perfect tribute to the museum's new locale. The trip to the museum couldn't be easier on the No. 7 subway. Now you can tell everyone you're chic: you've been to Queens. Hours: Thursdays through Mondays from 10 a.m. to 5 p.m; to 7:45 p.m. on Fridays. Admission: $12; $8.50 for students and 65+ (Kimmelman).

* "HELIO OITICICA: QUASI-CINEMAS," New Museum of Contemporary Art, 583 Broadway, between Prince and Houston Streets, SoHo, (212) 219-1222 (through Oct. 13). "To organize delirium" is the phrase Haroldo de Campos, the Brazilian poet, came up with to describe the work of Oiticica. I couldn't put it better. A Brazilian proto-installationist of the 1960's, Oiticica wanted nothing more than to have people kick off their shoes and immerse themselves in the karmic pleasures he devised. This show focuses on his somewhat tangential work of the 70's, when he lived in New York: it consists of rooms slung with hammocks or padded with mattresses or covered with sand and balloons; slides of Jimi Hendrix, Marilyn Monroe and Luis Bunuel flash on the walls to music by Yma Sumac, the Latin diva. This description makes the work sound juvenile or pointless, which it is not. A buoyancy derives partly from the sly humor, self-mocking and pervasive. Art was for Oiticica a state of mind and a condition of the heart -- a university for the soul with an open-admission policy. Hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, noon to 6 p.m.; Thursdays, noon to 8 p.m. Admission: $6; $3 for students, artists and 65+ (Kimmelman).

* "THE PAINTINGS OF JOAN MITCHELL," Whitney Museum of American Art, 945 Madison Avenue, at 75th Street, (212) 570-3676 (through Sept. 29). The impact of Mitchell's works, especially the later ones (she died of lung cancer 10 years ago, at 66), is so immediately intoxicating that a natural reaction is to distrust the art. Abstract paintings this suave and sure-footed must be glib and manipulative, you may be excused for telling yourself. Distrust your distrust. Lush, opulent fields of colors, seemingly all paradisiacal, contain shades of melancholy that reveal themselves to you after your eyes adjust to their light. Mitchell absorbed the influences of Pollock, Gorky, Kline and de Kooning. There are ferocious paintings of clotted splatters in the 1950's. Then hovering shapes appear in muted green, gray and blue in the 60's. They give way by the early 70's to more vividly colored multipanel paintings in which increasing varieties of shapes and lines jostle. Mitchell, who had moved to France, denied the influence of Monet, which was undeniable. Her last works, from the 80's and early 90's, push Monet into the late-20th century ecstatically. Hours: Tuesdays through Thursdays, Saturdays and Sundays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Fridays, 1 to 9 p.m. Admission: $12; $9.50 for students and 62+ (Kimmelman).

"QUEENS INTERNATIONAL," Queens Museum of Art, Flushing Meadows-Corona Park, (718) 592-9700 (through Nov. 3). This selection of work by 40 artists, from 12 countries but all now living in Queens, includes paintings, videos, performance art, installations and other contemporary forms. The art reflects the globalization of postmodernist pluralism as much as -- if not more than -- cultural diversity. Highlights include intricately patterned, mandala-form collages by Marietta J. Ganapin; John L. Moore's dreamy, supplely painted abstractions; Larry Litt's politically provocative video "The Blame Show"; and James Johnson's full-scale copper-clad fantasy airplane, more offbeat labor of love than professional sculpture. Hours: Tuesdays through Fridays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, noon to 5 p.m. Admission: $5; $2 for students and 55+ (Johnson).

Galleries: Chelsea

PAUL AMENTA, "Quivering Twilight," Marvelli Galley, 526 West 26th Street, (212) 627-3363 (through Oct. 5). Working on panels of wallboard that come with blue paper surfaces, Mr. Amenta cuts into the paper and peels it away to create graceful brown silhouettes of leafless trees. He also pierces the surface and fills the holes with white joint compound; sanded down, these become glowing stars in the blue sky. Call it Home Depot Sublime (Johnson).

ROWENA DRING, Elizabeth Dee Gallery, 545 West 20th Street, (212) 924-7545 (through Oct. 5). This young, Amsterdam-based Englishwoman makes Pop-style, photo-based landscapes by a surprising technique. Using a sewing machine and black thread, Ms. Dring produces her pictures by stitching countless pieces of colored fabric to stretched canvases. The effect is more impressive the bigger the size, as in a picture of a forest waterfall that measures 7 by 10 feet. In its expansive, percussive luminosity, it is like a Tiffany stained-glass window (Johnson).

* OWEN GRAY, "Paintings From the Southwest and Tropics," Blue Mountain Gallery, 530 West 25th Street, (646) 486-4730 (through Sept. 28). With a relaxed but exacting painterly touch and in a Cezannesque palette of muted colors, this mid-career New Yorker paints visionary bird's-eye views of tropical swamps teeming with plant and animal life and inhabited in some cases by corpulent, naked white people. Mr. Gray is painting a kind of primordial peaceable kingdom, a Freudian never-never land where the ego lives in close touch with churning instinctual energies (Johnson).

TODD HIDO, "Roaming," Paul Morris, 465 West 23rd Street, (212) 727-2752 (through Oct. 5). Mr. Hido's captivating pictures combine old-fashioned photographic beauty and an up-to-date feeling for cinematic narrative. In those shot at night on the seedy edges of town, dark shadows and the misty glow of streetlights over pedestrian walkways generate tantalizing states of suspense. Bleak daytime landscapes made in late autumn or winter are like moments in a movie version of a Russell Banks novel (Johnson).

JENNY HOLZER, "Protect Me From What I Want," Printed Matter, 535 West 22nd Street, (212) 925-0325 (through Sept. 30). Ms. Holzer's blunt, insistent sound bites have been buzzing through the collective culture since the early 1980's, conveyed on baseball hats, T-shirts, Styrofoam cups and bumper stickers, as well as with nylon stockings and china. This survey thoroughly samples these ephemeral efforts and celebrates her distinctive way with words, filling the premises with Holzer-babble. Its subversive consciousness-raising and sense of apocalyptic foreboding seems freshly pertinent (Smith).

* MICHAEL HURSON, Paula Cooper Gallery, 521 West 21st Street, (212) 255-1055 (through Oct. 12). At the heart of this show are seven drawings done from a reproduction of Seurat's painting "Sunday Afternoon on the Island of La Grande Jatte." They reiterate the painting's gliding figures and majestic recession of space, while replacing its seamless surface with the quirky, slightly anxious, multitextured intimacy that Mr. Hurson has developed over the years, and puts to excellent use here (Smith).

JOSEPH MAIDA, "Interior Portraits," Wallspace, 453 West 17th Street, (212) 675-5804 (through Sept. 28). Hanging around the homes of his friends, Mr. Maida captures images of people in relaxed, unposed and unguarded moments. His rich, medium-large color photographs may call to mind Nan Goldin's diaristic imagery, but they lack the alienating, self-conscious bohemianism (Johnson).

YOSHIYUKI MIURA, Von Lintel Gallery, 555 West 25th Street, (212) 242-0599 (through Oct. 12). Using industrial materials, Mr. Miura makes sculptures that are as visually gripping as they are physically seductive. The centerpiece here is a circular work consisting of hundreds of vertical steel rods, each with a golden bronze tip, which grow taller as they progress concentrically from the center. The geometric order gives way to shifting, optically pulsating patterns of radiating, glinting gold dots and vibrating black verticals (Johnson).

ANTONIO PETRACCA, "Forecast: Sunny and Clear, High in the Low 80's," Kim Foster, 529 West 20th Street, (212) 229-0044 (through Oct. 12). Rendering cropped, snapshot images of the twin towers, construction cranes and ground zero workers with a fine eye for light and a soft yet exacting touch, this Battery Park City painter has produced a low-key meditation on 9/11 (Johnson).

ELLIOTT PUCKETTE, Paul Kasmin, 293 10th Avenue, at 27th Street, (212) 563-4474 (through Oct. 12). Ms. Puckette continues to work with her trademark device of crisp, tapering white lines that suggest improvisations by an 18th-century engraver. The whiplash calligraphy is actually cut with a razor into blotchy, watery fields of gray or a single color painted on wooden panels, but it gives the impression of floating in front of atmospheric space as though it were painted on glass. The play between surface and depth is appealing, in part because it seems so ripe for further complication and development (Johnson).

SCOTT RICHTER, Elizabeth Harris Gallery, 529 West 20th Street, (212) 463-9666 (through Oct. 5). Contemplating his mountainous heaps of oily paint on sturdy used tables, you might wonder how much Mr. Richter spends on paint in a year. Whatever the sum, he puts his resources to good use with some new twists: in several cases, he has piled the paint into curving wedges with the raw texture of mud-pie construction on one side and, on the other, smooth, convex planes in which color blends to give an impression of expansive and luminous skies (Johnson).

TOSHIKO TAKAEZU, Charles Cowles, 537 West 24th Street, (212) 925-3500 (through Oct. 5). This eminent ceramist is justly celebrated for her enormous pod-shaped vessels that seamlessly combine rugged physicality, expressionistic glazing and classical serenity. The biggest stand about human height and have bulbous profiles and nipple-like protrusions at the top, all of which makes for a certain primal, maternal presence (Johnson).

IVAN WITENSTEIN AND DAN FISCHER, Derek Eller Gallery, 526-530 West 25th Street, (212) 206-6411 (through Oct. 5). Each of the seven fiberglass and cast resin sculptures in Mr. Witenstein's impressive New York solo debut, titled "Here Comes the Son, Here Comes the Knight," is like a psychedelic version of American-style Social Realism, with references to war, racism, popular culture, 19th-century literature and 20th-century history molded together with a visionary zeal. Mr. Fischer revisits photo-realism in a series of detail-perfect graphite drawings based on magazine illustrations of art world stars past and present. These icons look every bit as weird as the figures in Mr. Witenstein's sculptures, and are no less virtuosically made (Cotter).

Galleries: Brooklyn

"CONSUMING PLACES," 16 Main Street, at Water Street, Brooklyn waterfront near the Manhattan Bridge, (212) 206-6674 (through Oct. 27). Space in its various contemporary manifestations -- architectural, virtual, commercial and otherwise -- is where the action is for lots of avant-garde-minded folks. This exhibition, sponsored by Creative Time, presents two individual artists (Bill Fontana and Marjetica Potrc) and three teams (Asymptote, Greyworld and 212box). Their technologically complicated works reflect the layering of material and immaterial dimensions that shape modern experience. It is conceptually interesting but less fun than a Spielberg movie (Johnson).

* MATT MARELLO, "The Pollock Project," Pierogi, 177 North Ninth Street, Williamsburg, (718) 599-2144 (through Oct. 7). This wry yet mythically resonant meditation on the cult of the Dionysian artist features video projections in which the artist has digitally inserted himself into clips of Jackson Pollock painting, the Led Zepplin percussionist John Bonham drumming and the action-movie star Bruce Lee performing with nunchakus. A fourth shows the view from a car driving at night. Actual drumsticks, nunchakus and a paintbrush, all carved from wood found near the site of Pollock's fatal car crash, are displayed in a vitrine like sacred relics (Johnson).

"POP PATRIOTISM," Momenta Art, 72 Berry Street, Williamsburg, (718) 218-8058 (through Oct. 6). This group show satirizes commercial exploitation of post 9/11 patriotism. Thomas Sherrod's lovingly painted teddy bear paints stars and stripes on a dollar sign in the sky; David Opdyke's "Suburbanistan" remaps Afghanistan as a suburban tract; Christy Rupp offers "Taliban Barbie," the real doll in a burka; Heidi Schlatter's video compiles a montage of narcissistic pop stars singing patriotic anthems; and the show's curator, Peter Scott, displays his collection of red-white-and-blue kitsch, including key chains, magazine covers and flip-flop sandals (Johnson).

"YOU'RE JUST A SUMMER LOVE, BUT I'LL REMEMBER YOU WHEN WINTER COMES," Priska C. Juschka Fine Art, 97 North Ninth Street, Williamsburg, (718) 782-4100 (through Oct. 6). The young artists in this larky group exhibition share a downtown sensibility (rooted in this case in Manhattan's Lower East Side); various kinds of friendships; and an anarchic, school's-out-forever aesthetic, which might be described as a post-punk-hippie-grunge hybrid. A retro-60's strain is played out in stained-glass sculptures and painted rainbows. A video by Kid America has the streetwise visual snap of graffiti and the frantic pacing of a television commercial. The art world may be fixated on Well-Made Objects these days, but a high, here-today communal energy is the story here (Cotter).

Other Galleries

JOHN BISBEE, Plane Space, 102 Charles Street, Greenwich Village, (917) 606-1268 (through Oct. 4). Each of this Maine-based sculptor's three projects is made of king-size nails welded together and calculated to weigh precisely one ton. One has the 12-inch spikes fused into a semisolid mass; another is a set of nine scary-looking spheres made of radiating spikes; the third is a structure like a low garden fence that meanders some 240 feet across the gallery's concrete floor (Johnson).

KARL MANN, "Retrospective: 50 Years," Viewing Room, 114 West 17th Street, (646) 638-1920 (through Sept. 29). Doll fragments, wallpaper, plastic animals, superhero toys, electric and mechanical parts, antique photographs, magazine ads, heads of Jesus, Madonna and Elvis: all this and much more goes into the mix of Mr. Mann's collage and assemblage work and is arranged with an unerring design sense. An internal editor might help to give his work a more personal focus, but one nevertheless admires his boundless creative energy (Johnson).

* "PERFECT ACTS OF ARCHITECTURE," AXA Gallery, 787 Seventh Avenue, near 51st Street, (212) 554-1704 (through Oct. 19). During the 70's and 80's, when the building industry was depressed, some intellectually ambitious architects like the five luminaries represented in this exhibition of drawings often realized their most radical ideas only on paper. For Daniel Libeskind and Thom Mayne, that meant different kinds of play with traditional conventions of architectural drafting. Peter Eisenman made geometric diagrams based on the linguistic theories of Noam Chomsky. Bernard Tschumi drew and collaged a noirish narrative. And, best of all, Rem Koolhaas produced an Orwellian fable about utopian social engineering (Johnson).

PAUL HENRY RAMIREZ, "Space Addiction," Whitney Museum of American Art at Philip Morris, 120 Park Avenue, at 42nd Street, (917) 663-2453 (through Oct. 11). In flat, hard-edged graphics, Mr. Ramirez's zany montage of spurting breasts, delicately hair-fringed orifices, dangling genitalia, targets, polka dots and stripes harmoniously proliferates all over the gallery's walls. It suggests that what underlies holistic fantasies of Modernist design is infantile yearning for the ideal mother. Out in the courtyard, "Outer City, Inner Space" (through Jan. 3) includes an undulating, tubular ceiling by Teresita Fernandez; an internally illuminated, futuristic igloo by Stephen Hendee; and a giant Chinese food takeout bag by Ester Parteg -- all resonating to good effect with Mr. Ramirez's Neo-Pop lunacy (Johnson).

Last Chance

"THE ARTIST'S EYE: JANE FREILICHER AS CURATOR," National Academy of Design Museum, 1083 Fifth Avenue, at 89th Street, (212) 369-4880 (through Sunday). The academy's sixth artist-selected show has been chosen by Jane Freilicher, whose reserved yet opulently colored landscapes and still lifes might be said to mediate the shrinking gap between the academic and the progressive. To some extent this show explores that gap: its 50 paintings are weighted toward portraits and landscapes and juxtaposed with unusual subtleness and intelligence. They form an engrossing meditation on subject matter, the painter's craft and the history of the academy. Hours: Wednesdays and Thursdays, noon to 5 p.m.; Fridays, Saturdays and Sundays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. Admission: $8; $4.50 for students and 65+ (Smith).

* "CHANGING HANDS: ART WITHOUT RESERVATION," American Craft Museum, 40 West 53rd Street, (212) 956-3535 (through today). In this feast of a show, about 90 American Indian artists from the Southwest -- established and emerging -- exhibit weaving, pottery, jewelry, glass, sculpture, paintings and tableware. Chosen for their venturesome challenges to the traditional and the tribal, the artists help redefine contemporary Indian work as art rather than artifacts. An outstanding contribution is made by the jewelers, especially L. Eugene Nelson of Albuquerque, whose intricate, finely engineered brooch uses traditional Indian silver and stones but is modeled on a computer chip. In pottery, another stellar category, two big earthenware vessels by Jacquie Stevens evoke the baskets of her Winnebago ancestry, yet have an elegant modern look influenced by contemporary art. This is the first of three shows that will explore the current state of the arts in pre-European American societies; the series is off to a promising start. Hours: Daily, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Thursdays, to 8 p.m. Admission, $8; $5, students and 65+ (Glueck).

* "IRONIC/ICONIC: KIRA LYNN HARRIS, AIDA MILLETT AND KEHINDE WILEY," Studio Museum in Harlem, 144 West 125th Street, (212) 864-4500 (through Sunday). The Studio Museum's artist-in-residence program has advanced many young careers in its 35-year history. This year's three participants look more than promising. Ms. Harris shows shots of New York City dissolved into patterns of light; in Ms. Millett's installation, upwardly mobile dreams and on-the-skids reality meet; Mr. Wiley's paintings of African-American men combine portraiture and stereotypes, leaving the line between the two ambiguous. On the first floor of the museum is a wall drawing in progress by Edgar Arceneaux titled "Drawings of Removal," based on his father's fragmentary, contradictory memories of a Texas childhood. Mr. Arceneaux will be executing and obliterating the drawing periodically throughout the exhibition. Hours: Wednesdays through Fridays and Sundays, noon to 6 p.m.; Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m. Admission: $5; $3 for students and 62+; $1, children under 12 (Cotter).

* "FRIDA KAHLO, DIEGO RIVERA AND 20TH-CENTURY MEXICAN ART: THE JACQUES AND NATASHA GELMAN COLLECTION," El Museo del Barrio, 1230 Fifth Avenue, at 104th Street, (212) 831-7272 (through Thursday). El Museo began in an East Harlem storefront; now it's a capstone of Museum Mile with a show that many a larger, richer museum would welcome. Kahlo is a big part of the attraction. Seven of her self-portraits are here, reason enough for a pilgrimage. Sure, she's been oversold, but she's great. Her husband, Diego Rivera, looks good, too, with his visionary "Calla Lily Vendor" and a slinky portrait of Natasha Gelman that is pure Tinseltown luxe. There are, in fact, too many Gelman portraits on hand, along with some other second-tier work, but with so much else of interest the show is a must-see even for museumgoers who usually stick to the mainstream. Those for whom Kahlo is the She-Who-Must-Be-Obeyed of modernist painting are no doubt lining up at the door. Hours: Wednesdays through Sundays, 11 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Thursdays, to 9 p.m. Admission: $7; $3 for students and 65+ (Cotter).

GRAPHIC: Photos: A large detail of a Wang Yuanqi work in "Cultivated Landscapes." (Metropolitan Museum of Art); "Study for the Musicians (Work in Progress)" by Michael Hurson, in an exhibition of the artist's works on paper at Paula Cooper in Chelsea. (Paula Cooper Gallery)

HEADLINE: MY BROOKLYN; 
A Tower of Dentists Wears a Golden Crown

BYLINE:  By ANDY NEWMAN

 BODY:
It is the undisputed king of the Brooklyn skyline, the most populous borough's only widely recognized piece of architecture that is not a roller coaster. Its gigantic clock tower looms up in half the apartment windows in town, a communal wristwatch that sometimes seems to be watching you.
 It is the Williamsburgh Savings Bank building, Brooklyn's tallest, the 512-foot, 34-story colossus that casts its shadow over the congested crossroads of Flatbush and Atlantic Avenues, towering a good 400 feet over almost everything in the vicinity and visible from the Jersey Shore. The American Institute of Architects guidebook says, "Inadvertently, this was New York's most phallic symbol . . . dominating the landscape of all Brooklyn." Crustier observers have likened it to a giant hand offering a salty Brooklyn salute. 
 But for a landmark, the buff-brick and limestone tower at 1 Hanson Place, now owned by HSBC Bank, is a bit of an everyday mystery. Most Brooklynites have probably never set foot in it. Those who have and know what riches it holds -- a stunningly lavish banking hall topped by bank offices and 20 floors of mostly dentists' suites -- may wonder how it got that way. 
Architecture buffs might well ask, "Why a golden Renaissance-style dome atop a modernist skyscraper?" Literalists may wonder why the building is not in Williamsburg (as the bank's original home is now spelled) but at the southern end of Fort Greene, half a block from the Brooklyn Academy of Music.
And many neighbors, especially those whose homes look out on the east face of what was for decades the largest four-faced clock in the world, would like to know why such a celebrated timepiece so often provides the wrong time. (Prevailing winds turn out to be the culprits.)
For the 16,000-odd customers of the branch, the basilicalike banking hall remains a pretty awe-inspiring place to fill out a deposit slip. From a 63-foot-high vaulted gold-leaf ceiling mosaic of zodiac figures and other celestial ephemera to the intricate wrought-iron biblical-looking men and women that serve as the legs of an inch-thick green glass counter illuminated by lamps hanging from stylized metal camel faces, the place dazzles. "One is fortified at the banking screen by animals representing strength, courage and fidelity," wrote Richard Brotherton, an architectural historian, in the Landmarks Preservation Commission's report on the interior. 
Downstairs in the gymnasium-size bank vault, the door alone -- some five feet wide and deep and eight feet high -- is bigger than many Manhattan kitchens. It weighs 60 tons. From the upper-floor dental chairs, the views of all of New York City and the waters and lands beyond provide a welcome if incomplete distraction.
As grand as it seems now, though, the building was envisioned as something grander. It was to be the anchor of a new downtown, strategically located near the convergence of Flatbush and Atlantic Avenues, nearly a dozen subway lines and a busy commuter station of the Long Island Rail Road. The wishful mosaic that dominates one wall of the banking hall shows the tower as a shining beacon, relaying the sun's rays to a golden city.
A week after the building opened, in April 1929, the floors above the bank were 75 percent rented. "This certainly speaks well for Brooklyn and indicates that more skyscrapers will be erected in the near future," the president of the Brooklyn Real Estate Board, Lewis H. Pounds, told the press.
Then came the Depression, followed by decades of more local ups and downs. It was half a century before the next cluster of tall buildings went up in Brooklyn, and they were built half a mile west, closer to the old downtown. 
But the bank tower somehow remained above it all, an island dedicated to silver and gold in the sea of brick and concrete. Dentists may not be the most glamorous tenants, but their business is recession-proof, and the rents they pay today -- more than $45 a square foot -- are some of the highest in the area, said William O'Brien of M. C. O'Brien, a commercial real estate broker. 
Besides, "when you have a building filled with a large amount of tenants who don't take up much space and pay the rent on time, why change?" said John Maltz, a managing director at Greiner-Maltz, a real estate company in Long Island City, Queens. "That's golden."
In the early 1920's the original Williamsburgh Savings Bank, a domed temple at Broadway and Driggs Avenue in Williamsburg that is also now an HSBC branch, was the fourth biggest savings bank in the country. It was ready to expand, but banks in New York State were limited to one office. Then in 1923 a state law allowed branch banks, and the trustees began looking for a second site for a new flagship.
They picked a spot and hired the architects Halsey McCormack & Helmer, who went on to design several other landmark banks. Architect and client quarreled over the design: the bank wanted to crown its new headquarters with its signature dome, even though it clashed with the soaring modern look of the rest of the building. Client won. "Dome was required by Bank over our dead protests," reads an architect's note.
Regarding the interior, there was no such squabbling. The chief architect, Robert Helmer, wrote that he wanted the building "to be regarded as a cathedral dedicated to the furtherance of thrift and prosperity." He hit his mark. The banking room, a triumph of Romanesque Revival design with the naves and aisles of a church, is a tasteful riot of wrought metal, stone and tile. 
Twenty-two varieties of marble grace the floor and support posts. Sculptures by Rene P. Chambellan, who did the decorations at Radio City Music Hall, abound. 
On the mezzanine overlooking the banking hall was a ladies' lounge, now converted to offices. The bank president rode up to his office in a private elevator. The 26th-floor observation deck, now closed to the public for liability reasons, offered magnificent views.
Upstairs, the building quickly became a magnet for dentists -- in particular specialists at the top of the profession: oral surgeons, periodontists, orthodontists. The reasons are not quite clear. Mr. Maltz said it could be as simple as one dentist following another. Dr. Robert Seminara, who has fitted braces in the building since 1963, said it made sense that specialists, who might not be able to find enough business in a neighborhood practice, would be particularly drawn to an impressive building at a transportation hub. 
"They realized that if they were going to do more advanced or progressive dentistry, they had to be in a central location," he said. "And patient expectation of what quality treatment they receive is based on what the eye can see."
After World War II the area around the bank flourished. Through the 1940's the Atlantic Avenue terminal was the busiest station on the Long Island Rail Road, and the blocks around were lined with places to eat and shop. Dentists and other people of means took their meals at the Gondola, a fancy Italian restaurant on Flatbush Avenue. By the 1950's there was a big barber shop and a restaurant on the mezzanine level of the bank building.
Then came years of urban decay, middle-class flight and the usual roster of ills. The fancy residential hotel around the corner became a homeless shelter. In the early 1960's the city tore down buildings across the street from the bank to make way for the Atlantic Terminal urban renewal project, which, thanks to an endless series of commercial and political squabbles, remains an enormous pit.
The Williamsburgh Savings Bank itself was to some extent implicated in the area's woes. Though 1 Hanson Place's cornerstone dedicates the building to the bank's depositors, who through their hard work and thrift "swept aside the petty distinctions of class and birth and so maintained the true spirit of American democracy," the bank's loan department was accused of redlining. 
Critics charged that Brooklyn residents had deposited $932 million at the bank but had been granted only $32 million in mortgages and home-improvement loans. (In suburban Suffolk County, by contrast, the bank lent out far more than it took in.) The bank had to reform its loan policies for the building to receive landmark status in 1978.
In the 1980's the Williamsburgh Savings Bank ran into more trouble, hobbled by high interest rates and inflation. In 1986 it was acquired by Republic National Bank. Republic in turn went the way of so much banking flesh, being devoured in 1999 by HSBC Bank USA, the American division of the London-based bank, one of the world's largest.
Meanwhile, the neighborhoods surrounding the bank -- Fort Greene, Park Slope, Boerum Hill and Prospect Heights -- have rebounded. Brownstones were restored to their former glory; swank restaurants filled the avenues. Under the aegis of the Brooklyn Academy of Music an arts district is taking shape. A shopping mall, Atlantic Center, opened near the bank.
Inside 1 Hanson Place, though, not much appears to have changed. HSBC has taken over the 7th through 11th floors for back-office operations. Upstairs, the space is 96 percent rented, said Stephen Elbaz, a leasing agent for the bank. The roster of dentists has been reduced from its heyday; the offices are now filled out with a smattering of other doctors, as well as other professionals and nonprofit agencies like the Brooklyn Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children. 
The building's age and design make it unappealing for a large corporate tenant, Mr. O'Brien said. Big tenants, he said, want more space between columns, higher ceilings, 21st-century infrastructure. Especially at the upper levels, which are set back progressively farther from the street, there is simply not enough floor space.
The dentists don't mind. "To practice in this building is amazing," said Irwin Kolin, an orthodontist on the 21st floor who has been in the building for 43 years. "I wouldn't go anywhere else. You can consult with your colleagues. If we run short of X-rays, we help each other out."
The clocks, after all these years, still have a vexing tendency to run slow sometimes, and not even uniformly. One face can read perfect time while another lingers in the past. 
Up in the control room of the clock tower recently, with Brooklyn laid out in dizzying 360-degree splendor just outside the door, the building engineer, William Harris, explained how this happens. 
The four clocks run on separate motors, so there is nothing to keep them synchronized. "And sometimes," he said, "when you get a heavy wind, it can spin the hands." The hour hands, nine feet long, weigh almost 300 pounds. The minute hands are nearly twice that size. The wind is stronger. The strongest winds, Mr. Harris said, blow on the east and south sides, so those clocks have the most trouble.
As he spoke these words, at 4:16 p.m., the east clock, facing Fort Greene, read 3:58. Mr. Harris grabbed a large crank and wound the hands forward 18 minutes, undoubtedly puzzling anyone who happened to be looking up.
"That should do it," he said.

HEADLINE: INSIDE ART 

BYLINE:  By Carol Vogel

 BODY:
Selling European, Buying American
 Since 1986 the Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts has been quietly selling off its collection of European paintings to create a fund for the acquisition of American art. The decision to sell paintings by masters like Courbet and Boldini is a way of refocusing its mission in the 21st century, its officials say. 
 When the academy was founded in 1805, the Philadelphia Museum of Art didn't exist, so it was natural that the academy would collect European works. But over the past 125 years the holdings of the Philadelphia Museum of Arts have made it an important encyclopedic institution, and so the academy no longer needs to retain European art. 
"We have to be a living, collecting institution for American art in order to stay alive," said Derek A. Gillman, the president and chief executive of the academy. 
Over the years it has sold art at Sotheby's and Christie's, as it will this fall. Sotheby's will auction 28 19th-century works in two parts, 20 of them on Oct. 28, and 8, including 2 by Courbet, in the spring.
Christie's is to auction 20 works, most of them in its sale of 19th-century paintings on Oct. 30. The cover work for Christie's catalog is Alexandre Cabanel's "Birth of Venus" (circa 1865-69), one of three versions. Napoleon III bought the first in 1863, when it was shown at the Paris Salon; it is now in the Musee d'Orsay in Paris. Another is in the Metropolitan Museum of Art. The one for sale is thought to have belonged to Henry C. Gibson, a Philadelphia banker. While researching the painting, experts at Christie's discovered 1871 advertisements for the sale where Gibson bought the painting, thus confirming that it is older than the Met's 1875 version. Christie's estimates that it will fetch $400,000 to $600,000.
Why has the academy waited so long to sell the painting? "People felt very attached to it," Mr. Gillman said. "Curators recognized its importance. But there comes a point where we finally had to say, 'The Cabanel, too.' "

Budget Casualties
As concerns over money continue to plague museums across the country, some exhibitions that would have been expensive to organize are being canceled, at least until the economy turns around. The latest to drop off the exhibition schedule is a retrospective of the notorious British duo Gilbert and George at the Brooklyn Museum of Art. The show, which was to have opened in March, would have included about 80 works. When officials began having trouble organizing other American venues for the show, it was first postponed and then canceled.
"People are being careful about budgets," said Arnold L. Lehman, director of the Brooklyn Museum. "The show was to occupy about 10,000 square feet, and for some museums that's a lot of space, especially for a contemporary art exhibition." What made it so expensive was the cost of shipping the works, which were to have come from collections worldwide. "I didn't let this go easily," Mr. Lehman said. "There's always tomorrow."

The Spanish Influence
In a perfect world, museum sponsorship is decided a year before an exhibition's opening. But in these tough times museums happily take sponsorship whenever they can get it, which may explain why the Metropolitan Museum of Art is only now announcing that Accenture is the sponsor of "Manet/Velazquez: The French Taste for Spanish Painting," a show of about 150 paintings by masters of Spain's Golden Age and the French artists they influenced, among them Delacroix, Courbet, Millet, Degas and especially Manet. Last year Accenture, a Bermuda-based consulting concern, split off from Arthur Andersen, the accounting firm that was convicted in June of obstructing the government's investigation into the collapse of Enron, an Andersen client.
A version of the show opened on Tuesday at the Musee d'Orsay, where it will run through Jan. 6. "We are doing this with the Louvre," said Philippe de Montebello, director of the Met. "Our version is bigger. It will also extend to American artists who were touched by Spanish painting."
As the sponsor, Accenture will collaborate with the Met to design a special feature on the museum's Web site (www.metmuseum.org), which will post biographical and historical information about the artists featured as well. Visitors will also be able to follow the paths of the artists as they traveled through Spain studying the Spanish masters.

Job Switching
Laurie Beckelman's expertise navigating the bureaucratic mine-fields of building in Manhattan have made her a hot commodity. Two years ago Ms. Beckelman, a former chairwoman of the New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission, was hired by the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum as its deputy director for special projects, a job that meant being involved with the creation of the museum that it hopes to build overlooking the East River at the foot of Wall Street. Since it appears that the Guggenheim's project is going to take years, Ms. Beckelman has agreed to oversee the planning and development of the American Craft Museum's new home at 2 Columbus Circle. She will remain a consultant to the Guggenheim.

Competitive Fees
Phillips, de Pury & Luxembourg, the struggling third-place auction house, announced this week that it was raising the fees it charges buyers to match those of its competitors. It will now charge 19.5 percent of the first $100,000 and 10 percent of any amount above that. Sotheby's and Christie's have been charging these fees since the spring. (Phillips' buyers' premium had been 15 percent of the first $50,000 and 10 percent after that.) The only exceptions are for sales of jewelry and watches, for which Phillips will charge 18 percent on the first $100,000 and 10 percent after that. For Swiss art it will charge a flat 18 percent.

HEADLINE: Unwanted Coins 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 In "Brother, Can We Spare the Penny?" (NYC column, Sept. 17), Clyde Haberman muses about the fate of the penny. But why not debate the merits of the lowly nickel, too? 
 Without these coins, prices would be easier to calculate for those of us who are arithmetically challenged. Removing them from circulation would also encourage the use of one-dollar coins, which last longer and ultimately cost less than paper dollar bills to produce.
Supporters of the penny argue that it continues to be a profitable venture for the United States Mint. But the mint can make even more on each larger-denomination coin. More important, the cost to the economy of handling pennies and nickels would be eliminated.

JEFF FLEMING
Milwaukee, Sept. 17, 2002

HEADLINE: DRIVING; 
Living the Fantasy At Full Throttle

BYLINE:  By BRUCE WEBER 

 BODY:
THERE'S a motorcycle on my tail, and it's bugging me. He's a reasonably serious dude. (I think so, anyway; what do I know about motorcycles?) In any case, as we head up the mountain maybe 20 yards apart, he's leaning hard into the switchback curves, back and forth, left and right, swiveling with fluid aggressiveness on the upright axis and making sharply acute angles with the road. He's cool to watch through the rearview mirror of this purring and potent hot-guymobile I'm at the wheel of, this manifestation of my wished-for middle-age libido, though I feel it as a clear affront that I can't lose him.
 The narrow, not quite two-lane road climbs drastically and winds dangerously on Mount Tamalpais near San Francisco, and all the other drivers (in their family sedans, tank-like S.U.V.'s and four-cylinder five-seaters that all look the same these days no matter what country they're made in), have instantly gotten the message when I've appeared behind them; as if with a gulp, they've all pulled off to the side, squeezed uncomfortably onto the shoulder and let me go by with resentment on their faces and a secret salute in their hearts. But this biker, he's hanging in. And I didn't come all the way out here to have my manhood challenged, believe me. I came here to flaunt it, such as it is. 
 I'm not a car guy, per se, though I am male, after all. That is, I have the chromosome. It's a recessive trait, fortunately; I live in Manhattan. But I've owned cars, even a new car. A nice, expensive one, in fact, a convertible. All right, so I sold it to pay for psychotherapy, but that's beside the point. Actually not; both have a lot to do with bolstering self-image.
In fact, self-image is the reason I'm driving what I'm driving where I'm driving it. Not that mine needs bolstering at the moment (adjusting, perhaps), but the idea of driving as a metaphor for masculinity seemed worth testing.
So I came here to Mount Tamalpais State Park in Marin County, just north of the Golden Gate Bridge, which just happens to be the place where more car commercials are filmed than in any other. It's a fantasy locale, in other words, where television images tell you you're supposed to envision yourself as the kind of driver you're not but wish to be, and maybe by extension the kind of man you've always been in your curious, wishful dreams.
The car, a test vehicle provided to The New York Times for a fee, is a new BMW Z8, silver, the kind that James Bond drove in "The World Is Not Enough," which, as images of manhood go, is pretty much antithetical to my own reality and coincidental with my reveries; I'm not claiming any particular originality in my daydreams. It really pleased me when a teenager on a skateboard called to me as I left the parking lot of my motel.
"Yo, James, nice car, dude," he shouted. "Peel out!"
It's a sports car of sports cars: low to the ground, with a long snout, snazzy dual tailpipes, tight steering, red and black leather interior and a simple elegant dash, not to mention a sound system better than the one I have at home (even though all I'm listening to is NPR -- so shoot me).
The accelerator pedal was so responsive it seemed to react when I sneezed. (Without effort, I got it up to 110 on the freeway, and the car just seemed to be coming out of a yawn and showing some interest in the driver when I began to worry about the police and chickened out down to the speed limit. Some James Bond.) The retail price is somewhere north of $130,000.
And it is made for the roads of Mount Tam: the climbing curves that dip in and out of a pine forest on the Panoramic Highway on the way in; the caverns, cliffs and twisting, tire-squealing hairpins of Ridgecrest Boulevard heading inland to the mountain's east peak; the straw-colored hills and fields with the precipitous drops toward the distant Pacific and views from above the clouds on Bolinas Ridge Road; and the magnificent drop through the viney redwoods to Lily Lake on Bolinas Fairfax Road, countless S-curves cutting through fog that blows in suddenly like cold smoke.
The variegated terrain is one thing that makes Mount Tam so appealing to auto manufacturers and their advertising agencies. The scenery isn't immediately locatable; in a way, it's generically beautiful, which allows commercials to speak to a national audience; your fantasy just might be possible in your neighborhood. And there are a lot of different fantasies you can create up there, from exotic family vacation to lovey-dovey-couple-in-an-econo-compact to luxury cruise to, well, James Bond. (Another thing is that there are few roadside eyesores like telephone poles, guard rails and signs. Also, the roads are owned by the state parks department, which charges no use fee.)
In any case, the photo and film crews go up there in a steady parade. According to a list compiled by the California Film Commission, some 60 or so different ads have been shot on Mount Tam since 1996, including spots for dozens of makes and models, from BMW, Porsche and Mercedes-Benz to Honda, Ford and Subaru.
"You can shoot anything up there," said Jeff Miller, a freelance producer of commercials who has shot ads for Mazda and Lexus on Mount Tam. "It is almost always clear because even when San Francisco is clouded in you're above the cloud level, and what you get is a layer of cotton. On a clear day it's spectacular as well. I've been there when there are paragliders, and it's unbelievable."
Unbelievable isn't a bad word, because the combination of the scenery, the blacktop and the sports car gave me an experience unlike any I've ever had. If it were only the car, I'd be afraid of being perceived as one of those guys with two divorces, an orangey tan, a comb-over and ponytail (even though I have none of those things) trying to send out sugar daddy vibes to young babes. But the environment clearly influences this scenario, and the only reaction I get from anyone, aside from that teenager, is a 70-something gentleman's stopping me in the parking lot of the motel to reminisce about his T-Bird.
In any case, on the mountain, it feels like a visit to another world, a place where there is, indeed, such a thing as a driving muscle that makes you feel hormonal when you flex it. I confess to a testosterone rush; well, maybe not a rush so much as a gradual accrual.
For two long afternoons, Mount Tam has been miraculously and happily free of film crews (though I did run into some habitual park users who crabbed about the clogged roads and traffic jams the crews cause). And I began the way you might expect a city-dwelling, subway-riding, pale-skinned, confrontation-avoiding, middle-age fellow to begin: tentatively, grinding the gears occasionally, underusing the power in my control, and naturally terrified of an accident or even of scratching the slick paint job that probably cost more than all of my furniture.
As I grew more confident and adventurous behind the wheel, however, more eager to test the Z8's cornering capabilities at higher speeds and higher altitudes, more able to soak in the scenery as I drove without losing concentration and my hold on the road, more intent on tailgating the not-so-fierce, not-so-speedy, not-so-opulent vehicles on the mountain and forcing them humbly to the shoulder, I felt my spine straightening and a swagger gathering in my chest. I felt like a worthy person, a topic of conversation. I felt like anything that was have-able was something I deserved as much as anyone did. This was, after all, my own personal commercial I was temporarily living in.
As for the manliness thing, I don't know. The encounter with the guy on the motorcycle gives me a clue. It is the last couple of hours of my time on Mount Tam, my last ascent up into the park. I'm pushing it, being as reckless as I get, feeling my oats. It's in my head that I want to take this guy, dust him, make him feel like he can't keep up. Does he feel the same way? Is this an actual contest? We go up the mountain, maybe 20 yards apart the whole way; he never really gains on me, but I can't tell if he's trying. At some point, he veers off onto a fork in the road, leaving me to ponder my performance. How manly am I? Manly enough? It doesn't matter what fantasy you're in; there's always some doubt that creeps in on that score, isn't there?

HEADLINE: OPEC Leaves Quotas Intact, but Says It Can Pump More 

BYLINE:  By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: OSAKA, Japan, Sept. 19 

 BODY:
The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries left its current production quotas intact at a meeting today but declared that it was ready to pump extra oil on short notice if shortages developed, including any resulting from an American attack on Iraq. 
 By deciding not to authorize any additional pumping of crude, OPEC makes it somewhat more likely that inventories will continue to fall in oil-importing countries, which in turn could lead to higher prices that would damage an already fragile global economy. 
 But OPEC ministers went out of their way before and after their meeting today to say that they were prepared to increase output at a moment's notice if any acute shortages developed and if prices soared for any reason. 
Oil traders had been expecting OPEC to leave quotas unchanged today, and the price of crude oil rose only 2 cents, to $29.50 a barrel, in trading in New York. 
Rilwanu Lukman, the current president of OPEC and Nigeria's top oil official, said at a news conference after the meeting that while the group had not specifically discussed its response to an attack on Iraq, the member countries would respond immediately to any shortages that an attack might cause. "'We stand ready to move," he said.
Some ministers from Arab countries also said that they were ready to pump more oil quickly to keep oil prices stable if war occurred. "If there is a supply disruption, we will satisfy the demand in the market, whatever the reason," said Chakib Khelil, Algeria's minister of energy and mines. The cartel is now officially pumping 21.7 million barrels of oil a day, although industry experts estimate that member countries are exceeding that by about 1.5 million barrels a day.
Alvaro Silva Calderon, OPEC's secretary general, cautioned in an interview tonight, however, that while the cartel wanted stable markets, the effects of a war in Iraq could not be predicted. "Whether there is a war is out of the control of OPEC -- the consequences of a war are out of the control of any person," he said.
OPEC scheduled its next meeting for Dec. 12 in Vienna. Mr. Khelil of Algeria said that the group wanted to wait until then in the hope that the economic health of major oil-consuming nations and the political situation in Iraq would become clearer.
Still, OPEC ministers have changed quotas in the past by using telephone conference calls, and could do so again if the need arose, Mr. Lukman noted. 
A communique released at the end of today's meeting said that "OPEC is committed to continuing to monitor the market and to taking any further measures, including the convening of extraordinary meetings, when deemed necessary, as has been done in the past, to maintain prices within the range of $22-$28" a barrel. (OPEC tracks the prices of seven grades of oil, and its benchmark is typically a couple of dollars lower than the price of oil traded in New York.)
Iraq is one of the 11 members of OPEC, although it has no production quota from OPEC because its output has been limited by United Nations restrictions and, more recently, has slowed to a trickle because of a series of pricing disputes. Saddam Hasan, Iraq's deputy oil minister, led the Iraqi delegation in attending all the meetings here today but did not speak to reporters.
A bigger concern for oil traders lies in the proximity of the Iraqi army to the oil fields of Kuwait. Iraqi forces destroyed much of the pumping equipment during their retreat in the Persian Gulf war in 1991, although production resumed with surprising swiftness after replacement parts were flown in.
Sheik Ahmad al-Fahd al-Sabah, Kuwait's acting oil minister, warned here before the start of the meeting that Iraq could retaliate against Kuwaiti oil fields if the United States attacked Baghdad. "Yes, he has done it before -- we have to be worried all the time," Sheik Sabah said.
Mr. Lukman and other oil officials here said that they did not believe recent warnings from oil-consuming nations that oil supplies were too low, pushing oil prices higher as a result. Mr. Lukman estimated that fears about a possible war in Iraq had pushed up prices by $3 or $4 a barrel, and noted that prices had fallen more than a dollar a barrel in a single day earlier this week when Iraq said that it would let weapons inspectors in again.
"It showed perhaps we are right in assuming the price is not due to fundamentals," he said.
The International Energy Agency, a Paris-based group that represents oil-importing countries and tends to push for greater production and lower prices, has been warning lately that stockpiles are not high enough. Antoine Halff, a principal administrator of the agency, said today that what mattered was not the official quotas but how much oil is actually produced by OPEC, especially given that many countries have been cheating lately and producing more than their quotas.
"Official OPEC quotas don't matter as much as actual production," he said.
Mr. Lukman said that OPEC wanted member countries to show greater discipline in adhering to their quotas, but characterized compliance as "voluntary" and gave little emphasis to the subject. Oil analysts said that OPEC was at the very least turning a blind eye to overproduction, treating it as a way to balance supply and demand and stabilize prices without resorting to changes in quotas, which require a lot of negotiation.
"It has been coordinated cheating, and that shows the organization is aware of the need to supply the market," said Raad Alkadiri, an analyst with PFC, a Washington consulting group formerly known as the Petroleum Finance Company.
Today's meeting was haunted by ministers' grim memories of their last meeting in Asia, which was held in Jakarta in 1997. OPEC members raised quotas then just as Asian economies turned out to be heading for a crash, and the combination produced extremely low oil prices in 1998 and 1999 that ruined the budgets of many oil exporters.
As Mr. Lukman observed this evening at the conclusion of his news conference, "We don't want a repeat of Jakarta, and maybe that has something to do with our caution."
