Bergstresser, Democrat), two other members of the Board of Selectmen and the 230-member Representative Town Meeting, all elected to two-year terms.CODES: Area, 203: ZIP, 06807.STATE OF THE ESTATES: Cos Cob has not been without its large estates and wealthy people. For example, Col. Robert Montgomery, who collected as many cone-bearing species of trees as he could find, gave his 62-acre property on Bible Street to the town in 1953 as a garden education center called the Montgomery Pinetum. Workshops, trips, classes, lectures and the May Market plant sale are held there annually. The author and naturalist Ernest Thompson Seton established a forerunner of the Boy Scouts on his Orchard Street property in the early 1900's, where Cos Cob schoolboys were taught Indian crafts and self-reliance. His wife, Grace, was a writer and a founder of American Pen Women; their daughter, Anya Seton, was a popular novelist. In 1912 the estate was sold to Maurice Wertheim, a wealthy New Yorker. His daughter, Barbara W. Tuchman, the Pulitzer Prize-winning historian, had three daughters, two of whom are suing each other over the division of the proceeds from the pending sale of 43 acres to the town, which has a contract to purchase the property. A trial in Stamford Superior Court is expected in October. The town has already bought 70 contiguous acres from the Pomerantz family, relatives of the sisters. The town will spend $35 million on the 113 acres. Map of Connecticut highlighting Cos Cob.

SECTION: Section 2; Column 1; Arts and Leisure Desk; Pg. 7

LENGTH: 1408 words

HEADLINE: THEATER; 
Langston Hughes Meets Damon Runyon, Eventfully

BYLINE:  By MARJORIE ROSEN 

 BODY:
SETBACKS, splintered hopes, crazy risks.
 Hardly a musical has come to town that has not had to clear hurdles as high as an elephant's eye, and "Little Ham," which opens on Thursday at the John Houseman Theater, is no exception. 
 Billed as a "jazzical," this fable, based on Langston Hughes's obscure 1936 folk comedy of the same name, is about inhabitants of a Depression-era Harlem neighborhood who, led by a rogue named Hamlet Hitchcock Jones, must reclaim their beloved numbers game from two flea-brained mobsters. At the Hudson Guild in Chelsea, where it had a showcase last December, "Little Ham" won raves. Bruce Weber, in The New York Times, called it "a jazzy musical bauble with nothing to recommend it but fine songs, a cast with sass and charm and an attractive, modest production." It would, he suggested, make a fine last-minute Christmas gift.
This is the kind of review producers fantasize about, since it is usually sure-fire bait for backers. Yet in this post-Enron, post-Sept. 11 and post-dot-com economy, finding investors for any show can be a roll of the dice. Worse, while Broadway revues featuring black performers and songwriters, like "Ain't Misbehavin' " and "Sophisticated Ladies," have enjoyed success, most original shows about black life fight a losing battle for audiences. 
But Eric Krebs, the producer of "Little Ham," insists that his show has universal appeal. "This is not a black musical in the sense that it deals only with black issues," he said. "It's about little people getting inspired to overcome obstacles in our society and disenfranchised people trying to climb into the mainstream."
"Little Ham" began its own journey into the mainstream in 1985, when Mr. Krebs, who has taught theater at Rutgers for 33 years, was searching for a play for his students to read. He came across Mr. Hughes's comedy and, beguiled, immediately showed it to his friend Judd Woldin, the Tony- and Grammy-winning composer of "Raisin," the 1974 musical based on Lorraine Hansberry's play "Raisin in the Sun."
Mr. Woldin, who had worked with Mr. Krebs on a failed musical, "King of Schnorrers," took "Little Ham" with him on a train trip to Florida. By the time he returned, he says, he was so inspired that he wrote eight songs.
A few months later, Mr. Woldin and Mr. Krebs held a staged reading of "Little Ham" at the George Street Playhouse in New Brunswick, N.J., where Mr. Krebs was artistic director. Mr. Woldin rearranged Mr. Hughes's text and introduced 14 songs. But Mr. Woldin's lyrics were inconsistent, and the play creaked. So he contacted the lyricist Richard Engquist, with whom he had collaborated on a musical, "Lorenzo," about Mozart's librettist, Lorenzo da Ponte, in 1981.
"I had just seen Richard's musical 'Kuni Leml,' and his rhymes were so brilliant, every one just snapped like a bullwhip," Mr. Woldin said. "I played him my score, and he said: 'Judd, half your lyrics are fine. The other half I can improve. But we've got to write some new ones.' And that's the way it turned out."
The creative team also enlisted Dan Owens to write the book. Mr. Owens, a graduate of the Yale School of Drama whose plays have been produced by the Negro Ensemble and the Afro-American Studio Theater, was working for the New York City Human Resources Administration. He met with his "Little Ham" collaborators during lunch hours. His mandate was to freshen up Mr. Hughes's play.
"When I looked at it," Mr. Owens said from Seattle, where he now lives, "I thought about 'Guys and Dolls.' So I said, 'Yes, it's Harlem, yes, it's Langston Hughes, but let's bring another flavor to it: Damon Runyon.' Langston Hughes wrote a more naturalistic kind of theater. I was just trying to make his characters bigger -- and funnier." Eventually, at Mr. Woldin's suggestion, Mr. Owens created a white villain, Louis (The Nail) Mahoney, and strengthened the title character, Ham, a former shoeshine boy who eventually saves Harlem and finds love with the unattainable beautician Miss Tiny Lee.
This new "Little Ham" was staged at the George Street in 1987. "We all felt very good about it," Mr. Owens said, "but we knew it still needed work."
So the collaborators made changes -- "missteps," Mr. Owens now calls them -- for a two-week run that fall at the Westport Country Playhouse in Connecticut. The reception was disastrous, Mr. Engquist said, and "Little Ham" languished. The writers went on to other projects, and Mr. Krebs, distracted by more pressing ventures, lost the rights. "Every year, I'd call the agent," he said. "Finally, two years ago, she said, 'Yup, the option is available again.' "
Then, serendipity of sorts. Donna Trinkoff, the artistic director of the nonprofit Amas Musical Theater, which is devoted to producing multiracial projects, suggested to Mr. Krebs, who is chairman of the Amas board, that the company showcase "Little Ham" at the Hudson Guild. Mr. Krebs invested about $150,000, and the fledgling director Eric Riley, the choreographer Leslie Dockery and the conductor David Alan Bunn joined the effort.
Mr. Riley, who had been an actor and dancer in shows like "Ain't Misbehavin' " and "Once on This Island," wanted "to avoid making the characters cartoons," he said. "I didn't want people to feel that they weren't human. There's a certain strength about these people who take back their neighborhood." Mr. Riley also breathed new life into songs like "On the Side of the Angels," which, he said, "screamed out to be a gospel number."
In contrast to Mr. Riley, the songwriters were veterans. Mr. Woldin has written seven musicals. "Raisin," the most visible, took 10 years to get to Broadway, in part because investors were wary of backing a black musical. What's more, he says, the play's producer, Robert Nemiroff, who was also Ms. Hansberry's widower, was inexperienced.
"Even though we got 40 rave reviews, the show never went into the black," Mr. Woldin added. "So I had a musical on Broadway for two years and then two on the road, and I had to waive royalties to keep it going."
But the worst part was the dashed expectations. "You think you've rolled the stone up the mountain, only to find you're in worse shape than before," he said. "It was very serious, and I went into a terrible depression."
Mr. Woldin's most recent musical, "The Prince and the Pauper," was produced late last year in Seattle and St. Paul -- "to standing ovations," he reported.
Mr. Engquist, the lyricist, joined the conductor Lehman Engel's Musical Theater Workshop in 1972, "as a fluke," he said. A former magazine and book editor who now teaches at the workshop, he added: "At the time, I was staying home and taking care of my small children while my wife, a professional writer, was supporting the family. And I got caught up in lyric-writing." Since then, he has written lyrics for 25 shows. But only one was a financial success: "Kuni Leml," which won four Outer Critics Circle Awards.
Did Mr. Woldin or Mr. Engquist have reservations about being white and writing a black musical? "Never," Mr. Woldin said. As a teenager, he played piano with a black jazz band at the Club Caravan, a Greenwich Village strip joint. Later, he was in house bands featuring musicians like Coleman Hawkins, he arranged two albums for Lionel Hampton, and for 17 years he had his own jazz trio at Windows on the World. "Of all my shows, 'Little Ham' was the most natural," he added. "Anybody who writes a musical has to accept the responsibility of getting into whatever is required."
Mr. Engquist said: "Some people say I've got a lot of nerve trying to write for black people. I say, 'Well, I've written six shows for Jewish people, and I'm a Minnesota Swede.' You've got to be able to write for anybody."
After the rosy reviews last winter, Mr. Krebs coveted a Broadway production, but in the wake of Sept. 11, he couldn't raise the necessary $3.5 million. So he booked "Little Ham" into an Off Broadway theater, the John Houseman, which he himself built and holds a long-term lease on, and budgeted it at $750,000. Even so, investors were scarce, and Mr. Krebs initially put up $150,000 of his own. But in recent weeks, backers have been buzzing around like bees to honey. "By the opening," he said, "none of the money invested may be mine."
For him, every gamble along the way was a no-brainer. "This show," he said, "is simply too good not to let happen."

Little Ham
John Houseman Theater, 450 West 42nd Street. In previews; opens Thursday.

 CORRECTION:

HEADLINE: ART/ARCHITECTURE; 
New Yorkers Now, Their Gifts Were Nurtured in Texas

BYLINE:  By EDWARD M. GOMEZ 

 BODY:
SEVERAL fast-emerging artists in New York have been generating the kind of creative heat that tends to catch the art world's attention -- and lately has. All of them -- Susie Rosmarin, Giles Lyon, Jeff Elrod and Julie Mehretu -- are painters, and their work, ideas and personalities are unmistakably varied. But their professional histories have something in common, perhaps unexpectedly: strong, formative links to Texas, specifically to Houston's vibrant art scene.
 "In Houston, there's a lot going on, but you're never overwhelmed by all the art that's available," said Ms. Rosmarin, a painter of bold, geometric abstractions who moved from Houston to New York four years ago. "There's no pressure to follow any dominant trend. It's easier to develop in a place like that." 
 Ms. Rosmarin's dealer in Houston, Fredericka Hunter, the director of the Texas Gallery, agrees. "Houstonians are especially nonhierarchical," she said, "without the social or economic restrictions you see, say, in Dallas. "For artists, if there's something they want to do, they can make it here." 
Ms. Hunter, who has been involved in Houston's contemporary-art scene for three decades, credited the city's museums for supporting local artists. "Curators are really tapped into the local scene, where interest in abstract or nonrepresentational painting has been especially strong."
Ms. Rosmarin's abstract work is on view in her first solo show in New York, at the Danese gallery. Before heading north, Ms. Rosmarin, 52, worked in the shipping and receiving department of Tootsie's, a women's clothing store in Houston run by her brother. Her paintings, with their energetic colored grids and stripes, have been influenced, she said, by the gingham checks and other fabrics she saw there. Recently she based a painting on a pattern on a miniskirt that caught her eye in Chinatown.
"My early paintings were more conceptual, more mathematical," she said at her studio in the Greenpoint section of Brooklyn. "I liked Sol LeWitt's art and made my own 'all-the-variations-of' works based on geometric shapes." In black and white, Ms. Rosmarin painted the fuzzy gray "snow" of blank television screens, an early exercise in replicating random patterns in the everyday environment.
Later she developed a technique in which she marked off sections of canvases with narrow strips of masking tape. When painted over with acrylic, the canvases yielded precisely measured horizontal stripes after she removed the tape. By painting stripes in the same manner perpendicular to each previous layer of stripes, Ms. Rosmarin found that she could make either spontaneous or more controlled grid-based patterns that recalled woven or printed fabrics.
Well known among her peers as a disciplined artist who often experiments on small canvases before making larger ones, Ms. Rosmarin feels strongly, she said, that her work "is about sensation." 
"For a long time in science and art, we've mistrusted our senses," she added. "But there's no irony in my work. I'm interested in the experience of seeing. I've had it with postmodernist cynicism that doesn't allow you to appreciate painting or a painting as an object. I'm interested in what we know through our sensory perceptions." 
Ms. Rosmarin, who admires the hard-edged works of the veteran, tape-and-paint abstractionist Al Held, said she does not paint over errors. "If I make a visible mistake in a line of color, I don't fix it," she said. "It's all part of the process."
Giles Lyon said: "Susie's obsessed with process. As an artist, she's the real deal." 
Mr. Lyon, 35, who shows his wildly abstract, mixed-media canvases at Feigen Contemporary in Chelsea, got to know Ms. Rosmarin after he arrived in Houston in 1989 to take part in the Core Program at the Glassell School of Art, which is operated by the Museum of Fine Arts. Now celebrating its 20th anniversary, the artist-run Core Program provides young artists with stipends and studio spaces for up to two years. It has become one of the most renowned museum-sponsored residency programs in the United States. Recently it started accepting critic-curator participants, too.
In an interview at Feigen, Mr. Lyon, a buoyant and loquacious native of New Jersey, recalled that thanks to the Core Program, he and his fellow artists "could really dive in and not think about anything except our work." In the 1980's, he said, Houston's "nascent art scene" was nurtured by Core Program alumni who remained in the city after their residencies ended to start their professional careers.
"I was probably as influenced by the sky and the light and the space in Texas as I was by the people I met there," Mr. Lyon said. An admirer of the painter Philip Guston's cartoonish abstract art, he said: "I don't want a painting to be a picture. I would like it to be a thing." With titles like "King Kong Napalm" and "Star Stock," his thickly encrusted works on canvas feature biomorphic squiggles, scattered puddles of color, thickets of Dr. Seussesque protrusions and such collaged items as cut-up credit cards and his grandfather's old neckties. "I'm fascinated by all the complexity in the world today," Mr. Lyon said. "Essentially, my work is about sprawl."
By contrast, the work of Jeff Elrod, 35, a native of Texas and a Core Program alumnus from the early 1990's, seems less dynamic and more studied. Mr. Elrod, who shows his work at Leo Koenig Inc. in SoHo, earned an art degree at the University of North Texas in Denton at a time when the artist-teacher Vernon Fisher was regarded as especially influential there. (Mr. Fisher is known for a wide-ranging body of conceptualist works that often combine texts and images.)
To create his spare canvases of nearly all-over color, Mr. Elrod first makes sketches with computer-based drawing programs. Using projections and masking tape to "draw" razor-sharp lines, he transfers an image line for line to canvas. After rolling paint onto a canvas, he removes the tape to yield larger versions of his initial sketches. Technically and aesthetically, Mr. Elrod's work combines analog (that is, handmade) and digital (or high-tech).
"He's plugged into so many interesting ideas," Mr. Lyon said of the inventiveness and concentration that Mr. Elrod, his friend, brings to his work. "He's a maniac."
JULIE MEHRETU, 31, who was born in Ethiopia and grew up in Michigan, has made the evolving nature of urban space a central theme of her abstract paintings and drawings. A Core Program resident from 1997 to 1999, she now keeps a studio in Harlem near the Project, the gallery that represents her in New York.
Ms. Mehretu, who has lived around the world, is now exhibiting a large painting, "Retopistics: A Renegade Excavation" (2001), in "Out of Site," a group show at the New Museum of Contemporary Art in SoHo. She also just exhibited her work at the White Cube art space in London. 
"Houston offered a completely different visual experience," Ms. Mehretu said. "It was very open, sprawling, without a traditional center. I was there when, working backward, this largely suburban place renovated neighborhoods to create more of a downtown."
Ms. Mehretu uses a computer to make drawings or manipulate source material like architectural plans of airports, then she transfers this imagery to her canvases. Streams of dashes, arcing lines and colored forms swirl tempestuously in the broad pictorial space of her compositions.
While the imagery the artist uses in her work might refer to the actual built environment, she said she thinks of the marks she makes symbolically, "as agents that have character and behave in certain ways, as though they're constructing or deconstructing societies." Humans create and occupy many different kinds of spaces, Ms. Mehretu said. Her works seek to evoke the varied atmospheres and energies that characterize such constructed places.
The Core Program's current director, the sculptor Joseph Havel, attributes the number of notable artists Houston has turned out to its "very risk-taking, freewheeling" atmosphere. 
"At first, that's a little disconcerting," he added, "but it also creates opportunities. This program has exploded the art scene and really made it international."
Of course, only time will tell whether these artists' accomplishments, separately or together, will be short-lived or viewed as something more emblematic of the art of an era. For now, though, veteran art watchers like Adam Sheffer, Ms. Rosmarin's dealer at Danese, are beginning to sense an art-historical current that may have a discernible context, even without a name.
"Looking back," Mr. Sheffer said, "many important artists of the 1970's had studied at Yale, and many significant artists of the 1980's were associated with CalArts, in southern California. Who knows? Someday we may look back and see that for many important artists of this period, Houston was that special, influential place."

Susie Rosmarin
Danese,
41 East 57th Street.
Through Oct. 12.

Julie Mehretu
Out of Site, a group show.
New Museum of Contemporary Art,
583 Broadway.
Through Oct. 13.

HEADLINE: FILM; 
Herzog Goes Hollywood? Yes, but Actually No

BYLINE:  By LISA ZEIDNER 

 BODY:
HE trekked up volcanoes about to erupt and waded through jungle rivers full of poisonous stingrays. He employed tribes of South American Indians as extras, hiring prostitutes to keep them happy on location; he shot scenes involving monkeys that made audiences wince long before there were "we've been kind to animals" disclaimers. For a generation of moviegoers, the German director Werner Herzog is the epitome of the fearless, visionary filmmaker. But to American audiences, at least, he has had rather a low profile recently. So it may be mostly loyal fans who will be shocked to learn where Mr. Herzog now lives: Los Angeles.
 Herzog in Hollywood? It seems about as likely as Sinatra in Sumatra. But Mr. Herzog, 60, says he loves the city. Furthermore, as his new movie, "Invincible," demonstrates, he has not lost his feel for the nightmare landscapes of his ancestral Europe. 
 He was two weeks old in 1942 when a bomb struck the building next door in Munich. His divorced mother found him asleep in his cradle, buried under debris and glass shards -- unscathed. Terrified, she fled with her children to Zachan, a Bavarian village so remote that Mr. Herzog claims he saw his first movie at 11 and made his first phone call at 17. 
A Freudian might use this story to explain the director's fascination with danger and escape. Although Mr. Herzog hates Freud -- "Psychoanalysis is one of the great mistakes of our civilization, as much as witch-burning," he cheerfully declared on a recent Manhattan visit -- he believes that his childhood village strongly informs his imagination. From the Transylvania of "Nosferatu" to the Brazilian rain forest of "Fitzcarraldo," the archetypal Herzogian hamlet is isolated yet vulnerable. And what village better fits the bill than a sleepy Polish shtetl before World War II?
"Invincible," which opened Friday in New York and Los Angeles, follows Zishe Breitbart, a Jewish blacksmith, as he leaves Poland to perform as a strongman in Weimar Berlin. At Hanussen's Palace of the Occult, the simple, good-natured Zishe is "Aryanized," with a name change and a Viking costume, to appeal to his National Socialist audience. But after Zishe (Jouko Ahola) reveals himself and Hanussen (Tim Roth) as Jews, he returns to Poland to warn of the dire threat coming from Germany.
Unlike many past antiheroes -- the morose vampire of "Nosferatu" or the ruthless Spanish conqueror of "Aguirre, the Wrath of God" -- Zishe is a rarity for Herzog: a deeply nice guy. But kindness won't save him. His fate may be quieter than the plague, mayhem and carnage that have formed the climax of past Herzog films, but it is equally tragic and perplexing.
While Mr. Herzog has been busy in Europe, directing documentaries and operas, "Invincible" is his first fictional feature to be released in the United States since "Scream of Stone" in 1991. A $6 million German-English coproduction, "Invincible" avoids what he calls "the usual movie melodrama about Nazis and Jews" and instead showcases his signatures: the mesmerizingly slow pace; the surreal dream sequences; and the haunting images that are -- to use a favorite word of Mr. Herzog's -- stylized.
"What I like about 'Invincible,' " Mr. Herzog said, "is that the focus of the film is more densely concentrated than any other film I've made. I can tell by audience reaction. At 'Fitzcarraldo' they munch on popcorn and hold hands, but here they just sit frozen."
Judging from some of the European press, they are frozen in dismay -- but the lukewarm reception abroad does not appear to ruffle Mr. Herzog.
"In Germany I got very, very bad reviews, but that is not unusual for me," he said. " 'Aguirre' got horrible reviews, and 10 years later, everyone thought the film was great. Germans don't like their poets; it's a tradition. You have to be dead first. Plus with me it's good sport, good hunting -- I can live with that."
Like many of Mr. Herzog's films, "Invincible" mixes fact and fiction, aiming for the kind of "mysterious and elusive" storytelling that the director has called "ecstatic truth." Zishe Breitbart is a historical figure who did indeed die, in a most unheroic way, weeks before Hitler gained power. One of Breitbart's descendants, the Los Angeles producer Gary Bart, approached Mr. Herzog with the material and presented a script. But the script, Mr. Herzog said, framed Mr. Breitbart's journey "as a success story: the strongest man in the world becomes even stronger, makes it to Broadway, end of movie."
Mr. Herzog's invention was to put the innocent Breitbart in collision with an evil, devious Hanussen. Tim Roth plays Hanussen with -- literally -- hypnotic intensity. Mr. Herzog hypnotized all of the actors for his 1976 film "Heart of Glass," and he had Mr. Roth trained in the art for "Invincible." The actor showed a talent for it, Mr. Herzog said. "I looked up in the middle of the scene and realized that the cinematographer was kind of reeling and staggering backward. I had to grab him and shake him by the hair, and then he was back."
The part of Hanussen, Mr. Roth said by phone from Los Angeles, proved "tricky because it requires a bit of overacting."
"You can't get away with conversational acting, because the dialogue isn't naturalistic in any way," he added.
While Mr. Herzog had a legendarily volatile relationship with his favorite leading man, Klaus Kinski (subject of the 1999 documentary "My Best Fiend"), Mr. Roth found the director "very gentle and workmanlike."
"We would have almost musical conversations, really," he said. "We'd talk about him wanting a scene huge or wanting it very soft."
Mr. Roth is one of the few trained actors in "Invincible" -- as many European reviewers have grumbled. They may be forgetting that Mr. Herzog has always worked with untrained actors, most famously using Bruno S., a homeless man who had spent 23 years in mental institutions, as the star of "The Enigma of Kaspar Hauser" and "Stroszek," both featuring naive, mentally unstable protagonists. The Russian pianist Anna Gourari has her first acting role in "Invincible" as Hanussen's piano-playing girlfriend. Mr. Herzog said he knew she would have "great radiation on the screen" the first time he saw her perform, in a concert that won her the Clara Schumann Award.
The Finnish bodybuilder Jouko Ahola, two-time winner of the title "Strongest Man in the World," plays Breitbart. "Invincible" is Mr. Ahola's first acting credit; he barely spoke English when he took the part. "I've been long enough in the business," Mr. Herzog said, "that I know when I am seeing something momentous in a performance -- women instantly like Ahola. Instantly. Women have a clear sense of who is a good, reliable, sweet man."
Mr. Herzog, who casts even the extras himself, found Mr. Ahola by scouring strongman contests. "Zishe had to be a credible strongman," Mr. Herzog explained. "There are so many Herculeses and Schwarzeneggers in movies. We moved a real ship over a real mountain in 'Fitzcarraldo,' not a toy ship on a set in Hollywood, and audiences know the difference. I want audiences back in a very basic position where they can trust their eyes again. When you see the strongman lift 900 pounds, he actually lifts 900 pounds."
Mr. Herzog's reputation as a mad genius who will take any risk for an authentic shot was cemented by "Burden of Dreams," Les Blank's 1983 documentary about the making of "Fizcarraldo." But Mr. Herzog claims he has always worked efficiently, economically and safely. He credits much of the false impression to one of the documentary's cuts, which lops off Mr. Herzog's remorse in a conversation about an extra who drowned after stealing a canoe. The documentary "gave the impression that I was this daredevil who would kill anyone to make a movie," he said, "but because I am very careful, I have never lost a life in relation to shooting, not once."
Given the extreme dangers involved, it's possible to miss how character-centered Mr. Herzog's films are, how tender and respectful he is toward his subjects. In "Little Dieter Needs to Fly" (1997), Mr. Herzog brings the American pilot Dieter Dengler back to Vietnam, where he had been a prisoner of war in hallucinatorily gruesome conditions. And in "Wings of Hope" (1999), the director accompanies Juliane Koepcke to the site of the plane crash in Peru where, at 17, she was the sole survivor and forced to tramp through jungle for 12 days in a torn miniskirt and with maggots swirling in a hole on her arm. Mr. Herzog is less interested in the gory details of these heroic quests than in subtler issues of memory and identity. Can someone who survives the jungle or the Viet Cong return to marry, shop for food, live a normal life?
He emphatically rejects the term documentaries for these films. "I've always been out for a good movie story," he said. "It doesn't matter whether it's true or not. They're not documentaries -- they're too scripted, too staged."
But he does concede that "what the industry would call documentaries didn't get much media attention and weren't theatrically released."
"In the understanding of a common audience, I haven't been all that visible," he said. "But I'm not returning, I've never been away."
With "at least" three projects in the works -- including "Pilgrimage," about the Dalai Lama, to be filmed in Nepal -- Mr. Herzog is often on the road. 
For a while he lived in San Francisco and found that city "too sleek, too leisurely." Los Angeles, where he moved earlier this year, "has more substance," he said.
"One simple example: my wife is a photographer, so we immediately made contact with the best lab, and a young man emerges from the back who is one of the only people in the U.S. who can master daguerreotypes. You might find someone like him in Rochester, at Eastman Kodak, but you wouldn't find him even in New York. In L.A., we run into him on the second day."
His social life there, he reports, involves "no limousines, attorneys, vitamins or pyramid energy schemes."
"The other day I invited Benicio del Toro to have a steak of monstrous size," he said. "He looked like a man who needed a big steak."
Mr. Herzog is also investigating "new horizons and different coalitions" for his filmmaking.
"I have a great advantage -- Hollywood does not need me and I don't need Hollywood. Without them, I've done close to 50 films. I've always worked for audiences, and I'm trying now to connect to wider strata of audiences."
Might films like "Invincible" -- stately in pace, maddeningly hard to pigeonhole, special-effects-free -- be too artsy for Hollywood? "I don't make art," Mr. Herzog insisted.
"I have a great problem speaking about artists. They belong to a time when men fought in pistol duels and damsels fainted on couches. I don't distinguish between art and entertainment, either. I just find it difficult to label myself that way. I'm just a good foot soldier of the cinema, and that's all I want to be."

GRAPHIC: Photos: The German director Werner Herzog in Central Park. His latest film, "Invincible," opened Friday. (Suzanne DeChillo/The New York Times)(pg. 13); Tim Roth runs a seance in Werner Herzog's new film, "Invincible." (Beat Presser/Fine Line Features)(pg. 20)

HEADLINE: Psychotherapy at the Price of Volunteering 

BYLINE:  By DICK AHLES 

 BODY:
IN Connecticut, you can barter four hours of volunteer work in a soup kitchen for a private hour of therapy with a psychologist, courtesy of a group known as Volunteers in Psychotherapy or V.I.P.
 Not that you would be restricted to working in a soup kitchen in exchange for your therapy. You can help out in a hospital, a museum, a shelter, a library or any charity you choose so long as it is recognized as a legitimate, nonprofit organization. 
 V.I.P. was founded in 1999 by four psychologists and two nonprofit specialists to make psychotherapy truly private and available to anyone who needs it, according to Dr. Richard Shulman, one of the founders and the current director of V.I.P. The founders were motivated by the conviction that the treatment offered by their profession and the rules of health insurers are a bad mix. 
If a person isn't up to volunteering for four hours for therapy, he or she can work three hours and pay a $10 fee, or two hours and $25 or one hour and $40. The going rate for psychotherapy in the Hartford area is around $100 an hour.
Volunteers in Pyschotherapy is located in a modest, one-room office over a restaurant on South Main Street in West Hartford Center. It is on the Web at www.ctvip.org.
V.I.P. is overseen by a volunteer board of directors, composed primarily of professional psychologists. 
After a decade at a clinic operated by Hartford's Institute of Living and Hartford Hospital, Dr. Shulman had become increasingly concerned that managed care and its financial pressures were severely cutting into the private therapy the clinic was providing. "People were shifted into short-term group therapies and pills were overemphasized," said Dr. Shulman, who has a private practice but devotes more than 30 hours a week to V.I.P.
He was especially troubled by the rejection of two young women who said they had been sexually abused as children and were seeking therapy. "But managed care wouldn't pay for such 'unfocused' or 'exploratory' therapy discussions," Dr. Shulman said. 
When therapy is approved, "insurers require doctors to send detailed reports about the therapy and the private life of the client every three to six sessions," Dr. Shulman said. This doesn't happen to patients with physical ailments and Dr. Shulman said he sees it as a way for insurers to discourage therapy and therefore discourage payments for therapy. 
Laurie Ahearn, who heads the National Empowerment Center, an organization of recovered psychiatric patients, agreed there are problems. "With the advent of managed care and the rationing of psychotherapy," she said, "the ability to build a trusting and empowering relationship is elusive at best, if not impossible."
The Connecticut Association of Health Plans, a trade association of managed-care companies, has a different view. 
"It is decidedly untrue that there's a blanket effort to keep people from going into one-on-one, long-term psychotherapy," said Keith Stover, a lobbyist for the association. He added that essential information is not collected to discourage such therapy or invade the patient's privacy.
"Its purpose is to help the insurer determine if an effective treatment plan is being followed, whether for a physical or a mental illness," Mr. Stover said.
As to workers' concerns about embarrassing information reaching employers, Mr. Stover said, "Providing such information would violate both state and federal law and Connecticut's law against dissemination of such information is as stringent as you'll find anywhere."
He said a perception that employers would have access to information about an employee's mental health care dates back to a time when large companies were self insurers and there "wasn't a large enough fire wall between the people paying the bills and the people running the company."
He added that most Connecticut employers "recognize the real need to provide good mental health coverage because it makes for happier, more productive employees."
But that may not always be the case. Dr. George Allen, a professor of psychology at the University of Connecticut who also has a private practice, has found that even high-ranking employees of supposedly enlightened managed-care providers had reason to worry about their privacy.
"Over the past decade," he said, "I've seen six individuals who worked in rather high-level administrative positions within the insurance industry. Without exception, all declined using their own insurance benefits to pay for services." 
In a letter he wrote to Dr. Shulman, Dr. Allen said one of the insurance executives told him that if an executive's therapy was reported to his own insurance company, he would according to Dr. Allen "most certainly" lose his job. 
"Ironically," said Dr. Allen, who is a contributor to V.I.P., "these individuals all had the financial resources to ensure their own privacy yet they held positions in an industry that denied the same basic rights to those who were less economically advantaged."
Had Dr. Allen's insurance executives sought the services of V.I.P., they wouldn't have had to worry about their privacy but they couldn't have paid cash for their therapy even though they could afford it. V.I.P. insists that clients exchange at least the minimum one hour of charitable work and $40 in cash for an hour of therapy because, said Dr. Shulman, "giving something as a volunteer is a form of therapy in itself."
"We've had people who were physically abused as kids who worked with hospitalized children, people with physical problems of their own who have worked with handicapped folks," he added.
Those for whom volunteering is therapy come to "appreciate being valued by the volunteer agency," he said.
In 2001, V.I.P. clients received 250 hours of therapy. This year, they have already surpassed 250 hours and are on their way to more than 500 hours. Support for the nonprofit group comes from individual donors, foundations and recently, the federal Department of Health and Human Services.
The psychologists see people with various forms of depression, anxieties, difficulties in coping with everyday life, marital and parenting problems, substance abuse and other disorders. Some clients need many hours of therapy while others require only two or three sessions, which is the number usually sanctioned by insurers before the therapist is, according to Dr. Shulman, "pressed to provide pills and not therapy."
He doesn't entirely blame the insurers for this problem. 
"We shrinks are ultimately responsible for this," he said. "Years ago, we fought for health insurance coverage to include the problems for which people sought psychotherapy. Many therapists and clients were happy at the prospect of a free lunch, of therapy sessions paid for by someone else. But these third-party payees -- employers, governments and insurance companies -- eventually realized he who pays the piper calls the tune." 

GRAPHIC: Photo: Dr. Richard Shulman is one of the founders and the current director of Volunteers in Psychotherapy, which barters volunteer work for therapy. (George Ruhe for The New York Times)

SUBJECT: PSYCHOLOGY (92%); VOLUNTEERS (91%); NONPROFIT ORGANIZATIONS (90%); MENTAL HEALTH PRACTICE (90%); FOOD BANKS & SOUP KITCHENS (90%); PSYCHIATRY (90%); MANAGED CARE ORGANIZATIONS (89%); HEALTH INSURANCE (89%); BUSINESS & PROFESSIONAL ASSOCIATIONS (78%); BOARDS OF DIRECTORS (74%); INSURANCE ASSOCIATIONS (73%); MENTAL ILLNESS (73%); RESTAURANTS (73%); PHYSICIAN PRACTICES (69%); SEX OFFENSES (69%); APPROVALS (64%); MUSEUMS & GALLERIES (56%) MENTAL HEALTH AND DISORDERS; VOLUNTEERS

PERSON: AHLES, DICK

HEADLINE: In the Region/Long Island; 
1 Subdivision, 36 Architects With a Modernist Flair

BYLINE:  By CAROLE PAQUETTE

 BODY:
ON land surrounded by dense trees and low-bush blueberries in the area of Bridgehampton and Sagaponack that is just north of the South Fork's main road, 36 internationally known architects are designing 36 houses that are being built on speculation.
 The project, an 80-acre subdivision called the Houses at Sagaponac, is being developed by Harry J. Brown Jr., a Southampton resident for 30 years and the president of the Brown Companies in Manhattan, an international real estate investment company. 
 The plan is to have widely known architects design homes that are relatively modest and economical by the standards of this very prosperous part of the world. It was conceived after Mr. Brown purchased 150 acres that were in foreclosure for $1.6 million in 1994. Another developer had subdivided the original parcel into 45 lots and built some houses before going bankrupt. 
Mr. Brown set out to construct houses on the property that would be "fun-oriented and blend with the outdoors" and that would revive the spirit of small summer houses typical of the 1960's. And, he said, they would provide "an antidote to the trend" of so-called McMansions that have proliferated on the East End.
The first 10 houses, most of which are in the final permit stages, are expected to be completed by next summer. Six were designed by prominent New York City architects: Henry N. Cobb, Richard Gluckman, Stan Allen, Gisue and Mojgan Hariri, Lindy Roy and Annabelle Selldorf. The other four are by Marwan Al-Sayed of Phoenix, Shigeru Ban and Dean Maltz of Tokyo and New York City, Stephen Kanner of Los Angeles and the late Samuel Mockbee of Canton, Miss.
To advise him on the project, Mr. Brown turned to a friend, the New York City architect Richard Meier, designer of the Getty Center in Los Angeles. Mr. Meier designated the sites and chose the architects -- who range in age from Ms. Roy, 38, to Philip Johnson, who is 96. "Basically, I wanted younger architects so they could show what they could do in residential design," Mr. Meier said. "But I also chose some older, more established ones to create a good mix."
The architects chosen were all modernists, because "that is what I believe in," he said. "Choosing who got what site was arbitrary," he added. "I put people who I thought would get along with one another next to each other so they could talk."
The sites range from 1 to 2.7 acres. The houses, which range from 2,100 square feet to 4,800, will sell from $1 million to $3 million.
Each architect's fee will amount to 11 percent of the construction budget of his or her house. The overall project is expected to cost $70 million and has until now been financed personally by Mr. Brown. The company is currently meeting with banks to arrange construction financing, according to Sunitha Ramachandran, the project manager. 
The sites are relatively indistinctive for the area. Sagaponack, north of Montauk Highway, primarily includes vineyards and pondfront property with homes ranging from "cottages to castles, that sell from just under a million dollars to multimillions," said Judi Desiderio, vice president of Cook Pony Farm Real Estate, which has seven offices on the South Fork. 
"It is an interesting idea to take what otherwise would be just a subdivision of spec houses," said Mr. Cobb, who is designing the National Constitution Center in Philadelphia. 
"It's unusual for a group of architects like this to be invited to shape a subdivision. What its significance will be in the end is hard to say; it will be in the quality of the house," he said. "It will be interesting, a great many different architect's voices in one place operating within the constraints of zoning."
ACCORDING to Southampton's zoning code, 30 percent of each parcel may be cleared, and the rest must be left in its natural state. The maximum lot coverage of a roofed structure is limited to 15 percent of the cleared area. Working within these constraints, the architects received additional guidelines from Mr. Brown, including that the houses be less than 5,000 square feet and that they could be priced for about $250 per square foot.
The Sunshine Group, a Manhattan marketing and brokerage firm, will be involved in marketing the houses, and they will also be made available to local Hampton brokers, according to Mr. Brown.
The architects participating include 10 women. The sisters Gisue and Mojgan Hariri, winners of the Young Architects Forum in 1990, applauded the fact that women were invited to participate. "The 21st century, finally!" Gisue Hariri said. 
Their 4,600-square-foot, four-bedroom L-shaped house, which is the first under construction and is on the largest site, is expected to sell for $2.6 million. The property is adjacent to a site assigned to Zaha Hadid of London and across the road from the Selldorf and Roy sites.
Mr. Cobb's house is on 1.3 acres adjacent to the site of his partner, James Ingo Freed. Including a courtyard, the building covers a total of 12,000 square feet, although the house itself is 3,600 square feet.
It will be the first house ever designed by Mr. Cobb, 76, whose credits include the John Hancock Tower in Boston. "I think after more than 50 years of practice, I'm ready to build a house," said Mr. Cobb, a former chairman of the Harvard Design School. 
His house, which is estimated to sell for $2 million, incorporates "a need for infinite space," he said. Because his lot is relatively small and heavily wooded, he designed the two-bedroom house around an interior courtyard, which includes a circular planting of 13 white fringe trees, which meet at a north-facing 26-square-foot towerlike studio with a 13-foot-high ceiling and high windows, he said. 
A porch runs along the interior of the house, facing the courtyard, with its "idealized landscape that removes the owner from the world of a subdivision," he said. 
Ms. Roy said she liked "the idea of providing an alternative to the overblown McMansions." Known for her designs for "extreme sites, such as a health spa in Botswana" she said she "was taken by the idea of what is a weekend house."
A blue mosaic-tiled swimming pool penetrates the interior of the first floor of the three-bedroom house. A sheet of water cascades from the second level into the pool.
The 3,300-square-foot house will sell for $1.9 million and has been reserved for a "well-known person in the arts field," Mr. Brown said. 
There is also a potential buyer for the 3,600-square-foot house designed by Mr. Gluckman, who is designing the Musee Picasso in Malaga, Spain. 
The three-bedroom simple box-style house, which will sell for $1.95 million, reflects Mr. Gluckman's minimalist approach and is similar to his own house on the East End. It will have a large balcony and features wooden slat-screen panels configured to modulate the sun and shade. 
Mr. Gluckman said that the project was challenging but that he would have favored more restrictions, such as using similar building materials and uniform sizes to "create some homogeneity among the buildings, but with no design restrictions."
Because the sites do not have significant features or views, Ms. Selldorf, who designed the Neue Galerie museum in Manhattan, said the project gave her "the opportunity to create an environment of its own."
Her 3,400-square-foot, four-bedroom house on 1.5 acres, which will sell for $1.85 million, incorporates views of a sunken flower garden, an apple orchard and a courtyard.
The master plan for the Houses at Sagaponac, which includes walking trails throughout the development that lead to a public park, was designed by Stephen Stimson Associates of Falmouth, Mass.
The company is also creating the plan for the park, which is to be on a 13-acre preserved parcel leased from Suffolk County at the northern end of the property. It will include gardens, a pond and tree nursery, according to Anne Bohlen, the landscape project manager.

HEADLINE: In the Region/Westchester; 
Rentals for Seniors Seeking to Live Independently

BYLINE:  By ELSA BRENNER

DATELINE: RYE BROOK 

 BODY:
HOPING to be in the forefront of a shift in the housing market for those 62 and over, Sterling Glen Communities of Manhattan has begun construction of 166 luxury rental apartments here for active adults -- a growing group of seniors who are still independent and do not require assisted living.
 Called Stone Gate at BelleFair, the resort-style complex constitutes the final phase of BelleFair, a 140-acre, 250-home project whose other sections were completed last year by Spectrum Skanska. A "new urbanism" development, BelleFair was designed to emulate some aspects of life in a small town and encourage interaction among neighbors of various ages. 
 The concept of active-adult housing is already a familiar option in places like Florida, Arizona and California. But active-adult housing that is also part of a larger multigenerational community has not been tried elsewhere, said Barbara Kleger, president of Senior Living Consultants, a Philadelphia-based consulting and development firm specializing in retirement housing. 
David Schless, president of the American Seniors Housing Association, a trade group representing senior housing developers, managers and financiers, described Stone Gate as a unique project. 
Stone Gate, which is offering one- and two-bedroom apartments in a four-story building, is being built for people like Rita Aborn, a widow who is in her 80's and still plays golf and bridge and drives a car. "I know I'm old, but I feel young, and I enjoy being with young people," said Mrs. Aborn, who is living in a condominium in Brookline, Mass., and wants to move closer to her daughter, Jane deSeife, a resident of Rye.
So far, about 70 people in addition to Mrs. Aborn have placed deposits on units at Stone Gate, which is expected to be completed at the end of 2003. Some of those who will be moving to Stone Gate have children and grandchildren living in BelleFair, which is operated separately.
Rents will start at $3,600 a month and go up to about $7,000, said Michael Daly, president and chief executive of Sterling Glen, which is a subsidiary of Forest City Enterprises. He said the apartments at Stone Gate, which will range in size from 650 square feet to 1,200 square feet, will all include full kitchens, washers and dryers and wall-to-wall carpeting. Services will include weekly housekeeping and laundry service for towels and sheets, transportation to local shopping and medical appointments and recreational activities. 
Sterling Glen is building a stand-alone active-adult community in Rosyln on Long Island; it is called Bryant Landing and is scheduled to open in 2004. Currently, Sterling Glen has eight operating senior residences and three in development. Its parent company, Forest City Enterprises, is a publicly traded real estate company based in Cleveland that owns and manages commercial and residential real estate properties in 20 states and the District of Columbia.
STERLING GLEN acquired the property here, along with two other existing communities in Connecticut -- Westfield Court in Stamford and Stony Brook Court in Darien -- from CareMatrix, which had planned to build a retirement home next door to BelleFair but then filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection about a year and a half ago. Mr. Daly would not say how much his company paid for the five-acre site here or the other properties.
Hoping to move to Stone Gate when it opens, Mrs. Aborn said she preferred a rental -- even a high-end one -- to tying up equity in a deposit on an ownership unit. "Stone Gate isn't inexpensive," she said, "but there are more expensive communities, and most of them you have to buy into. Personally, I'd rather rent."
In keeping with the goal of integrating Stone Gate with BelleFair, the active adult residents are to have access to the gym, health club, library, computer center and indoor and outdoor pools at BelleFair's 18,000-square-foot meeting house, which is next door to the senior residences. BelleFair also has a specialty food market and small cafe, where many residents congregate for lunch. 
In addition to the amenities at BelleFair, Stone Gate residents will have access within their apartment building to two restaurants, a cocktail lounge, hair salon, fitness room, spa and small private movie theater. 
Mr. Schless of the American Seniors Housing Association observed that as the population of those 65 and over grows and as its members stay healthy longer, the housing market for seniors has been shifting away from assisted living, which was popular in the 1990's and overbuilt in some areas. Statistics from the trade group show that while those 65 and over constituted only 12.7 percent of the population in 1995, they are expected to represent 20 percent of the total by 2030.
Also, Mr. Daly noted, the assumption used to be that as people aged, they would surely need long-term nursing care. "Now statistics are showing us something totally different," he said. "They indicate that 95 percent of the older population will in fact not need that kind of care."
Ms. Kleger, the consultant, described the population considering active adult communities as "people coming from homes they've lived in for 30 to 40 years and planning what they want for the next 20 or more years."
Typically, nursing homes offer round-the-clock care to the very sick. Assisted living is designed for frail elderly residents who need meals and some assistance with daily tasks. Independent living facilities generally offer physically stronger residents two meals a days and the option of cooking in small kitchens in their quarters.
By comparison, Mr. Daly said, Stone Gate will be "like an upscale bed and breakfast with health care available." He said people from 62 to 96 years old have expressed interest in moving to Stone Gate, which will be affiliated with the nearby Greenwich Hospital, which offers geriatic wellness programs. Under this arrangement, there will be a medical suite at Stone Gate, and Greenwich Hospital doctors have agreed to take residents as patients and to make house calls if needed.
Because Stone Gate is being marketed to residents who already live in the area, specifically those who do not wish to relinquish long-established affiliations in the community by moving to distant retirement locations, it is also developing agreements under which tickets would be made available for residents to make use of the Neuberger Museum of Art and the performing arts theater at the State University of New York at Purchase and a golf course at the Doral Arrowwood conference center. 
Stone Gate was designed by Culpepper, McAuliffe & Meaders, architects and interior designers in Atlanta, who specialize in senior living residences, including Hyatt's Classic Residences and buildings for HealthTrust America, a developer of senior housing.
Jim Culpepper, the lead architect on the project, said the main goal with high-end senior housing is to make it "look and feel familiar."
W HAT we're trying to achieve is a country club feel and a country club environment, but with an eye to the special needs of the population using the space," Mr. Culpepper said. "At this high end of the market, what we avoid at all costs is a sterile look."
There will be handrails in hallways to assist residents, he said, but they are designed to look like a chair rail and blend in with the decor. And because seniors often have vision problems, lighting is a paramount concern. "With lighting," Mr. Culpepper said, "the trick is to provide lots of it but without creating an institutional glare."
As Ms. Kleger, who ran focus groups for Sterling Glen before construction started, explained it, "This kind of high-end senior living can't be run-of-the-mill.
"It's not a case of, 'Here's what we offer, take it or leave it,' but rather, 'How would you like us to customize your new home?' " she said. "Similarly, when a place like Sterling Glen offers valet services, it's not just a matter of bringing the car to the door, but also taking the snow off of it and warming it up first. It's all very client-driven."

HEADLINE: At House Museums, Instructive Vignettes From the Past 

BYLINE:  By BARBARA DELATINER 

 BODY:
PICTURE this, if you will: A pair of blue satin men's slippers, complete with silver buckles and Cuban heels, on the floor beside a plush canopied bed. Then consider a homespun shirt made of flax that was grown, cured, dyed, woven and sewn on a subsistence farm.
 Or contrast a cluttered early Victorian drawing room prominently displaying a large, ornate music box with a bare-bones sitting room whose main source of entertainment is a novel by Sir Walter Scott lying open on a table. Or how about a lavish bathroom commode fashioned out of mahogany to replicate a throne juxtaposed with a five-hole outhouse, with the holes ranging from very small to very large. 
 Visiting Long Island's historic homes suggests that the more things change, the more they stay the same, for the haves, the have-lesses and the have-nots. Here are snapshots from a recent tour that included 6 of the 50 or so historic homes open to the public, homes both modest and prosperous from Colonial times, the mid-19th century and the turn of the 20th century.

Rock Hall in Lawrence
There are older houses on the Island, but few as grand -- and as pure architecturally and in terms of furnishings -- as this eight-room Georgian mansion built in 1768 by Josiah Martin on 600 waterfront acres in Lawrence. Mr. Martin, a wealthy sugar planter from Antigua, moved to New York to oversee his business affairs. Rock Hall is a simple yet elegant two-and-a-half-story wooden house built on a high site to catch the breezes from the ocean to the south, yet accessible on the north to the road, now Broadway. 
While later Martins added Federal-style touches, much of today's museum is original since only one other family, the Hewletts, owned the mansion before the Town of Hempstead acquired the house and its remaining three acres in 1948. The Hewletts preserved the oldest rooms unaltered, but they added an east wing and a west porch after buying the property in 1824. 
With the help of an inventory of Rock Hall's contents that Dr. Samuel Martin, the last of his family, included in his 1806 will, the town has been able to recreate the museum rooms authentically.
Delft tiles outline the fireplaces; a "crumb cloth" under the dining room table can be picked up and shaken out after each meal; sea grass carpets were put down in the hallway during the summer; fancy chairs adorned with carved pineapples, symbols of welcome, spruce up the best parlor; in the bedrooms nightshirts for men and women are laid out under brocade canopies, and in truly innovative touch, the front windows have two layers of shutters recessed in the wall and raised by ropes.
Today, a school and subdivisions surround the house, cutting off the water view, and the outbuildings -- the kitchen, slave quarters, icehouse, dairy, smokehouse, carriage house and barns -- are gone. Still it's easy to picture the kind of lives the Martins lived in what was essentially their own kingdom.
They were waited on by the estate's 17 slaves (the most in any household in what was then Queens County, according to the 1790 census). They gave parties that the whole countryside attended, sometimes staying for days, dancing in the spacious hall, playing cards at a tilt-top table, lighted by the silver candlesticks in the best parlor. Palm Beach or the Hamptons, anyone?

Conklin Farmhouse In Huntington
There are no silver candlesticks in the David Conklin Farm House Museum, a modest house in Huntington, and no best parlor, either. The original homestead, built around 1750 by the fifth generation of Conklins to live in Huntington, is a one-and-a-half story simple shingled building. Essentially a one-room house, it had a second-floor loft with "belly windows," so named because you had to lie on your belly to see out of them, and a lean-to where messy work like candle making, butchering and butter churning was done. Four subsequent generations of Conklins added Federal and Victorian sections, now part of the museum. 
David Conklin and his wife, Sybil, raised nine children in the 20-by-20-foot main room with an alcove large enough to accommodate a cradle, a cupboard and an rope bed for the couple with cornhusk and feather mattresses. The older children slept on mats in the loft. 
Life centered around the hearth and the fireplace, which provided heat, light and fire for cooking, clothes washing and bathing. Here, Mrs. Conklin prepared the meals, combed and cleaned the wool from the farm's sheep, soaked the flax cut from its fields and wove both into cloth, which she dyed, using native plants. Indigo was a special favorite because, when set with urine, the blue got deeper with time. 
Though the farm covered 105 acres and provided a self-sufficient life, the Conklins were not prosperous. During the Revolution, Mr. Conklin, a patriot, had to seek refuge in Connecticut and was imprisoned by the British when he returned and then made to work on their fortifications. 
The Conklins and their descendants left no possessions behind, save for the rope bed, which was found in pieces in the basement. There certainly was no inventory, so the Huntington Historical Society, which has owned the property since 1917, furnished the house with appropriate items from the last part of the 18th century. These include a table, chair and foot warmer used by George Washington; a tilt-top table with a family Bible and a "gossip wheel" that was used by two women at a time to spin flax.
Mrs. Conklin would have used samplers like the ones now on the walls to teach her children to read and write, and from them her daughters would learn their stitches. Resourcefulness and aesthetics all rolled into one.

Village House in Orient
Profits made during the Civil War increased the size of the middle class and created something new called the vacation. By the 1870's, Village Lane in Orient had a charming boarding house that allowed city dwellers, mostly from Brooklyn, to escape to the sea and sun. The cost was $7 to $10 for a room for a week, with three meals a day and laundry service, too. 
In its early days, Orient, which traces its origins to 1662, was mostly known as a way station for travelers going to or coming back from New England via stagecoach or boat. To earn extra money, Augustus Griffin, the local schoolmaster, turned his one-story 1798 cottage into a small inn, enlarging it in 1807 and 1832. Samuel Vail, a fisherman, bought the inn in about 1856 and renovated it, adding some Italianate features like a veranda with arched openings.
But it wasn't until the 1870's, when his daughter-in-law Nancy -- Mrs. Jeremiah Vail -- took over, that the summer operation really blossomed. She advertised in the New York papers to attract guests and furnished the inn in impeccable taste. The two front drawing rooms contain upholstered sofas and easy chairs, including platform rockers that rocked but didn't wear out the carpeting, and for diversion, a parlor organ, music boxes, books and checkers. Straw matting covered the floors in summer, and gilded mirrors and oil paintings hung on the wall-papered walls.
A dining room ran the full width of the house, seating 20 guests who ate from pottery produced in Hempstead and Greenport. The upstairs hall, surrounded by bedrooms, became a kind of children's sitting room, complete with small table and chairs for checkers. Although outhouses were still in, a pump brought water into the building.
With the help of her two unmarried daughters and an occasional hired helper, Mrs. Vail ran the inn until her death in 1898. The daughters took over after that; they died in the 1930's. In 1944, George R. Latham, a local boy who made good as a lumber baron, bought the property for about $4,000, supplemented the original furnishings by calling on local residents to empty their attics, and gave everything to the Oysterponds Historical Society, which he founded. Village House is testament to small-town initiative and get-up-and-go. The Vails made their money the hard way: by working for it. 

Conklin House in Old Bethpage
 No matter how hard Joseph Hull Conklin worked, he never really made it. From 1835 to 1842, he started out as a stagecoach driver on the run from Greenpoint in Brooklyn to Greenport, a two-day journey with an overnight stop in the Village of the Branch. There at Thomas Hallock's Inn, Hull Conklin, who was descended from a branch of the numerous Conklin clan, met the innkeeper's niece, Thankful Udall, whom he married in 1842.
The couple moved to Greenport, and since the Long Island Rail Road was putting the stagecoaches out of business, he became a bayman, catching fish, eels, crabs and shellfish and hunting waterfowl. In 1853, the young couple -- now three with their baby, Sarah -- returned to Smithtown and bought a house and two acres of land from Mr. Hallock for $600. They lived in that house until the 1880's, when they returned to the East End. 
Their house, built in 1830, was donated by later owners and moved to Old Bethpage in 1965. It was restored as a typical workingman's cottage, circa 1853. It is a small two-story saltbox with Greek Revival appointments inside. The first floor has a combination parlor and dining room and a kitchen with pantry-workroom off the back. The second floor has two tiny bedrooms and a "lumber room," an old term for storage room.
The furnishings are sparse: a table and chairs and a highboy in the parlor-dining room. A 12-gauge shotgun and powder flask, duck decoys and a threadbare rug can also be seen. There is a baby tender in the kitchen, its legs spread wide to prevent tipping. The workroom holds jars of spices and tools of the bayman like an eel spear and eel raps.
In the absence of family records and heirlooms, the Old Bethpage curators furnished the house using items they considered accurate to the time and the Conklins' economic and social status. The total picture is pretty bleak, indicating just how little the have-nots had.

Westbury House In Old Westbury
The John J. Phipps family did not want for anything. They didn't have to, since Mr. Phipps was the son of Henry Phipps, a partner in the Carnegie Steel Company, and his bride, the English-born Margarita Grace, was a member of the Grace shipping family. So at the turn of the 20th century when the Phippses decided to build a country home on 175 acres in Old Westbury, they were destined to give the palaces of the Old World a run for their opulence.
Planned by George A. Crawley, a London designer, with on-site help from Grosvenor Atterbury, the American architect, Westbury House is a stately three-story Charles II manor, completed in 1906 and surrounded by 88 acres of landscaped grounds, including 25 acres of gardens. 
Walking through the brick and limestone house with 20 rooms on the first two floors -- the servants and children lived on the third -- is like touring an English palace like, say, Hampton Court.
Westbury House is packed with museum-quality art and objects: priceless antique English furniture; crystal and gilt chandeliers; handmade carpets, some of dating to the early 1700's; and paintings by Gainsborough, Reynolds and Sargent. Stradivarius and Guarnerius violins were once stored in a closet behind a panel of fake books in Mrs. Phipps's study.
The estate was a self-sufficient farm, with vegetable gardens, orchards, a dairy, barns, stables, a laundry and for fun and games, two kettle-hole lakes, a swimming pool, polo fields, tennis courts and even a golf course. Fourteen house servants, plus grooms, gardeners and chauffeurs, saw to the family's needs.
It was an idyllic existence until 1959, when Westbury House went the way of many of the millionaires' estates on the Island: out of private hands. The estate, which is on the National Register of Historic Places, became the nonprofit Old Westbury Gardens, owned by a board of trustees and operated as a tourist attraction, with some financial support from a Phipps foundation.

Hallock Farm in Riverhead
Of all these historic homes, the David Halsey Hallock Farm, part of the Hallockville Museum Farm and Folk Arts Center in the Northville section of Riverhead, seems to be most contemporary. Not architecturally or in terms of contents. There is nothing extraordinary or modern about the musty farmhouse and the knickknacks that cover almost every surface. 
It's just that in the late 19th century, the Hallocks, who were descended from the original settlers of Southold in 1640, found an acceptable way to work themselves into the middle class and seem to have enjoyed every moment of acquiring what their newfound money could buy, within reason, of course. As typical hardscrabble, subsistence farmers, this branch of the plentiful Hallock family lived in a house that started out as a simple one-a-half story cottage, probably built in 1765. Succeeding generations, including David Halsey Hallock, who inherited the property in about 1845, added to the basic building, creating a two-story hodgepodge of architectural styles and rooms.
Then during the last decades of the 19th century, the North Fork farmers planted potatoes that could be shipped easily and cheaply. Like their neighbors, the Hallocks were off and running. Soon they would join the middle class.
The farmhouse shows what happens when nouveau riche meets farmers' thrift. For example, a front porch was added in 1907, but the doors and windows for a kitchen addition came from the original 18th-century house. A water pump was put into the kitchen, but indoor plumbing was not added until well into the 20th century. A phone appeared in 1903, but electricity not arrive until the 1920's.
Eventually, the family added the true sign of having arrived: a lawn was planted and the more noxious outbuildings like the chicken coops were moved back away from the house.
The house is preserved as it would have appeared from 1880 to 1910. It is cluttered with doodads, most of them original, acquired from traveling salesmen and mail-order companies, showing that the Hallocks had spare money to spend.
There are all sorts of "modern" laundry devices designed to make washing by hand easier; trinkets like wall hangings made from human hair; an Edison Victrola, a piano, an organ and a Morris chair; Currier & Ives prints; and perhaps the most innovative period piece, a slow cooker, a wooden cabinet that held gallon pails set on ceramic discs that had been heated overnight in the wood stove. When put under the pails, the discs would cook the family's dinner, but they took all day to do it.
Ella Hallock was the last member of the family to live in the house, until 1979. The family had sold the property to the Long Island Lighting Company, which donated some of it -- house, barns, outbuildings and some fields -- and a nonprofit museum farm was set up.
Its mission is to tell the story of rural Long Island, where the potatoes that propelled the Hallocks into middle-class comfort have now given way to wine grapes, the nectar of today's upwardly mobile.

HEADLINE: YOUR HOME; 
Ins and Outs Of Sales Contracts

BYLINE:  By JAY ROMANO

 BODY:
THE purpose of a real estate contract is to provide written documentation of the terms and conditions on which a buyer and a seller agree for the sale of a piece of property. Most people are aware that the failure of either party to live up to those terms and conditions can result in a lawsuit for breach of contract. 
 In most contracts, however, certain provisions, known as contingencies, allow either party, or both, to cancel the contract under certain circumstances. While some contingencies involve inspections to find defects in the property, others, including the mortgage-commitment and home-sale contingencies, go to the heart of the buyer's ability to go through with the purchase. 
 The mortgage contingency is included in a contract when the buyer has to get financing to purchase the property. 
And while it may appear to be relatively simple, the mortgage contingency "can be one of the trickiest clauses in the contract," said John G. Hall, a Staten Island real estate lawyer and former chairman of the New York State Bar Association's Real Property Section.
When drafting a real estate contract, he said, lawyers must carefully define the terms of the mortgage contingency, specifying the amount of the mortgage needed, the maximum interest rate the buyer is willing to pay, and the term of the mortgage.
Just as important as the terms is the language used. Some mortgage contingency clauses, for example, say that the contract is subject to the buyer obtaining a mortgage; others say that the buyer must obtain a mortgage commitment. 
What is the difference?
"If the clause says the contract is subject to the buyer obtaining a mortgage, the buyer is much better off because he actually has to get the mortgage to be bound by the contract," Mr. Hall said, adding that the obvious advantage of such a clause to the buyer typically makes it unlikely that an alert lawyer for the seller will agree to it.
As a result, he said, most mortgage contingency clauses provide that the borrower must obtain a mortgage commitment -- that is, a promise by a lender to make the loan -- within a specific period. Once the commitment is issued the buyer is basically locked into the contract. (That can pose a risk for the buyer, Mr. Hall said, if the commitment expires before the purchaser is ready to close -- most commitments are good for only a certain period, usually between 45 and 90 days -- and the lender declines to renew it because rates have risen so high that the borrower no longer qualifies for the loan. In such cases, buyers can their loose their deposits.)
Accordingly, Mr. Hall said, while a mortgage contingency clause must give the buyer enough time to obtain the commitment -- between 30 and 60 days -- the closing date agreed to by the parties should not be so far into the future as to risk expiration of the commitment.
Another issue that must be addressed when drafting a mortgage contingency clause is what action, if any, the parties must take if the contingency has not been met.
One possibility, he said, is to include language that permits either party to cancel the contract if the buyer does not satisfy the mortgage contingency clause by a specific date. "The problem with that is that the seller's lawyer sometimes falls asleep at the switch," Mr. Hall said, explaining that in such a case, and with such a clause, the contract will remain in force until one of the parties actually cancels it. A better solution -- for the seller, at least -- is for the seller's lawyer to include language in the contract that requires the buyer to notify the seller, within a certain period, if the buyer has not been able to obtain a commitment. "If the buyer doesn't notify the seller that he didn't satisfy the contingency, the contingency clause is of no further force and effect and the contract becomes binding," Mr. Hall said. "And if the buyer can't make the deal, he could end up losing the down payment."
One of the most difficult contract contingencies to negotiate, real estate lawyers say, is the home-sale contingency, in which the entire deal depends on the buyer successfully selling his or her home.
"The problem with a home-sale contingency clause is that there are a number of factors that are totally beyond the control of the seller," said William Selsberg, a Stamford, Conn., real estate lawyer. For example, he said, the seller in such a deal typically has neither knowledge nor control over the sale price, condition or marketability of the buyer's property. Even if the buyer enters into a contract to sell his current home, that is no guarantee to the seller that the deal will ultimately go through.
"It's true that a majority of buyers have to sell their existing home to buy a new one," Mr. Selsberg said. "But if you're depending on your buyer being able to sell his house before he can buy yours, you have to ask yourself, do you really have a buyer?"
There is a way, though, to draw up a home-sale contingency clause that will be acceptable to both the buyer and seller.
Christopher J. LaMonica, a real estate lawyer in Brick Township, N.J., said that some lawyers use what is known as a "72-hour kickout clause" when a prospective buyer must sell a current home to purchase a new one.
With such a clause, Mr. LaMonica said, additional provisions are included that allow the seller to continue to market the home and entertain offers from other buyers. 
The contract also provides that if the seller finds a new buyer willing to purchase the home without a home-sale contingency, the seller can then give the first buyer 72-hour notice to waive the home-sale contingency and set a closing date, or cancel the deal. If the first buyer does not provide the seller with a written waiver of the contingency within 72 hours, Mr. LaMonica said, the seller is then permitted to cancel the first contract, return the first buyer's deposit and enter into a new contract with the second buyer.
"The important thing to remember with a kickout clause is that all of the notice provisions should be very clear," he said, explaining that since timing is critical, the contract must spell out in detail what constitutes effective notice and upon whom such notice must be served. "You don't want your client signing multiple contracts and then ending up being bound to two buyers," he said.
One potential problem with the 72-hour kickout clause, Mr. LaMonica said, is that the first buyer, when faced with choosing between either waiving the contingency or losing the deal, might decide to gamble and waive the contingency.
Dale Orlovsky, a real estate lawyer in Toms River, N.J., said that to protect sellers in that situation, he typically includes a clause in the contract that requires the buyer to come up with an additional deposit -- typically 10 percent of the purchase price -- when signing the waiver.
"A lot of times, a buyer who is waiving a home-sale contingency is putting up a smoke screen," Mr. Orlovsky said. "So you have to make the buyer put up some real money and prove he has the wherewithal to go through with the deal."
While the 72-hour kickout clause is used in parts of New Jersey and Connecticut, it is rarely seen in the New York City area and in places where there is a strong seller's market.
