HEADLINE: Commercial Property; 
Expanding Law Firms Soaking Up Office Space

BYLINE:  By JOHN HOLUSHA

 BODY:
AT a time when financial services companies, traditionally the mainspring of New York's economy, are laying off workers and putting unneeded space on the sublet market, another sector is showing surprising strength.
 Real estate executives say that locally based law firms are growing internally and merging and that the New York offices of firms based elsewhere in the country are expanding as well. They say the growth in bankruptcy and corporate litigation practices appears to have more than made up for the decline in legal work connected with merger and acquisition activity that was so prominent until recently but has fallen off. 
 As a result, law firms have become the largest leasers of office space so far this year. According to figures compiled by Julien J. Studley, a brokerage that usually represents tenants, law firms leased 919,389 square feet of space in January through August of this year. Financial companies were second at 705,613 square feet. 
This is quite a contrast to the same period in 2001, when financial companies were clearly in the lead, leasing 2,596,015 square feet. Law firms were in fifth place with 447,330 square feet.
"Law is the fastest growing industry in New York," said Bruce Mosler, the president of United States operations at Cushman & Wakefield, the brokerage and services company. He said much of the leasing activity was the result of mergers among law firms that want to have their entire staffs under one roof once the merger is completed. 
Mr. Mosler said a deal he helped shape is typical of the trend. The firm of Bingham Dana, which originated in Boston, merged with the San Francisco-based firm of McCutchen, Doyle, Brown & Enersen to form Bingham McCutchen.
Subsequently Bingham McCutchen leased 142,000 square feet on the 19th, 23rd, 24th and 26th floors of the building at 399 Park Avenue, at 53rd Street. This is in addition to space the firm already has on the 19th, 20th and 21st floors and allows it to consolidate its operations from 885 Third Avenue, at 53rd Street.
Increases in the size of the New York offices of law firms based elsewhere in the country are adding significantly to the demand for space here, said Peter L. Malkin, a lawyer who is general partner of the group that controls the lawyer-friendly Lincoln Building at 60 East 42nd Street.
"The New York branches of some of these firms are bigger than the home offices," he said. "A lot of it has to do with international finance and trade because New York is the center of international activity."
No less than 153 law firms have their home in the 1.15-million-square- foot Lincoln Building, which has a law library with 15,000 books that is available to tenants. Although a lot of legal research is done electronically today, "sometimes it is useful to have the books," said Nancy Connery, a partner in the firm of Schoeman Updike & Kaufman.
She said her firm is negotiating to lease another floor in the building's tower in addition to the floor it now occupies, to accommodate growth.
The space became available, she said, when the firm occupying it merged and consolidated in another location.
Because law firms are partnerships, the costs of leasing and equipping offices come directly out of the partners' pockets, rather than from faceless shareholders, a situation that can lead to difficult choices. "Law firms have to strike a balance between image and overhead," said Michael T. Cohen, president of GVA Williams, a brokerage and services company.
"There are some firms who can attract customers while operating in Class B buildings -- but they are in a minority," he said. "Most tend to gravitate to Class A," he added, referring to the newest and best-equipped buildings.
Mr. Cohen said it seems that some current activity is from law firms trying to lock in leases while vacancies are high and rents low compared with the highs in 2000. "Some of them appear ready to use a trough in the cycle to capture that subsidy -- if not now, then next year," he said.
BECAUSE lawyers tend to favor offices with good views and lots of polished wood paneling, they can reduce their capital expenses if they can find space that has already been built by someone else in an acceptable or semi-acceptable fashion.
This was a factor in the move of the firm Richards Spears Kibbe & Orbe from 35,000 square feet at 1 Chase Plaza to 85,000 square feet at 1 World Financial Center, said Ted Rotante, a managing director at the Studley firm. 
"They are growing, so they needed more space, but what impressed them was the quality of the building and the installation," he said. The interior offices, formerly occupied by the investment banking company Kidder Peabody, had "about 75 percent of what they needed already in place," Mr. Rotante said. "That was a key piece of the puzzle because it is expensive to build and it is their own money." 
Building out law firm space costs about $150 a square feet, including furniture and equipment, said Kenneth D. Rapp, a senior vice president of CB Richard Ellis, a brokerage and services company. This is more than it costs for a standard office building, but probably less than for investment bankers who want costly trading desks as part of their operations, he added.
As a result, when a law firm moves out of a space, the next tenant is likely to be lawyers as well, to take advantage of the prebuilt space, brokers say. Not all aspire to the drawing-room look, they say. "Some firms like a lean and mean look that tells clients they won't be gouged with fees," Mr. Rotante said. "Others want to emphasize their long-term presence."
Most recent deals involving law firms have been done in Midtown, said Lewis Miller, an executive managing director of Insignia/ESG, a New York-based brokerage and services company. "Most are Midtown oriented," he said. "They will consider downtown, the East and West Sides, but in the end they want to be in the center because they have to recruit people."
And they like certain types of buildings, where partners can have offices with views on the outer part of a building, with interior space for associates and clerical staff, he said. "They need floors with a high ratio of window space to core space," he said, and they favor floors with 25,000 to 30,000 square feet to accommodate the proper ratio of partners, associates and support staff.
Law firms tend to benchmark each other on things like associates' pay levels and the amount of real estate allocated to each person, said Marcus J. Rayner, a principal in CRESA Partners, a New York-based brokerage and services firm. Most top firms allot about 1,000 square feet per partner.
But with market rents along Park Avenue averaging $62.34 for each of these square feet annually, according to Cushman & Wakefield (down from a peak of $68.99 a square foot in 2000), some firms are seeking to pack people in more tightly.
"If someone can get that down to 600 square feet per lawyer, they would be locking in a tremendous competitive advantage," Mr. Rayner said.
Because the availability of space in a building seldom coincides with the decision of a law firm to expand or merge with another firm, many large firms are involved in what Mr. Rayner calls "the space management business." As space becomes available, the firm leases it protectively and then tries to sublease it on a short-term basis until the need to occupy arises.
Some landlords have been historically reluctant to deal with law firms because the firms have few assets and will not sign leases holding partners personally responsible for rent payments. That reluctance has softened in the current environment of rising vacancy rates, and as a practical matter most firms are growing rather than collapsing.
"The notion that they have no assets is rapidly becoming silly," Mr. Rayner said. "With one or two specific exceptions, they do not go out of business, they grow and produce profits."

HEADLINE: After Graduation, Lessons in Renting 

BYLINE:  By NANCY BETH JACKSON

 BODY:
THE F train packed at day's end with 20-something commuters rumbles toward Brooklyn, but passengers look animated, not exhausted, and chat away as though they're off on a college football weekend. They are living out their dreams of making it in New York City even though they cannot afford Manhattan rents and often make the commute twice a day -- once to work, and once to hang out in SoHo or the Village, East or West.
 The seasonal tsunami of young graduates perched on their first career rungs has swept into town and they are adapting to the realities of real estate in the New York City area. Those with jobs but slender salaries discover that a sort of dormitory life continues, though perhaps with the fitness benefits of a long climb to a walk-up apartment. Even those with well-paying first jobs find that pooling rent money pays dividends in space and surroundings. And countless parents discover new meanings, and the arcane New York City complications, of the word "guarantor." 
 "We definitely sacrifice to live here," said Nissa Larsen, 22, who just moved into a two-bedroom, sixth-floor walk-up in the West Village with two college friends, one of whom sleeps in the living room. "But everyone has to live in New York at some point and I'm glad I'm doing it now." 
Finding that first apartment in the city has always been daunting, but the challenge is even greater today when the rule of thumb used by landlords and brokers calls for a salary of 42 to 52 times the monthly rent just to be considered a prospective tenant. A minuscule $1,200 studio requires a minimum income of $50,000 when many sought-after entry-level jobs, particularly in the arts, fashion and nonprofits, pay under $30,000.
Proof of sufficient income is only one requirement. Securing an apartment means a fistful of cash for credit checks, application fees, security deposits, brokerage or referral fees and perhaps several months' rent in advance. For some, a land-line telephone and cable television become luxuries. Most young people end up bunking with roommates who may or may not be friends, asking parents to co-sign leases as guarantors or shoehorning themselves into spaces smaller and darker than their closets back home. "You feel you must live here and will sacrifice by cobbling it together, because there's no other experience in the United States like trying to live and work in New York," said Anita Visser, executive director of the New York City Rent Guidelines Board. Her agency issues the annual allowable changes in rents for apartments subject to rent stabilization -- a category somewhat akin to a Holy Grail of new renters' desire, and equally hard to find. 
The newcomers find apartments the way people always have -- by word of mouth, classified ads and a lot of shoe leather -- but the Internet now lets their fingers do much of the walking. In a city without multiple listings, realtor Web sites update daily, advertising the latest offerings and open houses as well as explaining the parlance of New York real estate and what documents must be in hand. Some agents conduct almost all of their business online. 
Referral services sign up prospective tenants for a fee and send out e-mail alerts as apartments come on the market. Free services like Craig's List (www.craigslist.org) are visited daily to see what's just been listed for rent, for sale, to sublet or to share. Networks of friends circulate e-mails as apartments become available.
Books like "Gabriel's Apartment Rental Guide" to no-fee apartments and "Zany's New York City Apartment Sales & Rental Guide," each updated annually, make handy references. Internet resources are updated much more frequently, sometimes hourly, but should be checked for accuracy. No matter how much research is done, however, luck and accident can rule in a market where demand far exceeds supply.
IT also helps not to have romantic visions about that first apartment. Erin Brown, 24, a University of Missouri biology graduate who works on commission for a talent agency, jumped at the chance to move into the bedroom a sorority sister was vacating in a two-bedroom apartment in Long Island City. It lacks charm, light and location, but at $425 a month for her share, it gives her a launch pad in the city
"I didn't have any expectations," she said. "I wanted to find out if I could make it -- quote unquote -- in New York." But she admitted she would rather be in the bright lights of Manhattan.
Holly Golightly did not live in Hoboken and those aging buddies in "Friends" don't hang out in Brooklyn. Manhattan is where the jobs and lifestyle are, but fewer and fewer young people can afford to sleep there. Rents dropped somewhat in the last year but, brokers say, picked up again over the summer as the new crop of college graduates started shopping for apartments. The boroughs outside of Manhattan and New Jersey bring more space for the dollar, but the more desirable housing, apartment-hunters say, is not all that much cheaper. 
"The best and the brightest," said Michael H. Schill, director of the Furman Center for Real Estate and Urban Policy at New York University "still want to be here. Unfortunately, most want to live in the same neighborhoods." 
Those neighborhoods for the most part are Core Manhattan - south of 96th Street on the East Side and below 100th Street on the West Side - although neighborhoods like Williamsburg and Cobble Hill have developed their own cachet. The occasional bargain can still be found in the core, particularly in the Upper East Side and Lower Manhattan, but median rent for a newly vacated apartment there is double that in the rest of the city, according to the Rent Guidelines Board. 
"The rents," said Ralph Barocas, president of Rent-Direct, an online rental service, "are not back to what they might have been two years ago, but it's still going to be hard for the individual earning $30,000 to live here. Manhattan is like a country club, but not everyone can afford to join. " 
The salary-to-rent ratio also means that parents often have to co-sign the lease as guarantors. "The landlords leave you no choice," said one father.
Joining the club takes some doing, not to mention compromise.
"It's not totally impossible to find an apartment, but a little bit of stark reality is helpful," said Lynn Spanich, an Upper West Side specialist at the Corcoran Group. "Move uptown or move off the island."
She began scouting out Harlem five years ago and has begun renting apartments in Washington Heights and Inwood on the northern end of the island as neighborhoods all over the city have improved. "Maybe it's not their dream neighborhood, but there's a tradeoff," she said. "The farther uptown you go, the larger the apartments you get. It's rabbit warrens downtown."
Ms. Larsen and her roommates, Catherine Lai and Greta Lundeberg, have re-created their Vassar dormitory experience to be able to live in the West Village. Like others interviewed, they were reluctant to discuss details of their rent, but it takes all three of their salaries from jobs in public relations and nonprofit organizations to meet the rent formula. Ms. Lai sleeps in the living room. In exchange, she gets the view of the Empire State and Chrysler Buildings.
In an earlier era, they might have settled into a residential hotel for young working women. Early in the last century, the six-story Junior League Hotel on East End Avenue offered shopgirls, milliners and teachers a private room, two meals a day and use of a sewing room for $4 to $7 a week. From 1927 to 1981, the Barbizon Hotel on East 63rd was known as "New York's Most Exclusive Hotel Residence for Young Women." Private lodgings were also plentiful for young men in residential hotels. 
A number of such hotels, run by religious and nonprofit groups, survive in Manhattan such as the three women's residences operated by the Salvation Army, the 92nd Street Y's de Hirsch Residence for young women and men and Centro Maria on West 54th Street, where the Religious Sisters of Mary Immaculate look out for young women new to the city.
In exchange for monthly rents of under $1,000, sometimes with meals, young people at such residences may have to observe curfews, eat at prescribed times, forsake alcohol in their rooms and entertain gentlemen callers only in the first-floor lounge.
But almost any apartment requires more than two entry-level incomes. And today's communal living is more often in a two- or three-bedroom apartment (a temporary wall frequently dividing a living room to make an additional bedroom) with roommates of both sexes.
"Culturally we've shifted," said Ms. Visser of the Rent Guidelines Board. "Adults are now willing to share space. But my mother would say you're not a grown-up until you have your own place." 
At 27, Ben Eysselinck, who graduated from St. Olaf College in Northfield, Minn., into the Internet boom, would agree. "Unless you're independently wealthy or are willing to live in a closet apartment, no one in New York at my age/career level can afford to live alone," he said. 
When he, a girlfriend and his sister moved into a one-bedroom apartment in Williamsburg in March 2001, the landlord suggested they add a room by building a wall that would remain when the lease was terminated. Other landlords allow temporary walls. 
The challenge for Mr. Eysselinck, however, was finding someone to share his $1,400 rent when his company downsized him out of a job and his roommates moved. "I say go to the Web first and foremost," said Mr. Eysselinck, an interface developer and consultant. "Web users are a certain class of people and it allows you anonymity."
He suggested creating a new e-mail address for the sifting process and then interviewing the top five candidates personally. But in the end it was gut reaction that counted in his case. "You meet a potential when you're both chatting like blue-hairs over mah-jongg after five minutes."
Since last May he has had a roommate who shares not only the rent but also his views on "film, women, rain-forest deforestation and genetic crop dusting." Best of all, their schedules rarely mesh.
Roommates do not have to sign a lease, but they risk having very few rights if they don't, warned Ms. Visser, who suggested that they put their agreements in writing.
BROKERS are finding that in some sectors like finance, two and three people who could each afford a $2,000 studio are going in together on more luxurious apartments and lofts. "It changes the lifestyle," said Reza Namazi, who specializes in SoHo properties. "It adds glamour and helps your social life for sure."
His clients are often in modeling, film-making, finance and international business. Because of exchange rates, New York still looks incredibly cheap for many young Europeans, he said. 
While rents are not going down "dramatically," he find landlords offering several months free rent or picking up fees to fill new luxury buildings or to keep high-end properties filled.
Matt McGowan, 26, will soon be moving into a one-bedroom, two-bathroom apartment in one of the new Trump towers overlooking the Hudson for less than what some of his friends will be paying for a midrange studio in Manhattan. He and a friend from Lafayette College days are splitting the rent, which he calculates as $3,200 a month after the two months of free rent that was an incentive for signing a 14-month lease is taken into account. What's more, the management is putting up a wall "with a real door" across the dining alcove to give Mr. McGowan his own room with river views.
The native New Yorker graduated four years ago into the dot-com world of six-figure starting salaries and worked in San Francisco before starting his own hedge fund in Boulder, Colo., where he commuted to work by mountain bike. But he missed the city. He came back, lining up his apartment before finding a job.
Sherief Hammad, 25, also in finance, lived near Wall Street for three years after graduating from the University of Pennsylvania, but he wanted to move uptown, splitting the rent with two recent graduates from Georgetown and the University of Richmond. He thought the apartments advertised in Mr. Namzi's window too expensive, but walked in anyway to see if SoHo would be affordable if three shared. 
"I saw places up to $9,000, but a lot of landlords were ready to negotiate," he said.
After looking at five apartments, he and his roommates, also in finance, found a SoHo duplex that had been an art gallery. For what a studio could cost, each has his own room and can walk out into a neighborhood full of attractions. But the real payoff is the gallery space where they can gather after working long hours, sometimes seven days a week, and have friends over 
Finding that first New York apartment is the stuff of movies, books, television series and life passages, but it also has a dark side. Illegal conversions of buildings, whether private homes or warehouse spaces, violate city building and fire codes. Hair dryers and computers can overload electrical circuits in spaces without fire alarms or sprinklers. Fire escapes are sometimes nonexistent or inaccessible. Tenants in an illegal conversion can be required to leave if the violation cannot be corrected. If there is any doubt about legality, prospective tenants should check with the city's Department of Buildings before signing a lease.
The tight market also affects the labor pool. Mr. Schill, the Furman Center director, worries that the city's economic development will suffer if people start turning down jobs in New York because they cannot afford the housing or leave because they do not want to leave in rabbit warrens. "It's unacceptable that people have to pay half of their income for rent," he said. "Housing needs to be thought of hand in hand with economic business development."
Rebecca Steelman, who came to New York after graduating with honors from Southwestern University in Texas two years ago, is one of the bright young people who came and left. With her college roommate, she moved into a hostel dormitory with 12 other women while they looked for an apartment they could afford as waitresses making about $100 a night. They tried the usual routes for three months without success. A co-worker gave Ms. Steelman, fluent in Spanish, the name of a man who found cheap housing for Mexican workers. "He showed us terrible apartments in bad neighborhoods, but we were so desperate, we almost said yes anyhow," she remembers.
THEN a fellow waitress mentioned an apartment in Queens, only two subway stops from Manhattan, with a $750-a-month rent that included utilities.
"We screamed for joy when we got it," she said. "Never mind that there were only two tiny windows in the kitchen that looked upward to a patch of sky. So what if there were pipes all over the place. Call it modern art. When winter came, we still had to stay fully dressed at home or crawl into bed right away to keep warm. But we decorated and made do."
Her tradeoffs were the proximity to Manhattan, great neighbors and some cheap family restaurants nearby, but she ended up being stressed and unhappy -- and leaving New York to study abroad.
"It wasn't a great place to live," she said. "It was cheap enough and good enough to be bearable, bad enough to keep you searching for better. It was equally fabulous and terrible at the same time. It was a symbol of New York itself really."
When she left, her roommate found a replacement and soon was replaced herself. The apartment continues to be passed along by word of mouth as the tenants either find somewhere better or give up. 
"New York City has an appeal, a promise and an offer," Ms. Visser said. "New York can make you feel that you're at the center of the universe. You consume yourself with your passion, so it doesn't bother you to go back to a tiny place and fall asleep face down."

HEADLINE: BOOK VALUE; 
Beware WhiteKnights Who Wreck the Castle

BYLINE:  By WILLIAM J. HOLSTEIN

 BODY:
CORPORATE directors, Wall Street analysts and the business press are too easily smitten with the charisma and personality of chief executives who promise sweeping change when they take over, according to a new book that will surely intensify the already hot debate on corporate governance.
 The book, "Searching for a Corporate Savior: The Irrational Quest for Charismatic C.E.O.'s" (Princeton University Press, $29.95), argues that company directors rely too much on social connections when choosing a chief executive from outside, even when their companies face serious trouble. As a result, the book contends, boards have helped create a "distinctly American cult of the C.E.O." and encouraged extreme levels of executive compensation and other "self-interested decisions." 
 Much of the book, written by Rakesh Khurana, an assistant professor of organizational behavior at Harvard Business School, seems wonderfully rational, not to mention impeccably well timed. Hiring Jeffrey K. Skilling from McKinsey & Company to become chief executive of Enron, for example, obviously didn't work for the company or its shareholders, Mr. Khurana writes. Nor, he says, did the appointments of C. Michael Armstrong at AT&T, George M. C. Fisher at Eastman Kodak or Albert J. Dunlap at Sunbeam. 
Recruiting a "savior" often doesn't work, Mr. Khurana contends, because the new executive doesn't necessarily have the right skills or the right understanding of a company's long-term strategy. A couple of decades ago, in a time of what Mr. Khurana calls managerial capitalism, chief executives selected their successors, with less board involvement. But in the current period of what the author calls investor capitalism, the boards, which presumably represent shareholders' interests, often make the decisions without involving a departing chief executive. Almost one-third of chief executives selected by large, publicly traded corporations can be classified as outsiders, he says.
But it is not always clear where his academic analysis stops and opinion begins. Mr. Khurana spent seven years conducting his research, examining 40 chief-executive successions. He spoke with chief executives, directors and headhunters and developed mathematical equations to describe his research, which no layman can possibly fathom. But it doesn't seem neutral to write, as he does, that corporate management practices in America today resemble a "secularized religion" or that selecting a chief executive is like "crowning Napoleon."
What's good about "Searching for a Corporate Savior," however, is so good that it merits a full airing. Mr. Khurana starts by exploring the market for chief executives, which many people might assume is a wide-open competition that works in the same way as other markets.
But Mr. Khurana doesn't think that it is a real market, as the word is generally understood. He offers the case study of the Bank One board's choice of Jamie Dimon, formerly of Citigroup, as its chief executive, bypassing a candidate from within the company. Russell Reynolds, an executive search firm, placed only four external candidates on the board's short list, and it just so happened that board members had personal connections where all four candidates worked. They were able to get information about Mr. Dimon through these unofficial back channels, helping him win the job.
Mr. Khurana says the number of chief-executive candidates is quite limited and that social and professional connections are so essential that the search is a "social construction," not a market. He contends that major corporations are still dominated by the same class of Protestant, white males that was in charge a century ago, despite the rise to power of a relative handful of women, as well as members of other racial, ethnic and religious groups. The majority of chief executives and the directors who hire them may serve together on boards, belong to the same clubs and business groups or share educational backgrounds.
When a board looks for charisma in an outside candidate, its search is based on social values shared by everyone in the room, Mr. Khurana writes. The outsider has messianic appeal to directors who believe the new leader can heal what ails the company. That faith, Mr. Khurana writes, introduces "the first strain of irrationality into what -- considering what companies believe to be at stake in the choice of a new C.E.O. -- one might expect to be a rational, carefully considered process."
It is irrational, he writes, because the financial performance of a company is much more closely linked to other factors, like broad industry trends. He believes that chief executives are so constrained by internal politics, the company's investments and organizational norms that they can have little impact on performance in the short term.
Boards don't choose insiders because they are perceived as impediments to organizational change, the author says. Little value is placed on their experience, knowledge or relationships with other executives and employees. "Internal candidates, about whom the board knows more than it possibly can about external ones, are considered blemished while external candidates are easily idealized," Mr. Khurana writes.
So boards are tempted to go for glamorous "change agents" who promise sweeping reform and a pop in the share price. "In the era of investor capitalism, it is no longer enough -- or even of the first importance -- that a C.E.O. candidate have particular skills as a manager," Mr. Khurana says. "What matters much more is that a candidate have a particular kind of personality."
Many older executives from the era of managerial capitalism are understated in their comments, but "the new C.E.O.'s are more verbal, controlling and abrasive," he contends. "The new C.E.O.'s also display a brash self-confidence and even flamboyance that can be very seductive and inspiring," he adds.
A company must pay huge amounts in salary and stock options to attract a charismatic chief executive. Often, it must give the new chief the power to reshape the board, by adding more allies. Yet these chiefs ultimately fail, Mr. Khurana writes, because they are not supported by the institutions that they are supposed to lead and lack the power to deliver results by themselves. 
"Charismatic C.E.O. succession is a well-proved route to disappointment," Mr. Khurana writes. Later, he rightly adds, "No single individual can save an organization."
Recent events, of course, should make people care about the problems he spotlights. Some chief executives have either looted their companies or mismanaged them in ways that have wiped out billions of dollars of shareholder value.
"Corporate boards, in their pursuit of charismatic C.E.O.'s through the external succession process, have transferred literally billions of dollars from organizations and shareholders to the personal control of C.E.O.'s and ex-C.E.O.'s -- too often with little, nothing, or even less than nothing to show in return," the author writes. In the future, he adds, "we will look back and marvel at the colossal folly of this chapter in American business history."
WHAT Mr. Khurana's analysis does not take into account are cases in which hiring a charismatic outsider has worked. When a deeply troubled I.B.M. recruited Louis V. Gerstner Jr. from RJR Nabisco in 1993, some commentators howled that hiring a marketing man from the cookie industry would ruin Big Blue. They argued that Mr. Gerstner didn't move fast enough to articulate a vision. Yet few today would argue that Mr. Gerstner has not been a success.
Nor does Mr. Khurana directly discuss why executives who built their companies might engage in hurting them. He does not mention the executives who are under investigation in connection with such wrongdoing, such as Bernard J. Ebbers of WorldCom, or those who have been formally accused, like L. Dennis Kozlowski of Tyco International or John J. Rigas of Adelphia Communications. The extrapolation from Mr. Khurana's argument is that such executives, if guilty, got away with it by intimidating their boards.
The author does not offer a sweeping set of solutions. He seems to favor a tilt back toward the time when the emphasis was on developing chief executives internally. Obviously, he thinks that boards and search firms should focus more on a candidate's business acumen. And he is scathingly critical of Wall Street analysts and business journalists for fanning the flames of chief-executive worship.
Mr. Khurana, at 34, could be involved in the debate about corporate boards and C.E.O.'s for years to come. Born in India but raised in the Bayside section of Queens, he has offered a critique of corporate America that only a true outsider could offer. That, combined with the legitimacy conferred by his Harvard teaching position and Princeton publisher, will rattle corporate cages at a time when they sorely need rattling.

HEADLINE: BEHIND THE WHEEL/Ford Think City; 
Illuminating High-Voltage Commute

BYLINE:  By LEONARD M. APCAR

DATELINE: SCARSDALE, N.Y. 

 BODY:
TO drive an electric car you have to be a bit of an extrovert. I learned this behind the wheel of the Think City, a tiny, odd-looking commuter vehicle that I drove to the train station for two weeks.
 I liked it, and so did lots of folks I passed by. They waved. Some drivers rolled down their windows and asked how they could get one. Small crowds gathered when I parked. Two electricians leaning on their van gave me a pair of thumbs-ups as I whirred by. 
 Though it was fun while it lasted, I was not surprised when Ford announced recently that it had stopped making the Think.
The hard truth is that while electric cars are fun and environmentally correct, and the Think made a lot of sense for a drive-and-ride commute, they cannot provide the versatility that Americans expect of their cars. The City, a two-seat econobox built in Norway by an electric-car company that Ford took control of in 2000, had plenty of zip, but it could not travel far enough to be more than a station car.
While it would go 40 miles or so on a charge, if I strayed too far from my house or the train station -- two places where I knew I could find battery chargers -- I'd be stranded. Home Depot doesn't sell extension cords by the mile.
Electric cars have held promise since the earliest days of the automobile, but a breakthrough in battery technology has never come. More recently, advocates have pushed electrics as ideal second cars for commuters like me, an alternative to using a thirsty, polluting gas-powered older car to drive to the train station.
Indeed, the Think City fitted my specific needs well. It easily transported me to the train station at White Plains, just 1.3 miles from my house, and it competently helped me run errands. Most other Americans don't take trains to work, and often commute more than 40 miles. This electric vehicle was not for them. Their needs would be better met by a hybrid gas-electric car like the 2003 Honda Civic Hybrid that I test-drove at the same time I was commuting with the Think City. The Civic Hybrid is a four-door sedan that appears almost identical to a gas-only Civic in roominess, handling and acceleration. Its dual power source combines a modest gasoline engine (a 1.3-liter 4 cylinder) with a 10-kilowatt electric motor. You don't need to worry about finding a charger because you never plug the Civic Hybrid in -- its nickel-metal-hydride battery recharges itself by capturing energy that would otherwise be lost during braking or deceleration.
The Civic achieves an estimated 51 m.p.g. in highway driving and 47 m.p.g. around town with a manual transmission, 48 m.p.g. in both categories with an automatic. Instead of worrying about finding a charge you need only be concerned with buying gas every 650 miles or so. There is a substantial battery-maintenance service after 100,000 miles that costs $3,000.
The Civic Hybrid starts around $20,000 and qualifies for a $2,000 clean-fuel federal tax deduction. Toyota makes a hybrid and more models are coming, including a hybrid Ford Escape sport utility vehicle that arrives next fall.
Ford and others are working on hydrogen fuel cells, which have the potential of providing cheap, clean power. But even if significant technical hurdles can be cleared, fuel cell cars are years away.
My electric-car test was part of the Clean Commute program started last fall by Ford, the New York Power Authority and the commuter railroads in Westchester County and on Long Island. Their plan was to lease 100 Think electrics to test whether enough commuters were interested in driving one to the train where they could fully recharge it while they were at work so they could easily complete the return trip home.
After hundreds of commuters expressed interest, virtually all the cars were leased for $199 a month for 34 months. Ford has said it will back the warranty on all the Thinks until the end of the lease, including three more vehicles that program managers say will be leased shortly.
Parking spaces at certain Metro-North and Long Island Rail Road stations cost extra, but had the battery charger and free electricity. (At my station, the designated electric-car spaces couldn't have been any closer to the platform.) Chargers could also be installed at your home.
I had to test two Thinks because the first one had problems. It drained too much power on even the shortest hops, and never went farther than about 23 miles on a charge.
The second car got about 44 miles to a charge, short of the 50 miles that Ford had estimated it would travel, but still enough range for short trips from home.
But in both cars I found I had to constantly watch my dwindling source of power. I could have made it from White Plains to Times Square, for instance -- about 25 miles -- but I couldn't make it back without charging. 
Charging the cars was as simple as plugging in a cord. A full charge took six to eight hours. A gauge on the dashboard indicated the percentage of power left in the battery.
The top speed is said to be 56 miles an hour, and I easily achieved that. The City weighs nearly 2,100 pounds, with nickel-cadmium batteries under the front seats accounting for about a quarter of the weight. It goes from zero to 30 miles an hour in about 7 seconds, which won't set any records but I had no trouble accelerating from a stop.
At 7 to 9 cents a kilowatt hour, mileage on electrics is only a third the cost of gas-powered cars, assuming one pays $1.50 a gallon and averages 20 miles a gallon.
Compelling as that is, the Think City is essentially a small car with a limited purpose. After all, how many people commute by train and are willing to live with its limited range? Clearly for Ford that number was too small.

INSIDE TRACK: Electric or gas powered? Maybe the answer is both.

LENGTH: 2455 words

HEADLINE: So Pink, So New York 

BYLINE:  By ERIKA KINETZ 

 BODY:
THE seriousness of fall, with its early twilights, overbooked restaurants and new television shows, has descended, and the simple, enduring rituals of city life that seemed impertinent in the heat are reviving. In other words, brunch is back. 
 The quintessential New York brunch involves a deceptively simple triumvirate: bagel, cream cheese and lox. It is salmon that lies at the heart of this classic dish, and salmon that lies at the heart of its mystery. Those innocent pink ribbons of flesh could tell a tale of battered national pride, ecological battles, ethnic inauthenticity, economic flux and jousting connoisseurs, a tale that spans the globe and the centuries. 
 The history of a fish is bound to be blurry. But the story of where smoked salmon comes from and how it became a symbol of New York is especially elusive. 
A sign behind the cool glass counter at Russ & Daughters, a Houston Street delicatessen that began life in 1905 as a pickled herring pushcart, reads, "Lox et veritas." Both are in short supply these days.
Mark Russ Federman, the 57-year-old owner, grandson of the original Russ, pointed to a meaty, deep pink chunk of fish: lox, which in his store means the rich, brine-cured belly of a wild Pacific salmon. "That's where it all started," he said. 
But today, lox accounts for only a small fraction of his salmon sales.
"People use lox as a general term -- bagel and lox -- but what is traditional and genuine lox is not smoked salmon at all," said Mr. Federman's daughter Niki, who also works at the shop. "It is a salmon cured in salt brine. No refrigeration needed. When people come into the store, they ask for lox, and we say, 'Are you sure?' "
Terry Huggins, charcuterie manager at Dean & DeLuca, has not sold a piece of lox since 1990. Even at Barney Greengrass, that emporium of nostalgia, lox doesn't sell well, and Saul Zabar himself prefers the more modern, Nova-style smoked fish. Today, most of the Sunday-morning salmon sold in New York -- 2,500 pounds each week at Zabar's alone -- is not lox, but lightly salted and smoked salmon.
For some traditionalists, the dainty stuff now in vogue will not do. 
"When I'm in the mood, this is the only one that's satisfying," Mr. Federman said. "My grandfather started with this. Somehow that on a bagel makes it for me." His lox oozes with ocean, begging for cream cheese to counter the saltiness. "It is roots and nostalgia, that salt taste," Mr. Federman added. "I think we have a genetic predisposition to the taste of salt-cured fish."

The 20th-Century Mikvah
Tell a Scot about the wedding of a Jewish woman and a Scottish man at which the attractions included tartan yarmulkes and Jewish delicacies like smoked salmon, and he'll laugh.
"That's a good one!" said Roddy Wilde, until recently head of international trading for Pinneys of Scotland, one of Britain's largest salmon processors, as he drove toward Scottish Sea Farms near Oban, where much of the fish processed at Pinneys comes from. Mr. Wilde had a point. Smoke and salt have been used to preserve fish since antiquity. 
Countries of northern Europe have a long tradition of smoking fish to conserve salt. In fact, the word lox is derived from the German lachs, meaning salmon. Near the River Bann in Ireland lie the remains of what is thought to be a fish-drying and -smoking station dating to 2000 B.C. 
American recipes using smoked salmon date to the early 19th century, when it was a pricey restaurant food. But, according to Claudia Roden, author of "The Book of Jewish Food," there is no evidence that Eastern European Jews ate lox or smoked salmon in the shtetls. They ate copious amounts of fish, but salmon was usually too expensive.
Lox and smoked salmon became Jewish through an accident of migration. When European immigrants came to New York, they brought traditions of smoking and salting fish. But the stuff did not take off until the arrival of Eastern European Jews in the late 19th and early 20th century. 
In the United States, the opening of the first transcontinental railroad in 1869 connected the waters of the Pacific Northwest, which were teeming with wild salmon, with New York fishmongers. Barrels filled with hundreds of pounds of salmon interleaved with salt were transported east. The salt drew water from the flesh of the fish, creating a briny bath that preserved the salmon for up to a year without refrigeration. 
At the same time, the market for lox was exploding. Eastern European immigrants would have appreciated lox both for its price -- 9 cents for a quarter-pound in the 1920's and 30's -- and for its convenience. It was easy to handle -- and pareve, making it acceptable with milk or meat. It fast became a staple.
"Think about it in terms of tenements, the crowded conditions and absence of cooking facilities," said James Shenton, professor emeritus at Columbia University, whose specialty is immigrant history. "Lox had the advantage of not requiring the effort that would have made life more complicated than it was."
This phenomenon could be seen elsewhere in the Jewish diaspora: H. Forman & Son, the last of London's traditional East End smokers, was founded in 1905 by a Jewish immigrant from Russia. And as the fish's popularity grew, techniques for preparing it evolved rapidly. 
"When they discovered there was fabulous wild salmon coming down to Billingsgate market every summer," said Lance Forman, the fourth-generation proprietor, "they thought: 'Well, no point in shipping them over. Let's try smoking these instead.' " Thus was born the mild "London cure," achieved by curing fillets with dry salt for 24 hours and cold-smoking them over oakwood for 24 more. This process is still followed at Forman's, whose smoked wild Scottish salmon is sold at Fairway, Zabar's and Dean & DeLuca.
A similar drift from heavy salting occurred in the United States, especially after refrigeration rendered briny preservation obsolete. But salmon here was typically cured in a low-salt liquid solution, which creates a silky, chewier fish. Salmon prepared this way, much of which used to be imported from Nova Scotia and the Gaspe Peninsula, was often sold as Nova or Gaspe. Pacific salmon was often sold as Western Nova. The names stuck.

How the Fish Took the Town
The Lower East Side's ramshackle crush of diversity and poverty was fertile ground for culinary invention. By the early 20th century, cream cheese, lox and bagels were available in tempting proximity. One day, some anonymous genius combined them. 
"Who put the triumvirate together, no one knows," Mr. Federman said. But what is clear is that this inspired combination of immigrant Jewish foods rapidly won over mainstream palates. 
Lox's leap from the ghetto reflected a larger spread of Jewish culture in the 1920's that occurred as Jews moved out of the Lower East Side into mainstream culture, becoming prominent in show business and especially in the movie industry. 
"Jewish culture in a sense became fashionable because of show business," said Mark Kurlansky, author of "Salt: A World History." "If you think about people like Irving Berlin or the Marx Brothers, people who just became New York culture, they were Lower East Side Jews."
Herbert Goldman, Al Jolson's biographer, even suggests that the great Jolson himself might have sparked the combination's popularity. Jolson appeared regularly on Kraft's musical revues in the 1930's, and James Lewis Kraft, founder of the cheese company, told the performers to refer to company products in their routines as often as possible. Who's to say Jolson didn't rattle off a ditty about cream cheese, lox and bagels in a winning fit of commercial imagination?
Andrew F. Smith, editor in chief of the forthcoming Oxford Encyclopedia of American Food and Drink, has a more primal hypothesis: "Fast food," he said. "It's easy. It's good."

When Packaging Trumps Place
Today, New York bagels are dressed with an array of pink, red and orange strips of smoked salmon, which is typically marketed by country of origin. There are only two major classes of salmon: Atlantic, which is found throughout Northern Europe, on the Eastern Seaboard of North America, and in Chile; and Pacific, which is found in Alaska and the Pacific Northwest. But you can buy smoked salmon identified as Scottish, Irish, Norwegian, Gaspe or Nova.
These geographic distinctions are increasingly obsolete. Much of the salmon at emporiums like Zabar's, Fairway, Barney Greengrass, Russ & Daughters and Dean & DeLuca actually comes from Acme Smoked Fish, a third-generation smokehouse in Greenpoint, Brooklyn.
Acme's day begins at 4 a.m. The fish are prepared Nova style, cured in salt, water and brown sugar, before being cold-smoked on racks in a large oven. Fruitwood shavings burn in a small stove, making the 50,000-square-foot factory smell incongruously of a campfire. The salmon, whether farmed fish from Norway, Chile and the Faeroe Islands, or wild Pacific salmon from Alaska, is processed identically.
"Nova is really a style of curing fish," said Buzz Billick, vice president of sales at Acme. "Nova has nothing to do with the type of fish. At one time, yes. Today, no." 
The geographical confusion extends to the fish sold at Fairway, whose in-house smoked salmon is sometimes Canadian fish, sometimes Chilean. Olga Ortiz, a wiry Ecuadorean, smokes 150 sides -- 450 pounds -- a week in a small metal box at the end of a hallway lined with coats on the third floor of the Fairway in Harlem.
Fairway also sells Scotch-style salmon made at Acme by dry-curing Norwegian or Chilean fish and smoking it over fruitwood. 
Scotch-style salmon? "That's a New York invention," said Mr. Wilde of Pinneys.
And Nova lox? He laughed. "The problem," he said, "is you are looking for truth in something that is not very well developed. It has been a ramshackle band of misfits trying to make smoked salmon in many different countries."

How the Fish Lost Its Soul
Today, almost all the smoked salmon sold in New York is grown on a farm. Zabar's has not carried wild smoked salmon for a decade. Acme gets virtually all of the five million pounds of salmon it smokes each year from farms in Norway and Chile.
With farmed fish, how the fish are raised, cured and smoked has more impact on the final product than nationality, although some would argue otherwise. Scots helped establish some fish farms in Chile, and many farms in Scotland and Chile are owned by Norwegian companies. But Mr. Billick would never sell Russ Federman a Chilean fish. Mr. Ortiz of Fairway thinks Chilean salmon are the best. 
Some say water temperature and quality make Scottish fish different from Norwegian fish. But most variables involved in raising salmon can be controlled by manufacturers. This level of industrial control has made salmon a cheap, consistent product but the soul of the fish did not withstand the pressures of modern commerce. Salmon was dubbed the king of fish not only for its noble journey back upstream to spawn but also for its wily inconsistency. 
"They have a mystique all their own," said David Pullar, who has been fishing salmon commercially for three decades. "You think you've got their patterns worked out, what they are going to do next, and they do something completely different that throws all your reckoning upside down."
Every 12 hours Mr. Pullar checks his nets along the beach at Usan, one of Scotland's oldest fishing villages. "Salmon swim with the wind," he said. "They are like women. You never know where you are with them."
But in an era of mechanized factories, fish farms and supermarkets, chances are next to zero that the salmon on your bagel ever swam with the wind. The fish's vaunted unpredictability has become a liability.
"I think people are so excited about the fact they can get good fresh farmed salmon 52 weeks of a year," Mr. Billick said, "they don't think about what goes into making the fish this fat and this red."
The fat comes from a sedentary lifestyle and the red comes from chemically enhanced feed pellets. Without additives, the flesh of farm-raised salmon would be gray. Buyers can specify the color they want, using a standardized color scale that looks like paint chips. 

The Life of a Modern Fish
For some fish, the road to Zabar's begins on a tray in a hatchery on the Isle of Mull, off Scotland's west coast. Fish to be sold next summer were eggs in December 2000. The next spring, they were put in cages in freshwater lochs, where they stayed for a year, until the smolts were ready to go out to sea.
This April, Neil MacInnes, who manages a farm site for Scottish Sea Farms, bucked over the glassy surface of Loch Creran, near Oban, in a light metal boat. He was headed for one of the large plastic cages floating in the loch. The area was ringed by wild forest, tree farms, a few houses and an old factory. The beauty of the place was so complete, it seemed breakable.
The cages had been stocked two weeks earlier with 350,000 smolts, which will be harvested next spring. Mr. MacInnes fed the fish pellets made of fish meal, fish oil, soy and dye. Aside from the plunk of the small fish jumping and the scattershot murmur of the pellets, the place was silent.
On shore, at the Scottish Sea Farms processing station in South Shian, 11,000 identical salmon were being pumped from a boat up a long black pipeline to a shed, where their life ended with a sharp snap of a stun machine. All the fish were bled, gutted, tagged and shipped within eight hours.
From South Shian, a fish might move to a factory like Pinneys, which processes 13,000 tons of farmed salmon annually. Each fish travels a course of conveyor belts and chutes, along which it is mechanically guillotined, washed and filleted. The fish is dry-cured for 24 to 72 hours and smoked over oak for 14 hours. Saul Zabar's fish is hand-sliced and vacuum-packed before going on a plane in Manchester, London or Glasgow. The whole process takes at least 10 days.
"We are really no longer in the farmer's kitchen doing things haphazardly," Mr. Wilde said. "It is a big business."
For Mr. Federman of Russ & Daughters, salmon is also a good business. 
"My grandfather came over here, and it was all poverty," he said. "He left poverty. He came here and the streets weren't lined with gold. It wasn't the golden Medina. It was the Lower East Side ghetto."
His parents met over a barrel of pickled herring and worked six days a week, 12 hours a day, so the children wouldn't have to go home smelling like fish. Mr. Federman studied law but ended up a fishmonger. 
"The ultimate Jewish irony is that I would like my kids to be here doing this," he said. "My fish business is less fishy than most things out there. I am probably the only Jewish father who is disappointed his kid wants to be a doctor."

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: SOUTH BRONX; 
Bronx Zoo, Yankee Stadium, Jerome Avenue Auto Glass

BYLINE:  By SETH KUGEL 

 BODY:
As drivers edge toward Manhattan on the Cross Bronx Expressway, official highway signs direct them toward places like Yankee Stadium, the Bronx Museum of the Arts and Bronx-Lebanon Hospital. This summer, someone decided one more South Bronx attraction was worth plugging, and up went two very visible, very unofficial green-on-white signs that read: "Auto Glass Shops: Exit Jerome Avenue."
 A dozen auto glass shops sit just off Exit 2A, where a replacement for a taillight or a windshield can be picked from thousands of used parts that hang from chain-link fences and are stacked on shelves. 
 The signs, which direct drivers to a decidedly downtrodden stretch under the elevated No. 4 train that also includes mechanics and used-car dealers, started a buzz among the businesses, but no one knows who put them up. At least, no one is fessing up. 
"They've been up two and a half months, and no one knows where they came from," said Joey Santiago, whose family has run Best Auto Glass for 20 years.
Joshua Perez, a freelance auto glass man who works for several of the businesses, says he thinks owners of newer shops installed the signs to attract customers from New Jersey who usually patronized more distant glass shops in Hunts Point.
"Whoever put it on didn't tell no one," Mr. Perez added. "They didn't put it up in the daytime, I'll tell you that much."
Raul Santos, who works at a shop on Inwood Avenue that is somewhat removed from the highway, guessed that the guilty party was one of the first businesses drivers would see.
But Wilson Concepcion, a manager of Cross Bronx Auto Glass, the first shop from the highway, said his company was not the culprit.
Mr. Santiago theorized that the signs were part of an economic development plan. "I think the city did it," he said.
Fat chance.
"They're obviously not sanctioned by the city or the state," said Jennifer M. Nelson of the State Department of Transportation. On Thursday, the city's Department of Transportation dispatched a crew that took the signs down. 
 SETH KUGEL

HEADLINE: FIVE QUESTIONS FOR JOSEPH J. GRANO JR.; 
On Security Panel, Executives Think the Unthinkable

BYLINE:  By PATRICK McGEEHAN 

 BODY:
THE Homeland Security Advisory Council, a group of leaders from business, academia and state and local government, was created by executive order in March. Its 21 members have been meeting monthly in Washington to advise the Bush administration on strengthening domestic security. 
 Joseph J. Grano Jr., chairman and chief executive of UBS PaineWebber and a Special Forces veteran, is chairman of the council. He talked last week about the business role in guarding against domestic terrorism. PATRICK McGEEHAN

Q. What is the council doing?

A. The national strategy came out with three clear and succinct objectives -- to prevent terrorist attacks, reduce America's vulnerability to future attacks and minimize damage and recover from attacks when and if they occur. We as a group opined on that national strategy. We are making recommendations on how you coordinate and implement it.
 There is no way as a nation that we can achieve a high degree of protection without engaging the private sector. Protecting our critical infrastructure is one of six mission areas in our national strategy. What most people don't recognize is that 80 to 85 percent of all of the critical infrastructure in the United States is owned or operated by the private sector.
Among the initiatives in the strategy is to build and maintain a database of this infrastructure, things like the Lincoln Tunnel, but also private facilities. Securing cyberspace is also a very, very big issue. To do that, we need to work as a partnership.

Q. But companies tend to guard information and solve their problems alone. Is there a willingness to change?

A. These things are done more in silos by each company. My view is it probably has to be done industry by industry. If you were to pick a category to serve as an example, there is probably none better than Wall Street.
Heretofore, every company is focusing immediately on the issue of business continuity. We all have disaster recovery plans that we had to implement. But look at it from a full capital-market perspective, post-9/11, when the whole community pulled together to get the market back up. That type of coordination we now know is possible. 
I'm not going to say to you that we are arm in arm, walking in the sunset. But my experiences thus far and the letters that I have received from other C.E.O.'s have all shown a complete willingness to get on with the task at hand.

Q. The legislation to create the Homeland Security Department seems stuck in the Senate. Are you worried?

A. Right now, the problem is the politicizing there. This department should have already been formed. It's been a year and a day.
This is war. We need to start thinking about a 21st-century response to a 21st-century threat. The intelligence gathering of the private sector needs to be able to be communicated. There are, in my view, some archaic laws that are deterrents. I'd say, "Look, guys, you have got to give us some flexibility here about passing information."
If the American public understood some of the archaic and arcane rules and regulations that a bureaucracy can create, they would quickly rally to the side of the president. The F.A.A. Federal Aviation Administration has more flexibility than what Congress is trying to give this department. The departments of Health and Human Services and Agriculture have more authority to transfer their budgets.
If there's a unique threat on our borders, this department obviously should be held accountable to Congress, but they have to have the flexibility to marshal these 170,000 people and organize them against the objectives of winning a war. Today, if you found a border-patrol person drunk on the job and you tried to fire that person, it takes you 30 days and you have to pay them for those 30 days. You cannot have the equivalent of tenure in a school system being an albatross around the neck of our security efforts.

Q. Isn't there a danger that new ties between government and business over domestic security will hurt productivity at the time the economy needs it most?

A. I don't see the threat. The formation of the Homeland Security Department will be more focused than what we have today. As the partnership with the private sector and with local and state government gets synergized, it will create more productivity and create incremental new businesses in fields like security. I think it has a very positive ramification if we get it right. If we don't get this terrorist situation right, from the point of prevention and reduction, what do you think that would do to our economy? Let something happen and see what happens to our consumer base. There's your threat.

Q. How much time is this work taking away from your real job at UBS PaineWebber?

A. It is probably taking up 5 percent of my working hours. Of what little spare time I have, I am spending about 40 percent of that, mostly reading. And, I can assure you, it keeps you awake at night. Luckily, I don't need much sleep.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Joseph J. Grano Jr.

HEADLINE: PORTFOLIOS, ETC.; 
Traders Have One Question: Are We There Yet?

BYLINE:  By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
ALL the major stock indexes tumbled last week -- one by as much as 5.4 percent -- leaving the market perilously close to the five-year low it reached in the summer.
 As of Friday, the Dow Jones industrial average was just 284 points away from its low of 7,702.34. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index has to fall only 48 points to reach its low of 797.70, and the Nasdaq composite is only 15 points from its low of 1,206.01. 
 So investors may be wondering whether the bottom of the market is lower than they thought. 
When Wall Street analysts confront questions like this, they consult various barometers of market turns that they have used in the past, for good or ill. These include measures of market volatility, long-term moving averages of market indexes, gauges of value, volume, highs and lows, and meters of bullish or bearish sentiment.
Unfortunately, a glance at them does not give a clear thumbs up or down. But on the whole, a selection of these indicators doesn't say, for the moment, that things are going to become much worse.
Traders use some of these market guides for short-term readings -- to get a sense of where the market is going today, this week or this month. Notably, some barometers are moving back toward their levels of July 23, when the Dow and the S.& P. 500 hit their lows. The index of volatility compiled by the Chicago Board Options Exchange closed at 44.55 on Friday, not far from its close of 50.48 on July 23.
There may be some comfort in the volatility numbers. Before July 23, the last time the volatility index closed above 50 was on Sept. 21, 2001. That turned out to be a bottom for the market drop that followed the terrorist attacks. When the volatility index reached highs of 39.96 in 1997 and 48.56 in 1998, the market also hit bottoms.
Another measure, nicknamed Trin, takes a reading of advancing versus declining stocks and then factors in trading volume to test how meaningful the advances and declines are. Like the volatility reading, it is giving some hints of a bottom.
The ratio of stocks hitting 52-week highs to those falling to lows is neutral at the moment. But it has been moving in a positive direction as the number of stocks setting highs has increased.
Longer-term investment yardsticks, recommended by William E. Rhodes, chief investment strategist of Rhodes Analytics in Boston, also provide some reassurance. These measures of economic strength don't help to determine if the market will fall much below its current level. But they do hint at whether the longer-term underpinning for stocks is positive or negative.
Mr. Rhodes pays close attention to a proxy for economic growth -- industrial production, adjusted for inflation by the Consumer Price Index -- because data on the gross domestic product is released only quarterly. This indicator is bullish for now. That fits with forecasts that the economy probably grew at an annual rate of 3.5 percent or more in the third quarter -- not a robust number for a traditional economic recovery, but much better than the 1.1 percent rate in the second quarter.
Another measure, money supply growth, is off its peak but not worrisome, Mr. Rhodes said.
BUT investor sentiment has been moving in a bullish direction in the last few weeks after dipping in late July and early August to its most bearish level since the weeks after the terrorist attacks. This contrarian measure, calculated by Investors Intelligence, has to become more bearish for a market bottom to appear closer.
Mr. Rhodes adds his own bit of caution. When he runs stocks though his financial sorters, he is finding only one to buy for every 26 to sell. The market would have a better outlook, he said, if he could just find more buys than sells.
Perhaps the market will not fall much further, even if it does break through the summer bottom. But if many investors are as picky as Mr. Rhodes, there may not be much of a rebound when the bottom is found.
